I would walk across the street and go to Kevin's Pho. Came here on a Friday night and was seated right away. Our table a bun bowl, a #2 pho and the beef stew vietnamese flat rice noodles. 

I personally had the beef stew and it was alright. The beef was tender however the carrots were not cooked all the way. YUCK. 

If you're craving pho, and Kevin's is full - and you're still craving pho, I would go here. 

they do take cc!
author: Stephanie W.

description: Food was great, I had the #1 noodle.  I like how they give you a choice of beef, chicken or satay soup and they even let you choose your noodles.  The portion was generous and plenty if meat.  Soup was nothing but flavorful and I didn't feel thirsty afterwards which is a good sign that they did not use a lot if salt or msg.  Next time I would want to try the five spice chicken since many fellow yelpers are raving about it.
author: Yvonne L.

description:
My go-to not-for-pho Vietnamese restaurant in the neighborhood.

I come here mainly for their Curry Chicken (Vermicelli) Noodle Soup. I loveeeee the curry broth! Well spiced, not TOO creamy, and just hits the spot on a cold San Francisco night (which is almost every night). They give a fair amount of chicken, and the vermicelli is always perfect.

Other dishes they make well: Crab (Vermicelli) Noodle Soup, 5 Spice Chicken (over rice or vermicelli), and Imperial Rolls!

You see the trend? All these dishes are great because it's not their pho. If you're looking for pho, you're at the wrong place. Head across the street to Kevin's for pho. The broth here is bland and the texture of pho noodles are off :( But everything else is yum!

The service is good. They're always quick to take your orders and the food comes out promptly.
They serve tea or iced water depending on the weather-- which is very considerate :)
My friends and I usually play credit card roulette here, and the workers always get a kick outta that, It's nice to put a smile on the face of the typical miserable-looking Asian restaurant worker.

Parking can be a pain on Irving during primetime dinner/boba hours, but make a few rounds and you'll be able to find metered parking sooner or later. Always check the metered parking lot behind KFC on 20th Ave. btwn Irving and Lincoln Way too!
author: Melissa Y.

description:
The garlic noodles are one of the best in the City.  Parking around the area is not too bad and the price is reasonable.  It's nice that they're next to Starbucks, which is great for desert if you feel like it. 

The service is good and the wait is not too bad.  I recommend this place for the Pho too.
author: Wayne W.

description: Best broth ever, especially the beef broth that has been cooked all day! Big portions too with lots of meat, noodles and vegetables for their beef stew and phò. The broth is so good that we bring some home if there's any left after our meal.
author: Courtney W.

description:
My go to place for pho, especially on a cold day in San Francisco. Service is ok but they are pretty quick with coming out with food. Portion size is decent and prices are ok for what you get. Love their imperial rolls and their pho! 

They have many different types of pho but favorite by far is the coconut pho with chicken and potatoes. It is spicy but DELICIOUS!! Definitely recommend getting it. Their five spice chicken is also very good and worth trying! I usually don't get their vermicelli bowls but they are also yummy as well.

Can be hard to find parking because it is near 19th ave but aside from that, I have not had a bad experience with them. Highly recommend checking it out! Place is decent size but may have to wait a bit for a large party. Can expect it to be about $10 per person for a decent meal so not too bad for a meal in San Francisco!
author: Wendy Z.

description:
HMmmmmmm.

Decent food (SKIP THE VERMICELLI THOUGH) and quick service.

Imperial rolls- UM these were prob the 2nd best imperial rolls I've tried. I'm not sure exactly what's in them but yuuuuuuuuum, lol!

Five spice chicken vermicelli- SKIP THIS.The 5-spice chicken LOOKED good but it didn't really taste like much. The vermicelli also tasted like nothing. Maybe because they didn't give me enough fish sauce or something? I don't know.. I've never really had tasteless 5spice chicken or vermicelli before :(

Beef carpaccio- DERICIOUS AND FRESH. Probably about the same level's as Yummy Yummy's but without the wait.

Porkchop w/ rice- my bf's fav Viet dish ever. He said the porkchop is good because it's *ACTUALLY* grilled. The only gripe was there was no option to add a fried egg on top of it? Though I'm sure you can ask.
author: Emily C.

description: I always get the Five spice chicken Noodle soup.  Chicken is really good.  Service is better than what I've come to expect from most Pho places.  I always come here and am never disappointed.
author: Marvin M.

description:
So, dinner and two hours on the toilet later...

Was planning to go to Kevin's for pho with some friends tonight, but was diverted here instead because they really wanted the chicken curry pho. Wanting something lighter, I went with the popular-on-Yelp five spice chicken and pho, which, like Golden Star, comes out as two separate items: chicken on a plate, and a medium bowl of plain pho [ Photo: http://bit.ly/Wy1YCS ] for about $10 after tax and tip.

Now, don't get me wrong: the chicken was actually fairly tasty (though Golden Star does it better), and the pho wasn't bad either, albeit a bit too sweet (which I attribute to excessive MSG). But the fact that I ended up with, ah, digestive troubles after, be it due to the food itself, or the (lack of) cleanliness of their utensils, makes me highly wary of coming back here again. 

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - The tables are arranged so closely together here that it's incredibly troublesome, albeit not impossible, to get to any tables aside from the first row closest to the entrance. And when they're busy (and they usually are), that means asking a lot of people to get out of their chairs.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out, so I can't comment.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Only thing I like about this place is that it is open late, since the food is just passable.  Still blows my mind how so many SF restaurants close at 8 or 9PM most nights.  I always get late night munchies!

This place is nothing amazing, but I don't expect much.  It's quick service for when it's late and you're hungry.  Convenient location at 19th and Irving.  Very disappointed that they ran out of bún riêu. Settled for Imperial Rolls and Charbroiled Beef Vermicelli (Bun Cha Gio Bo Nuong).  It was decent but didn't come with enough sauce.

The bf got PPQ Beef Noodle Soup - Rare flank steak, well done brisket, tendon, tripe and beef meatball in beef broth with pho (Pho Phu Quoc Dac Biet).  There was only one meatball in there. Also, he ordered a coffee which never arrived but was on the bill.  He pointed it out to the waiter, however, who immediately apologized and took it off the check.

Meh, this place is ok if you're in the area and it's late, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go here.  Also prices are higher than average for what they have on the menu.  Across the street has cheaper prices and comparable quality.
author: Cat C.

description: Food is getting worst. When I moved to bay area at the beginning, this was my Pho place. If it is not because the location is close to bakeries and grocery stores, I won't even bother to stop by. I asked for tea, but they gave me ice water. I ordered Pho noodles, but they gave me rice noodles. It took me 20 minutes for my order to come. I don't want to wait for another 20 minutes. I just ate whatever they served. Soup was lukewarm. After I put the raw beef into the bowl for 5 minutes, the beef was still pink. Meaning the soup wasn't hot enough to begin with.
author: J L.

description:
good place like the food but the people who run the register (more than likely the owners) are really rude, No thank you, no how are you, no hi what can I get you. This is what I received and seen while there to pay for an order and order to go..
walk in the door and first thing comes out of there mouth is "what you want" after you order and pay for a $70+ meal, not even a thank you, hands you the bag and says here you go..wait staff are ok, food is actually really good but man those owners...LOL
author: J W.

description: The oxtail with rice dish is really good. I haven't been in love with anything else here though.
author: Jennifer P.

description: I found myself adrift in a tumultuous sea of broth set upon by shoals of brisket, noodles and vegetables. Struggle as I might, I was drowned in a powerful undercurrent of overwhelming flavor. I awoke what felt like an eternity later, having washed ashore on the island of satisfaction...
author: David S.

description:
Took me months to finally write a review about this place. Another Vietnamese restaurant that might be own by Chinese cause one of my friend order in Vietnamese and the waiter seems not know the language when asking my friend to say it in English. 
I've been a lot of Vietnamese pho restaurant, to me this place is the worst and not the authentic place to get noodle soup.
 I had their Bun Bo Hue. Although this soup has the spicy broth, i thought they put a little too much spicy which made it harder drink the broth. if would have better if it was a small among of spicy. but after sipping a few of broth, it still have the bland flavor. Also there's more noodle than meat which I wasn't satisfy enough since I wasn't even full after eating it. I would rather have their rice dishes than their noodle soup. 

Service was slow too since it was a busy Friday night.
author: Julie N.

description: Tried the curry pho here bc my sister was craving. We shared the curry pho and imperial roll vermicelli. Good combo of wet and dry. Typical pho. I would say it's very similar to Kevin's Noodle across the street. Just go here if that place is packed. I obviously have a bias for Kevin's! There's not as much space here.
author: Michelle C.

description: Love this place and love the food. Been visiting this place every time I come to San Francisco.  Service is fast and food is always delicious
author: Bogdan Y.

description: PPQ offers a great selection of awesome Vietnamese Pho and plates. The five spice chicken is perfect every time and the imperial roll beef noodle bowls can be eaten and enjoyed everyday without missing a beat. The owner is very nice and the staff are quick and courteous. We love this local gem!
author: Paul B.

description:
Meh. Decent Viet food for the area, but its not the best.

I got a Duc Biet, which is my go-to pho (unless we're talking Turtle Tower, then its chicken noodles all the way). The broth was pretty decent, but the noodles and meats weren't as impressive. My noodles were quite hard, and no matter how long I soaked those suckers for, it still didn't soften. The beef balls they used had no tendons in it, which...I like. I feel like it makes the beef ball better, and love when restaurants use those. Instead there was one measly beef ball what was a little too soft. The rest of the meats though, were pretty decent.

I'd say a decent place to get a quick bite, but don't expect amazing food.
author: Lily W.

description:
You know what? Eff this place. We just finished eating, so I threw down $15 cash and told them to charge the rest on the DBF's card. They bring the CC slip back, charged for the full amount of the bill, and my $15 was nowhere to be seen. So I flag the guy down, asked where my $15 was, and told him that that should've been subtracted from the bill and the rest charged on the card. His answer? "Oh, uh...I didn't know." WTF DUDE, REALLY? Did you think I was going to leave a $15 tip for a $30 bill? NO. 

"So what do you want me to do, recharge your card?" He asks. 
"No, give me my cash back," I answer testily. 

Does he think we're so drunk that he can pull that sh!t on us? FYI, we had NOTHiNG to drink tonight; we are stone cold SOBER. 

You definitely don't deserve a 50% tip for mediocre service and even more mediocre food. You can take those $3 I left and stuff it up your a$$.
author: Dee W.

description:
The food here was not that good. There was a place across the street that we wanted to go to instead but it was packed. So we came here instead. We ordered some Pho and a curry chicken. The Pho was not that good. The soup was kinda blah and meh Ive had much better. The chicken wasnt that great either. The Spring rolls were just ok.

Service wise it wasnt too bad. They were just grab order and bring order didnt check up on us or grab a refill of water for us. Oh well on to a better place.
author: Helen T.

description:
Most of us know about the PPQ vs. Kevin's rivalry, but since I haven't tried Pho at PPQ yet, I have no opinion on it.

PLACE:
Small place, it unfortunately smells a bit like a towel that had been used for a long, long time. It disappeared afterwards but it did make me more wary of anything touching the table.

FOOD:
My friends ordered Pho, while I decided to get the Bun Bo Hue (#12). I was surprised by the amount of meat I received, a plus with me. I am also a person who loves spice, so anyone who loves spicy noodle soups should definitely try it. If you also don't like blood cubes, this the bun bo hue for you. The noodles were also bit chewy! Yay! I personally love it so I was sad they didn't have any. Skimped on the basil on their plate of toppings too :(

SERVICE:
Quick, average wait time.

OVERALL:
Worth trying, will come back to try the pho some time soon.
author: Joanna N.

description:
Delicious Pho + Unfriendly Service = PPQ

Normally when a restaurant has yummy food but crummy service, I won't give them more than 4 stars, but PPQ is the exception. It's one of those places where the unpleasant servers somehow contribute to the whole magic of the overall dining experience. You can tell your friends "let's go to PPQ. The food is great and the servers look like they want to murder you, but it's sorta comical."

I get the Curry Chicken Pho every time because it's just so goddamn delicious. My boyfriend always gets the Seafood Pho and is happy enough that he never strays from that choice. Long story short, everything that any of my friends have ever gotten there has been a hit. Now you might be thinking "if she loves this place so much, then why doesn't she have more check-ins?" Well folks, I'll tell you why. I love this place so much that sometimes I will run to the gym (sans phone) just so that I have an excuse to stop by PPQ on my way home from the gym (for those paying attention: no phone means I can't check in). You should also know that I hate running, so the fact that I'll run just to have some sort of reason to eat here is a big deal.

Here's the kicker though: it is so so cheap to eat here. Even the large bowls of pho are under $10! And I always get the large bowl so that I have leftovers. Speaking of, the pho is even good reheated!!! But word to the wise: if you're ordering pho to go, DO NOT ORDER THE LARGE. Experience has taught me that they put the same amount of food in the to go containers whether you order a medium or a large, so you might as well save a few bucks and get the medium.
author: Stephenie S.

description: Dude, I can't vouch for the pho soup, but the five spice chicken is off the hinges...I order the dinner with an over easy fried egg on the bed of rice:) every bite is nirvana:)
author: Al T.

description:
Coconut curry chicken pho was phenomenal! Noodles had a great bite and the chicken was perfectly cooked! First pho without over cooked chicken!! 

They also provide cute plastic bowls for kids.
author: Nors P.

description:
This has been one of the spots we go to for lunch after church either with friends or with the hubster.  

Crab soup - I'm not very familiar with this dish but I actually like it.  
Pho - Not salt flavor but real pho flavor.  I got used to pho in Daly City where you taste mainly salt, but with the broth here, it has more depth.  

Price - not expensive at all.
author: Claire J.

description:
This was my go-to spot for pho in the past, but recently the taste has just not been the same, a bit bland in my opinion.

This place does have one of the best imperial rolls in the city, by far. I definitely recommend getting a plate of those as an appetizer. (Cha Gio)

Also, five spice chicken here is pretty good, I recommend that as well.

You can't go wrong with a five spice chicken and imperial roll vermicelli plate; solid.

The restaurant itself is a bit small, but it is not the cleanest place, but it is bearable for sure.
author: Sam K.

description: I had a beef and rice dish here; it was horrible, it had no real beef in it, but something like the skin of the animal. I didn't eat it (it wasn't edible anyway, I would need to chew 1000 times if I wanted), and the waiter didn't give a damn about it when I asked about it. I had vietnamese food in various countries, but never seen anything like this.
author: Azer K.

description:
Pho Phu Quoc is a lively and popular HITW in a busy part of Sunset.  We came with my in-laws for a quick bite and scored a serendipitous parking space right in front so I thought we were in for a treat.  Kiss of death would prevail as it was a full moon out on Friday the 13th and the meal itself, at least my own bowl of pho, was disappointing at best...

I was looking forward to ordering some pho tai gan which wasn't on the menu but a popular enough dish elsewhere that I thought I might be able to order on the fly.  As soon as I tried the waitress gave me a dull "what are you talking about" look.  Ironically, I wound up ordering the #2 Pho Tai Nam Sach, and yes, I thought of pulling a Jack Nicholson and tell them to hold the sach.  I noticed that the large bowl is only a dollar more than the medium so I went with that and it was a pretty prodigious sized bowl of noodles.  Famous for their certified Angus Beef, it was pretty shredded when I ordered it on the side.  The noodles themselves were initially very clumpy which is a pet peeve of mine but fortunately the broth was served hot enough where it wasn't an issue to loosen up, particularly since I ordered the tai on the side because I like rare beef to actually be rare.  The broth though lacked the beefy depth that I was looking for, in fact I doubt it was beef-based at all, it tasted more like chicken.  They gave us the usual Thai basil, bean sprouts, sliced chili, and lemons instead of limes but they were pretty miserly about it as we all had bowls of pho and they didn't provide any extra garnishes to account for the four of us...

My sister-in-law ordered the five spice chicken in her pho which I guess PPQ is known for;  I didn't try it but it reminds me of a brick chicken with a spicy coating.  We also ordered an order of Goi Cuon Chay or Veggie Summer Rolls which came with a soy vinaigrette dipping sauce.  Not bad, just ok...

Everyone else seemed to like their bowls of pho, so perhaps I'm the one who was picky.  I usually go to my beloved Pho Filet 2 in San Gabriel once a week to satisfy my pho cravings so I guess I'm going to have to wait til I get back from my vacay and hope I don't have withdrawl symptoms.  It did occur to me that I ordered the wrong thing and it wasn't one of their strengths, but oh well.  Also sorry I didn't post any pics as my phone was dying.  Sounded like 4 stars from everyone else at our table but I wouldn't give it more than a 2 myself...
author: Lawrence L.

description:
Come to PPQ for their delicious five spice chicken, imperial rolls, or curry chicken noodle soup (so good!!!). Skip everything else as there are better options in the area. I've had different variations of their pho (little meat and flavorless broth), beef satay soup (oily and no depth of flavor), and bun rieu (just "ok"). 

Service is generally fast once you get in, but there can be quite a wait during peak hours. Overall, come to PPQ if you're in the area for a relatively quick meal, but go somewhere else if you're looking for a nice hearty bowl of beef pho to hit the spot.
author: J C.

description: Love this place! I used to go across the street to Kevin's (because it was larger and never had a wait) and then finally went to PPQ and couldn't believe that i had been missing out the whole time.  I'm more of a bun (vermicelli) person and the bun here is my absolute favorite in the city.  It's so freaking delicious! I always get the pork with imperial roll.  I've never found a bug in my food and the servers do their job just fine.  Gotta waive em down for a check, but that's just how it goes and yeah, don't split the bill in a complicated way because it's SF and all the restaurants seem to hate that.  The pho is always good too, especially the satay and I am quite fond of the beef carpaccio as well.  I don't live in the sunset anymore, but every once in a while I make the trip out and bliss out on some awesome bun.
author: Caroline W.

description:
tl;dr

FIVE SPICE CHICKEN RICE PLATE.

---

Look, this is not a nice place to impress your date with. It's a neighborhood joint to grab a bite when you're staving at 2:30 PM and all the lunch specials have expired. The tables are dirty, the servers are rude, but if you really cared about that, go to Perilla on 9th.

The Five Spice Chicken Rice plate is all you need. A full bowl of rice (approved by my young male metabolism), tasty grilled chicken thigh, and some random assortment of vegetables as an afterthought.

It's greasy, a lot of food, and probably 1000 calories on a plate. But if you really cared about that, you wouldn't have came here.

I ate literally six of seven of these plates over six or seven weeks this summer. So good, so full, and so cheap.

Skip the pho (medicore), and whatever else is on the menu. This is the best Five Spice Chicken in the city and you're missing out if you don't get it.

PROTIP: Get an extra fried egg with it. Yes, it costs $1.50 and you can buy a dozen eggs with that price and fry it yourself at home, but a fried egg on the chicken rice plate is like the maraschino cherry on top of an ice cream sundae. It isn't quite the same without it :)
author: Chris S.

description: Went here on and off for a while.  I come here for the 5 spice chicken rice dish.  The food has been okay and the service good as well.  This place gets busy during lunch time.  I recommend take out if this place is packed.
author: Guest U.

description:
The last couple times I came here I really enjoyed the food.  I tried bun, bun rieu, pho bo, hue noodle soup and they were all good. they even had beers that we enjoyed in vietnam.

the place isn't super clean and service is ok but what do you expect from a pho place?
author: claudia y.

description:
PPQ Noodles has the solid #1 spot in our current noodle rotation, holding it down with its layered, pleasantly unctuous and all around delicious, curry noodle soup. 

THE VIBE:

Um, noodle housy. Service is quick and polite, nothing wrong here. Always a table when we've come. 

THE SLURP:

Beef pho and chicken pho have both been solid, but it's the curry noodle soup that I dream about at night. That I crave in the morning, looking at the clock above my desk, counting down the minutes until dinner time. The curry is multi-layered, citrusy and rich from the coconut milk. Doesn't need a drop of chili sauce, or shredded basil. Comes out perfect. 

Their spring rolls are pretty excellent too, nice flaky fried crunch before you dig in. 


PRO TIP:

The hours listed on yelp are wrong, they've been updated and they open later then stated. Call ahead.
author: Patrick T.

description:
Good food to soak up a booze filled
night but loaded with MSG! I'm very sensitive to it and was up all night with a racing heartbeat. Never again will I eat here - ugh.
author: Jenny P.

description: Love their beef platter and garlic noodles! Have enjoyed their Pho too. Great staple in the neighborhood for eat-in or pick-up.
author: Dani A.

description: When here with my bf ans friends on a recommendation from a lovely lady at Portola Nail salon. I love it. They loved it. It was a good time. :)
author: Karin B.

description: I've never felt the need to write a review, good or bad, but this place was amazing. I got the medium seafood pho with curry broth and I've never been so satisfied with a meal, seriously. One friend got the lemongrass porkchop the rest of the table ordered the five spice chicken pho/rice and it was all really good. The whole crew was blown away by how good it was. Great menu, great food, good portions, we'll be back!
author: David L.

description:
I initially didn't like this place but after trying their five spice chicken pho (pho ga quay chao), I was hooked!

A good pho soup has many layers to its flavor with the infusion of many different spices and this totally nails it. The chicken is also very nicely grilled with a crispy skin layer.

SF has finally redeemed itself from the lack of quality pho!!
author: Henry P.

description: Service here is subpar. The pho isn't all that great and the bun bo hue isn't that great here either. Just another mediocre place in my opinion.
author: Eric A.

description:
My finger rested over the 5th star to rate PPQ and my only hesitation is that I haven't tried enough of their (extensive) menu. What I've had, however, is 5 stars all the way.

PPQ's Pho, their Five Spice chicken and amazing Imperial rolls are delicious. And, each entree can easily serve two people (add appetizer if you're super-hungry).  At under $9/plate for an entree, it's more than a solid deal.

PPQ's Five-Spice Chicken is mouth-watering, succulent and savory. PPQ's Imperial rolls are the best I've had since I lived in Paris during Junior year abroad and the plethora of inexpensive Vietnamese restaurants fit my tiny budget.

(You need to ask for extra lettuce and mint for the Imperial rolls. They'll give it to you at no charge but you need to request it- what they give you is not enough).

So, yesterday I followed my own Yelp review advice and got my nails done at Sunset Nails (the best!) and then did take-out at PPQ.

I love San Francisco.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
I came here with two friends and we were seated immediate,y  the restaurant wasn't as full as it could've been which was really nice. When I tried calling a waitress to take our order she completely ignored me. I was waving at her and she just stared off into the distance. My friend to,d me that we weren't in her section but as if I'd know which section belongs to who. She could've at least told me that someone else was going to take our orders. We placed our order with our correct waiter and our food came between 5-10 min after that. 

I ordered b2 imperial rolls with five spice chicken vermicelli for $9.25. It was pretty good. The five spice chicken was sooo good.The imperial rolls were super crisp and delicious. I thought the noodles tasted pretty much like every other vietnamese vermicelli that I've tastes. The one thing I was a little disappointed with was that this place didn't have that chili flakes in the oil condiment that I love eating and so I had to make do with sriacha and hoison sauce. 
 
After getting the bill and and paying, we waited for the cashier to return our change but she didn't and I guess decided to keep it. I get really annoyed when cashiers do this and they think we tip when we pay. It really makes me not tip people when things like this happen. In the end we just left because she just kept the $2 extra. Oh well she just got less than 10%. That's something they don't deserve but I guess they should be happy we gave a little more than our exact change.
author: Alex T.

description:
Definitely come here for the pho. The price and portion size are reasonable, and the wait time for your pho is within 5 minutes.

For other kinds of dishes, the price will be higher and wait time much longer. I ordered the ox tail stew rice plate. The place was empty because it was not quite dinnertime, yet I still waited for my food for 10+min while everyone else was already halfway through their pho. Nevertheless, I enjoyed my ox tail stew. Obviously, the people with whom I came also enjoyed their food very much as they did not think twice about waiting with me.
author: Judge F.

description: Taste good, charbroiled pork cake with rice is nice. They charge $1.5 extra for chicken broth. Should come with the order. Minus 2 stars. They are selling broth to non soup food.
author: Terry K.

description: I live in Atlanta now but every time I visit San Francisco curry chicken is my first meal of every visit and I visit a lot. I wish I could have this here in the ATL!!!!!!
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I loved the Pho.  Didn't too much care for the curry broth, but I'm sure you may love it.   I tried to try something different.  The lemongrass broth was all I needed!  But everything else about the pho was great.  They weren't skimpy with their meat or their tripe or their tendon.

The beef carpaccio was also a dish I really enjoyed.  It was a bit sweet which was a tasty surprise.  Enjoy!
author: Wouldn't You L.

description:
There was wayyyy too much hype for this place.  Frankly, my low score is due to one main factor: service was outrageously horrible.

It was pretty empty for a Saturday afternoon, so we were seated immediately.  My mother's been talking about their curry chicken noodle soup for a while now.. apparently, it tastes like this Burmese soup my family loves.  What a disappointment... the soup was extremely oily and there was way too much coconut that it completely overpowered the curry.  In addition, they used flat rice noodles... it just didn't go well with the dish at all.  
Score: 2/5

Next, I saw pictures of the crab meat noodle soup on Yelp and knew I had to try it.  I was totally in love with the previous crab meat noodle soup I had at another Vietnamese restaurant.  This was probably the main dish that I was excited for.  Guess what, they got my order wrong and brought out a nasty starchy egg-drop-like soup with broccoli... WHAT IS THIS?!  I've never seen this dish.. ever.  I saw maybe one or two tiny pieces of crab floating around... 

I kindly asked out waitress what it was... this was definitely not the noodle soup I ordered.. where were the tomatoes?  the crab?  the noodles?!  Impatiently, she said this was what we ordered and said no exchanges.  Great.. we had to pay for this disgusting thing when it was clearly their fault.
Score: 0/5

Oh, and I forgot to mention, the owner was just sitting towards the back giving me the most evil glares from the minute I walked in.  After the little situation with our waitress, she walked over to her and presumably asked what happened (I assume because they were staring and pointing in our direction).... uhg.. it made me furious! 

I tried my grandmother's 5 Spice Chicken dish too.. So grossly oily..  
Score: 0/5

Needless to say, I'm totally not happy with this place and would never go back.  It's understandable if there was a language barrier and they didn't understand what I was ordering.  But I ordered in Chinese.. and they still got it wrong.

No thank you.
author: Cecilia S.

description:
A friend recommend we go here for a late dinner. So glad she did! 

What did I love about this place? 
They are open late. We got dinner after 10:00pm

We got our food lightening fast

Very good value. Lots of food for under 10$

The curry chicken pho- not like any other I have had!! OMG, the chicken was plentiful and so tender and flavorful!! The broth is curry with a coconut milk base. It was insane. I scarfed down this whole large bowl. It really was amazing. I am a white girl who does not know what is authentic Vietnamese or not, but this was tasty!!

Hubby had the crab pho in tomato broth. He loved it. 

Cons-
Parking can be tricky

We had to ask for water. Staff is not attentive. 

Definitely check this place out.
author: Keri V.

description:
HIGHLIGHTS:
IMPERIAL ROLLS - just short of over-fried, crispy and flavorful
RARE FLANK BEEF PHO - solid all the way around, the beef in here is excellent!

OK:
Five Spices chicken - good but a little bland to me.  I was expecting more flavor fulness with the name "five spices". Did not live up to the hype.
Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce and garlic - pretty standard, sold veggie to balance out the other dishes

You definitely get more than you pay for here at PPQ. Prices are good.  It's not amaaaazing, but it's a good neighborhood spots - If I lived in the area, I imagine I'd hit this place up frequently.
author: Navin W.

description: This place is so much better than the pho restaurant across the street. The beef broth is much richer here and the taste of the meat is higher quality. PPQ is less of a chain pho restaurant than the one across the street so the quality is maintained at a very high standard. My favorite item to get is the brisket, tripe, and flank steak noodle soup. So good.
author: Jonathan Z.

description: Your typical Vietnamese restaurant, got all the selections just like others out there. The pho is pretty good and the beef over rice with fried egg is a must try!
author: William C.

description:
Old traditions die hard, don't they?

My family and relatives came here for years. I came home from college one day and pleaded with my mama to take me here so I can stuff my face in their SPICY SATAY NOODLE SOUP WITH BEEF BALLS. And what do you know? My cousin also came back from her college that day and brought her friends here the same time I was there. Another time, she stopped by my house coming back from college, called me up and asked, "You wanna grab some Viet food over at the usual Pho place in Sunset?" Uh, did she even have to ask?

Oh my gosh, I LOVE their spicy satay noodle soup with beef balls so much! I love spicy food, and this bowl of noodles definitely satisfies me! I also love ordering a plate of their five spice chicken on the side to go with it if I'm real hungry! But yea, this is a good place to stop for Viet food if you're by the Sunset or live close by ;)
author: Karen T.

description: Just order 2item to go waiting for so long and give me wrong item looks light not busy
author: Lohu K.

description:
I see folks complaining about how "expensive" a bowl of soup is here and it frustrates me.  Most noodle houses that are less expensive do not use fresh REAL ANGUS BEEF in their stocks etc. and soup made from frozen cheap beef bones almost always has a slaughter house smell to it.  These guys throw down some of the best soup in town.  I get the number one large and I get the satay broth for an extra buck and always leave feeling well nourished.  Hangover cure hotspot.
If you want cheap soup go to Loi's a few blocks down and that place is hitting for the bargain bowl of pho.  PPQ's owner is a great guy to boot.  I was in the Silver Spur one day and got a free drink and it turned out to be the owner remembering me and stoking me on a shot.
author: Johnny B.

description: I have a feeling this Vietnamese restaurant gets a bit overshadowed by Kevin noodle house across the street, but they're both great in my opinion. Their pho is a cheap and has big portions. One of my favorite things to get here is the five spice chicken and their curry broth. I usually order a five spice chicken pho and change the broth to curry broth for an extra dollar or so. It's so worth it. The curry isn't too spicy but adds a lot of flavor to the pho. It's definitely a must have.
author: Julia P.

description: Suffered food poisoning after eating the chicken pho. The hygiene here is really bad. table is greasy all the time and the utensil not throughly clean. I won't recommend this place to anyone.
author: nathan a.

description: I like the food for its price and the quality. The phos that I've tried are pretty tasty.
author: Dominique S.

description:
PPQ is awesome!  

The Curry Chicken Noodle Soup is a cannot miss.  The Satay Beef Noodle Soup is also great!  The imperial rolls are great.  Pretty much, everything I have tried here is flavorful with various spices, with decent portions.

If you are around the Irving area, you can't lose with PPQ.
author: Bernie C.

description: Love the bun here. The prices are a bit high for traditional Vietnamese food, but well worth it. The bowl was adequately full of vermicelli and sprouts/basil/carrots/peanuts and fish sauce. The veggie spring rolls were tasty and plentiful. Had I had the charbroiled shrimp summer rolls (3) first, I probably wouldn't have needed to order the bun, as the serving size was also plentiful. This summer roll was likely the best one I've ever had. At $8.50 it was also the most expensive, but as I said earlier well worth it! I would definitely come back here again when in the city next. Thanks guys!
author: Tammy Y.

description:
This place is great. It's the best pho spot in the Sunset and possibly the city. Many people rave about Tu Lan's but I think the pho here is better. 

The thing about PPQ is their ingredients are of better quality and you can taste it. Some people complain it's "bland" but their used to modified MSG and higher salt content which in my opinion doesn't make better soup. 

The staff has never messed up order and the main guy, Tin, is really great, helpful and fun to talk to. Part of the reason why I go. 

Their phu is always in the money with really tasty broth and noodles. I almost always go with the curry pho which is creamy, slightly spicy and very tasty.
author: Jack S.

description:
Holy crap! Their spicy, curry broth pho is seriously the best pho I have ever had! I am really bummed that I live in Colorado just for this reason. 

Their service isn't the best. Ok - actually, they are pretty slow and borderline rude. In all honesty the food surpasses the service! 

You most definitely need to try that curry broth!
author: Shani T.

description: Loved their Pho and the fresh five spiced duck rolls. Very reasonably priced. For a party of two, I think an order of one appetiser and a large bowl of noodle soup is more than enough to share.
author: Bomin K.

description: Stopped by for lunch with a friend.  The service was good, prices very reasonable and they kept the place clean.  I had vermicelli with pork, imperial roll and had them add shrimp.  Excellent dish and the shrimp were large, fresh and perfectly grilled! The imperial rolls were flavorful and the pork not too fatty and grilled to perfection. I will definitely be back to try the pho.
author: Brian K.

description: Pretty good I would highly recommend the charbroiled beef rice plate. Interesting way of waiting- they have u sign in and you wait. I found it to be refreshing as it's nice to see which party is ahead of u and how long the wait is
author: Rj A.

description:
Food here is over seasoned with salt, sugar, and msg to make up for the lack of flavor depth. 

The pho soup barely tastes of beef... The kitchen over salts to compensate. 

Vietnamese carpaccio has good meat quality but was over sugared. It tasted like I was eating raw beef candy. 

I suspect the restaurant has a change of chef or ownership recently, because the recipes appear solid, but execution is very shoddy. 

They are also tight with ingredients compared to other restaurants in the area.... This isn't a restaurant that takes pride in its food.
author: Kit T.

description:
Curry is good, vermicelli is tasty, pho is decent, spring rolls are yummy.

One of my go to places for Vietnamese food. 

Try the rice plates - i've heard good things! :)
author: Jenny E.

description:
The Satay (Angus) Beef Pho and Curry Chicken Pho are both equally amazing, making the choice always a difficult one. 
Imperial Rolls are a MUST! (**warning: they're addictive and me order may not be enough).
Looking for grilled meats? Yep! They got 'em and they're delectable (my fave is Grilled Pork with rice stick).
Cabbage salad with tofu rocks too!

...eat here & you'll walk away well-fed at a great price.
author: Kristofer B.

description:
Dropped a dish on the floor, picked it up then put it back in stack for use. 
Picked out dried food from a cup and handed it to me to use. 
Longest time waited for a bowl of pho ever! 
But considering it was fast food, I wasn't expecting much in the first place.
author: k k.

description: Once in a while I get this craving for their chicken coconut curry pho . Usually it's my go to hangover or drunk food. Always on point! Always busy especially on Saturdays and the hangover Sunday brunch time. Must try this spot at least once.
author: Chris C.

description:
How many Pho restaurants are there in the San Francisco? 
Too many. 

How many can make a bomb-ass Beef Carpaccio?
PPQ, raise yo hand!

The Beef Carpaccio really is that damn good. If you don't know what that might be, it's an appetizer of raw meat, in this case beef, beaten down paper thin and served with various spices, chili's, greens, peanuts, or whatnot. 

Here's PPQ's - [http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/nR6QJjVq4h6wWnP7_dQthA/l.jpg]

Now I've eaten a ton of raw beef before, some good, some unpleasant, and some just regrettable.. but this simply blew me away. Their beef was very fresh, well-marbled, and combined with the sheer execution of the dish, burst with an array of spicy and delicious collaborative flavors! 

It's a shame that their evening pho was pretty lackluster after eating their amazing beef carpaccio.. It wasn't even on the same level. The broth could have definitely been much better. However, I'm leaving this on a good note and praising their Beef Carpaccio. You gotta go check it out for yourselves.
author: Albert L.

description: Bright, lively family-style restaurant packed with all kinds of folks happily slurping pho or devouring noodles. Garlic noodles with grilled prawns was amazing, so suffused with garlic that was almost truffle-like. Prawns were large and intense. Veggie fried rolls were a little greasy but so crunchy.  Will be back to try more!  Complaints about service do not seem justified.
author: Evelyn L.

description:
Curry Pho with 5 spice chicken instead of that weird white mystery meat.  Imperial rolls.  

'Nuff Said.  Go get some.  Good enough to eat 2 days in a row.  Whoa.

P.S  You can split the large if your feelin' skinny
author: Cat A.

description:
Been here twice. Once because Kevin's was closed and the other was because the line was too long.

Great quality, a bit more expensive than kevin's. I've had the pho and bun bo hue and the pho definitely was not as flavorful as kevin's.

Would I come here again? I would come here if already in the area with friends if other places were crowded but I would not choose to come here.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Overall it was pretty disappointing experience! Not sure what the problem is but we arrived before everyone else and they started to get served before us on a non-busy day. After about 20mins of watching everyone else get their food before us i was greeted by a water down bowl of bun reiu. Where is the love!? i was expecting a dark red tomato base soup but it was was not tomato base, but a clear chicken broth that lacked favor served with raw onions and tomato? what is up with that?

I couldn't think of anything nice to say about this place, bottom line? Avoid this place, this place is a fake and a fraud!
author: Calvin S.

description:
Boo me all you want, I'm only giving three stars. 

Born and raised in San Jose makes me a bit of a Vietnamese food snob. Let me say, unbiasedly, that the food here is phenomenal. The broth is flavorful and non artificial, and everything that comes out of the kitchen tastes homey and delicious. 

The minus two stars are based solely on their service. They never checked up on us, the food came out at different times, and they forgot about our egg rolls until the very end. We ordered a plate of egg rolls, two Pho bowls and a rice plate. The Pho bowls came out after waiting some time, with the rice plate no where to be seen for ten minutes. We asked someone to check on our order, and without even asking what we ordered she quickly gave us a generic, "Okay 5 minutes." We reminded about the egg rolls a few times and didn't come out until we were absolutely stuffed and finished with our respective bowls and plates. We had to take the egg rolls to go, which made them inedible, for we all know, left over egg rolls aren't the same...

The two (large size) bowls of Pho are super huge and filled to the brim with broth and noodles. They both ordered the chicken Pho and were extremely satisfied with the broth to noodle to meat ratio.

I ordered a rice plate. Grilled pork, shredded pork and an egg loaf. All for 9 dollars, not bad. I felt like I was eating at my relatives house, everything seemed really home made and made me slightly nostalgic. 

I'm definitely coming back for the food. The service should be better though. Also, the waiter did not understand us at all, which was slightly unfortunate, he did understand pointing and numbers though.
author: Mindy T.

description:
Didn't realize I was here before during my old high school days, but it's been that long, it's pretty much my first time here. Came here with a group of 7 and it wasn't that long of a wait before they could combine two tables together for us. It was pretty packed, but it's normal for a New Years Day. Ordered the Bun Rieu (my usual in viet restaurants) and it was okay. Not exceptionally good nor bad. I hardly tasted the crab though, it was mixed into the egg base, there was no tomato in sight other than just the broth itself. It also has two piece of tofu and two slice of meat, is that in a traditional bun rieu? The table ordered their famous carpaccio and I heard yummy noises. I don't eat beef THAT raw, so I won't be able to give you my personal review on it. From what it sounds like, it would be one of their dishes to try.

The restaurant itself isn't that big, they try to squeeze in a table with two seats every corner they can. Definitely not upscale.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Been coming here for 20 years.... Love the 5 spice chicken rolls. A real good food place. Hard to find parking. It was busy as usual but we got seated (6) within 10 minutes. Love this place.
author: George T.

description:
the Pho broth here is really good.
I just wish there was more pho noodles (considering a medium bowl is $7.50) and the meat was better cut and more abundant.

the shrimp/beef spring rolls left a lot to be desired...it wasn't very good plus it was expensive (6.75) for 3 rolls.

friend got the 5 spice chicken, which he completely raved about.
author: Philip M.

description: What happened to my PPQ?! I used to have cravings for this place that would cause me to drive out of the way to eat here. They had the best peanut sauce, the best five spice chicken and the best broth. Was there a change in ownership or the cooks? Everything is bland now and tastes completely different. I went twice because I thought the first time about a month ago  was just a fluke but no. The food was so bad I didn't even want to eat it. The service was great. They are very prompt and nice so I gave two stars but I won't be returning and am in deep mourning for my old favorite pho spot. :(
author: Annya S.

description: Seated very quickly as we came a bit early for dinner. Below average service. Tried beef carpaccio, egg rolls, pho and 5-spiced chicken. Really liked the egg rolls and the 5-spiced chicken.
author: Fran S.

description:
Ordered a bowl of Five Spice Chicken, and they literally just threw on what looked like instant noodles (noodles came in a rigid, square formation) and an overcooked side dish of chicken. The broth itself also tasted like cheap chicken broth that you could get from Costco or Chinatown.


The waiters also don't give you back your change and have this attitude of entitlement to a tip. My friend was waiting for her change and the waiters never came back - they straight up ignored her and started clearing out the table while she was still there.
author: Zhi L.

description:
What the pho do they put in their broth!  There has to be a significant amount of MSG, my mouth is super dry, tongue has that itchy feeling.  Let's start with service, sat down and was handed menus.  Literally the waitress turned around and turned back and said what you like to order.  She clearly saw we did not even open the menus up.  She came back 15 seconds later and asked the same question, quite comedic.

Ordered spring rolls $6.75 and #2 pho with beef, tendon and tripe.  Kinda on the high side for pho and rolls, just saying.  Spring rolls came, they lacked girth with barely any ingredients inside.  The lettuce was spotted brownish as well.  For the three spring rolls if I eyeballed correctly the shrimp meat came from one single shrimp cut into six super thin slices.  

The pho, at first sip the broth is very watered down tasting.  Salt dominated the flavor there was no sweetness or hints of beef essence you normally get in good quality pho.  The noodles were undercooked, was in a ball of yarn in the middle of the bowl.  The cow the meat came off of must have been a marathon runner if it can only produce six strips of beef, two silver dollar sized rubbery pieces of tendon and chopped up tripe that if you put it together would have been an inch long.  

Pho sure go elsewhere, one of the worst bowl of noodles I have had ever.
author: Grubnoisseur Y.

description:
$10 bowl of pho. $10 bowl of pho. $10 bowl of pho. $10 bowl of pho. $10 bowl of pho. 

With the abundance of pho places on Irving, I am appalled that Pho Phu Quoc has the brass balls to charge such a steep price for a mediocre bowl of pho. Let's also remind ourselves here that Pho is sold primarily by street vendors and is targeted towards the poor in Vietnam. I have eaten pho in Vietnam and its significantly cheaper than most other dishes you'll find; the same should translate to Americas standards. Instead, we have made pho trendy causing the prices to hike for such a simple dish. This is where Pho Phu Quoc steps in and rears its ugly head. 

The service was quick but inattentive. The tea was hot. The pho tai was standard... nothing special, at all. minimal meat, brick-like noodles. so-so broth that i had to douse in siracha (good broth shouldn't need much/any) And... drumroll... $8.64 for a medium bowl BEFORE TIP.  W.t.f.

You re better off going to Kevin's across the street for a better soup in a bigger bowl for a cheaper price. Loi's and Lam Hoa Thuan are also notable mentions. 

Did I mention I just paid $10 for a medium bowl of pho?
author: Ryan L.

description:
Midnight or late night snack @ 1040PM? ok...sure, they don't close til 11PM.

We had #1 large pho which came with rare steak, tripe, tendons...for $8 which felt sort of pricey for me. $7.95 ok but $8 seemed like DANGGG. Also ordered spring rolls, the sauce made it good, it wouldn't have been good on its own. I got a soy bean drink which I thought they made, but no it's canned & for $1.75. WHAT!!!!!!!! I could have bought this at Sunset Super for less than $1, owell. Expectations were too high.

They were cleaning up while our & 2 other groups were still there. We left when we they started to clean floors & it smelled bleach yuckkk. I'm not sure what time we left though...but we weren't the last to leave so it was all good.
author: Kylie L.

description: Perfect for what it is. It's not trying to be special or fancy. I had the garlic noodles and five spice chicken with imperial rolls. It tastes so good but the chicken had a lot of fat on it. The noodles had a real oily layer on them. Try the egg and condensed milk soda you will be pleasantly surprised. I've also had the pho and the large is huge!!! The Vietnamese iced coffee comes with a little pour over and condensed milk device that dumps into a glass of ice. Not a flashy joint. Reasonably priced. Service is main reason for the 4 stars instead of 5.
author: Mike L.

description: This noodle house has standard pho and spring rolls. It's a nice place to go if you just want to sit down and unwind with a big cheap bowl of noodles. It is always pretty busy and the food comes out quickly, but don't expect to be wowed by service. On the multiple occasions I have been here, the server has taken a while to refill water, never asked how the food was for us, and would often sit around unless called upon by a table. I must admit that I do like the pho from Kevin's Noodle House across the street better than PPQ, and if I'm going to get pho from inner sunset I will most likely go to Kevin's. What will bring me back to PPQ, however, is the word on the street that their curry pho is really good. I'll have to make an updated review after trying the curry, but until then, this is a standard, cheap, but unimpressionable place to satisfy the pho cravings.
author: Jen W.

description:
This is my go-to Vietnamese restaurant. My food of choice? The curry chicken pho, fosho! Nothing else in the city compares and I'm not sure if any other restaurant makes it... But seriously, CURRY CHICKEN PHO. ORDER IT. You won't regret it. 

And if you're not a fan of curry, go with what my girl Annie C. recommends... "FIVE SPICE CHICKEN - HOLLA".
author: I. L.

description:
Every once in awhile, I'm looking for a different kind of dining experience - greasy, grimey and quick, the type of night where the waiters don't say a word, take your order, and you're out in less than 30 minutes. This is that kind of spot.

Like others have said, turnover is quick - the entire 20 or so minutes I was there, the waitress didn't say a word to me but to take my order and hand me the check. I had the coconut curry vermacelli soup sub five spice chicken (a must - the chicken skin was SUPER crispy and tasty). 

This ain't your fine dining, fancy shmancy stuff - and if you're OK, definitely drop by.
author: Anthony L.

description: This is one of my favorite pho spots in SF. I tried a couple different items but always seem to go back to their spicy chicken curry pho which is amazing. Where this place is lacking in cleanliness  of their restaurant they definitely make up for in their flavor.
author: Natalie S.

description:
Ok I HATE it when wait staff get orders wrong-so I ordered  Shrimp Spring Rolls WITHOUT BEANSPROUTS.  I mean the menu didn't even list it containing beansprouts but I double checked with my waitress and she assured me that it wouldn't have bean sprouts-she even FLIPPED the MENU OPEN to REVIEW the contents of the spring rolls!!!  I'll let you guess what was in my spring rolls when they arrived. Yes, that's right-BEAN SPROUTS!!! GAWD!!! So I had to order another order.  When it arrived it smelled like damp dirty towels-which is probably the bacteria laden cloth towel they used to dampen the spring roll skin :(  Sorry, I know it's gross, but what's grosser is I had to smell it.  

Pluses were: Their 5 spice chicken was flavorful, and the Curry Chicken Pho was delish and flavorful-I ordered mild, it was still spicy but not too spicy where I was pissed. Just spicy enough that my eyes watered a wee bit and I had to blow my nose between bites.  I had it with the flat "hoh fun" instead of the vermicelli.  The imperial rolls were good and the ice coffee was good as well.  Two stars off for getting the order wrong when we painstakingly reviewed the order and said no bean sprouts and also the dirty towel smells on the spring rolls.
author: JP P.

description: My friend and i came here for lunch.  She ordered a seafood noodle soup and the seafood were so few in the clear broth.  You can basically count how little it was.   Crab noodle soup was better but i did not taste any crab there.  I could tell there were two pieces of tofu and a few "egg flower" with some white stuffs inside.  Both not satisfying..
author: D F.

description:
Coming back from Vietnam, we realize how Pho Phu Quoc is authentic. The nice fresh roll, great papaya salads and amazing five spice chicken.
The service is fast and yet the staff is very nice and welcoming. I have been eating at Pho Phu Quoc since 15 years and always have a great dinner.
Kids friendly
author: Marielle C.

description:
The service here isn't that great - which is understandable since it's always busy.

I came here with a friend and we ended up sharing our pho. I can't remember what we got but man was it delicious. The prices were reasonable and I will definitely be back! Absolutely delicious!  :)
author: Anonymous ?.

description:
Love the pho here...when they get it right. I have to say the quality of the broth is a little unpredictable. Most days its rich and delicious but other times it's a bit dilute and flavorless. I also enjoy getting the five spiced chicken pho with curry broth. However, the spicy-ness of the curry broth is a bit unpredictable as well. Some days its just enough spice and heat to enhance the flavors and other days the spice kills my taste buds and I can barely enjoy my meal. 

With that being said, overall I love the food and service at this place. But, I do wish the quality of the broth was a bit more consistent.
author: Ashley D.

description:
5 spice Chicken over rice or noodles - SO GOOOOD! MUST TRY

Pho is on par with the other restaurants on Irving. They remodeled a few years ago so the inside is nice. You'll see a lot more non-asians here than Kevin's across the street.
author: Daniel S.

description: Not bad but most definitely not the best. The service is very slow which is understandable since I did go during dinner time. I usually go to Kevin's Noodle House which is across the street and I never wait more than 5 minutes for my meal. At this place I waited for about 20 minutes. 20 minutes is a lot when a person is hungry! The food was disappointing too. Even though the portion was decent, the food lacked in flavor. I'll be getting my pho fix from Kevin's Noodle House from now on.
author: Lisa H.

description: Taste good but not clean. I found a piece of paper from in my noodle soup. So friendly reminder, check before you eat.
author: Eric L.

description:
I've gone here a few times in the afternoon after a long night of drinking. Perfect spot for a hangover remedy. 

I recently tried their Chicken Curry Noodle Soup. It was really good, though I felt like it was more like a dish that would go with rice than a soup with noodles. The portions were perfect and when I couldn't finish a meal, they made sure to separate the soup from the noodles to prevent the noodles from expanding and absorbing all of the soup!

However, the only problem with this place is that their service is extremely poor. Every time that I've gone here, it seemed like during the duration of my stay each visit, their service would get worse. Initially, they would be available for all questions and make sure you were ready to order. Once you placed your order, however, it's like the entire staff does not see you anymore. By the end of the shift, you even wonder if they remembered that you have yet to pay for the bill. 

Otherwise, the food is great, and if you don't mind being super thirsty when your water runs out, and waiting a while just to pay, go get some pho! I think it's still worth it!
author: Odes K.

description:
My nickname for this place is PPQ cause saying the whole name is just a mouthful. But the food here is definitely a good kind of mouthful. My party and I had the grilled pork which was divine. It was served on a sizzling platter and had the flavors of garlic, shallots, lemongrass and more. It was tender and full of amazing flavor. We also had a beef stew which was a standard along with a crispy chicken dish which went well with steamed rice. 

The highlights were the imperial rolls which were tasty and my friends and I had fun rolling them in the butter lettuce. The cabbage salad is definitely worth the hype with so much different flavors and a great dressing. It is like the Vietnamese version of a Burmese rainbow salad. I enjoyed my meal and thanks to PPQ, I found my new favorite sandwich shop, Toastie's which is also owned by PPQ.
author: Danster L.

description:
Decent pho place in the Irving market area. The place is a bit crammed, and the service isn't necessarily always easy to catch. But they are very quick, and seem to be understaffed, as it seemed that there were only 3 waitresses running about 20 tables. The broth was nothing special, and didn't have a unique taste, but the good thing was that they gave a lot of meat and noodles so it was still a very filling meal. Don't get me wrong, the food was decent for a pho place, and probably better than anything in this area! But I have had better Pho in Chinatown and this doesn't compare to that. If this place had a better and tastier broth, this place would definitely be an amazing location for Pho. 

TLDR: Decent pho. Thats about it.
author: Nakul B.

description:
PPQ is one of the best places for your Vietnamese food! You can't go wrong with (almost) anything on their menu. I tried their carpaccio recently and it was delicious!
Why then, are they missing one star? Well, I love bun rieu, which is the crab and tomato based noodle soup. It is my absolute favorite Vietnamese soup, and PPQ's bun rieu doesn't really cut it for me. Sorry, but everything else, I definitely recommend!
author: Athena L.

description:
Been here a number of times and this is my first review here (shame on me).

PPQ is a great place for yummy and plentiful portions and one of the best in the area.  Irving street is a challenge to park so get lucky and bring a lot of quarters to keep the meter people away. 

Now for the food: Over the numberous times I've been there, had the charbroiled beef, chicken, and pork vermicelli each with imperial rolls. The meats are nicely seasoned and tender.  These are the favorites and the portions are plentiful. In the cold Sunset ordering a cold dish doesn't make sense but who cares, food this good is much appreciated.
author: Stefan L.

description:
As someone who does not eat beef, Pho has always eluded me... that is until my good friend Stephanie who goes to SFSU nearby brought me to this local hotspot one cold, rainy SF night.

Little can be said about the meek interior, with mirrored panels lining the walls with plywood-wood paneling and simple furniture...you could tell that PPQ (as the locals call it) was one of those places you go to eat, not to look or expect the best service of your life.

I've been here a few times (as I'm from LA, I can eat here 2-3x a year when I visit), but every time I've come here, I've gotten the same experience, which is a good one.

The servers are friendly, which is surprising as I'm a picky brown guy asking for custom orders every time I visit. They serve you some fresh chinese tea on the house in a pot, so you can drink on up as you wait for your orders to arrive. Get the veggie egg rolls, they are to die for...just make sure you have a lot of napkins to wipe off the gallons of oil/grease on them. After that, you're in for a yummy treat.

Like previously states, I don't eat beef or beef pho, so I always get the curry chicken pho in coconut milk. For under $7, you cannot go wrong. All the ingredients are fresh, savory and leave me wanting more. I dump in bean sprouts, basil and a pint of hot sauce/chili oil to kick it up a notch.

Fifteen minutes later, I've called it a day, pay my bill and heat out... completely satisfied and looking forward to more when I come back next. PPQ is delicious and will be a regular spot for me when I'm in the bay area. Must try.
author: Hemang S.

description: PPQ is my favorite place for a quick dinner in the Sunset. Love their traditional beef pho and chicken curry, and the satay skewers are totally moist and delicious! Avoid coming here on a Thursday or Friday night as it gets pretty packed, but perfect for a mid-week dinner on the cheap!
author: Victoria K.

description:
After my very first visit to PPQ Restaurant, I like it so much that I couldnt resist on going back again for the second straight day once more for lunch before, I go on to try another Vietnamese Restaurant...

Once Again This What I Ordered From PPQ Restaurant

                   ~~~~~Charbroiled Beef Rice Plate~~~~~~
    ~~And Of Course I Gotta Have My Favorite Soft Drink Coca Cola~~
author: William B.

description:
Overall I'd come back.

Five slice chicken was solid, my gf and I would come back again for that.

The meatball pho was bland, would not order again.

Reasonable prices.

Servers were present and always had a smile.
author: Charlie B.

description: PPQ is a mixed bag, some dishes are yummy superb, and other are disgusting. For example, the Sizzling Iron Platter beef I keep coming back for, but some noodle soups I've had contained questionable inedible meats, even though the broth and noodles were excellent. I keep coming back though, perhaps that's just what the food is supposed to be like. I claim no expertise whatsoever with Vietnamese food, I'm going by my own taste buds.
author: Rob C.

description:
Decent Viet restaurant in Sunset. Pho was a little bland, but the rest of the food was good. 

Decor is homey and no frills. Service is good as any neighborhood joints would be. I'll go again if in town and really wanted Viet food and didn't want to hop in the car and go far.
author: Huong V.

description: I've been coming here a lot out of convenience, but their borderline rude service is making me prefer Kevin's Noodle House (which also happens to be cheaper/more spacious/better quality) across the street.
author: An Y.

description: Super delicious. They're open late. Their imperial rolls were crispy and awesome, their vermicelli solid. Big portions. Quality veggies and fixins. OPEN LATE. Standard pricing. Did I mention they're open late? Also got the five spice chicken appetizer roll. GET IT. Amazing flavor.
author: Shaymaa M.

description:
Great Bun Rieu for a restaurant. Love their imperial rolls as well. They do take visa/mc so that is another plus. Service is decent but depending who you get. 
If you go during peak hours, you can expect to wait at least 30 min for a table.
author: Tracy L.

description:
I prefer PPQ's pho more than the other popular spot in this block. The broth is clean, has depth, and they have different choices in noodles. 

But let's be real, ya'll can kick the price down a notch! Who ya'll trying to fool?! Your server dipped his thumb into my bowl, as he handed it to me!
author: Diane N.

description: Where's the beef?  Not enough beef but at least it was good beef.  Noodles was good.  Broth is good.  Tendon is good.
author: Byron L.

description:
I used to come here for pho when the one across the street was full..and so was the case last night. 

I was very disappointed that I paid $8.95 for pho #1 and was skimped on meat. One meatball and a few slices of meat in their largest bowl. I didn't like their broth either..Maybe that's why everyone else goes to Kev's.
author: LC B.

description: Just came back from this place and had to write a review. That was the absolute worst pho I've ever had. I ordered the beef stew and it had about a quarter inch of fat floating on top and very little flavor. I got there about 30 minutes before they closed, and judging by the other reviews I suspect the kitchen gave me tomorrow's pho which they hadn't skimmed yet. I tried skimming the fat off myself, but after filling up my tea cup and still having a thick layer of fat in my bowl, I gave up, ate my 3 fatty pieces of beef, and called it a night.
author: Natalie W.

description:
Updated on 6-20-2016 after a horrible meal

I had first eaten at this restaurant about a month ago and wrote the review below just recently. Thinking about it made me want it tonight so off we went and now must downplay the rating from 4 stars to 2stars. There were 4 of us last time & we all ordered our own dish but today decided to order family style. What a mistake. The five spice chicken was the only dish that came out ok. They served the grilled beef & grilled pork on a cast iron platter which cause the meat to be way overcooked. It costed much more and didn't seem like it was worth it. I thought I'd give the oxtails a try since we love ox tails. If you've never ordered it, don't! There were 2 pieces of decent sized oxtails, 3 pieces that were smaller than my pinkie and these white floating things that we thought were potatoes! Imagine how disgusted we were when we bit into a mouth full of FAT. It had no taste and was so greasy. I'm so disappointed & disgusted.

By the time I got home, I was literally sick to my stomach. I'll spare you of further details. 

Ox tail stewed with potatoes and carrots in a savory sauce
15.75
..............................................................................................................................
It's been awhile since i've given a 4 star rating but everything we ordered was really good. I've seen this place for years but just never stopped in. I was craving Viet food at 10pm and this place was open. We ordered the following:

17. 炸春卷
Imperial Rolls - Crispy fried rolls filled with ground pork, taro, carrots, and silver noodles. Served with lettuce, mint leaves and cucumber with nuoc mam (3 rolls) 
(Cha Gio) $6.95  

43. 五香雞飯
Five Spices Chicken Rice Plate 
(Com Ga Quay Chao) $8.25  

45. 燒牛肉飯
Charbroiled Beef Rice Plate 
(Com Bo Nuong) $9.25

46. 燒豬肉飯
Charbroiled Pork Rice Plate 
(Com Thit Nuong) $8.25

47. 燒豬扒飯
Charbroiled Pork Chop Rice Plate 
(Com Suon Nuong) $9.25 

Most of us replaced the rice for garlic noodles, I don't remember how much they added but it didn't matter b/c it was good. My son's girlfriend ordered a plain pho and said it was good. I don't know, I don't eat pho. I will be back and will order meat as ala carte so we can eat "family style".
author: May G.

description: their pho broth is really good and flavorful. my coworker ordered the curry noodle w/ 5 spice chicken. the curry both was really good too . i think i will order that next time. you can substitute noodles w.out any charges. too bad its pretty far from our work place cause if not we'd be here more often.
author: Siling C.

description:
P lenty of reasons to like PPQ
H as been my most reliable place in SF for Pho
O r any other Vietnamese dish

P erfect start to the meal: Imperial Rolls
H oly mother of spring rolls these are amazing
U nbelievable taste and crisp to these little guys

Q uite fond of the flavor in the Five-spice Chicken
U sually get mine with Vermicelli -- ask for extra sauce
O xtail Soup with Rice comes with a great broth
C om Suon (Pork Chop) is moist and barbecued nicely
author: Anthony N.

description:
*** CORRECTION!! - They do accept credit cards now!!!

One of my favorite pho places in the city...and quite affordable!  Although there are other places that can do the traditional pho just as well (and sometimes better), I have yet to find a place that can give me a bowl of pho as good as their Satay Beef pho (#5).  Despite the oil that just floats there on top, there's not much better to eat on a cold SF night.  Otherwise, their Charbroiled Beef rice plate is great, as is the chicken and pork .  But before you get into all that...be sure to start it off with an order of their Imperial Rolls!  For my friends and I, it's not a trip to PPQ without an order of these crispy treats!

Mmmmm give me a regular #5 and Imperial Rolls and I am a happy camper.
author: Mike L.

description:
Love love love this place!!! One of best Vietnamese restaurants of San Francisco. Their Curry chicken soup is a bummb!!!!! It's slightly spicy but amazing flavor. I love everything about this place. 
The place is moderate clean, reasonable price,  and yummy food. It gets busy sometimes especially when the weather gets cold! I always get vegetarian noodle soup either their curry chicken soup It tastes like out of this world!
I strongly suggest this place!!! Parking can be a bit challenge this neighborhood!
author: Jun Y.

description:
Ate here again, December 2011, as I do at least once a year.

Five spice chicken noodle soup. 5 stars.
Triple order of imperial roles. 5 stars (and then some).
Beef and imperial role Bun. 5 stars.

If I could give PPQ fifteen stars, I would. But this is Yelp, so it gets 5 solid. Rock on, PPQ, rock on.
author: Jefferson S.

description: This place is not good at all. I ordered the garlic noodle with chicken. Everything was bland including the fish sauce. Don't add the imperial roll. It is $2.25 for one small roll that is cut into three pieces. Such a waste of money.
author: Scott T.

description: Love their Curry Chicken Vermicelli noodles. Hot, tasty & spicy! Reminds me of my parent's home cooking, Ka poon. Sometimes it's too spicy that my taste buds can't handle it. I love spicy foods though. At least I don't sweat like men do :) however, extra napkins sure helps out with my runny nose :o*/ and glass of water. And oh, their imperial fried egg rolls are delicious! I can eat a bunch of those but one order is enough. The five spice chicken with rice is good too. Great service. Busy place.
author: Amy H.

description: The pho is a bit watery tbh (definitely not as good as Kevin's), but it's the only late-night option.
author: Daniel B.

description:
They had the best VNese rice plates (#26 combo) around. Another good item is "bun thit nuong" (rice noodle with imperial rolls and charbroiled pork) - all friends liked it. The five-spice chicken pho is also very popular with non-VNese. The egg rolls are salty, but good with rice noodle or rice. Note the pho is only OK, go across the street if possible.

Returned because friends wanted to try a different pho place than our usuals. The rice plate was still good and their pho has gotten better, though still not great.

Thinking they also own Toastie's (http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?q=toastie&userid=09T1oyi6c-9lvyt7gQCD2w), since both places are listed on the menu.
author: Peter L.

description:
not a fan of their pho - I felt the broth was flavorless even after I added tons of fish sauce, hoisin, and sriracha

would not return nor would I recommend
author: Lev E.

description:
Our usual pho spot in the Sunset (Pho Huynh Hiep) was closed today for the Lunar New Year.  We were craving noodles so decided to try this place across the street that was open.  BIGGEST mistake ever.

Ordered a very safe bowl of Pho Tai (noodles with rare steak) - the broth was bland, the noodles broke every time I tried to pick them up with my chopsticks and the piece of beef were also small and seemingly chopped up instead of the large pieces of beef we're used to.

Needless to say, even though I was starving, I forced down three bites and had to push my bowl away.  This bowl of pho was offensive to my people.
author: Lilan D.

description:
SOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO...LIDD... as a ROCK. Like Chevy. Like steady. Are you ready??? You ain't ready.

You know how when you go to the doctor and he gets a little gavel and knocks your knee at the perfect spot to make your knee plop straight out (and you just sit there looking a fool)?? Well, PPQ is like that. They know how to hit my spot.. they make my knees pop straight out!! ..every. single. time! I swear, It's really hard to do. I've tried it myself, but can't quite get it. Good thing I can go to PPQ to do it for me.

Get PHO with beef and brisket. Beef on the side. The beef is that spot on that you can have it on the side. 

Get the curry chicken pho. It's spot-abulous.

Get the charbroiled chicken/pork/beef with rice. Add an imperial roll. and don't forget to egg it. It's really spot on. I'm seeing double.

Or just get Imperial Rolls. It hits the spots.

And don't forget the single drip vietnamese iced coffee. Just don't stare at it.. The longer you stare, the slower it drips.

Hell, get everything. It's SPOTTY DOTTIE like A PARRRRRRTY in ya mouth.

PPQ=My ultimate GO TO SPOT for comfort soul food. I always leave happy and satisfied as can be. Oh so happy. 

I'm gonna go curl up into a ball and hug my blanky now just thinking about it.
author: Angela W.

description: Literally the worst pho place in San Francisco! We got seated and waited a good 15-20 mins just for someone to come up to the table. The place was not packed either. The waitress then took our order. We got part of our food and did not receive plate to eat it on for about another 10-15 mins we had to wave down the woman 4 times. She stood around staring at the customers instead of helping them. Then after the second part of the meal was on the table she then decided to bring our drinks. After we were done the meal we sat at the table for another 20 mins waiting for the check after that we just went up to her for the check because once again she was just standing and staring. Worst service out there rude waitress. Go to the Pho place across the street probably 100% better then this place.
author: Marcella F.

description:
I always order one of two things when I'm at PPQ - it's either #2, Rare Beef, Tendon, & Tripe Noodle Soup (small $5.25) aka Pho Tai Gan Sach or Five Spice Chicken Rice Plate with jasmine rice ($5.95) aka Com Ga Quay Chao.

When I'm craving pho, #2 is my staple.  I think the only difference between #1 and #2 is minus the beef balls.  And yes, I need to load all the sides into my hot soup as well...the bean sprouts, the jalapenos, the lemon juice, and the rest of the green stuff.  And I always use the red Sriracha hot sauce and the plum sauce for dipping.  (I don't squeeze it into my soup like I know others do.)

The problem with the rice dish (for me, at least) is that it comes with a HUGE helping of rice...probably the equivalent of two rice bowls.  And when I'm eating that chicken and using the dipping sauce...I can't say no to the rice.  It doesn't matter how late it is or how hungry I'm not, I just have to eat my white rice with that yummy as hell five spice chicken.  And what makes it even more special is that not all Vietnamese restaurants have a five spice chicken dish.  So, sometimes you just have to forgo the pho and get the chicken and rice!

Service is basic if anything.  Last night, my rice dish arrived a good while before my friend's pho dish arrived.  You had to wonder if they were killing the cow out back since it was taking so long.  Usually pho comes out first, but not in this case.  I was halfway done with my meal before any signs of her soup arrived.  

I like how they have the napkin dispensers out because if you're like me and when you're eating pho, you need hella napkins.  One is for the mess you're making and the second reason is for how often you need to blow your nose from the heat of the Sriracha sauce.  

I rarely ever stray from those two, and sometimes I'll even throw in a Vietnamese ice coffee to complement my meal.  But if you catch me there, odds are you'll find my face buried in a bowl of hot soup or stuffing my face with rice.  

Sidenote:  I once got a real bad case of food poisoning from here.  It was January 2003, I ordered #2 and my three other dining companions also ordered pho as well.  The only difference was that I used all those side things and no one else did.  I had a real bad case of it - the shakes, the fever, vomiting, diarrhea, etc.  It was coming out from all ends.  And yes, I do know it was from there because that was the only meal I had that day.  I conclude that there was probably some cross contamination going on.  So, you ask why do I still bother going there?  Well, percentage-wise...I've eaten there a lot and it was just that one time.
