Plus, I attribute my severe reaction to my body readjusting after spending some months abroad.  It's never happened again...from there, at least.
author: Teri C.

description:
I'm not really a fan of any pho places in the city! Pho in San Jose just shits on all these places! And I hate how they use thicker rice noodles! I like the thin ones that they usually have in San Jose haha. 

Anyways the last time I came here they didn't have veggie pho so I had to improvise. I ordered curry noodles with tofu and vegetables. It was decent not as great as home made Cambodian curry though. Yes I'm a hater ha.
author: Linda D.

description:
RUDE PEOPLE WORK HERE that's all u need to know
If you're nosy, read on.

Food here is cool. Taro root drink could've been better--they really need to dice up those taro they serve, like really. Waitresses there are bad; no smile, they just point at a vacant place for u to sit, and they mess up your order even if they had to write it down... Really now? Really? Don't think I'll be coming back.
author: ABC Z.

description: My favorite neighborhood place for garlic noodles & grilled pork, it's the best in the sunset area IMO.  The pho is always consistent and tasty as well, but I would say the garlic noodles is their specialty.  Never disappoints!
author: Wendy H.

description:
4 stars for food- deep fried imperial rolls, beef carpaccio with dipping sauce, and the curry chicken noodle soup with pho noodles are bomb! I almost always order all there and share with a friend- the waiters always do double takes and ask us if were sure we want all the items and if we know that beef carpaccio consists of rare beef...

Yes we know!

3 stars for service or lack of it I suppose (typical fast food asian spot) and difficult parking- they're situated in a busy ass neighborhood so what do you expect right ?
author: Cora M.

description:
If a restaurant is named in some Vietnamese words that I can't pronounce, I expect to have REALLY authentic Vietnamese Pho! In fact, the name was so Vietnamese, most people just nickname this place "PPQ." BUT never judge a book by its cover. I was sooooo wrong... this place's pho SUCKED! 

I ordered my favorite Vietnamese pho, called "Bun Bo Hue." And even though my best friends are Vietnamese, this is the only word I learned to say when I run to their house and their FOB Moms ask me what I want to eat. 

I'm sorry to say... PPQ's Bun Bo Hue SORELY disappoints. No flavor, all water, and disgusting meat! Their beef tasted like it was rotten in the sun for a day before they cooked it. 

I recommend getting their rice dishes...it's not as bad. It's not special or anything, but it's definitely not terrible compared to their Bon Bo Hue. 

On top of that, RUDE service. I told them to come back after awhile, because I haven't chosen what I wanted to eat yet, and I clearly saw the waitress roll her eyes and leave. Not even a "sure, take your time," or even a "sure."
author: Rose W.

description: Good Portion of Noodles, but wish there was more pork with No.15. The restaurant is surprisingly large inside and like any good Pho place, its filled with loud Asian customers. Oh and there is no such thing as small in this restaurant cause the waitress said "Medium is Small".
author: Theresa D.

description:
Pho and shrimp spring rolls make me happy.

This place has both, and they're pretty tasty and inexpensive.

Gave it an extra star because (1) I'm feeling generous and (2) even though there might be a wait on a Saturday night, it goes pretty quickly.  I wouldn't recommend coming with a big group. The best size is a group of 4 or fewer.

Easy, inexpensive, and quick food.
author: Audrey J.

description: Pho was okay, a bit bland. Really missed mint and peanuts or some nice chilli sauses to top it of with. Not just soy. I felt like they just prepared the stock? Not impressed overall. much better places a few blocks down on Irving.
author: Manon V.

description:
Fresh from out hair cuts from Cutting Corner (read my review) we wneet to get some pho to warm us from from the cold weather. 

I ordered a PPQ beef noodle soup & he got a Rare flank steak noodle soup.  Even before we got out phos we were served with disappointment - the plate of sprouts came with lemon instead of lime!   My bowl of noodles was pretty tasty with rate slices of steak, nicely cooked pieces of brisket, & not super MSG'y broth.  However, I didn't like how the tendons were cut into really small pieces.  Thy boy's pho was really disappointing since all the slices of rare steak were fully cooked.

Both of use got Vietnamese coffee (me=hot, him=iced) which tasted so strong & so bitter that we could barely swallow it.

The prices were pretty in line with other pho places in the area & the quality of the food was definitely better than the pho place across the street with the red awning.  But at the same time, there are definitely better places nearby such as Yummy Yummy (read my reviews).
author: Karen S.

description:
Definitely the BIGGEST pho portion I've ever had, but the pho broth was so uninspired and empty, I don't know that I would even consider it broth. No smell of anise or slow-cooked meats. Even after a generous air raid of sriracha and hoisin, the noodles were still starchy and tasted like they'd just been boiled in water. Nice portions of whatever meat of choice you want, but still.

Not sure I'll be back.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Generally I love this place , but I just wanted to comment on the five spice chicken rolls. Why call them chicken rolls  when they are only full of noodles and lettuce . The only chicken that was in there was as big as a bean sprout .
That's really sad . Don't order these!
author: Kat L.

description:
Been here a few times actually, but I never see to write a review about the small "holes in the walls."  These kinds of places are like your GO-TO place on a regular basis.  And PPQ on Irving is definitely one of them!!

They always have a busy dinner service and if you go late, a tendency to run out of pho!  Can you believe that?!?!  But it does happen.  So you know this place is good!  And as far as pricing....definitely decent price for Viet food.  Not the cheapest but nothing inhibiting.

I have pho.  I have had rice plate.  Imperial rolls too.  Chicken curry....a subtler version of similar Thai yellow curry.  Everything is tasty.  And if the wait isn't too long, it's definitely great!  The service is also very accomodating and fast!!! (they allowed me to charge my cell at the desk once)

I like it...and I think you'll enjoy this fast paced place too!!!
author: Cary L.

description: First time here after hearing all the raves about this place.  Ordered my usual; grilled pork chop over rice and iced Vietnamese coffee.  The portion of the plate was very generous.  The coffee was a tad pricey for one could finish it within 3 sips.  They are part of AMEX small-business offer.  Overall, pretty good.
author: Chi T.

description: I got chicken curry pho and vegetable eggrills togo for dinner and i swear it was more food than if i were to sit in the place. They did a great job and included the sprouts mint hoisin sauce and lemon in my bag. I ordered a large pho and they gave me a big box of noodles, they didnt skimp. Great containers didnt leak even with my soup accident ly lying sideways in my bag, that woukd of been a hot mess if they had janky containers. Food all good but eggrolls super oily, soaked through four napkins.
author: Karen T.

description:
This is one of my favorite pho spots to go when I'm not in the mood for my usual order of beef pho. I always order the spicy chicken curry pho. OMG! Smackin! The broth is the perfect remedy to cure anything; from having the flu to having a hangover! When most people hear curry, what automatically comes to mind is Indian curry. No, it's nowhere along those lines. Think more towards Thai curry or even some kind of heavenly Asian type curry. The curry broth is subtle. It doesn't have an over powering taste. It has that hint of curry and what almost tastes like lemongrass to me. Whatever ingredients they use, it's amazing! The spiciness has the perfect amount in it to give you that kick. Included in the soup they give you vermicelli noodles, thin pieces of chicken, potatoes, and on the side sprouts, cilantro, and more lemon to add if you'd like. 

This is the only place I'd come for this soup! Thumbs up!
author: Cassie D.

description: Great curry Pho. Popular. Waited about 30-45 minutes to be seated because so many people come here.  I would have given 4 stars if they actually packed our uneaten leftovers, but they did give us containers at least and a bag. I would have given 5 stars if the meats, etc were organic. It's a bit noisy and bustling and if you're seated by the door, you may have people waiting to be seated right behind your chair. Not a great place for a romantic meal with your love.  Great place to take kids for a hot pleasurable lunch or dinner. If you're under the weather - order the curry pho and it will knock that nasty virus right out of you!
author: Mary P.

description:
***Rating based on a pick-up order***

I decided to try the highly recommended CURRY CHICKEN PHO w/ pho noodles and it really lived up to it's hype.  The broth was SO good.  It was an even amount of Coconut to Curry and spice.  Ok, yeah, there was a lot of oil around the rim floating at the top BUT the soup was flavorful, the chicken was tender, noodles were perfect and the sprouts gave it a crunch texture that just made it the best coconut/curry dish I've ever had!!  Can't wait to go back!

(Minus 1 Star) for Customer Service.  Everything was great when I walked in and ordered my food. I got seated right away and got my drink and food pretty quick... in about 5-7 minutes.  As soon as I got my food, I stood at the cashier for awhile waiting to pay. There were 3 employees at the counter; one was talking to a friend at the counter. The other was just chillin' and the third was putting dishes away but they all made eye contact and saw my card in my hand but waited for the "friend" to leave the counter. That person didn't even eat there. I should've just walked out with my free meal.
author: Resa N.

description:
Dear PPQ, 

After not coming here for 3 years, your LARGE Pho Dac Biet, Beef Carpaccio and Chao Tom Bun Hoi hasn't failed me yet! Thanks for your delicious and generous sized portions unlike some of the other places I've Yelped recently.

In case anyone else is wondering, this is all I ever order here. ;)
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Eww I use to love this place for their curry chicken noodles but yesterday I ordered Togo home and found a short black hair ( looks like pub hair) in my soup! I called back told the owner at ppq 
What I ordered
What time I came in 
And how much it was. 

By now I already drove home. He told me to bring it back , drive all the way there and give it to him and he will make me a new one. 
I said I can't come back now, but I can come tomorrow. But he said he can only give it to me now. Wtf and he didn't even say sorry and hesitate to give me back my $. 
Until I argued with him. It's not suppose to have hair in it in the first place. He said he didn't believe me. I came back today for my refund and see all the kitchen lady with their hair tied up but falling all over the place and wiping sweat off their face with their hands. No gloves no hair net. 

the family owners have horrible customer service and cleanliness. They are the same owner at ppq dungeonous crab on clement.

I won't be supporting these two business again. They didn't even say sorry. 

You just lost 20 customers, all my friends family and boyfriend in sf won't be coming back here again!! 

What is more important ppq, giving your customer back $9 of pho that probably cost you 2$ to make or losing a customer who would come back every week. 

Go to Kevin's noodle house next door instead.
author: Quyen T.

description:
Dear cashier lady who counts dollar bills at the front desk, you are not allowed to take my pho soup bowl away just because there are three people waiting in line. Yes, she literally took my half finished bowl away because she assumed I was done eating. Even though I told her that I haven't done eating, she hesitated to let go of my bowl and put the bill on the table. As I was patient enough to wait in line for lunch, I'm sure everyone else in line can wait for their turn to be served. Anyway, I ordered medium satay beef pho noodle soup and (yes the bowl is big) however, three strings of beef stew and bundle of noodle swimming in the broth. As I was saving beef to consume at the end of the meal, that's when the front desk lady took my bowl away (just because she couldn't see any bundle of noodle swimming in my broth anymore.) Thank you for your hospitality. 

People say this place is cheap but they served you less meat. I'd say this place is overpriced, especially satay beef noodle soup.
author: Celene S.

description:
Tables are small, restroom is wet but not clean, and the food is decent. All the people start heading here because this is one of the few places that are open till 11pm on a weekday. Really getting a lot of business from the bars around. 

This was the exact reason we came here. A $6.50 average for a medium bowl of Pho.
author: M C.

description:
Pho Phu Quoc PPQ Beef Noodle House. Wow, that's quite a mouth full of words to say.

== Food ==

Beef pho with meatballs and beef. The broth tasted alright, but it wasn't really beefy. I didn't like the meatballs. They were peppery for some reason, which surprised me and threw me off. The pho came with a few pieces of beef. The long thin slices of beef were kind of chewy and they were definitely not great of quality beef. The vermicelli noodles were good like any other vermicelli noodles. 

== Service ==

Service was kind of sucked. The waitress disappeared off somewhere and it was hard to get any service. Tried to get the bill twice and each time they forgot.

== Overall ==

Lame service and decent food.
author: Steven B.

description: Disappointed to drive across town and they're out of pho 15 minutes prior to closing time?  Offered me curry plate of rice instead?!?  Umm, no thanks, you're a noodle house.  SMH!
author: John D.

description: Best place for pho in the sunset. Love there satay beef pho. I would recommend the this place to anyone looking for authentic and flavorful noodle soup
author: Benjamin W.

description: The pho is pretty good.  You just wait a few minutes and pho will be right out.  Usually I just get  the number one pho.   You can always add extra noodle to your pho if large is not enough.
author: Jen J.

description:
This place is not known for their Pho. Actually their Pho is not good at all. However their vermicelli and rice plates are excellent. Their best and most popular vermicelli would have to be their five spice chicken vermicelli. Of all the chicken vermicelli i have tried at different Vietnamese restaurants, they have the best one. It is crunchy on the outside,flavorful, while maintaining the chicken's juiciness. If you are looking for Pho just walk across the street.

What I recommend:

Five Spice Chicken Vermicelli ( can upgrade w/ fried eggrolls)
author: Andrew W.

description: While I prefer the pho across the street at Kevin's, I have to say the rice dishes here are much better! Granted they're pricier, but there is so much more flavor and the meat is better quality. After 10, they often run out of most things on their menu, so I'd recommend coming earlier. There aren't much selections in terms of pho in comparison to Kevin's but it is still solid. The portions of pho are also big.
author: Nikki R.

description: I have been coming here for years. Nice large portion sizes and fair prices. Convenient location and good take out service too, orders are usually ready in 10 min for take out.
author: Clark P.

description: Gross.  Salty and msg ridden.  What happened to this place?!  It used to be pretty decent.  Do not get the pho here unless you like salty water filled with noodles and overcooked beef.
author: Christina L.

description:
Saturday night. Hubby's been working all weekend and has been sick all week. Chicken noodle soup for asian equivalent is pho.

Came here around 9pm and the place was packed! Who knew that pho was happening on a Saturday night?

We ordered the shrimp spring rolls, pho tai (#1), the charbroiled pork with egg casserole and shredded pork, and vietnamese coffee.

I'm from L.A where Vietnamese food is ABUNDANT. PPQ is definitely o.k. but not excellent.

Shrimp spring rolls-puny pieces of shrimp
Charbroiled pork-pretty tasty
Pho-noodles are decent, a little bit too chewy; soup base was o.k. but not unforgettable
Vietnamese coffee-strong

Service-non-existent

Price: Inclusive of tax and tip: $30. For that price you just can't beat it. If we're in the mood for pho again, we would come back (although I think Kevin's right across the street is more spacious)
author: Betty C.

description: My boyfriend and I always get the beef carpaccio. It's so good. The herbs, sauce and jalapeños makes this dish so delicious, I forget that I'm eating raw meat.
author: Mary S.

description: Do yourself a favor and order the curry chicken vermicelli noodle soup.  This is one of the best soups I have EVER had.  I might move to San Francisco just so I can eat it again.  I also tasted the five spices chicken noodle soup which was very good.  I was not a fan of the satay beef noodle soup, as I found it to be a little bland.  But the person who ordered it in my group did like (not love) it.  Did I mention how good the curry chicken soup was??
author: Nina K.

description:
When it comes to Pho, I usually go across the street to Kevin's Noodle House now. The quality of the pho is better there and leaves me more satisfied, but that's not to take away anything from PPQ. This place has some good pho and definitely feels good when you're sick, like I have been this past week. While I usually prefer the Pho at Kevin's Noodle House, there is one Pho here that has me hooked, and that's the Curry Chicken Vermicilli Noodle Soup. That one is extremely delicious and I can't seem to find anything like it at other Pho places. But outside of that one Pho, the rest are just your standard Phos in terms of taste and quality. 

I will say that I did prefer the service here more than I did at Kevin's. Since it is a smaller establishment, seating is sometimes harder to get but once you are seated, they make sure to take care of you, and that is something I really appreciate.
author: Gajan K.

description: I go here a lot because it's right down the street from where I live. I'm Vietnamese American and from Orange County, so I have pretty high standards for Vietnamese food. Of the places I've tried in SF,  they're pork chops are seriously one of the best. They also have pretty good vegetarian egg rolls!
author: Jack N.

description:
It's so good here, I just had to write an update. This is now the only place I'm getting pho, and I branched out to their curry-based soups and I'm hooked again. 

Thank you PPQ for serving such yummy food!
author: Susan W.

description:
My kids are obsessed with this place.  Whenever we go out to eat, they beg for PPQ.  I personally like Kevin's across the street just as much, but once kids decide they love something there is no arguing.

The noodle soups are excellent - chicken, beef, curry, everything.  The other dishes are pretty good too - try the rice dishes and the various appetizers.  

Unfortunately PPQ noodle soup (like just about all vietnamese noodle soups) does not keep well in the fridge at home.  But that's ok, because we don't have much left in our bowls when we go there.

BTW - parking isn't the easiest thing.  Try up the numbered streets a couple blocks.
author: K C.

description: I come here for the ox tail lo mein. Cant find it as well made anywhere else in the city. The 5 spice chicken is very good and the pho is on point. Can get crowded at lunchtime.
author: Jay Rome M.

description: Great food and great price (4/5). My favorite is the curry chicken vermicelli. Service is decent (3/5). Ambiance: kind of homey feel to it (4/5)
author: Zippi B.

description:
I eat at PPQ once a week for consistently solid Vietnamese comfort food/hangover remedies.  

- The soup base is amaze-balls.  Toss in some Siracha and hoisin sauce, a few serrano chilis, a handful of bean sprouts, and tear some basil up - you're golden! The #1 PPQ Beef Noodle Soup has all the goods - I get it sans tripe.
- The Imperial rolls are perfectly fried and not at all greasy.
- If you sort of wanted Mexican but got conned into Vietnamese, get the charbroiled pork wraps and pretend you're eating an Asian burrito. 
- This is not a place for a romantic first date - it's a place to get your grub on; the ambiance is what you'd expect from a pho house in the Sunset - bright lights, kitchen-style tables/chairs and Asian-motifs.  Go there for the food.
- Consider biking or walking.  Parking is a real pain in the ass.
author: Veronica Y.

description:
I will always remember this place as where I ate my first piece of straight up RAW MEAT aka carpaccio. The idea of consuming raw beef to me is absolutely disgusting.  Well, so I ate it and it wasn't too bad but I'm still grossed out, sort of... so no, I will not eat that again.

However, I did order the five spice chicken.  It was EH!  I didn't think it was that great, maybe it was the aftermath of eating carpaccio.  Haha, I kid.
author: Tina L.

description:
I'll take the Dungeness Island locale over this one.
The pho was good. We had three types. The best was the chicken coconut.
Part of the problem is not their fault. I took some home and it was SO GROSS the next day that it turned my stomach. I shouldn't have ventured to try it though.
Also, it was a chilly night and no heat in this spot.
author: Andrew K.

description:
PPQ is definitely my go-to place for Pho.

You can always rely on them for a good bowl of soup. I used to go to Kevin's Noodle House (across the street) for fear of PPQ's long(er) lines, but after I tried their Five Spice Chicken Noodle Soup, I just couldn't get enough. Their broth is solid, reliable, and consistent. I'm never disappointed. 

I go to college across the bay, so whenever I'm home for a weekend, I HAVE TO go to PPQ. At school I even met a fellow San Franciscan with whom I struck up an entire conversation solely based on the fact that we both eat at PPQ. Hah! 

Luckily, I haven't had the experience of having to wait for very long. Nevertheless, I think if I were put in that situation, I'd still wait it out just for a bowl of their Pho -- I just don't know of many other places around the area that have good Pho like PPQ does.
author: Alyssa T.

description: The pho was good. It's the first  pho restaurant that I actually enjoyed. I tryed their coconut curry soup noodles before and that was really good too. I would definetly come back again.
author: Katrina L.

description: Poor service, and you have to ask for the tea or because of one person?...the shrimp roll was decent but the pho was bland ,very disappointed!  The most reliable thing was when you wanna pay your bill. Not coming back again .sorry!
author: Ice C.

description:
You can never go wrong with a hot bowl of pho on a cold day (or a hot day!) Delicious choices of pho with flavorful soup and plenty of meat. Large portions for a good price? That's what you should expect when you come to PPQ. 

It gets pretty crowded during normal eating times (you can expect to wait 15-30 minutes) because the restaurant is relatively small so head over early! When isn't a good time for pho??
author: Kevin H.

description:
Okay service, Pho broth felt very watered-down. PPQ is more expensive for Tai (just for thin rice noodles and steak) than across the street. 

Won't be returning, save $$ and go across the street.
author: Alissa M.

description: I came here in a lazy afternoon. It was super fast and tasty. Definitely coming back!
author: Qiushi Y.

description:
Not too crazy about their pho but what keeps me coming back (other than my mom wanting to come here lol) has to be their veggie summer rolls. You HAVE to get this! I can't describe how good it is, it's just ... really good.  Their soy vinaigrette + the veggie summer rolls = ____.  You can fill that out when you try it.  The rolls are slightly different from a spring roll because it has sauteed vegetables inside.

Since we're here, we might as well just order something, right?  So I normally get their charbroiled beef vermicelli which is pretty good with nice amount.  I've also had their rice plates but there wasn't a lot of meat so that's too bad. 

Overall, 3.5 stars.
author: Deborah W.

description:
I've been eating here for the past 4 years and love their curry noodle soup. I always order the plain rare beef on the side pho and add curry as the soup base. Although, i love their soup, I must say this place has gone down hill. Over the years they have increased the prices but quality and quantity have decreased! 

Just came here last night and found out they increased prices again and their Medium Pho only has a few bites of noodles but is now almost $8 and to add the curry soup is another $1. We also ordered the rice plate with the egg meatloaf and grilled pork, which only had about 5 sad thin pieces of pork for $9! You may as well go to LOI's a few blocks down for their delicious grilled pork rice plate but order to go, you'll thank me later!

I might just have to find another place to get my curry noodle soup fix! bye bye PPQ.
author: Mich L.

description:
I've been eating here a lot lately. I eat here with a huge group of friends, with my beau and by myself, too. There's so much good food around me and yet I choose you, PPQ...I. choose. you.  

Oh brother, I feel like I'm writing a love letter.

It's all about:
* dac biet pho. rare beef on the side. extra limes please~~
* Curry Chicken vermicelli or whatever it is. 

After coming here so many times, I come during a time when they run out of beef stock. I cry a little and order chicken stock with my dác biet pho and thankfully, it's good. It's more than good. I would order pho ga here. Maybe five spice chicken pho. Then I go into a debate in my head about whether or not good pho is like good design. 

Yeah! The parking turnover rate is way higher than that at Perilla which is why I despair whenever I want garlic noodles and five spiced chicken. There's no parking around Perilla and PPQ does not sell garlic noodles. Dammit. 

I normally review nonchalantly but PPQ has made me really happy these few months.
author: Margaret S.

description:
LOVE the chicken curry pho!! I always ask for it with pho noodles, it's kinda spicy but it's so good that you won't want to put down your chopsticks and spoon. I always crave it on a rainy day. If you don't like noodles, the chicken curry over rice is good too! Other things that are delicious and worth trying: imperial rolls, five spice chicken, and garlic noodles!

It can be busy here and will take longer if you come in a big group since they have all small tables, they would have to move tables together for big groups.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Been coming here since I was in high school so nostalgia befalls me for 3 stars.  It's more of a 2.5 for me.  I was also here last week when I had no other option later in the evening.

I'm pretty sure there are a bunch of PHO'real jokes out there already so I'll skip that however tempting it might be. Props to Ringo M. newly Elite yelper for the Fergie reference calling it PHOgalicious. I see you. 

Let's start off on a good note and to the point (PHO jokes aside) with what you should order because I wouldn't come here if I didn't have to.

Go for the curry chicken noodle.  If you are anything like me and love some fresh aroma and flavor added ask for extra onions and cilantro to brighten up that light tasty curry. The curry isn't strong and pungent like that of an Indian style of curry and not super sweet like that of a Thai curry.  It's more in the middle on both ends of smell and taste.  The pleasant and subtle sweetness of the curry soup is thanks to the coconut milk they put in there.   There's a much better spot for this on Noriega but over here this is on the top of my list.

The five spice chicken is alright here. They always use a marinated dark meat so it always comes out juicy and tender.

You can't go wrong with the appetizers like the fresh spring rolls and egg rolls.  Any restaurant that can manage to screw this one up is a failure.

The 3 stars for this review is because I personally don't like their pho broth as much as other pho spots. Beef soup of the pho is the star of the show here and yet it falls short.  I ordered the Pho Dac Biet aka Combination Beef Noodle Soup.  A little more on the bland side with not much going on.  What I mean is that you can taste a soup that has been cooking for hours on end creating depth of flavor in the soup base from its ingredients. Then there are some that just seem like it has been cooking for the minimal amount of time needed to get it boiling lacking depth, and rather monotonous to the taste.  Keep in mind that although I speak in terms of depth, most restaurants would load up the MSG so it's hard to say what they do here.  I love a good soup without the MSG if possible. Nonetheless there's gotta be a great base before all else. Some of my friends like their soup so I'm sure it is a preference thing.  For me I want some love in my soup.  Whoever it is behind that range stove should be making love to my soup for hours before it even gets to me.  No love here.

Bring floss if you are going for the ox tail.  A nice tender ox tail needs to be  braised properly also with a little bit of love.  No love here either.  The ox tail is rather tough, fibrous, and surely lacking flavor.  If you happen to try it out anyway and didn't bring floss, you're in luck... they have plenty of toothpicks. Take full advantage of those.

2 stars for their service.  A little slow side most often times.  We could be sitting there for awhile and still no one comes to take our order just like last week.  There's also this one girl that always has this funny attitude.  It's hard to ask her anything because she expects us to know every detail on the menu as a customer.  She's been there working there forever so I had a few instances of that.

I'd very much rather head 6 blocks down to Yummy Yummy for better service, variety, and depth of flavors or to Quan Ngon on Irving for better soup bases.
author: Colin M.

description:
Honestly, if this is the last Vietnamese restaurant around, I may want to retry this place.  I am very disappointed with their food and services.  They suck like vampire sucks blood.  And yet there is a whole mess of people who actually like this place.  

Their pho and rice entrees are ok.  I must say that their portions give them an edge over other Vietnamese restaurants. But what is so good about having a huge bowl of pho if the pho is bland and tasteless? They probably put so much msg to give the soup some flavor.  Again, I always say less is more.

 Like I say, restaurant of this type don't have good customer service or if any for that matter. So don't expect it, you ain't going to get it.
author: Angela L.

description:
As far as the overall quality of food is concerned, I'd rate Pho Phu Quoc between 3 and 4 stars.  The imperial rolls and charbroiled beef wraps is what kept me coming back to this place for over a decade.  The level of service is where they lost me as a long-time customer.  There are two separate situations that motivated me to try out new restaurants.

The first instance was where I ordered the Ox Tail "with" potatoes and carrots in a savory sauce.  The savory sauce was there, ox tails, but no potatoes.  When I received the dish, I really didn't eat much of it.  I explained the situation to the waiting staff, and showed the description of the entry on the menu.  "I ordered the Ox Tail, and as you can see here your menu says "with potatoes".  However there are no potatoes?"

The response from the waitress was a blank stare with really no explanation for the missing ingredient.  Considering I ate very little of the dish I was expecting at least some sort of concession to be made.  Nothing was offered.  After some insistence and pressure on my end, they finally agreed to remove the entrée from the bill.

The second instance of poor service was when I ordered two items for pick up.  After driving across town to pick up the order, it appeared nothing had been processed.  I indicated I had spoken with a man over the phone who according to the lady at the register had never received my order.  They offered to take the order right then and there while again not offering any sort of concession for the miscommunication.  I declined the order and instead went to the restaurant across the street. 

I understand that mistakes can happen, but the response should never be a blank stare, especially in the restaurant business.  I've decided to find another restaurant for my occasional imperial roll craving.  Perhaps it's a language barrier.  Either way, I feel the level of service at this establishment needs major improvement.  If both situations were handled with a sense of courtesy and respect, I'd likely still be ordering meals here.
author: Frank T.

description: 5 SPICE Chicken there is exceptional. I like the spicy noodle soup but they do not include pork blood or pork feet like typical spicy pho does. This may meet most population's needs better.
author: April E.

description:
One of our favorite pho places.  Highlights include the beef pho; the five spiced chicken; the imperial rolls, and the cold vermicelli noodle salad.

Tonight I had the grilled pork vermicelli noodle salad and was somewhat disappointed with the quality of the pork.  It was tough, fatty and stringy; and hardly grilled.  I've had this dish often, and this is the first time in recent memory that it was bad.  Hope it was just a off night.

I like to get the combo vermicelli salad with the imperial rolls.  You get two rolls cut into six pieces.

Many times you need to wait for a table; however, it depends on what time you get there.  Come before 7pm to avoid waiting for a table. Else, you'll probably wait on the sidewalk in the cold foggy night since the place is very narrow.

Overall, place is still 4 stars for good food and good price.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Most amazing Pho. I've been eating here for a couple years now. My fav is the curry chicken vermicelli soup. Unreal. Spicy and filling. Add in some chopped baby bok choy or Chinese broccoli, extra jalapenos and you are going on all cylinders. GOOD GLUTEN FREE OPTION since the noodles are rice.

Park east of 19th Avenue for easy parking. You can call in and do pick up if you are in a hurry or they are busy.  

The staff are friendly, the place is clean and gets high marks from the city on cleanliness.
author: F M.

description: I love this place. I come here about twice a week. The food is amazing, and so is the service. Never a bad experience.
author: Kim B.

description:
This place is maybe a 4 star on it's best day, but a few things keep it at a 3.
I'm not saying Chinese people can't make good pho, but the waitress and cook who came out of the kitchen were all Chinese, so I'm a little hesitant already.
I found a huge hair in my vermicelli, I know it can happen and I know it's probably pretty common in Asian restaurants so I removed the hair and ate it anyways.
Lastly, it's cash only, I hate places that are cash only, who has room to carry cash anymore.

Food was good, but nothing significantly better than most other Vietnamese places in SF.
author: Binh D.

description:
I don't come here for pho (I usually just go to Pho Hoa Hiep aka Kevin's Noodle house -- I agree with what Shirley W. says in her comparison to the two places). HOWEVER, this place is known for their Curry Chicken Vermicelli Noodle Soup (Medium = 6.75 Large = 8.00) and the Five Spice Chicken. I haven't found another place that made Curry Chicken noodle soup as good as this place. 

Don't come here for the regular pho, you will be disappointed, but do come here to try a hardy rich bowl of curry noodle soup. Be prepared to see tons of oil, if you are afraid of that... this dish is not for you.
author: Erica T.

description:
Good (not great) but my five spice chicken had hairs on it still..

So.. I would rather go to Cafe Bunn Mi or Perilla for my five spice chicken..
author: Lily S.

description: I've come here twice and the first time I got tomato crab pho which wasn't too good because I am pretty sure the crab meat was from a can. Did not like it. The second time I had the five spice which was okay, but I don't think the noodles here are fresh at all. Also both times they kept the change when I went there which I was not okay with because I would rather willingly give change then have them take it from me.
author: Kaitlin V.

description: I've been here once or twice. On both occasions the customer service was terrible! Pho is good tho. I personally,  like when I'm welcomed and feel respected... The waitress gave me an attitude when I asked questions about the different dishes...
author: D G.

description:
Cantonese speakers call this place by its Chinese name Fu Gwok Ngau Yok Fun.

It is close enough to its Vietnamese sounding name Phu Quoc Pho. Something semi meaningful like "rich nation". Hey aren't we all $triving for riche$!

And yet it is so ea$y to fall into the high school traps to make it sound like this restaurant is cursing or swearing about invading your mother's privates.  

Opened since 1995....doesn't seem like a long time, but this place has always hit the spot. Affordable, fairly consistent, and efficient to an extent. Not the best, but at least we know what to expect. And it is not uncommon to find hoard$ of Cantonese speaking locals...after all they are right in the Sunset, with mostly Asian Chinese businesses and clientele. Somehow this place jives right with them, kind of like your favorite haunt that hipsters, foodie wannabes, and many others hate because of other criteria, but somehow memories, sentiments, that one particular decent dish that appeals to you, and things misunderstood by others except you, make you enjoy this spot.

Sure it is not San Jose, Orange County/Westminster Vietnamese. And you can order in Cantonese without getting WTF looks. Perhaps the Vietnamese food nerds and pho snobs prefer 100% Vietnamese stuff (or fusion overpriced crap) and don't like Vietnamese Chinese approaches even if average?

There's another pho place across right the street. It can get scary in the evenings around here because some mofos a few years back decided to bust a few caps or pull out some blades one night and serious chit (and bodies) went down.

It was a toss between King of Won Ton noodle just to have their bandaged color fresh egg but eggless flavored bamboo pole noodles (not for the broth or wontons)....or revisit a familiar stomping ground.

The beck and call (more like "buck buck buck buck buck!") of PPQ's five spice chicken, likened to a military call for gastro duty, could not be ignored.

The plate seemed a bit bigger than last. A slight dripping of grease from the good ol' chicken thigh fat....crispy skin and excellent grill heat with the outsides a bit dry, but oh so juicy moist on the inside. Not a fancy prep by any means, but somehow I have not found a better rendition. The bowl of pho in soup as starch? A mere distraction. Sure it is not fantastic, but it helps a little bit.

The cafe sua da? Tasted bitter strong in the beginning on the tongue, but afterwards did not have that powerful feeling once it went down the tubes. Luckily, did not keep me awake at night.

Waitstaff don't smile much here....maybe my cheapster brethern and sistaz are still outrageously tipping 10% Sunset Chinese style.
author: Ken K.

description:
My last visit here.. was okay. I've been eating here forever, but that last visit just didn't cut it for me..

I ordered pho with rare steak flank, tripe, and tendon. Can I ask where my meat was!? The noodles were still in a tight square--fine. That's fine with me. But the meat.. MAN where did it all go!? I got like two pieces of steak, two pieces of tripe, and like.. one piece of tendon. WTF!? And wait I'm paying $7? Good grief. Even SD has better pho! This can't be the end of good pho in SF.. This just CAN'T.

Quality wise--acceptable. OKOK, I guess it should be quality over quantity. But c'mon, we're talking about PHO here, guys. REALLY, now??

I'm gonna order the curry chicken next time. My friend got it and it was dee-lish.
author: Leslie C.

description:
The food at PPQ is as great as Thang Long and Crustaceans... BUT CHEAPER!!! For $54.95, you can get a dinner special for 2 people of imperial rolls, chinese chicken salad, garlic noodles, crab, and fried banana with ice cream. Talk about an easy no fuss deal that doesn't compromise taste or quality.

First up are the imperial rolls and chinese chicken salad. The rolls are thick, hearty, crispy, and ready to be dipped in their special sauce. (There is Hoison sauce & Sirachi available as well.) The salad blends well with cabbage, tender slices of chicken, nuts, and light (definitely NOT overpowering) dressing.

Next up are the bowl of garlic noodles and your choice of Roasted Crab or Peppercorn Crab. The Peppercorn is my FAVORITE of the two. It comes out deep fried, seasoned perfectly with garlic, onions, salt & pepper.  The crab is awesome and meaty. (Be sure to ask for a side of vinegar.) The garlic noodles are a PERFECT complement to the crab. They are not full of grease, like from other places, and for extra crunch & seasoning I top them with the baked garlic and onions from the crab entree. Mental note: Don't forget to wear your bib!! Cracking crabs get messy!

Lastly, the fried banana and 2 scoops of coconut and mango ice cream. The sweet banana is deep fried with a light syrup base, and paired with both flavored ice creams. Simple, but a pleasurable to the palate type of dessert.

I tend to come during lunch or early dinner because it gets pretty packed at nights. The service is good, but parking isn't good.

Bottom line: I absolutely loooooove PPQ!!! :)
author: Joy A.

description: Curry Chicken is amazing!!  Come here weekly.  The service is sort of slow, and one waitress in particular doesn't seem to pleased to be working there, but she's always there.  :)  totally worth it.
author: Adam M.

description:
No frills good food: all you need to know is that the curry chicken soup is outstanding.  It's spicy and slightly sweet, creamy, filled with big chunks of chicken and a hefty helping of vermicelli.  I've never been able to finish the medium sized bowl, so at $6.75, it's a bargain.

The other pho I have tried was also good (crab, beef satay), but the curry chicken is so good that there really isn't any point in trying anything else.  

The service is always prompt and friendly, even when it's crowded.  Definitely a favorite neighborhood spot for the +1 and I.  Hey, and did I mention the curry chicken soup?
author: Jennie K.

description:
PPQ was delicious! I had the basic rare steak pho noodles and I loved it! It was flavorful and extremely filling! I tried the 5 spice chicken pho as well and it was amazing! You get complementary Jasmine tea with your meal and the service is really quick! 
One downside is that they don't really like to split checks, so try and bring cash that you can just put together to pay.
author: Erin R.

description:
Pho Phu Quoc is a decent, typical, run of the mill Vietnamese spot in the outer sunset.  Food is decent and cheap, as with most other Pho places in the area, nothing particularly stands out.  Service is lacking, as is par with most other Vietnamese restaurants in the city. 

I appreciate that they'll serve spring rolls with shrimp only and no pork.  That's definitely a plus.  Whenever I come here I stick with my usual Shrimp Bun.  Carrots and sprouts and peanuts are all relatively fresh and give my noodles a nice crunch.

Papaya salad is also decent and a good sized portion; great if you want a light dinner.

I'll continue to frequent this place as it is convenient, cheap, and tastes good.  I can't recommend it over other Vietnamese restaurants in SF though.
author: Timothy C.

description:
Uhhh... I'm sitting here at PPQ right now, was eating my pho with (burnt) five spiced chicken until my lips started breaking out in hives!!!

This place is DIRTY. Please don't come.


But if you decide to ignore me, id get the chicken pho. It's alright. Five-spiced chicken isn't really that good, it's actually kinda bad. Le Soleil's five-spiced chicken is much, much better.
author: Bianca W.

description:
[M]ona: 4 Stars
[W]ayne: 4 Stars
Average: 4 Stars

+ Open Late
+ Clean

- Cash Only 

[W] This is definitely a great alternative from your stereotypical pho restaurant. I ordered a Pork chop with egg over rice plate and added on some salty egg cake that was suppppper good! Mona had a Five-Spice chicken with pho and an egg yolk soda. Only thing that they didn't get more stars was because they forgot all about my Egg Rolls until the end when I had to remind the waiter. 

Other than that, I felt really comfortable eating at this place because it looks like more of a cleaner upscale-ish Vietnamese restaurant as opposed to a typical one with the restaurant momma/poppa yelling at you to sit down. (You know what I'm talking about). The food was very good. The 5 spiced chicken that Mona had wasn't salty at all like how some other places make it, but it was actually juicy and tender. 

[M] I really loved the pho here. Normally I would only drink the soup and skip the noodles but this time I finished the whole thing. I've had pho that are hard and clumpy, and ones that are soggy like they've been sitting in the soup for too long. PPQ makes it perfectly. Not undercooked, not overcooked. The 5 spiced chicken was crispy on the outside, and tender on the inside. I would definitely order this again.

[W] Don't forget that this place is CASH ONLY so if you forget you money, don't forget to bring your yellow Rubbermaid gloves because you're in for some dish washing haha jk.
author: Mona C.

description:
Let me start off by saying that I do not every find myself craving a bowl of Pho. I'm the type of person that so happens to be invited out to eat pho and I agree. My friend found this place and convinced me to go - I will definitely come back. The wait wasn't too long, but it was a Monday night so I'm not sure that's an accurate gage. We both came here to try this chicken curry pho that we read about. I wasn't too sure how the flavors would blend, but I must say I was pleasantly surprised. I really enjoyed the pho and I find myself craving it again already and it hasn't been long. My only complaint is that this place, like many noodle houses, charges more for what they call a "large" but my friend got the regular size and I honestly struggled to find the difference between the two. The value is what lead me to leave four stars as opposed to five just because I feel like it was an optical illusion with a differently shaped bowl. 

Nevertheless, I recommend trying this place.
author: Tyler V.

description:
The 5 Spice Chicken is DELICIOUS!

The only thing is the service tends to be a little slow...
author: Michelle L.

description: Absolutely love their Beef Pho.  I don't know what they do to their noodles but it's always slightly al dente and that's how I like it.  Also when I'm done I'm not dying of thirst.  Another fav is cold noodles with egg rolls and pork.  Super Yum!
author: hannah t.

description: Papaya salad with 5 spice chicken: 5 stars. Everything else including pho and spring rolls 2 stars. The spring rolls were really bland and hard. Pho didn't have much flavor either. If I do come back here, it'll just be for the 5 spice chicken dishes.
author: Tanya Y.

description: The spring rolls are wrapped tightly with a thin wrapper.  I hate when I get to the end of the roll & there is a mouthful of wrapper.  Lots of great ingredients & none of the filler. Bun was awesome, the noodles were elastic, chicken was crisp & fragrant.
author: Cynthia C.

description: Love their 5 spice chicken and fried veggie roll. Grill beef over rice and plenty of flavor. This place does get crowded during dinner time and towards closing so give yourself extra time.
author: dave w.

description:
Highly recommend  Five Spices Chicken Vermicelli (Bun Ga Quay Chao). When I want to eat something light I think of PPQ. The Vermicelli topped with big chunks of chicken marinated in the five spices really adds flavor to this dish.

 I also love the spring rolls they have there which is stuffed with taro too! so yummy! This is by far the best Vietnamese food I've ever had, portions are big, prices are reasonable and they also remodeled the place a bit so it's much more comfortable to dine in.
author: Elsa Y.

description:
very good chicken pho with flat noodles. awesome beef pho. very good cha gio (vietnamese spring rolls) very good bun (cold noodle salad) incredible curry chicken pho with egg noodles and the beef stew noodles and satay beef noodles are fantastic. 
outside of the t-loin, this is really the best spot for vietnamese pho is SF. consistently good, and much cleaner than the pho restaurant across the street. this is a no-brainer.
author: Jeff W.

description: Great food and I really like that you can add flavors to your broth whatever pho you choose, otherwise just a straight forward pho resturant.
author: Matt B.

description: Very popular spot for Pho in the "real Chinatown" Sunset district, but a bit lacking in the noodle and broth departments, IMHO. The portions are large and fairly well done, but may not be worth the long wait-times. They proudly advertise their exclusive use of certified Angus beef, but I can't tell the difference to be honest, and it does jack up the price a tiny bit, as other Yelpers have observed.
author: Edwin C.

description:
Pho's good

GET THE VIETNAMESE CARPACCIO!!! MUST HAVE!!!

Great Hangover food!!!
author: Jonathan C.

description: The food here is not that bad and been coming here for years. Can't say much about the woman/ owner at the cashier. She alway look like she is piss off at the world. The end
author: Tommy P.

description:
The Pho was good, but i've had much better at Turtle Tower. I've had a few dishes; the rolls were yummy, but we had to ask for lettuce (3x) which should be standard with this dish. The Beef with vermicelli was ok, nothing to write home about and the service was almost questionable (even thought he gal i was with was Vietnamese. 

The saving grace has always been the Chicken curry Pho. Honestly one of the best I've had anywhere. Doesn't give it 5 stars, but  i would go back for this dish anytime.
author: Adam X.

description: The chicken curry and five spice chicken are must-haves here. We also ordered imperial rolls which were good. Service is quick and food comes out nice and hot.
author: Bo L.

description: Wide selection of dishes, nice staff, and convenient location. Had five spice chicken and fried calamari, my bf had one of their gigantic beef noodle soup. Everything was fresh and delicious, I'm excited to come back and try other dishes on their menu. Great place!!!
author: Francesca L.

description:
Their pho is ok. Lacked flavors and not enough meat. 

My friend got the beef ball pho and it came with 3 balls....

Come on now...
author: Alice Z.

description: Yes! Been coming here for 20 yrs. Still consistent in quality and flavor. 5 spice chicken rules
author: Rater 1.

description:
The first time I came here, I was seriously unimpressed. I judge a bowl of pho by the quality and tenderness of the beef, and the first time I came I was not blown away. In fact, I remember it being chewy, mealy, and overdone.

A friend of mine recently recommended I try their Chicken Curry Pho and substitute the chicken for rare steak. People, this is seriously as good as it gets. It's getting to the point where I crave this curry pho just as often as I crave regular pho. The beef that they put on the curry pho is sliced so thinly, and comes in the bowl rare (which is a must have in my book). Tip for the curry though: Stir the beef around when the curry comes hot, as the curry broth does not cook the beef quite as fast as regular pho so make sure you get it all cooked in the beginning.

Another tip: You can get the curry with either pho noodles or vermicelli. I prefer the vermicelli. One time they didn't ask me and just gave me pho and it was a bit of a disappointment.

I've had the Viet coffee before too which is also excellent! Highly recommend the chicken curry vermicelli!!!!!! (Because seriously that's all I get here)
author: Eliza F.

description: All I can say is FIVE SPICE CHICKEN! Service can be a bit crappy sometimes but I keep coming back for the chicken.
author: Omar M.

description:
This is definitely my go to Pho restaurant in SF! It has never failed me, and always satisfies my random cravings for Vietnamese food! 

PPQ has delicious food at great prices that don't break the bank. 

My faves: 
- Bun Bo Hue - Spicy beef soup with rice noodles
- Combo Beef Pho - has rare beef slices, flank, brisket, trip, tendon, and beef balls
- Five Spice Chicken
- BBQ Pork Rice Plate
- BBQ Pork Vermicelli with Imperial Rolls
- Red Bean Drink
author: Sharon L.

description:
This is my favorite pho restaurant. I've tried many different places but this one wins because of the quality of beef they have and the taste of their broth.  I love, love, love their beef capriccio, many people might not be able to stomach raw beef, but their beef is so tender and it doesn't give you any type of chewing textures, it melts in your mouth. 
Overall, if you want some good quality pho with quality beef, this is the place to go. The service there is not always great, but the food is good enough where it will not hinder my meal experience.
author: Diana L.

description:
Been going to PPQ for more than a decade. At this point I prefer Kevin's across the street for their pho, I prefer the broth over there, but I prefer PPQ for their bun and imperial rolls. I recently went back to PPQ because I was in the mood for the spicy Hue style noodle soup and Kevin's doesn't have this variety. Soup was delicious, service was great as always.

PPQ tends to be a bit more crowded and has a smaller dining room than Kevin's but the percentage of Vietnamese customers is consistently higher at Kevin's where the broth is just more concentrated tasting.
author: Sam P.

description:
Its been a while since I've gone to PPQ...so one day we decided it would be best to come here for lunch..

Ordered the beef carpaccio, now I've never ordered this dish before and boy was I surprised. This was delicious! the mix of flavors and the fried garlic slices. And the way they presented this, usually I see this dish set up like shabu meat, in slices and lined up. Instead they mix it up like a raw beef stirfry. I will definitely order this again..

After that I ordered the bun rieu...this wasnt anything special. It was good none the less but it didnt stand out. The soup just seemed a little too light, not enough flavor. 

Portions are good, I stuck with a medium on the bun rieu which was more than enough. Service is minimal in some sense where its just to the extent of them getting your order and check. Perfect for this kind of restaurant.
author: phillip w.

description: I've been eating here for 17 years. Get the spicy satay beef noodle soup, you can sub that soup for any of the pho noodle soups. 5 spice chicken, imperial rolls are both delicious, but really get the spicy satay beef noodle soup. Trust me.
author: Wei Cheng C.

description: Located right near 19th & Irving, this place has great pho with Angus beef.  I like the beef carpaccio, grilled beef, Thai iced tea, pho with rare beef & tendon (squeeze some lime & the soup is perfect), and most everything my wife orders.  It's cheap, tasty and reliable!  Great place when we're on the go in SF.
author: Ned L.

description:
My all time favorite Pho restaurant in SF and I've tried a few. 
My new favorite is the curry chicken, but I substitue rare beef. The soup is a lower tempurature that the pho broth, so the beef cooks slower. aka more tender. Yum. Wash down the spicy soup with a cold vietnamese iced coffee. The perfect meal.
author: Beatweeze C.

description:
I hesitate to rate a place so poorly but PPQ actually deserves zero stars.  My boyfriend and I decided to try it last Sunday night--what a mistake.  We were sat and given menus and after five minutes a waitress, who seemed friendly enough, came over and asked us what we wanted.  I was hemming and hawing a lot, also my boyfriend had never had pho before so we told her we needed a bit longer.  Probably 20 minutes later, another waiter finally came over and very rudely took our order.  I was planning on ordering a drink but was so taken aback by his rudeness/apparent disdain for us (gave him the benefit of the doubt and figured maybe he was just busy) and decided to wait to order it when he brought the food.  

I got asparagus and crab soup and a tofu salad and my boyfriend ordered the ox tail pho.  He basically just dropped all of the items on the table and ran away.  My salad was okay--the tofu was tasted fake and overly fried but the dressing was pretty good.  The soup, however, looked like chopped up asparagus thrown into dish water.  It tasted bland and flavorless with no discernable sign of crab (I wouldn't mind if they scrimped on the crab but it was $8).  My boyfriend's dish looked like ramen cooked in beef broth.  The ox tail was so tough and undercooked that he couldn't even eat it--LITERALLY because neither of the waiters came back over to us to ask how things were and didn't give us silverware or even water.  There was no way this meat was coming off the bone without a heavy duty knife.  We were pretty angry at this point because plenty of other tables had water and silverware, and if the staff was so busy, they wouldn't all be staring into space or looking at their smart phones near the counter.  

tl;dr: Horrible service, incredibly rude staff, food is terrible, do not eat here.
author: Kate R.

description: Their food is ok... but the service ...sign. I order a five spice chicken noddle but the noddle came ten-fifteen  minutes before the chicken came. My gf even finish eating before. I would say not ordering the chicken during busy hour
author: Stanley T.

description:
Actually stumbled upon this place on accident. Definitely meant to go to the pho spot across the street but got the names confused... whoops! Plus my hungry ass was starving for some pho so I definitely didn't pay attention the name, hehehe. #fatgirlproblems

Anyways, this place was still good! Both my friend and I ordered the #3 which was the pho with brisket, tendon & tripe and HOLY CRAP, the speed. I swear we had JUST ordered our meals and they came out under 5 minutes. BOMB. So down for a place with super fast service. 

Scarfed it down and it was the perfect thing on a cold summer night in SF. Why must you be so cold, SF? I guess I can't complain if it makes pho taste this good.
author: Steph W.

description: Out of all the pho places I have been to, this one is my #1 go-to. The broth is so well-done and flavorful. I usually get the seafood pho or the chicken pho. When I was a kid, I was never a big fan of #1 and #2 with all the beef balls, briskets, and tripe. But I ordered this dish the other day, and it was delicious! The beef was tender and well-cooked in the hot broth. Every bite was flavorful and washed down with some barley tea. This is all-around the best pho place on Irving Street!
author: Joanne K.

description:
So since the boy and I are apparently both getting sick, we decided we needed something soupy to soothe our sore throats and coughs. We decided since it's sorta between our two places that we would go on 19th. Theres two pho places across the street from each other and we already tried the other one.

I ordered the #1 medium sized and it was a nice sized bowl, decently priced at 7 dollars and I feel better after eating it. Add a little bit of sriracha and hoisin sauce and it is really flavorful.

having pho while sick is a great idea.
author: Nina Y.

description: Meat portion gets smaller every time I come here and the soup base is getting blander and they only give 1 meatball?! Are you serious?! Really not impressed with the quality of service as always... We sat there for like 15 minutes looking for someone to take our order. Lady at the register sees us like 4x and doesn't do shit. Wtf mah bad princess. She only reacts to money. #rude
author: Christal T.

description:
One of the reasons why this place lacks a lot of positive reviews is because the Pho needs more flavoring and because Kevin's noodle house is across the street. Price is similar so it's no surprise that most prefer to walk across the street. 

On the flip side, I have heard that that their rice dishes are much better than their Pho and much better than their primary competitor which I have absolutely no problems believing. (Their rice places at Kevin's taste quite odd to me.)

My advise: eat rice plates here. If you like pho that is less seasoned, more plain, order otherwise. 

Last note, I worry about the cleanliness here sometimes.
author: Sue T.

description:
I arrived just before 9pm on a Friday night with a friend. The place was packed. We put our name on their waiting list and were seated at a table against the wall not three minutes later. While standing to wait for our table, I saw a couple tables that had big bowls of what looked like spicy soup, not the typical pho I've had elsewhere, and I wanted to try it. The menu didn't have pictures, though, so I had to guess (or ask the waitress, but that's less exciting).

I guessed right by ordering the Curry Chicken Vermicelli Noodle Soup. It was delicious, and the medium size was plenty for me (I was solidly hungry; 9/10 on the hunger scale). My friend got the Veggie Combo Noodle Soup, large size, and it was too much for him (he said he was quite hungry, too, so order wisely).

We originally came here on his recommendation, but the Veggie Combo soup wasn't up to par. The broth tasted a little bland, and broccoli pieces were HUGE, as were the tofu chunks. Why not chop them into something closer to bite-size if the only utensils your customers have are spoons and chopsticks? The chunks of chicken in my curry soup were also on the large side, but they fit in my spoon and were quite tasty. My soup was spicier than I expected but still in the "good spicy" range.

Our soups were served with the typical plate of bean sprouts and basil. Hiding beneath them were a couple lemon wedges and two or three slices of (I think) jalapeno pepper. The sprouts and basil seemed fresh, and they complemented my curry soup well.

The prices and service were both quite fine. Tea was served quickly, and one pot lasted us almost the entire meal. I asked for water, which was brought over swiftly as well. I'll likely go here again. Yum.
author: Kiki J.

description: This is a Ph place but they can't understand tái sách bò viên. And if you like this place so much bring a fly swapper in case you need it.
author: Henry T.

description:
One of two pho restaurants next to 19th Avenue, this place isn't bad at all. 

This restaurant serves your basic Vietnamese foods, from their signature pho bowls, to rice and vermicelli platters with meat, and other noodle soup options.

Other than that, the pho is pretty good. I wouldn't mind coming back here. Parking can be tricky depending on what day and time you arrive for your meal.
author: Rob L.

description:
My favourite pho stop! This restaurant is also cousins with the owner of Pho Ha Tien on Ocean, which is not so great. This place is typically open later than most pho places, which is great so I can grab teaway and ppq on a late night.

The portion sizes are perfect, the fried dishes aren't too greasy, the veggies are fresh (except the jalapenos), the noodles are never soggy, and the broth doesn't taste like it's been loaded up with MSG.

They have all of my favourite appetizer dishes, and tasty thai-style salads, if only they had banh xeo, this place would be perfect. The imperial rolls here are the best I've ever tasted! Ultra crispy (I think they use rice paper). 

They're definitely not as cheap as Loi's, a few blocks down, but hey, you pay for what you get, the food is really THAT good. The service is just alright; most of the time the staff will avoid you or give you disapproving facial expressions (but I've learned to live with it in Asian cuisine).

Pros: The food is great, tastes fresh all day long, wide selection of the menu
Cons: A little pricey for pho, poor service
author: Jenn D.

description:
It's been a couple of years and I have learned to appreciate the intricate flavors of pho... The spices, the herbs, the tender meat, the soft noodles, the hot broth... 

I still get the Coconut Curry Pho but I was always weary of the chicken pieces that usually accompany this bowl of noodle soup. The chicken pieces are usually big, tough and dry. Whenever I got this pho, I would pick out the chicken and just eat the soup, noodles and potato... My friends thought I was crazy to waste the meat but I just didn't like it...

Until now! 

PPQ has totally upped their chicken game! The chicken is now tender, lean and small so they're easier (for me) to eat! This was the first time in my PPQ history that I ate all the meat instead of all the rest of the dish. Each piece, no matter how long it stewed in the hot bowl of broth, stayed tender all the way through my meal. It was amazing, delicious and surprising! 

We also had their spring rolls with the addition of shredded pork and though there was a charge for the addition, it was darn tasty! The shredded pork was a bit garlicky and added a delicious element to the spring rolls. 

Yay, PPQ!
author: Christine C.

description: The curry chicken soup is awesome!  I've come in 3 times for it.  Great little spot.
author: T. E.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Bun Bo Hue #0 = Not so great. Broth wasn't that thick, hearty, or spicy. The stuff was skimpy. It's owned by Chinese and in the heart of Irving, so it's no wonder. Gaddam did not make the most of Viet food in Sj when I was there 
2.) Carpaccio = Carpaccio was good though. Yum. Sesame seed.

SERVICE:
Fine for asian place.

ATMOSPHERE:
Like typical Pho restaurant.
author: Angela L.

description:
Whenever I come here, I order the five spice chicken with imperial rolls and the vermicelli noodles. I like it a lot! The five spice chicken is really good and the imperial rolls has the right crunch. I've also tried the bun rieu (crab paste noodle soup) and it's also good, but I prefer going to Loi's for bun rieu. 

The service here is decent. This place can get crowded on certain times of the day, especially during the lunch hour. Parking can also be a hassle depending on what time of the day you're coming here, but is usually ok to find parking.
author: Vivian L.

description:
I absolutely love pho, especially after a long week! Ironically I had not actually gone out to try out some of the places in the neighbourhood until this week. It took my getting sick to venture into the cold to get some of that yummy goodness. 

I asked around before going, and even Yelp'd a few places before giving PPQ a try. I ordered the medium #9, Shredded Chicken Noodle Soup (Pho Ga Xe Phay) to go.  I didn't mind the wait as I love to people watch. The restaurant seemed cozy and I am thinking of going back with some friends for a sit-down meal there and try out some of the other things they have to offer.

When I got home, I found the broth was separate from the chicken, noodles and cilantro. Smart move. There was also a bag of sprouts, lemon, jalapeno, and basil along with that really yummy spicy sauce. The broth alone is sweet and the chicken and noodles cooked perfectly.  Add in the condiments, and you have a bowl of Heaven. The spicy was perfect to help kick this cold in the butt, and because you have control of how much chicken and noodles and spice, you don't have to worry about having a ginormous bowl of spicy soup that you can't eat, if you can't handle the heat (I can!). 

The medium was perfect for 2 meals and I am so glad I finally gave PPQ a try. You can even phone ahead for pickup. It's a rather casual place, where you can bring a group of friends, and it is within walking distance (as are most places around here) from the bars or other areas of attraction. (You can walk a few more blocks up towards 22nd or so and find Bubble Tea). It's also a perfect place for tourists looking for a more off the beaten path kind of place as most touristy places are rather Americanized and pricey.
author: Erin W.

description:
Still on the lookout for amazing pho in SF.

This was pretty good though: 7/10 on the Pho scale.

The spicy chicken curry soup is pretty good (kind of like a Laksa) and packs a decent punch. 5 spice chicken was less than overwhelming.
author: Sid R.

description:
This is my favorite place for pho and their imperial rolls are the best.   I've had Imperial rolls from many other vietnamese restaurants and they always ends up being super greasy and flavorless.  Kevin's noodle house, I'm looking at you.

Anyway,  if you're ever in the city,  Ppq is the place to be for really good vietnamese food.
author: JB C.

description:
Okay, so I'm going to cheat and actually copy and paste a review I wrote for this place a while ago.  I used to write in a food blog, but then I realized that Yelp was probably a more appropriate forum for these kinds of food essays, so I'm slowly going through the process of transferring my blog posts to Yelp.  

Anyway, here we goes.  A blast from my writing past, but still relevant to the food community, I suppose:

One of my favorite joints for a simple bowl of pho or Vietnamese food in San Francisco is PPQ Restaurant on 19th Avenue and Irving in the Outer Sunset. You can always locate it as you're walking down Irving St. because it's got a cardboard cut-out of a large cow standing in front! Suh-weet! They straight up tell it like it is. I like that. Honesty.

So, this joint serves up your standard Vietnamese fare, including bowls of pho, vermicelli and rice plates, egg rolls and spring rolls, and other noodle plates. The prices are very reasonable, ranging from $5-$8 for a generous entree, and the atmosphere is casual.

It's pretty fun to go here with large groups, because it's one of those kinds of joints.  Noisy and unpretentious.  I dig. 

Recommended dishes:
+ Five-spice Chicken with imperial rolls. I've never had this, but apparently, this is one of the signature dishes at PPQ.
+ When I discover a certain food that I like at a particular restaurant, I tend to become a creature of habit and order that dish over and over again. Charbroiled pork with egg rolls and chopped peanuts on top of vermicelli with a bowl of fish sauce!  This is one of my favorite dishes at Vietnamese restaurants, and I often get it because I know it will be stellar wherever I go.  The charbroiled pork is cooked to perfection, with just the right amount of charred taste and tenderness. The egg rolls are always perfectly crispy. I've never had a bad egg roll in this dish. It's a safe and tasty choice! MMM! And at PPQ, it's #15! I recommend!
+ All their phos!  Are excellent!  I mean, they're all pretty standard, but still all excellently made!

Now, let's sing a song!
T to the
A to the
S T E Y
Food
YOU TASTEY
T to the
A to the
S T E Y
Food
YOU TASTEY

ANYWAY.

Another good thing about PPQ is that it's located on Irving Street, which many consider to be the "New Chinatown." Not nearly as crowded or historical as San Francisco's Chinatown, Irving Street is where the local Chinese-American community go to get their hair cut, to eat out and grab a cup of tapioca (naw, we don't call that stuff "boba"! that's only for the SoCal crowd), to buy their groceries. There's a good mix of cute accessory and stationary shops, grocery stores (Sunset Super on 25th and Irving), Asian and fast-food restaurants, hair and nail salons, many bakeries, and even a Bay Area/Frisco merchandise and clothing store. The local high school kids at Lincoln and Lowell High Schools also come here to hang out and eat after school too, so expect to see lots of loud crowds of happy kids.

After you fill yourself up with a hearty lunch at PPQ, you should definitely stroll down Irving and grab yourself some tapioca and walk the calories off.

Walk it off!

-Vivian C., circa 2007
author: Vivian C.

description: Pho-get about every other chicken pho in the city. The five spice chicken soup here is the bee's knees. Beef pho was also good and the imperial rolls weren't messing around either. No frills and basic service, but delicious food at a good price.
author: Dead Eye D.

description:
5 Stars for the variety of delicious Vietnamese dishes!

This is not a place where you half to be afraid of ordering anything besides beef Pho. The beef Pho is 4 Stars, only because the broth could be a bit deeper in flavor. However, they offer a wide variety of choice in not only the type of noodles available, but they have various kinds of broth (savory,curry, traditional, etc).

Everything I've had on the menu is really good and this place is packed every time I show up!

Bottom line- 5 Star Chicken Curry Pho, try the beef pho, and feel comfortable ordering ANYTHING on the menu... it will be delicious!
author: Kevin D.

description: I usually hate pho unless it's homemade but shoot... Props on the satay pho! Didn't need any hoison sauce nor sriracha. It's a bit spicy and sour I LOVE ITTT!
author: Bi L.

description: From the name (a lesser known place in Vietnam), I thought it would be more authentic and less of a commercialized pho restaurant, but nope. Definitely just a place to go when you're drunk and in a pinch when Pho Kevin across the street is closed (exact situation that drove us there). The prices aren't ridiculous, but definitely pricier than Vietnamese food should be. Both the vegetarian rice plate my friend had and the vegetarian pho I had were just basic noodles/rice with a bunch of bland tofu, baby bok choy, and broccoli dumped over it. I can't really say service was horrible because it was nonexistent; once they brought out the food, there wasn't a waiter to be found and flagged down for more tea/herbs/anything.
author: Cat N.

description:
To be able to go to this excellent place just a block from Golden Gate Park is just one of life's greatest conveniences.
 
We had the Five Spice Chicken Bun and the Green Papaya Shrimp Salad along with their Fresh Spring Roll. Service was quick, friendly and the quality and flavors were excellent. This has been my family's favorite pho joint for years and its consistency is one of its greatest strengths.
author: Glenn H.

description:
I really enjoy coming to this place especially when the weather is gloomy or rainy. 

Every time I come to this restaurant seating is never a problem and the food is always served quickly (about 7-10minutes later). The shredded chicken pho is super yummy!
author: Lorena M.

description:
Good food tasty broth, would go five but soup had less beef in it than I wanted.
Service was good I was alone and got a table right away.

Was really busy on a Sunday night does say they have good food.
author: D F.

description: I think this is the best pho is town, but I'm giving 3 stars because this place is dirty.  The wait staff should bring your food out on a tray instead of carrying your bowl across the restaurant with their thumb hanging in the soup.  It's disgusting to see the dirt under their nails!
author: E F.

description:
For years, I have ordered nothing but the curry chicken pho.  It is fantastic.  I live in Santa Cruz, but try to visit whenever I am near Golden Gate Park.  Once, I had it for lunch and then again for dinner.  Totally happy.   

I wondered why the potatoes are so amazing, so I asked: They fry the potatoes and then let them cook in the curry sauce.  A huge bowl for just $8.75.  I just read another review that suggested substituting chicken for rare beef and changing the noodles.  It's hard to imagine it better, but I might risk that next time.
author: Miguel A.

description: I tried very hard to like this place given all the rave reviews by coming here twice. First time I got pho --- lackluster and bland. Second time I got the five spice chicken everyone raved about --- the seasoning isn't bad but it's not like super amazing. In the end, if I want good pho, I'd either go to Turtle Tower & Pho 2000 in the tenderloin, and if I want good herbal roasted asian chicken, I can go to a good Thai restaurant.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
PPQ! PPQ! PPQ!

My brother is the King of Pho, and when he mashed his way to PPQ upon our return from Half Moon Bay, I knew we would be in for a treat!

... I recently dubbed Pho the Gio as my favorite Pho spot, but it's over... I am returning to PPQ today just to eat the Lemon Beef and try something else out on their menu!  

I am now officially no longer a Lemon-Beef Virgin.. I've watched my brother eat this before at  Pho Ha Tien on Ocean Avenue, but it did not look visually appealing and the beef just tasted "gamey" to me... He's been raving about this for some time now, and I knew that if he drove us all the way to SF just to eat  when we could have easily hit up Gellert Square for lunch, my cousins Sheila and JR and I would be in for a treat.

As soon as we entered the restaurant my eyes began to wander at everyone else's food.  I could already see that the portions were huge and the quality of the food was to my standards!  I was equally shocked that my brother did not order Pho and instead selected the Curry Chicken Soup for JR and himself.  When someone strays from a norm, you know whatever they chose is going to be good! Sheila and I opted for noodle dishes and both ordered sides of chicken soup!

We did not wait too long for our food, and upon serving us the Lemon Beef, my excitement escalated to PURE JOY!  The color of the beef was rich and the presentation with the crispy fried garlic and peanuts made the whole dish more appealing to the eye!  Jason mixed in the house special sauce and 2 slices of Lemon, gave it a stir, and within minutes I was already planning the next time I would be eating this dish and all the people I wanted to enjoy it with!

My BBQ Pork over Vermicelli was also outstanding!  There was also something about the rolls and the crispiness of the shell that I really loved.  I also tasted Jason's Curry Chicken Soup order which was also delicious.. it had the perfect balance of coconut and curry!

I kept thanking my brother all day for taking us there... I could see myself ordering the Lemon Beef with a side of noodles the next time I go... So simple and so good!

Does anyone know if they fry their own garlic or can I buy that in a bag somewhere!?!?! OMG SOOO GOOD!

PPQ YOU OFFICIALLY PASSED my QUINT-ESSENTIAL PHO REQUIREMENTS!!!

Ps: the Proudly advertise that they passed their February 12, 2009 Inspections with 90 Points! Good For You guys! That's an A in my old Nursing classes! LOL
author: Chrysantha C.

description:
