I'm not big on pho, but I left lunch today pleasantly surprised with everything I tried:

Imperial rolls: what a great way to start! I felt like the food transported me to Vietnam in one bite. 

Shrimp rolls: refreshingly good. Flavor stays with you long after you finish one.

Chicken curry vermicelli noodle soup: Outstanding taste; really warms you up on a cold summer day.

Thai icea tea: Spot on.

I hope to be a repeat customer.
author: Steve S.

description:
I came here after a stressful day at work with some friends/coworkers spontaneously. At first I was looking on Yelp on my phone trying to figure out what people like here since I had no clue whatsoever on what to get.

My friend insisted that the five spice chicken here is the bomb. I gave it a try with the five spiced chicken rice plate and I have to say it was awesome! The chicken tasted really good, especially the crunchy parts even though it may be unhealthy for you, haha. 

My friend got a #1 (Pho Dac Biet) I believe, not too sure what it was. She said it wasn't that good, and she only had one beef ball in it. She wasn't as satisfied as we were.

I would definitely come back here not for pho, but for the five spiced chicken!
author: Brian T.

description:
I can't say I'm a fan... but it is better than Pho 99 which I rated 3-stars but not as good as Kevin's across the street, thus the 4-star rating. 

We use to come to this place a lot back in high school and early years of college. But since have switched to Kevin's. Many people will contest that the five spice chicken here is THE dish to order... I agree it's a must. But also try the curry chicken noodles - yellow curry soup base with a drizzle of coconut milk. Not bad...
author: Stephen Y.

description: I crave their five spice chicken pho like a chain smoker craves that first cigarette of the day.  Their imperial rolls are amazing.  Their crab noodle soup is off the hook.  My girlfriend is giving me grief for writing this review from bed on my phone but my desire for their crab asparagus soup is making me crazy and I must write about it.  Get there early.  They run out of crab daily so if your hitting this place late night plan on them being out.
author: Theron L.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!! 
Their "curry" pho is so freaking amazing. The mixture of spices, and coconut milk, and the pieces of chicken. AMAZINEBALLS in my mouth. 
I take all my friends there.
author: Gretchen B.

description: You really cant mess anything up here broth is good noodles is good everything issss good haha. Love this place cant ever get enough.
author: Alex S.

description:
The only thing I ever come here for is the Satay Beef Pho which is one of my favorite things to eat so PPQ automatically gets three stars. However, it's never really consistent as a few times I've had a bowl that wasn't very spicy or a a bowl that was overwhelmingly spicy. I've also noticed that the prices have risen over the past few years and I'm starting to think it may not be worth it anymore.

PPQ is still great if you're looking for a pho place in the Sunset though, if only for the Satay Beef Pho. The Spring Rolls are pretty good as well. 

Parking on Irving may be a bit hard to find as well, but the 28 stops just around the corner!
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
Don't do it! Please! Go across the street, please!

I was always iffy about this place. I had decent experiences and then less pleasant experiences. They have a few things going for them like the fact that they are especially cheap and that they have lots of space. 

Their service is always pretty much horrible, which, okay, what pho place has good service right? Most of the time my complaints would be limited to: "Can I get some damn water?" or "Can we get the check already?". But one of my first real turn offs was when they wheeled the trash can right by us as we were eating. Can you please take the dumpster out when customers are not around??

Unfortunately my bf came here religiously. So there would be occasions where I would reluctantly return. The final straw for me came one night through the dinner of a couple next to us. Randomly, the woman next to us started pointing at her dish and showing us. We took a look and it was a LIVE SLUG! I'm talking about at least 2 inches long, disgusting, slimy, alive. I wanted to throw up right there. They took the plate back and I'm pretty sure the couple got a free meal. Now when I've explained this story to others, I've been told that this could happen anywhere because most restaurants neglect to wash their greens before serving them. Especially lettuce that would be placed as decor to the dish. My response: if it could happen to anyone, why did it happen here. gross, gross, gross. 

Eat at your own risk, I suppose. I, on the other hand, will not.
author: Danielle G.

description:
FIVE SPICE CHICKEN - HOLLA


Came here and ordered the highly recommended five spice chicken with pho noodles on the side, or is pho noodles with the five spice chicken on the side?  Whatevs, it was hella bomb.  Fried to perfection and greasy as a mutha, just the way all yummy things should be.   I was a little worried when I ordered it that the chicken was going to be IN the broth and the whole "it's gonna get soggy" factor, but it came along side in it's own lil dish so no worries ya'll!  Def gonna re-order when I'm back again.



Had to come back for a round 2 on my review cause I just discovered an even better combination of yum. Curry chicken pho with a SIDE of five spice chicken *drools.
author: Annie C.

description: I can't believe I've not stopped here before and I'm always on Irving St. Anyways, I came here 10 mins after they opened with my mom. I got the five spice rice platter bc of yelp reviews. She got the #1 beef noodle soup which is supposed to be their specialty dish. I did notice all the dishes were a $2-$3 more expensive than the usual place but I really believe you're paying for quality. My five spice chicken was grilled perfectly and seasoned with just the right amount of spices. It wasn't burnt or to salty. I also really enjoyed the dipping sauce that came with it. I ate some of my mom's beef noodle soup and it was also very good. The beef slices were fresh. The noodles were the right amount of chewy. I did prefer the five spice chicken over the noodle soup just because I'm a rice person. This place is definitely replacing my old pho place.
author: Vivian L.

description:
A full meal for $6. 

I'm sold. 

I had the famous five spice chicken and while I almost got it on rice I decided to go with the vermicelli. It was a very generous portion and only $6. 

They had  lot of other dishes including a chicken soup that looked really tasty. 

I will be looking for excuses to be going back here. 

Decorwise - don't bring a date here unless you're trying to test whether she's down with good food that is affordable. 

I came here with our tri team and I know understand why this is one of their staple spots.
author: Carlos A.

description:
The best pho, the best char broiled pork over rice, great spring rolls (fresh and fried). I grew up on Irving just blocks away from this place. Everytime me and my family go back to visit San Francisco we HAVE to stop by here for lunch. 

Great prices and quick and friendly service. I have never seen this place empty and look forward to eating here again!
author: Nicki T.

description:
My vegetarianisms become questionably non existent whenever I enter the realm of my favorite all time soups... Pho.

Okay, I love PPQ for it's menu overall. I've picked off plates of other friends that I've brought here. I've been eating here for years and just now had the inkling to write a review. Why now? Why PPQ? I've been to the best pho places in town, and I always order the same thing. I'm so predictable. I always order the number 1. It's a repetitive yet pretentious habit.

Tonight, things changed. I ordered the number 7. What is number 7 you ask? It's the noodle soup with five spices chicken. They serve it on two separate dishes so you can decide the fate of the chicken, they leave the meat drowning to you. Well, the bean sprouts definitely took a dive with the leaves, and peppers. But the chicken had to be savored by itself.

Good service? Sure! Too bad they don't take American Express, but that's expected from most asian restaurants. Heck, if I had a restaurant I'd be cheap too. =P

But hey, where's the dessert? If you've also eaten at the other pho restaurant across the street, which will remain nameless during this review, you'd know. They have better desserts. In fact, they have one of the best avocado shakes around, as long as they're in season of course.

Oh no, I can't believe I just mentioned it without having the liberty of grasping it's ultimate (fattening) power in my hands. What now? Come on PPQ, I know you're reading this. Get it together for that final star!
author: Ryan R.

description:
I broke out after I ate here. Sure it might not have been what I ate here, but chances are, it was.

Besides, you can get the same thing (actually, it's better) right down the block at Loi's for much cheaper. The only good thing about this place is that it's opened late.
author: Sara K.

description:
its only the best spot to go when everything else is closed.  I remember liking this place when I was going to high school, but somehow between 2000 and 2010, the quality diminished or my taste buds matured. 

And as a taste bud matures, the restaurant must mature with it.  Iono if that's true or not, but still the verdict is this...  PPQ.  You've forsaken me.  You use to have the great tender broth that I grew up to love, but now you're broth is sort of stale and the noodles are too mushy.  Get off that comfort high horse and get back to working that magic behind the kitchen.  I think even the crispy calamari went away.  How am I suppose to want to come back after this?  

In any case, not my favorite, but its a staple since it opens till 11pm.  (seeee, if you were really good, you wouldn't have to open so late!)
author: Vincent K.

description: Way too expensive for a bowl of pho. Not even that tasty. Oh, and the lady that sits and count money never smiles! The hell is her problem?!
author: B L.

description: I don't like this place at all.  Sorry.  I had the ox tail and it sucked.  My daughter had the A3 and she didn't like it either.  But the service was pretty nice. I gave them an extra star for service
author: Pernell N F.

description: This place had been recommended to me by many people so I decided to check it for myself. There was a good amount of people waiting to be seated but moved quite fast. To start off we ordered the sizzling steak which was amazing. Good quality beef and the sauce was on point. Next we had the steak phu. The medium size is more than enough for two. Great food ill definitely be going back!
author: Valeria B.

description:
My "go-to" spot. 
Cheap.
Fast.
Friendly.
Good.
Low-sodium.
Replaced Turtle Tower for me. 
Period.
author: Liz C.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here after reading all the great yelp reviews. 

I must say, the pho here was not bad at all. We both ordered the same pho, I don't remember what it was called specifically, but it was suppose to be spicy. I asked if there was a non-spicy version, the waiter said no but he could make it a little milder. Well, all he did was just dilute it with water, and drowned away all the flavor :\ I wish he had just told me that he was just going to to add water, because I'd prefer the non-diluted version where all the flavor is actually there.

Other than that, the pho is pretty good. I wouldn't mind coming back here.
author: Harriet W.

description:
parking is tough around this area...and surrounding blocks.

Nothing special.  Just consistent vietnamese food.  Last time i was here was on a sunday and it was CROWDED.  It was so busy that it took forever to get the food.  It was hot but i assume they made everything right off the grill because of the wait...whew, good, it was.

My BBQ Pork had some fat...okay, this time it had a lot of fat.  I wasn't very happy with it.  The BBQ Beef was okay though.  Nothing bad except for the fat.

The accompanying fish sauce, was EXTRA fishy...which was a bad thing for me.  Usually its non fish tasting at all.  You dip your fried rolls into it for the extra flavor...but with it being fishy, i didn't enjoy it.

Overall, i was just A-OK with it.
author: Bing D.

description:
3.5 stars? But rounding up.

Solid pho and other noodle -y soup dishes.  Def like this better than Kevin's down the street.  The bun bo hue was kinda disappointing but other than that, I keep coming back for a quick and convenient bowl of pho that always hits the spot!  Read the other Yelp reviews for further food suggestions.  

And they take credit card!!
author: Cynthia G.

description: i ONLY love them when they don't run out of bun rieu. not a lot of vietnamese spots in the city have this. and the places that have them in the sunset, aren't all that great. ppq has decent bun rieu. mMm...
author: Ann T.

description:
Regardless of the number of people crammed into the small entry space to escape the bitter wind and biting cold that is the outer Sunset neighborhood, I shoehorn my way inside to let the host know I intend to hunker down and eat some serious grub.

For more than 10 years I've frequented PPQ for their pho - my favorite one is the Satay Beef (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7vqX4rg0zxQ&feature=player_embedded) but their rice plates and vermicelli combos are worth multiple return visits.  The Satay Beef pho is my ideal comfort food when I have a cold because the spicy soup clears my congestion, and it's oh-so-slurp-worthy good.  I also like their Vietnamese iced coffee, which sometimes serves as dessert for me if I'm too full to eat their fried bananas with ice cream.

Expect difficulty finding parking and if you come for dinner -- plan to eat early to beat the rush but otherwise it's worth the wait.  Bring cash or get cash from the ATM down the street closer to 20th Avenue because they don't take credit cards or debit cards.  And if you plan to come here with a group during dinner, keep the group size small (maybe 4-6).
author: Rosella S.

description:
Perhaps I've been spoiled by Pho in San Diego, but even though my friends from San Francisco love coming here. I find this place to be very mediocre. The sign that this place might be a bust is that everything is in chinese characters... So right from the get go you might question the authenticity.

Their spring rolls are pretty good. Vermicilli with shrimip however its also $6 dollars for 3 spring rolls.. Definitely not worth it. Their pho was also mediocre. Nothing bad to say but nothing stands out either. If you're hungover and just looking for something to eat. THis place is great.
author: James H.

description:
I was not wowed by the noodle soups. I came here with a couple other people and we all ordered different noodle soups. The beef noodle soup was good. The seafood noodle soup was bad like it usually is in every typical pho joint. The curry chicken pho is supposedly recommended, but I was not impressed. The chicken was dry even though it was soaking in curry. Points for being spicy though.

If you need help deciding whether to come here or Pho Huynh Hiep 2 across the street, just flip a coin!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
4.5 Stars w/over 800 reviews?!! COME ON! It's NOT EVEN GOOD. AND HELLA EXPENSIVE. Ppl, there are way better Pho elsewhere in the city + cheaper. Cheaper + better, don't come here.

I don't get what ppl are raving about. I've tried everything on their menu from imperial rolls to their combo pho to all vegetarian options. Only thing worth mentioning is how SPICY their CURRY broth is (additional charge for curry).

DO NOT get their ice coffee here: $3.81 including tax = MOST EXPENSIVE viet ice coffee in the bay area!!!
author: Keiko C.

description:
I've been coming here for over 6 years but ask myself over again why I keep coming back given that I rate this place two stars?

The reason I give this place two stars is mostly due to their customer service (or lack thereof).  They are extremely slow, never smile, and are always forgetful.  I always ask for water with my order but 8 out of 10 times, they will forget to bring it.  Getting their attention to order your food is also a challenge.

The soup/broth lacks flavor but what I do like about this place is the type of beef they use for their pho (angus beef).  

The female (presumed owner) who usually sits at the cashier always looks frumpy and unhappy.  It almost makes you feel as if you've inconvenienced her for coming there to eat.

Not to mention, one time, I ordered a bowl of pho requesting to have the rare beef on the side (as I ALWAYS do).  The waitress repeated my order noting the 'beef on the side' but when my pho came out, the beef was cooked inside the bowl of noodle soup.  I kindly advised the waitress that the rare beef was supposed to be on the side.  She responded with, 'oh yeah, oops', and walked away!  The cook came out from the kitchen and starts yelling at ME in some foreign language about my bowl of pho! Are you kidding me???  Because I don't prefer the texture of fully cooked beef, I persistently asked for a side plate of beef; they charged me $5 for it...I ended up paying over $11 for a bowl of pho. Preposterous! 

I've decided moving forward that I'll be going across the street to eat pho (Kevin's Noodle House aka Pho Huynh Hiep 2).  They are so much more attentive and nicer there...and prices are way cheaper.
author: Unkle L.

description:
Do NOT, I repeat do NOT confuse this place with yet another spot with almost exactly the same name, on Irving too.  They are not related.  Unfortunately that other PPQ is only a block or two away, apparently. :/

Here's the real deal.  YUMMY Vietnamese comfort eats.

Why wasn't this place here when I was growing up? :P

Pho Phu Quoc is better than the other Vietnamese place across the street.

I love that I can ask for whatever noodle I want in the Pho.  BIG bowl of it too, as other yelp-ers have mentioned, with piles of fixins.

Rice wrapper spring rolls are fresh and crunchy.
Grilled/bbq pork entrees are D-lish.

My mom loves their dipping/fish sauce so much, she sometimes buys it... as in, one cup please, to go. (!)  Crazy mama.

P.P.Q. I heart U

:D
author: Jade T.

description:
the beef here is truly as good as it gets. the imperial rolls are a favorite as is the pho tai and the AWESOME 5 spice chicken. 

make sure to get a side of charbroiled beef if you like meat.
author: Natasha N.

description: The pho soup is not good at all, taste like they just boil the water and put in the bowl. The waiter didn't understand my order. I hate this place
author: Jesus D.

description:
When I eat hot noodle soup, my nose runs like there's no tomorrow.

When I eat hot, SPICY noodle soup, my nose runs like there's no tomorrow and I break a light sweat.

When I eat hot, SPICY noodle soup and add jalapeno peppers, my nose runs like there's no tomorrow, I break a light sweat, AND, you better believe it, my eyes begin to water.

And I love, love, LOVE every second of it! #5: Beef Satay Noodle Soup = PPQ's claim to fame.

A couple words of warning: either take care not to wear white when you eat here, or pin on a bib... if you're slurpin up the noodles like I do, you'll end up with a nice orangey-flecked work of art on your new shirt.

Oh, and why do they serve LEMONS with the garnishes here? Limes people, limes!!!
author: Kate V.

description:
I believe pho has healing powers. I can always rely on PPQ to satisfy my pho craving. Their chicken curry pho is delicious, as well as the rare beef flank with meatball pho. 

Simple food for an affordable price.
author: Kathy L.

description: My husband and I always look at each other to see who's going to order the Beef Satay Noodle Soup.  If one or the other gets one, the other is stuck ordering something non spicy for the kids.  Not that we don't like the other dishes but the "Beef Satay" is by far our favorite dish.
author: Anna D.

description: The curry chicken vermicelli is out of this world! Sometimes I'll just stop by if I'm in the neighborhood and take it to go. I just moved to NY and I'm more sad about leaving this soup than my family. Seriously.
author: Melissa W.

description:
This PPQ gives the other location on Clement a bad association.

I have to question the authenticity of a Vietnamese restaurant when most of the diners are non-Asian -- yah that's right, I said it -- what is this, a fushion joint? I've eaten at plenty of Vietnamese restaurants and this place is for people with "altered palates" aka people who don't know any better.
author: Cathrin P C.

description:
The food is tasty, inexpensive and the portions generous.  The three flavor beverage I had with coconut milk is the best one ever. In a big glass, lots of coconut milk, not watery at all - with clear jelly, red bean and yellow mung bean.  The imperial rolls for appetizer were ok, the large order of the spicy satay beef noodle soup is pretty good, and the chicken with vermicelli also pretty good. Everything under $25, the portions are large, enough for three or four people.

Small restaurant on Irving Street, the cross street is 19th Avenue.  Along with the They Love Us on Yelp sticker, there is also a Best of San Francisco 2007 sticker in the window.  It got busier while we were there and after a while all the tables were occupied. Metered street parking, on a busy street with asian grocery shops that stay open after 7pm.  Cash only.
author: Nancy Y.

description:
I'm a fan of the flat rice noodles, and I rarely find Vietnamese restaurants that serve them. It's a bonus this place offers them.  The Beef Stew was really hearty, though the carrots were under cooked. The beef had too much tendon and not enough meat and the broth was oily, but loved the flat rice noodles.

Con: no small option and the medium size was a very generous portion. I'd come back and order and ask for the flat rice noodles for my pho.
author: Lisa C.

description:
The best Five Spice Chicken ever.  It's my family's place....so get off my back.

There is a great group of loyal customers here and I love hearing from friends and co-workers that just light up when I tell them my relatives own the place.
author: David C.

description:
A century long debate answered: PPQ *greater than* KEVINS. 

I'd recommend the following: 
- obviously... the pho (imo, it just tastes better than kevin's)
- curry chicken soup - it is a curry based soup with coconut milk making it nice n' creamy. It does have a fair share of oil, but its worth it! I always get the wide flat noodles - I feel like it makes the dish 10x better!
- 5 spice chicken - its basically a noodle soup with a side of their yummy chicken.  

I dont know if it would really be worth a longer than 15 min wait. (i've never waited more than 5 min though...). Also, I heard it was chinese owned (!?) which apparently detracts from the authenticity of its vietnamese cuisine. WHATEVER.
author: Tim B.

description: Cabbage salad was really good.  Spicy Hue soup was just ok.  I'd eat here again, but change my soup selection.
author: Adrian V.

description: came here several times already. i always get the five spiced chicken pho. so yummy! most of my visits, the service was good. but the last time i went with my two girl friends, the service was extremely slow & not good. i haven't found another place that has five spiced chicken pho yet. just this one.
author: Amy C.

description:
Alright, people.  I got three words for you..FIVE SPICE CHICKEN.  I've never had it before, and frankly, I may not want it from anywhere else but PPQ.  I just thought it would be another pho restaurant.  You go in, order pho, eat your little heart out, and then go home and sleep off the phood coma (clever? *tumbleweeds roll by*).  

I ordered my usual large bowl of thinly sliced beef pho and noticed all my friends having the five spice chicken.  Five spice chicken plate...five spice chicken pho...it was madness.  So I thought, alright it's meat.  You love meat.  Eat it.  So, I snatched a few pieces from my friend and I never went back to my usual beef pho at PPQ.  

Enough backstory.  Onto the food.  The pho is pretty good.  No complaints.  The usual pho joint.  The chicken is what people come here for.  The best thing about the infamous Five Spice Chicken is that it's boneless.  No wasting time on eating around bones! Just stick it in your mouth and eat.  I perfectly seasoned and fried with a light crispy coating.  The only downside is that it can be a bit greasy.  

See you guys there soon!
author: Lisa X.

description: Another one of those places that I've been going to for years... Maybe 15+ years now? That makes me sound so old!!! I can always count on PPQ for a good hearty bowl of pho, but that's not what I come here for. I come here for their curry chicken vermicelli noodle soup and imperial rolls. Their curry chicken is very coconut-y which I love. And sometimes I'll get adventurous and switch out the vermicelli for pho noodles! Their imperial rolls are the ONLY imperial rolls that have taro in them in all of SF. Trust me... I've looked! Definitely will be coming here for many more years to come!
author: Bianca C.

description:
PPQ has the best rice plates you'll find on this end of Irving. 
Their pho is a different story. It's not bad, but it's not the best i've ever had either. The one thing i DO appreciate about their broth is that it is lighter than every other pho  place I have ever gone to in San Francisco. It's lighter, and not as salty. It doesn't leave me with an MSG migraine and feeling 99.9% parched. 
They also serve Vietnamese Beef Carpaccio here. It's not as good as the one at Yummy Yummy (upper Irving area) but it's still damn good. The meat just isn't sliced as thinly as it is at Yummy Yummy.
If you also have a hankerin' for some dessert, they offer a few items. 
I'd opt for creme brulee even though it probably isn't too good here but if you have a craving for brulee - why the hell not? Just order it.
author: Susy C.

description:
I finally got a chance to try this popular restaurant yesterday, and I'd have to agree that all of the positive reviews are justified.  They make a good bowl of pho at lightning fast speed.

While I've often eaten at Pho Hoa Hiep (now Pho Huynh Hiep 2) across the street I decided to give PPQ a try.  The restaurant was quite busy, but there were still a few tables available.  The waitress gave me a hand signal to take a seat.  The big menu features a wide selection of appetizers, pho, bun, rice dishes and main entrees. There are also specials posted on the wall.  A kettle of hot tea is brought to you as soon as you are seated.

I ordered a large bowl of the #6 Seafood Combo Noodle Soup.  A plate of bean sprouts, basil and sliced jalapenos was brought to the table and almost immediately after that came my gigantic bowl of pho.  I'd estimate the wait was less than 2 minutes.  The piping hot chicken broth was clear and I could see a mountain of rice vermicelli sitting in the middle of the bowl.  Shredded pieces of silvery lettuce floated on top of the flavorful broth, which featured fish balls, fish cake, tender slices of calamari and firm, butterflied shrimp.  Overall, it was a very good bowl of soup.

I'll probably stick to Pho Hoa Hiep across the street, but its nice to know there is a good alternative at PPQ.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Pho Ga was lacking. 

Like seriously lacking food!
All it was was broth, noodles and like 5 little shreds of chicken. 
Wahhhh.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Curry Chicken Pho...from the first time I tried this dish, I found myself gradually returning for more and more- almost to a weekly basis. Ironic part was that I didn't care much for it my first try but after the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th, I was HOOKED.

This exquisite meal brings a pleasant aroma before it even sets on the table. The noodles are soft and succulent, the chicken is tender, and the soup is blended to the perfect amount of sweet coconut and red curry. It is just amazing.

However, service (the owner) is really cold. I have been coming here for 6 years and she has never greeted me with a smile or any acknowledgment of familiarity. I wished she was more friendly but it doesn't matter since they have pretty good business.

BUT food is more important than the service so she has definitely not stopped me from coming back
author: Denise W.

description: My favorite pho place. The beef melts in your mouth, the broth is spot on and the portions are great. We have plenty of pho places by us but always make the drive to PPQ and it's well worth it.
author: Lenny E.

description:
Curry Chicken Pho? Wait...how do you mix curry + pho? No idea how that works but decided to give it a try since it was so highly raved and the results are in:

Wow! Cannot believe how interestingly tasty curry + chicken + pho tastes!

It's sort of like having noodles mixed in a watery concoction of Thai yellow curry (I know that may sound nasty but it's pretty good). And it's spiciness really adds to the flavor and overall experience, especially on a cold, chilly day.

I also sampled their Five Spice Chicken, which was pretty good (I'd have to admit). I think I was expecting a little too much when I heard the name, "Five Spice Chicken," as I was expecting to taste 5 different spices simultaneously. But nonetheless, still really good.

In terms of the service, I'd give it a 3 because they messed up our orders not once...but twice. Nice people but you can't be messing up orders more than 1x. The restaurant itself isn't all that flashy...but it's a step up from your normal "Chinatown" restaurant.
author: David W.

description:
Between you and me, this is the spot to go for after a day long hike in Marin with friends. Hungry, lost, and in need of some angus lovin, we parked our tired and sore bums in this pho gem in the Sunset. 

I've heard great things about the Five Spices Chicken, which came out really flavorful and crispy. Top some vermicelli with chicken and fresh egg rolls and you've got yourself a post hiking feast. 

To avoid slipping into a food coma, try the Vietnamese iced coffee. It's quite flavorful and strong, though a little too much condensed milk for my taste. I diluted it with 1 part water and all was good again. 

I think I mentioned that PPQ proudly serves 100% black angus beef, which comes thinly sliced with your pho. It looked quite delicious but given the Indian summer we're in, I passed on noodle soup today and went for the vermicelli bowl. Fresh ingredients, generous portions, and hot items. PPQ I shall return!
author: Patty L.

description:
I hate to leave a short review, but the food was completely unmemorable.

My friends and I went here since we had a hankerin' for some pho, but Loi's was closed (it was Wednesday, dammit!).

First bad sign was that our waitress didn't even speak Vietnamese. What!? My boyfriend was just trying to order a simple bowl of pho, but we had to point in the menu what we wanted to order. Isn't this a pho restaurant? Even though she wasn't Vietnamese, you would think that she would at least understand the names of the dishes on the restaurant's menu. You know, where she works. Lame.

The pho was alright; it had all the right characteristics, but the flavor was lacking. My friend's bbq pork was good, apparently. Unfortunately, we won't be back again.
author: Trang N.

description: Dang curry noodles, you tasty! I've only had this dish at Tung Kee Noodle in the peninsula. It was pretty rich though so if you get it, the regular is probably enough because with the large, eventually you're just trying to finish as the coconut milk laughs mercilessly at you.
author: Misha T.

description:
I've done take out at this place many times.

I am very pleased with how professionally the staff handles themselves.

The food is at the top of it's class for the cost.

I hadn't sat down to eat there since I know I could never finish the thing on my own in one sitting. 

What I like most is the option to build your own meal. Most places slab it all over without a care of the other person's likes. If I had lots of cash to eat out, I'd go there for noodles.
author: Jacen W.

description:
There is much diversity in the customers at this restaurant. People talk about this joint a lot, however i did not find it to be extremely amazing. The pho is alright. not great not bad either. 

Wait staff is young and speaks perfect english. They are kind.
author: Veranna N.

description: It was pretty tastey. I would've liked a little less grease/ mild in my curry pho, but my boyfriends beef broth pho was awesome. I've had better places, but it was still pretty darn good.
author: Kimber C.

description: This is such a great place to dine in when it's nippy out. After you place your order you get your noodles FAST. I always order the Chicken Spicy Curry noodles. My girlfriend's favorite is the #2 bowl (whatever that's called). If you like your noodles simple, try her favorite, which has rare flank, tripe, and tendon. If you want to try a non-traditional pho soup, try the curry noodles (#8).
author: James M.

description:
This is my go-to pho and bun spot in SF.  I cannot begin to guess how many times I've been here.  I also don't know why this place gets so many tepid reviews as compared to the place across the street, which I found pretty dismal by comparison.

There's not much variety or panache, but the pho is robust with plenty of noodles 'n' meat, the vermicelli in the bun is well cooked (not tough, not slimy), and the imperial rolls are the best in the city.  Both the five spice chicken and the grilled pork are very tasty.  They also do a curry that is nice and light-tasting in contrast to Thai curries which can be a little heavy on the coconut fat.
author: Tee Jay R.

description:
I ordered the Number 1 - PPQ pho..the soup was luke-warm and it tasted bland.  Nothing really special about this place, just another pho shop.

The place looks clean and the service is mediocre.  Cash Only.

My belly hurted when I got home, it's probably from the MSG-filled bowl of pho.
author: Elliot Y.

description: The Pho was bland. They didn't serve it how I asked for it, and the server seemed irritated that we had questions. All the chopsticks and soup spoons at the table were dirty. The lady at the table next to us washed her soup spoon by putting it in her tea cup and pouring the tea over it.
author: Michelle W.

description:
Cheap pho? Yes.
Do I like this place better than the pho place across the street? Yes.
Does parking suck? Yes.
Is this good pho? It's.. okay..

PPQ's space is not as large as the pho place directly across the street. I think the quality of pho is the same. I'm not really sure what the difference is really.  I know I don't like the cut of meat here though. The rare flank steak is like a thin sliver of what i would expect in my bowl of pho.

Nonetheless, pho is good on a cold, foggy, SF day.

BUT, If you're from the neighborhood, you'll run into everyone you know here.
author: Samantha L.

description: This place actually deserves 0 stars, however that is not an option on Yelp. Never have I seen such horrendous customer service. I vow to never eat here ever again. Never will I even give them a penny. I hope all you yelpers out there who have experienced such customer service will join me in boycotting this place. Businesses need to understand that it is the customers that keep your business open, and without us you would just cease to exist in this already troubled economy.
author: Vanessa K.

description: Pretty good. I tried the bun bo hue which was good but not amazing. Their five-spice chicken is pretty special. Huge portions!
author: Jenny J.

description:
5 spice-chicken + beef Pho + taro drink + Red Rodney = A hell of a time!

This is the fam's favorite spot to get a dose of all of the above, sorry you'll have top find your own Red Rodney, he's ours to keep!  (our family best buddy and good luck parking spot finder).

So the service is mediocre - you'll have to flag them down most of the time - but we don't mind that in exchange for really good food.

It's particularly wonderful on a cold SF summer day.
author: Michelle B.

description: Solid viet option. Very filling. Cheap. Cash only. Didn't like their peanut sauce which had too much hoisin sauce. Tasty crispy chicken.
author: Regina C.

description: service among the worst in the city.  food is okay for price but not worth the high blood pressure from the shitty workers (can't call them waiters;they'd have to be waiting on you at some point)
author: Derp D.

description:
After days of suffering from food poisoning, I am finally back! and can eat and write again! The first thing I eat after only eating congee for days had to be something flavorful and VERY VERY tasty!

Labor day, gotta end the weekend with a bang, since ive been on the toilet for the first three days. 

PPQ's wraps!!!!!!!!! There was a wait, but today there was a boss lady in the house.  She was polite, and tried to get us a table asap.  As I waited, i noticed that the health inspector only gave them 88...owell.  I just pray i dont get sick again. Getting sick has made me very cautious about the cleanliness of the bean sprouts, mint leaves, and utensils.   

We sat, and they gave us waters instead of boiling tea, good, cos it was HOT today.  But i did find a hard piece of black substance in my water.  It wasnt a tea leaf, but i didnt care, this was my celebration.

We ordered: of course the pork wraps, imperial roll vermicelli, #1 Pho, LARGE, and a pork over rice.  WOW, what a feast for my come back.  

I LOVE PORK WRAPS!!!!!!! especially because it involves making it myself.  I dont recall any other pho place that has this, or i have yet to find one.  but why do that if PPQ is doing it good?

We cleared everything on the table, and it was delish.  :] with 5mins to spare on the parking meter.
author: kim w.

description: Had the chicken curry pho for the first time. If you've ever had kapoon (Thai curry noodle), it tastes similar. The portions are pretty big too. I only gave it 4 stars because I didn't like the noodles which were small round noodles. But overall, the liquid was delicious. Good portion for the price you pay.
author: Sue L.

description:
Very disappointed in their Pho. Not authentic at all. Thought maybe to give this pho joint a try since it looked 'bustling' compared to their competitor across the street. The beef broth was watered-down, barely any flavor. Not even Sriacha sauce or Hoisin sauce could save it. The noodles were not cooked al dente - they were served stuck together! Very skimpy meat portions and their Dac Biet doesn't even include tripe pieces in their pho! No basil was served, only bean sprouts in their cold side accompaniment. And to top it off, they are OVERPRICED! I mean really, are you going to charge me $7.25 for a medium size bowl of pho!?

This place is more 'Chinese' than Vietnamese from what I observed, including the servers, cooks, and customers. If you want more 'Vietnamese' tasting pho, then head across the street to Pho Huynh Hiep (aka Kevin's Noodle House). Now that place is legit.

I was so disappointed in Pho Phu Quoc that I abandoned their pho and escaped to Kevin's Noodle House which is seriously only a stone's throw away. Kevin's pho is waaay more heartier and satisfying, as well as less expensive. I think $5.75 for a medium sized pho. 

I'm never eating at Pho Phu Quoc again, no matter how more 'bustling' it looks.
author: Kimberly T.

description:
I have been here 3 times now, twice for eat-in and once for carry out.  I have had regular Pho, forget what kind of meat, but it was solid.  Also had curry coconut chicken pho, which is a nod to tom kha gai from a thai restaurant, with spicy chili oil in the broth.  the broth is spicier by itself than with food in itfor some reaosn, but so good!  You must have at least moderate heat tolerance for it, though.

And then there's the #19 beef and imperial rolls.  Oh my god, amazing!  So much food.  Imperial rolls, perfectly seared, flavorful, quality (in an asian restaurant!) beef.  Dipping sauce, some pickled carrots, a ton of noodles, and a salad of lettuce, sprouts and mint leaves.  A huge meal for $8.45 and delicious.  Got it to go and they even poked holes in the top of the (perfectly presented) plastic container to preserve the crispiness of the rolls. They are courteous, reasonably quick, and always busy.  I had it 12 hours ago and I'm craving it again.  Is it wrong to review on Yelp while hungry?
author: Lauren J.

description:
I LOVE Vietnamese food but i HATE this place! I used to go here every so often since there is a slightly larger menu than Pho Hoa Hiep (now renamed Pho Huyen Hiep) which is right across the street and it also closes later..but F*** that. I'd rather go eat at Chabaa down the street. 

The food is average or below average. The service is HORRIBLE!!! I mean, i know it's not fine dining or anything, but still. The people are HELLA rude. Its like they dont give a S*** what you think and they dont need your $20. I REFUSE to EVERRR eat here again! Thats how much of an impression they left for me. I havent eaten there for so long I dont really remember the specifics of why I hate them so much, but I know i was very annoyed the last time I left. 

The Pho place across the street is cheaper and the people are nicer! Go there instead! The Pho and rice plates are a lot better too!
author: Linh P.

description:
Hole is the wall joints are the SHIET! I love their fatty, big portions shamelessly slathered with oil and grease. YUMMY--- I LOVE  PPQ! I love their mildly washed self-service utensil trays perched on each table and their mom&pop's style cuisines. I love their super speedy service, even though you sometimes have to ask twice to get water or extra whatnots. 

I love their No. 8 Curry Chick PHO--One of the my all time favorite dishes in the world!--you have to get it with pho noodle though because honestly, those thin vermicelli rice noodle are just not cutting it. PPQ has perfected their curry chicken PHO---a impeccable blend of creamy, sweet, spicy, and flavorful coconut milk and curry powder, mixed with the most tender chicken breast, and springy pho noodles. Omg I want some right now as I'm typing this review! Also their imperial rolls are to die for. It comes sizzling hot out of the kitchen within seconds after placing your order and you can actually taste the taro inside the rolls. Wraps the imperial rolls in the lettuce leaves, dip it in some tangy fish sauce and enjoy! I also recommend trying their beef stew with flat noodles and five spice chicken rice plate --- all very delicious and you won't be disappointed, trust!  

PPQ is what locals in the city eat on a regular basis and I come here almost every week, no joke. Sure the service is not quiet up to par, but who cares? You get all your basics met and it is super affordable and always delicious!
author: Ellen W.

description:
Tastes amazing. If that's all that matters to you then don't read on. 

Get the Five spice chicken and the imperial rolls. 

Service isn't slow especially considering how busy they get. 

Negative stars because I found a bug in my soup a few times... Normally I would freak out but the soup tastes so good I ignored it the first time, took the bug out, and pretended nothing happened. The second time it was much harder to ignore... The third time I really wasn't sure if it was a bug, but I think I got paranoid. 

Eat at your own risk. (I'm sure all hole in the walls have their share of special ingredients.)
author: Angela R.

description: This is my quick go to spot for a pho fix for lunch.  No frills.  Always consistent in taste, never will disappoint.  Fast service allows me in and out for my break time.
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
Across the street is Kevins Noodle House. Clearly their competitor. 

I truthfully think their pho and broth is better than across the streets.
However, if you want a rice plate, go to Kevins. 

Chicken Coconut Curry Noodle Soup:
Taste as good as my moms. The flavor is very wowing and not bland AT ALL. The noodles can be exchanged with any kind listed. I got a large and ate the rest for dinner. So, the quantity they give is very fulfilling. 

Service: 
Very nice and quick. They asked my mom and I 3 times to see if we were ready. Kind of annoying, but I can't expect much from a non-american restaurant. However, the reason behind this is to get you in and out. Their restaurant had a line of about two tables which is rare for a pho place. 
Also they gave us water as Kevins Noodle House, you have to ask and they still won't depending on your server. 

Go to PPQ! They also have many other locations!!
author: Tony C.

description:
Okay...why is this restaurant called PPQ? Is it related to the crab restaurant (also called PPQ) on clement? I dine out in the Sunset pretty often and always go to Pho Hoa Hiep (aka "The Pink Place"). My friends and I have always talked about coming here, but at the last minute  we would change our minds and go for what we are accustomed to. 

Came here once and I wish I stuck with "The Pink Place" instead. The pho was very average (no sing and dance routine from the flavors infusing in my tastebuds like what I'm accustomed to from "The Pink Place"). The imperial rolls are amazing though. The service was a bit slow. 

Lesson Learned: I'm sticking with Pho Hoa Hiep (The Pink Place) next time.
author: Sue L.

description:
Dear god this place is delicious.  I really like the pho and in particular the beef satay pho.  It's spicy with a great broth.  I ate the whole thing including the broth before my friend finished his noodles.  I felt unladylike when I noticed this but eh? I'm around friends.

There is usually a line so the earlier the better or if you're able to go on during the week, it's nice to find a table immediately.

The vermecelli is also great especially with the imperial rolls.  And go ahead and get the 3 colored drink.  It's a drink made from azuki beans, another sweet bean, and gelatin pieces and milk pours over it.  It's not too sweet and a filling dessert if you're not in the mood to eat.

I've been coming here for a few years now and have decided that this is my favorite pho restaurant I have found.
author: Ashley I.

description: Love the curry chicken noodle soup!!!
author: Christine S.

description:
Pho was flavorless. Much less meat than other restaurants and charge the same price. Should have guessed what was in store for us when calamari came with ketchup.

Go across the street instead. This place is a MAJOR DISSAPOINTMENT!
author: Cory R.

description:
It's a hole in the wall and frankly, not that clean but it's one those places that attracts people because of one thing: good food. Now I can't say every single item is good - I love their five spice chicken for instance but their broth could use some work. 

Btw, they have bun Rieu (crab pho). It's good if you've never had it before but there's better.
author: Shum S.

description:
If not the best in the city, its definitely the best in Sunset! I typically stop by here at least once a month, if not more and they have never let me down when it comes to authenticity of their broth and pho. 

Everything I have tried here has been superb from their five spice chicken rice plates to their build-your-own spring rolls. The broth they use for the pho is hands down the best I've tried so far.

Food Highlight: Build-your-own spring rolls!! You pick what kind of meat you would like, either grilled pork, shrimp, or beef and they provide you with the necessary equipment to assemble it including noodles, mint leaves, lettuce leaves, and of course, the rice paper.
author: Rich L.

description:
This review is for their beef pho.

This place is a little on the pricier side for pho, although you do get an enormous bowl. I prefer places that let you pick the size you want, because for a small eater like me, there is no way I can finish a portion that large. 

Their pho was a little disappointing. The soup, while hot, was not very flavorful, and their noodles were a little on the clumpy side :/ The meat was A-OK. My boyfriend ordered their five spice chicken pho, and I think his meat was a lot better. 

Would I come again? Maybe, but only for their chicken pho.
author: Kimberly F.

description: I always dream about their Curry Chicken Soup... so delicious, especially on foggy days. It's pretty spicy, but that's just one of the things that I love about it. The atmosphere is nice. Lots of tables, service is quick but they don't rush you if you want to stay and talk for awhile after you've finished your meal. Also, the price is right: 7 bucks for a great meal. Um, yes please! I love PPQ. One of my many bay area addictions!
author: Robyn B.

description: I tried giving their pho a shot but the broth didn't have much flavor.... I prefer Kevin's noodle house across the street. Although my friend ordered their five spice chicken which i found to be extremely juicy and flavorful
author: Philip M.

description:
I don't know what all the other yelpers are taIking about, because I liked this place 10 times better than Kevin's Noodle house across the street - the food and the service were both much much better.

Their five spice chicken pho I got was AMAZING- I'd go back just for that - and the delicious chicken comes on the side!  (i love that) My man's spicy beef satay pho was actually spicy!  Our other table companions got the bun (vermicelli noodles) and really liked it.

Perfect proportions (read: large) and a great price (read: cheap).

Looking forward to the next rainy day (hello San Francisco in July) for an excuse to come back here.
author: Roxane W.

description:
Good food
Would prefer appetizer came before entree. Overall good service 
But parking is difficult.
author: Wing W.

description:
PPQ is like the #1 place I would go to, for raw meat! Yes I said it,. raw carpaccio!

It's a plate of raw beef topped with fish sauce, fried garlic, onions, mint leaves?! and LEMON! soOO good.  I can eat a plate to myself,. that's how good it is.  Pho here is also decent, but I prefer Kevin Noodles House across the street for pho.  PPQ's pho soup is not rich enough and is just to bland for my taste buds.

I use to come here at least once a week,. but started trying out new places.  I wouldn't mind making this a weekly meal again.  

I LOVE eating raw beef and will be back!
author: Chanel L.

description:
The chicken curry pho was amazing.

Nothing fancy about the decor or prices.  Just excellent Pho!

The line to get in was out the door. It's that good.
author: Harry S.

description: I have been coming here for years and the food and service are always great. I get the number 4 Pho with extra basil and peppers and it is great every time. The meat is very high quality, juicy, and flavorful.  The service is friendly and attentive. My most recent visit was today. The second I ran out of hot tea they replaced it and we also had their Thai ice tea and it was yummy.  We also had the sizzling beef with jasmine rice, which was yummy especially the dipping sauce that they serve with it. If you like Pho, check this little place out; you will be glad you did and don't be fooled by the decor as meals are top-notch and prices are ridiculously cheap for the quality of and service.
author: Patrick R.

description:
Dirty tables, seats, corners. 

Noodles weren't all that great; noodle stuck to the bottom of the bowl.

Also overpriced and very rude customer service with attitude (especially the owner lady).

Wouldn't come back here again; I'd rather go across the street to Kevin's.
author: Wilson L.

description:
This is my spot! Well now it is... Thanks chelley and fat!  We are here every sunday night.  #1, #4, imperial rolls and maybe any one of their awesome vermecelli plates and your done!  I could eat here everyday since I'm a big soup fan to begin with...

Very cozy inside so wouldn't recommend big groups, but if you're looking for good eats with a small bill, this is your spot.
author: Myke Y.

description: put your name down and wait, and wait. i think kevins across the street is better but this is a close second.
author: B S.

description:
This place is perfect for the outer boondocks of the Sunset, where it's typically gray, windy and COLD.

Their pho rescues the soul with its warm, clean, flavor-packed broth, noodles, meat and vegetable fixings. I always debate weather to order the pho or B2 - the vermicelli with 5-spice chicken (bit fatty, but good) and imperial rolls drizzled with a light fish sauce. Lately it has been B2. 

If you're looking for a warm up that's fresh and full of flavor, this is the place to B.
author: Cathy K.

description:
After a whole day of walking, standing, and enduring a really cold day in Golden Gate Park this place was just what we needed.  It was past 10pm but the place was still going strong.  After a short wait we got the table by the door.  Instantly a waitress rushed by and left a tea pot and cups in her wake.  Burning the mouth hot tea was phenomenal to this poor socal girl who wasn't expecting SF to be so cold in the summer.  

I ordered the #1 with all the various meats and entrails.  The medium was more than enough.  Hot soup, noodles, meat, with srichacha thrown in the mix was heaven.  No one could be cold after that.  Well, except for the people trying to wait in the tiny doorway and kept keeping the door open.

Service kind of sucks but it was a packed house with like 2.5 servers running around.  I guess I'll give it a little grace, plus you don't go to pho for the service.
author: Mel K.

description:
Ive always seen this place but i always go to kevin's noodle house because i thought it was better.
So yesterday i step in here and ordered the beef stew with noodles,i thought it would be just like any other beef stew i ordered from any other restaurant but i was dead wrong.
When the bowl came it was filled with at least 12 pieces of beef, plenty of noodles and under-cooked carrots but otherwise it was worth it.
I also ordered the famous imperial rolls they were pretty good,all in all i would say i got my money's worth.
The service was decent not great but good enough.
And it wasn't crowded so i got to enjoy my meal in peace.
author: Corey W.

description:
The Pho Satay Bo is kinda greasy but good.  (spicy beef noodle soup)
you should try it
author: Alyssa K.

description: They make the best Curry Chicken Noodle Soup. But on busy days when they start to run low, I think they add water to the soup. This happens with the beef pho broth too. Substitute pho noodles though because the vermicelli just melts into the broth. The imperial rolls and veggie rolls are really good. Authentic Vietnamese style rolled in rice paper wrap and not Chinese egg roll wrapper. The five spice Chicken is one of the best I have had (when it is fresh). That is yummy served with the bowl of plain pho noodles in broth. And yes, they do accept credit cards: Visa, MC, and Discover. I paid with a credit card yesterday (5/29/2013).
author: Carrie W.

description: Unremarkable but solidly good food for cheap. This may be a weird thing to remark on, but I love how you get a big helping of peanuts on the veggie vermicelli. When eating similar dishes at most restaurants, I order extra peanuts, but I don't have to here.
author: Lauren O.

description:
Like seriously... I do not like being skimped on food when I go out to eat.
So this place is getting 1 star because of inconsistency. 

I ordered the crab and tomato noodle soup and there was 2 slices of that fanci meat, 2 little cubes of tofu, probably a fifth of a whole tomato in there and barely any crab....

You would think it would be more of the foods that are in the title but nope.... Skimped
If you are out of the ingredients then at least tell me so I can order something else.....
I have been here before and know what the portions are like.

BTW I ordered a LARGE BOWL.

So yeah...
author: Vincent T.

description:
So I was really craving some raw beef and bun bo hue after awaking with a bag hangover. I didn't want to make a drive down to San Jose so I decided to come here after reading Yelp reviews. I was not impressed with the raw beef and the bun bo hue I ordered. 

The plate of raw beef is huge! with mint leave, fried garlic, and onions. They give you 2 lemon slices to squeeze on top of the raw beef and fish sauce for dipping. For $13, this plate is well worth it. But I only picked at about a quarter of the dish and didn't want the rest anymore. I can taste the ice on the beef so it's been frozen and defrost. I know it won't be fresh, but I really didn't want to taste the ice still. 

The Bun Bo Hue was really bland and the beef taste funky to me; like it was bad beef or something. The noodle tasted like rubber band. The soup looks super water down.. I must of ate 1 piece of beef, and few noodle and left the entire bowl untouched. 

I left this place feeling super dissatisfy!
author: Jenny G.

description:
I went here today and was gonna get their porkchop rice plates but decided to get Bun Bo Hue. Oh damn, I'm sorry baby, we should have just went to San Jose for some there (AND, they add some yummy ox penis too). The taste was just not spicy enough! And since I was with my boyfriend, I did not taint the soup with the whole bottle of siracha. 

My appetizer - the calamari was just bread crumbs. Fried and oiled up like a tan baby's bottom. It made me cry since this was not how I remembered this restaurant!

I am gonna avoid the Bun Bo Hue and the sorry excuse of calamari here. Just go here for pho, at least that taste "alright" or so I remembered it.

I need to get something spicy in my mouth before I cry!
author: Karry D.

description:
My personal background: I've had PPQ's delicious curry chicken noodle soup over 50x in my lifetime, and I love spicy food. I love adding sriracha in my food, jalapenos in my sandwich, once in a while I also cook a killer spicy chicken tikka masala at home.

The food has been going downhill since a few months ago. A few months ago I came in for the curry chicken noodle, and was so disappointed I didn't come back until a few months later. NOT SURE if PPQ switched chefs or what, but food does not taste the same anymore.

I used to love this place so much. Used to come here for dinner once every 2 weeks, and there was evan a point where I came once a week at some point in time, when the chef of PPQ was consistent with their chicken curry noodle soup.

The past few months, PPQ has not failed to disappoint me as a regular. Service as usual was great, but the last 3 times I've visited, the chicken curry noodle soup tasted terrible. 

LIST OF SCREW-UPS (All on different days):

First screw-up: the noodle soup was SPICIER THAN USUAL. Normally the soup is spicy but perfectly balanced with the perfect amount of coconut milk and chicken stock. I had to take water breaks between eating the noodle soup, which made it less enjoyable. Still, not bad, but not as good as last time.

Second screw-up: Not sure what it was about the soup, but flavor was completely off? Still, this wasn't enough to prevent me from coming back. I thought maybe I just came in on a bad day. I'm a relatively forgiving customer.

Third screw-up: Came in with my boyfriend last week. WAY OVERSPICED!!!! My boyfriend is Vietnamese and the Vietnamese can HANDLE SPICY FOOD. That was how spicy the curry noodle soup was. The waiter was even kind enough to give us both two big bowls of chicken stock to add in the soup. But evan then, STILL so spicy that we needed to drink a lot of water in between! Not the delicious kind of spicy, but the "wrong measurement" kind of spicy. It totally killed my palate. 

On top of that, the next morning, both my boyfriend and I had upset stomachs and my face developed many red tiny bumps (which for me means that there was an extreme amount of spice in my food). First time this happened with PPQ. 

**I really hope the owner realizes that their curry noodle soup flavor is not the same as before and make some drastic changes with the chef/kitchen staff before they lose more loyal customers.** 

Til then, I'm taking a LOOONG break from PPQ.
author: Ree W.

description:
I've been here before and never had a problem. This is the type of place where you eat and go. 
Tonight I came in and was seated right away and menus were given to us immediately too. But, service seemed non existent after that. We sat at our table with our menus closed, waiting for a server to come by and take our order. No service. We waved down a guy who was at the register... He looked at us and continued his conversation with the lady at the register... A few minutes later he grabs a couple menus and gives it to the table next to us.. With a pen and pad in hand... But does not take our order. Seriously?!  He does come back around and eventually take our order. I wanted the spring rolls appetizer without mint. Is that a rare request?! He told me to wait while he asked the lady at the register. He came back and continued to take our order. I had to ask him if my request was okay.. It was. 
Anyway. Food comes and my friend ordered a large pho with beef on the side. He literally got.. 3 ummm.. They weren't big enough to be called slices... So let's call them small strips along with what I would call crumbs (picture uploaded). 

Taste wise though the food is satisfying. I just wish the service was better and the portions of beef of the side slightly bigger.
author: Diana L.

description: Had the Pho, it does taste different in a good way.
author: Isaiah L.

description:
Curry Chicken Pho.  Amazing.  One of the best things I've ever eaten.  The chicken is so soft and tender and moist and juicy.  The noodles are good.  And the soup.  Oh the soup.  Coconut milk curry...tastes so goood....its almost like a thai broth, but ive never tasted no thai broth this good.  This shit is frickin delicious!  Liquid crack.

On other occasions Ive also had the satay pho - good as well.  also tried the beef pho, had it take out and got home and it was cold :(  Nothing to wrtie home about.  

Eat the Curry Chicken Pho.  I think its #8 on the menu, but its #1 in my heart.
author: Sage S.

description:
I can't pronounce the name of this Vietnamese restaurant (it's referred to as PPQ by those linguistically-challenged among us), but I can pronounce that their huge bowls of delicious pho are worth the price of some $7-9.

The decor is pretty and neat, and while the restaurant was so full of people both times that I went here, that it was hard to navigate, the service was quite quick and the waitress was helpful, if a little harried.

I always get the seafood pho, since I'm not much of a meat-eater, and it's absolutely scrumptious, if a bit overwhelming since the portion seems huge (but this is a good thing!)
author: Daniela R.

description:
Though I finally tried this place to compare.
I will probably go to my usual place across the street run by Vietnamese people.

I don't understand giving two piece of lettuce for 6 pieces of imperial roll. The broth for the pho was just OK, not much flavor.

The service is also not as good.

One of the rare times that a Yelp sticker failed me. Also, you can usually tell by the clientele that this was a bad decision on my part to give them a try.
author: Brandon M.

description: i had the seafood noodle soup here, which was ok.  the bowls come in med and large, and the med was huge.  the noodles should have been broken up a bit.  each strand was way too long!  also, i think they use a ton of msg in the soup, so i didn't drink all of it (which i usually do).
author: Helen T.

description:
Good food... nothing like a hot bowl of Pho to keep you warm from the cold.

Too bad the service is not as warm.....

If you come to this spot.... be sure to tread lightly and not expect great service. 

With that in mind you will be able to enjoy the sweet lovin of some hot pho!
author: Gene M.

description:
Ordering my usual Pho with rare steak and tendon, I was expecting a treat because everyone keeps telling me that Pho on Irving is unrivaled.  

Well, it's rivaled alright.  It's not the best.  Probably average... at best.  The broth was on the bland side even to the point where lemon, hoisin sauce, and sriracha couldn't save it.

We ordered Imperial Rolls.  They forgot to bring them... but they sure as heck didn't forget to add it to the bill.  We had to remind them that we never received the rolls.  They looked at our table for a moment, saw no evidence of the rolls ever arriving, and took them off the bill.  

I had to go through several soup spoons before I settled on the least dirty ones.  I'm talking.. crust on the spoons that a dry napkin couldn't wipe off.  Splash some hot tea on the napkin, and suddenly, the spoon becomes very clean.... NOT what I was expecting pre-meal.

It was pretty busy that night, almost making it seem like a full-on legitimate Pho place.  Too bad its appearance and busy atmosphere didn't tell the whole story.  

So my quest for Pho greatness continues.  Perhaps I should take on the Pho challenge at Pho Garden... or maybe try what I've heard to be great Pho at Cali-pho-nia.  Who knows where my next Pho craving will lead me?  Definitely not back to PPQ though.

2 Stars... and it's because their service was not bad.
author: Johnson N.

description: I like Kevin's better. It is just a couple blocks from here. The broth here was full of body and flavor but no wow factor. I think the servings are just a bit smaller and their prices are a little more than Kevin's. Overall, good pho. Have to say, it was a packed house so clearly there are those who like it here.
author: Eve C.

description:
Sometimes it's good to change your routine.

I was used to getting the Beef Pho at PPQ.  Then I went to lunch with a friend who told me about the 5 Spice Chicken Pho.  She was really adamant about how good it was.

This set off a dialog in my head:
"Try something different!"
"But I really love the Beef Pho"
"You always get the Beef Pho!  Get the Chicken!"
"But the Beef is so....Beefy.  With parts of beef and bits of beef and that lovely beef broth..."
"GET THE CHICKEN!"
"But..."
"If you get the chicken and don't like it, you can secretly come back tomorrow and get the Beef."
"Fine."

You can probably guess the end of this story.  I LOVED the Chicken Pho.  The barbequed meat comes separately on the side, and it is delicious.  The broth is wonderful, too.  That plus a couple off Imperial Rolls, and you will be full and happy in just a matter of slurps.

Beef or Chicken, you can't go wrong at PPQ.
author: Liz S.

description:
This is the "cheap" PPQ (as my friends call it). Not to be confused with the PPQ on Clement St which is well known for their dungeness crab.

This was actually my second Vietnamese meal for the day. I went to another place to get pho for lunch and then it just so happened that my friend went here for dinner and picked me up something.

I decided to get the BBQ Pork on Vermicelli. The meat was very flavorful and tender. The orange sauce that came with it was spicy (not hot, but zesty) which made it even better. I was also happy with the large portions. It actually ended up being two meals for me and I had leftovers for the next day.
author: Laura P.

description: It was pretty good. I got just a regular chicken pho. One of my friend's order came out like 40 minutes late which is not okay. But other than that, he did say it was worth the wait, and they had pretty decent food.
author: Millissa T.

description:
I was brought here by a friend touting it was best pho in san francisco so maybe my expectations were a little high...

The pho was good... the best? probably not. I tried regular pho the first time I came here and the curry pho the 2nd time (and regular pho again the third time).

If you are in the mood for some hot steaming pho on a cold day or to cure a hangover, DO NOT get the curry pho. While good, it doesn't have that soothing feeling. 

Must order - Pho,  vietnamese carpaccio, imperial rolls (fried egg rolls, order the full order and it comes with lettuce/mint leaves that you can wrap it in).

The one major thing PPQ has going for it versus some of the better pho joints in the tenderloin is CLEANLINESS. If you are turned off by the cleanliness issues that are rumored to plague many of the great pho restaurants in the tenderloin... this is the place for you.
author: Noah P.

description:
Is it good or bad to get pho one night and then, after showering and changing clothes, to still smell and taste it the following day?

Pretty good service, huge portions - a bit pricey for anything that is not a small bowl of pho.
author: Shinny L.

description:
Their vermicelli dishes are always pretty good every time I come here, thought their fish sauce could use some help. It doesn't have that authentic Vietnamese taste that you get from pho restaurants in San Jose.

The pho broth is below average, and in my opinion, that just ruins everything.

Garlic noodles, however, are AMAZING!
author: Colleen M.

description:
This review is strictly for the 5 spice chicken and pho. I might come back to try something else.. but not any time soon.

I think the word "average" defines the pho perfectly. The broth was a little bland, but it wasn't so bland to the point of tasting like water. On my visit the noodles were overcooked, so it was mushy. =/ I heard a lot of good things about this place, but none of them held true for my experience. The 5 spice chicken was very flavorful, but was still average. When you have Kevin's Noodle House across the street, and Loi's a couple blocks down, this just doesn't cut it.
author: Munnie T.

description:
Bf and I decided to give this place a try because I was craving garlic noodles and this one had pretty good ratings. I was quite disappointed. First of all parking here sucks, we had to circle the streets like vultures. Second, the gentleman at the front desk was not very friendly. The whole time we were there I didn't see him crack a single smile. He didn't even greet us when we walked in. He just asked "how many?" I'm not sure if he's running the place or not but he definitely didn't have that warm hospitality vibe. Also, while we finished our first order of noodles and waited for our second I felt rushed because they kept asking us if we wanted to go boxes. The place wasn't even packed so I can't see why they would be so eager to get us out.

The two of us ordered 2 portions of garlic noodles, garlic eggplant, and shaking beef cubes which came out to $50.

Garlic Noodles: Fairly small portion for the price (hence the reason why we got 2). The noodles were quite dry and not very garlicy. I thought the one from Crustacean was much better (it wasn't dry and had all the buttery garlicy goodness that you would expect from garlic noodles).

Garlic Eggplant- This dish was the best of the three. It was flavorful and garlicy and the eggplant was cooked just right, not too mushy. 

Shaking Beef Cubes (Bo Luc Lac)- this dish wasn't all that great. It didn't really taste like the traditional vietnamese one I'm used to. Perhaps maybe because it's run by Chinese people that the dishes have more of a Chinese influence rather than vietnamese.

Verdict: For $50 (none of which was even for seafood), I feel like I could have gotten better food elsewhere. I am not a fan, perhaps I'll come back to try the crab if someone from my party wanted to give it a try but it's not on the top of my list.
author: Jeanette N.

description:
Wow. So... Where shall I start. Met up with my friend at this ppq restaurant thinking, "What is this place all about?". Well I see all these pictures of Imperial Rolls and decided to try it with rice after see all these delicious pictures of the Rolls. They're good!!! Caution: They're hot...so make sure you don't pop them into your mouth until they cool down a bit.

Parking's a bit of a trouble especially on Irving around 19th and 20th ave. But of course, there are always meter street parking around the place. Enjoy!
author: Eudora Z.

description:
After my horrible experience last time with this place, I was feenin' for some good ol' Vietnamese food. I looked over their menu and saw something that sounded perfect for me. Papaya salad with charbroiled beef. I gave it a try and it's exactly what I need. Something healthy, with no carbs. (simple carbs at least). 

I will be coming back here for my lunch rotations on Irving Street.
author: Alice E.

description:
My fav pho restaurant in the city.

Pho Ga Quay Chao - Five Spices Chicken Noodle Soup - my go-to dish.  Well seasoned chicken comes separate on a plate and adding it to the pho adds welcoming oil.

Pho Ga  - also very delicious

The veggie pho with tofu is also great with chicken broth.

Bun Tom Nuong - chargrilled shrimp with vermicelli topped of with nuoc mam (fish sauce). Typical tasting bun and yummy.

Bun Ca Ri Ga - Curry Chicken Vermicelli Noodle Soup - very similar to the the Thai noodle soup Kow soi, however I've noticed variations in the quality/ spiciness of soup
author: Jessica P.

description:
One of the biggest let downs after returning home from overseas travel is that no restaurant here can truly reproduce the quality (and at a lower price point I might add) of the native cuisine over there. PPQ's pho comes about 90% close to the pho I had in Saigon and Hanoi earlier this year. PPQ's pho is triple in price compared to the ubiquitous chain Pho24, and it's probably even far more expensive when compared to street stalls.  However, the quality of the beef is superior.  That's where we in the US have an advantage.

This place is still busy, but they do a good job of getting the food out quickly.  Thus, don't be scared off if there is a wait for a table. PPQ now accepts credit cards.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description: There's nothing like a piping hot bowl of pho on a cold day, especially when you're feeling under the weather.  The veggie pho was delicious; the vegetables (bok choy and broccoli) were fresh and crisp, and the tofu was soft and creamy.  I really enjoyed the simplicity and clean flavors.  I saw someone eating my old go to, the spicy chicken curry pho, but the veggie pho was just as satisfying.  The fried veggie rolls with taro and vegetables came out piping hot as well, and were served with a spicy soy as opposed to fish sauce.  The rolls were Slanted Door esque; fried while still wet so that the wrapper is bubbly and airy.  We were lucky enough last night not to have to wait for a table, but that was a first.
author: Sandy K.

description:
I just came here today at around 1 for some lunch. My dad ordered the combination rice (shredded pork, charbroiled pork, and egg loaf). I had their large pho with rare flank and meat balls. It took forever for a waitress to get our order, which was really unfortunate and not a good start. I wished I had taken note of that and left then.

The food was quite mediocre. I really like pho and charbroiled Vietnamese meat plates with rice and this place's was just a disappointment. There wasn't that much meat in the bowl and the noodles were still cold. The broth was only mediocre. I took some bites from my dad's plate and the egg loaf and shredded pork were just awful. The charbroiled pork, however, was amazing. It was marinated well but I wish there was a bit more meat and rice!

The place was mediocre from the food to the service. At least I didn't have to wait too long to sit down, right?
author: Rick C.

description: I am happy to say that this restaurant has returned to it's previous yumminess. Whatever they had changed that made the food less delicious, has been remedied. So once again, I will tell everyone I know, to hurry don't wait and get curry, chicken, noodle soup here!!!
author: Melody C.

description:
Imperial rolls - Amazing
BBQ Beef rice plate - ridiculous 
Curry chicken soup - get out of my face
Frozen Bananna- now you're just being cruel.
author: Ryan L.

description: a late night, pricier, more expensive, smaller portion, alternative to yummy yummy or loi's
author: Long C.

description:
I can never go wrong with this place. It's always satisfying to my hunger and keeps my wallet full. 

I highly recommend the Imperial Rolls and any of the Pho bowls if you go there for the first time :)
author: Quinallison D.

description:
P P Q

1) busy place, they don't take numbers so someone from your party needs to line up inside and grab a table when its free.
2) food taste the same as Yummy (similar restaurant a few blocks down), but a little cheaper.
3) pho is pho.
author: Roll N.

description:
I don't think their pho is as good as Kevin's Noodle House's across the street. That isn't to say it isn't good. The five or so times I've been here, it was also served at a hotter temperature than that served at Kevin's, too--a good thing for those like me who like near-scalding-hot foods. 

When I used to work in the area, I'd alternate between the two pho places. Never got tired of either! So I would recommend going to PPQ to try it out.
author: Elbert C.

description:
I remember this place used to be good, years ago.  What happened to it now?  We walked in a rainy day, first time we saw was a soaking wet Disney towel on the floor, being kicked around by the staff to absorb the wetness.  Uh.. gross.  Without a decent waiting area, we stood up close next to a table, and gave out apologetic similes.

Slurping sounds from the tables increased our appetite, we were so looking forward to our table.  Then yay! we got a seat.. on a smelly table.  Either the previous customer spilled the fish sauce, or the staff used a dirty table towel.  The beef bowl #1 was decent, not very tasty, but still nice to have in a cold rainy day.  Imperial rolls were ok with semi-soggy skin.  It was not crunchy and crispy.  Should I blame the wet weather?

And yes, they take credit cards now!
author: Carina N.

description:
When I walk into a pho place, I want to see the cast of Deer Hunter extras sitting around slurping so loud I can barely hold a conversation.  

I also wouldn't mind a couple of flies buzzing around.

What I normally get instead is the cast of Saved by the Bell eating on tables that have been bathed in Purell.

PPQ was ok.  

Nothing spectacular.

It's the clientele that defines most places for me.  

MOW!
author: Archie R.

description:
Standard, solid pho.

Satisfies cravings reliably.

Saturated with meat.

Steady, but not amazing.

Stick with the #1.
author: Andrew M.

description: I decided to come here to try out their pho, since I heard it was reallly good. I tried their beef stew and it was delicious! Although I wished they had more noodles. ITS GOOD. I finished it hella fast, and the food came quick! Good service too and not so crowded. I left the restaurant, full and happy(:
author: Sandy C.

description: the only place that serves curry based pho. omg SO delicious, make sure u get the steak on the side... yumm yummm yumm. and theyre open til ten. minus one star because the lady servers can be kind of bitchy. male servers are usually awesome :) hehe.
author: Mish L.

description: I frickin' wanna cry every time I eat you.  I lub you.  Don't ever leave me.
author: Rachelle P.
