description: I have only been here once and ordered just the Spicy Chicken Curry Pho. So good!! I will certainly return. Can't say I would recommend for groups, or a nice date night, but certainly for a casual night out or take out. Portions are large.
author: Anne K.

description:
We had great Pho and spring rolls! The service was slow but very nice. I had the curry coconut chicken Pho with vermicelli and it was sooooo gooood! I will definitely come again. 

Kevin's noodle house across the street is excellent as well. Way better than having two Starbucks across from one another!!!!
author: Dusty B.

description:
I came here with a friend to some pre-partying grub. At the moment, I was feeling a little bit hungry despite having had dim sum in Fremont not five hours prior.

I ordered the vermicelli with charbroiled bbq pork with spring roll. Pretty good, I mean, you can't screw that up. I make my vermicelli swim in the vinegary orange sauce they give you. I had two like ramekins full infused into my noodles. I read the ingredients in their spring roll filling and was surprised to see there was taro in it too.

The pork was tender and sweet - kinda like Korean galbi.

Maybe I am ignant but I was like: whoa, the server speaks Canto. Which I wasn't expected since most Viet joints I go to are mainly run by Viet folks! Forgive me, I am new to the area!

This place A-OKAY!: :)
author: Ellis L.

description:
New Years Day my friend took us to PPQ for pho to relieve our headaches from the hangover. This place hit the spot.

I had the Spicy Beef Satay pho, which was the perfect amount of heat because I usually add in a lot of sriracha to my pho. I paid $8 for a large, which honestly wasn't that big  -- and a little pricier than most pho places, but I thought the quality of the food was worth it. Their broth is definitely on point compared to most.

My friends ordered the Five Spice Chicken pho and Five Spice Chicken Vermicelli -- which they were both happy with, and between us we split a Charboiled Beef Rice Plate. I don't know how they marinated the beef, but it was SO DELICIOUS. 

My only complaint is our service experience. They automatically serve you hot tea once you're seated, but our waiter didn't even bother to ask if we preferred anything else. On top of that, when we asked for waters all around -- he never came back, so we had to ask another waiter. I'd be a little more understanding if they were busy, but they weren't.
author: Michelle S.

description:
PPQ hook it up with the noodles! I don't know about you guys, some restaurant are SKIMPY. (Minus Lois, because they hoooook it up more than they hook it up here!) 

It's been a long time since I ate here, but I went in on a Wednesday night, and thank goodness it wasn't too crowded. I ordered the usual, Number 5 Medium aka, Spicy Sate Beef.. one word, BOMB. If you love spicy soup, GET THIS! You won't regret it :)
author: Lianne D.

description: Great place at 19th and Irving. The beef and chicken pho is excellent but the Pho Cai Thap Cam seafood veggie pho is most excellent! Don't miss the five spice chicken!
author: Paul O.

description:
This place is average. I was just craving Bun Rieu and when I Yelp'ed it and this place seemed the most convenient to get to. The place looked like any pho restaurant and I had the idea this place would be just like any other one I've been to. Their Bun Rieu(Crab noodle soup) was alright, I feel like you really can't go wrong with it and if it were based on the dish alone I would give them 4 stars. 
The service however was terrible, I was waiting to be served and it took forever, and when they noticed us, they asked us if we ordered yet... Uh no?
The workers seemed really busy walking around but they weren't really doing much at all. After we finished we tried to get the attention of the waiters walking by but no one even looked. I finally got the attention of one of the workers and paid. It's pricier than most pho places, but $20 for 2 people isnt too bad. 
I wouldn't come again since the service here is terrible!
author: Veronica L.

description:
One of my most favorite Vietnamese restaurants in San Francisco.  Like some others have noted, the Five Spice Chicken here is the best you'll find almost anywhere.  The pho is also great.  Love how this place lets you have the option to change the noodles and the soup as well.

They meat that they use here is higher quality than all of the other places around.  It's very tender and has none to very little pieces of meat that are tough and rubbery.  Rice places and Vermicelli are better than the actual pho here, but the pho is still very good.  I go for flat noodles every other time and sometimes go for the curry soup also.  Imperial rolls here are good also.  Five Spice Chicken pho or the Rare Flank and Meatball pho with meat on the side are my 2 usual orders.

As far as the service goes, its very fast and usually pretty good except for these 3 or 4 times (in a row) where I asked for flat noodles but they gave me the regular pho noodles... No biggie I guess because I was in a large group during those occasions.

What I don't like though, is how small this restaurant feels.  They cram so many tables and chairs to fit as many people as possible, that there's hardly any room to walk around without your crotch or butt in someone's face.  Also hate when you wait for a table, and more and more people come in trying to wait right next to you. You end up having 10 people crowding the door, making it impossible to get outside without everyone having to go outside.

All in all, food and location are why I go.  Close to Wonderful Foods if I wanted to get tapioca right after.  Price wise, it's just barely more expensive than Kevin's Noodle House right across the street, but for a reason (because the food tastes better).
author: Kevin K.

description:
Came here with 4 other friends because we were headed to Golden Gate Park, and were starving.  Decided to yelp a place nearby with good reviews, and this came up.

[ATMOSPHERE]  Pretty clean and decent with dark wood tables/chairs

[DINING]  Ordered the #1 on the menu, pho with everything in it.  It came out pretty fast (~5 minutes).  I was expecting more from the place.  The Sriracha was highly watered down.  You could see the oil floating at the top of the broth.  The meat was okay, although a few pieces were still a bit raw.  The noodles were what I really disliked from the dish.  They were still hard and in the shape of a square package! Obviously they just tossed it in for 2 minutes and then brought it out.

[SERVICE]  Basic service, nothing to really complain about.  Gave us water, took our order, promptly delivered.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Date/Time:   Thursday ~9:30pm
Occasion:    Dinner 
Party of:   Four
Ordered:   Bo tai chanh + Bun bo hue & pho dac biet
Location:   Small, pretty typical Asian looking restaurant, clean
Total incl gratuity:   ~$15pp

Craving noodles after checking out Academy of Sciences nightlife.  Opted for this quaint little restaurant open rather late.  Their menu is extensive; worth coming back to check out the other items on the menu.  I was totally craving bun bo hue so I went with it.  The broth was definitely missing something - spice? fish sauce? Not sure but it was not spicy enough nor did I think it was thick enough.  The bo tai chanh, though pricey (about $15) was very good and is highly recommended.  Prices are very reasonable and the service is very quick. I want to return to try their large assortment of unique and tasty sounding noodles.
author: Jess C.

description: Ppq is by far one of the best pho spots in SF. Of course parking is difficult (it's SF) and the interior of the restaurant is no frills circa 1990, but the food and service are both above average. My favorite dish is the spicy curry chicken noodle soup. Spring tools are a great appetizer.
author: Troy H.

description:
Our group made a last minute decision to try something other than the tried-and-true Kevin's and stopped by PPQ.

We started with some spring rolls and egg rolls. The spring rolls were not very flavorful but the egg rolls were awesome. I wish the pho tasted as good as the egg rolls but it was only average. The noodle was a bit on the mushy side and the taste of the beef soup didn't highlight any particular notes.

I would repeat at this restaurant and try another dish other than the pho.
author: Lou T.

description:
My coworker and I came here on a Monday during prime lunch hour. We were lucky and found parking quickly, and we were lucky again because we got seated right away. Five minutes after us, there were no more seats!

The pho is delicious here! :) And the price is good!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I love this place. I always get the 5-spice chicken over vermicelli and the chicken is so moist and flavorful. 

I can eat so much food here but I still feel light and good afterward. Everything tastes great and the service is so quick!

This is THE go-to Pho place in the Sunset. :)
author: Rachel A.

description:
PPQ, you made me do it.
PPQ could have easily got 5 stars from their #7. five spice chicken w/ pho noodle soup. mix a little bit of hot sauce&hoisin sauce& WABAMMM. A 40 minute love affair.

But let me tell you why I subtracted two stars. TODAY DECEMBER 2ND 2009. This was a bad day for you to mess up PPQ, and you did, you did it big time. My boyfriend and I were in a little disagreement, where I was trying to own up&step up&ignore his ass. During this whole process, I was waiting for the damn menu, where was it ? Well.. it wasn't on my table! I finally decided what I wanted to order, just the imperial rolls for me today, please&thank you. That took another long wait. I was practically flagging down the waiters/waitresses too. I understand busy, but explain to me why the people next to us, who arrived later ordered and got their food before we even got our menus..

But that was just today. It was irritating&the only thing I had power doing was making them sound bad on Yelp. But you know what ? I actually like the food here.. ALOT. Thats the supposed 4 stars. If I were to rate based on the service, you'd be a -26. The imperial rolls just weren't hitting the spot today, due to the bickering with the boyfriend. But if it were any day but today, I'd highly recommend a Medium #7 &Imperial rolls. OH and the Lemon Soda         O:)
author: Wendy X.

description:
This will be my first and only ever "Who cares who made the food" post.

anyone who says:
"A Chinese Chef who prepares Vietnamese dishes does not make it authentic"
or
"A Korean Sushi chef will/can not make authentic Japanese food."

You are so crazy. Your country of origin has nothing to do with the authenticity of the culinary culture you choose to represent.

Thank you to anyone who chooses to even try Vietnamese food. and for those, brethren/sisteren(x) who decide to cook up our culture. 
MORE POWER.

... Only 1 of 3 Vietnamese Restaurants in SF i will stand in line for.
for 12.99$ a plate you can devour the Five Spice Chicken.

Be adventurous and order something from the chef's special menu.
Charbroiled pork on a skewer? try it!
Don't forget your Vietnamese Coffee (ask for a togo cup) it will help you with your food coma.
Finally run back to your car, because your meter is running out.
author: kevin h.

description:
mmm. great pho, rice dishes, and vermicelli.
this place would be really amazing with better seating and new tables. the place looks a little old.
but I love this restaurant nonetheless. definitely satisfies the stomach better than Kevin's
author: Isabel L.

description:
Best pho in the city.  I love it with pork and make it spicy.  This is my true "comfort food."

Their boon with imperial rolls is also delicious.

Worth the trip across town. Come early, as this place is packed with locals and foodies and there is often a wait.  I enjoy this for take out also.
author: Andy H.

description:
Whats not to like? Are you hungry? Are you low on cash? Do you want something quick? BAM here you are. Food for the hungry and empty pockets. 

Although, sometimes the food can be salty. Its really random every time I go there. Staff is random too. Sometimes shes happy and sometimes she just want you OUT.
author: Chris L.

description:
This place fills up fassst! We sat down to a half empty restaurant at 1pm this Sunday and by 1:15 it was so packed I hyperventilated. But I guess this is a sign that the food is good, eh?

And it is. Quite good in fact. I ordered the #7, which I believe is a five-spice chicken Pho. I haven't ordered enough pho yet to know when I'm ordering my chicken in the soup or my chicken on a side plate... but this was the side-plate kind and I barely ate it. I was all about the soup and completely forgot about the damn chicken.

The soup itself was perfect though... massive size, hot salty broth, tender noodles and fresh sprouts.

The imperial rolls here are some of the best I've had. Make sure you enjoy them with the lettuce and mint they come with.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Personally I think this is the best Vietnamese food I've ever had. This is my family's go-to place whenever we're craving Vietnamese in the city.

*Note* I have not tried the pho here.

My favorite things here are:
1) The charboiled bbq pork that you can wrap up all by yourself. They give you plenty of rice paper, veggies, and dunking sauce. I loveeeeeeeeeeeeee this stuff! I'm sorry I don't know what it's called, but it's so good!

2) Vietnamese Fried Eggrolls...dah...so good! They give you extra piece of romaine which I like to wrap around the eggrolls which gives it a fresher taste.

3) Chicken salad. Chicken + cabbage + fried garlic + lots of other veggies + the dipping sauce used for the eggroll that's poured over the salad...ahhhh, so fresh and so good. 

They also have this noodle in curry thing that looks really good, that I will NEED to try next time. Man it looks good.

And service is super efficient.


The ONLY down side about this place is that it's hard to find parking in this part of town, so it will delay you to the goods! Be prepared for that.
author: Gail N.

description:
Fast. great meat..grilled.
whole menu is superb. My favourite restaurant in the whole world.
Been coming here for years
Dont go changing.
author: George B.

description:
Can't believe I haven't review this place.

BEST Pho, at least for me. 
I love the Curry chicken noodle soup, U gotta try this one!
Because not all Pho places have curry soup, and even they do, it's hard to find good one. 
The curry noodle soup has thick broth yet not too much.
Portion is good, service is decent. 
Location 5*****
The rice roll is also worth to try.
author: Marlis T.

description:
3.0 Stars

Pho Phu Quoc. Nicknamed PPQ.

You can easily find this place by looking out for the Starbucks on the corner of 19th and Irving.

I came here yesterday for lunch and I'm sad to say it's not as good as I remembered it to be. I might have been spoiled since my last visit after enjoying the Vietnamese restaurants in San Jose though.

For my latest meal, I tried their large Satay Beef Noodle Soup (Pho Sate Bo) for $8.00. This noodle soup dish comes pho noodles and  well done brisket in a spicy satay beef broth. I liked the overall taste of the broth and it wasn't very spicy. I wasn't a big fan of the fatty beef pieces I got in my bowl. The pho noodles were also very clumpy and just didn't have the right texture I was looking for.

What I like about PPQ is how they offer such a great variety of dishes from pho noodle soup to vermicelli/bun bowls to grilled meat rice plates. There is something here for everyone! 

Although it wasn't my best Vietnamese food experience, it is still really good compared to some of the other Vietnamese offerings in San Francisco.
author: Jason H.

description: I ordered the 5 spice chicken pho at the recommendation of a friend who is totally a PPQ-regular. I was sadly disappointed. The beef broth was oily and well the chicken itself tasted like it was pure cartilage pieces. Yuck. I couldn't even finish my soup. Ate the veggies and the noodles and called it a day.  Off to look for better pho options in SF...
author: Erin W.

description:
disclaimer: review only for pho and chicken*****

so i used to come here with my ex cause he loved pho and this place was one of his favorites. Only bad part, as with anything in the sunset district, was the parking. UGH TAKES FOREVER! But anyways, onto the food. 

Pho Dac Biet: basically the pho with all the different types of beef in it. Pretty standard pho. Good broth and tons of meat

Five Spice Chicken: I thought this was really good! I'm a sucker for this type of Vietnamese roasted chicken stuff. It's sort of sweet, the skin is crispy, the chicken is tender. I say this was way better than the beef. It also comes with just plane pho with cilantro if you want some carbs, so I just ate the chicken with the pho. 

Overall, pretty good. I'd come again just for the chicken, not the pho.
author: Amy S.

description:
Not the best pho i've every had, but i'd say it's one of the top choices in the city.

Love their five spices chicken, except that its a bit oily sometimes...
The pho was good too, at least for me :)
Papaya salad...meh~

Best of all...loveeee the vietnamese iced coffee doesn't add excessive sweetened condensed milk and is hella strong which kicks my butt!
author: Shirley H.

description: I was referred to this place by a friend, if you are vegetarian you won't be disappointed, they are alway's busy,everything is really good as the line will attest, though if you want to go they are quick and accomodating, and the prices are great.
author: William P.

description: We had the Curry Chicken Noodle Soup, and the Asparagus Crab Meat Soup. Both were excellent! While my friend found the curry a bit too spicy, it was just right for me. Before ordering this for yourself, you should probably ask your server if they can lower the heat just a little bit. And the crab soup was absolutely delicious. The amount of crab meat they actually put in there was so much, it shocked me. The only reason I gave this place four stars was that our table was little sticky, and it took them forever to give us the bill.
author: Ron Z.

description:
Horrible service. One teabag in the large teapot. Bland flavored soup base along with cold and uncut noodles. Unedible beef that was super hard. Rude staff that demanded someone to move when a family sat down. 

Came here 3 years ago; still the same.
author: Vivian L.

description:
SO had the spicy beef noodle soup (aka bun bo hue).  Broth was good, but they ran out of the rice stick noodle, so the guy suggested egg noodles.  That's like preparing spaghetti with pad thai noodles.  Hehe -- okay, not that bad, but definitely a bit off.

Don't order the crab noodle soup (aka bun rieu).  It's bland and flat.  No chunks of crab floating or fried tofu.  Boo!  Maybe we should have ordered pho, but I was craving a different vietnamese soup.  

Service was good and prompt.  We went back the other night to try the pho, sign said open until 11p, but lady inside was waving her finger "no no no" at us through the window.  Time was 10:30p.  Maybe they ran out of pho, so they closed early *sigh*
author: Jennifer H.

description: The place is consistently good, especially with my fav #24. But we totally ended up sitting at the table right in front of the door, and that SUCKED. Not only are people stumbling around the table, but I felt like a zoo animal and everyone' was starring and surely judging how much I'm into my #24. Geez. Even if you're starved, don't take that table.
author: Natasha P.

description: This place was ok. Came to this spot because my 1st pick is never open between meal times. I always order beef pho to compare with every place I've been. This one ranked in 3 stars because the broth was a bit bland and there wasnt much meat. Other than that the service was fast and polite.
author: Joey M.

description:
This place was pho'king great! I went with the tái again and it was amazing. The broth was probably more what I'm used to, and the meat had obviously been added just before it was served (most of it was still pink). Something interesting to note: the meat was in small strips, almost shreds, which I find I actually prefer since it seems less tough that way.

We also got some spring rolls, which were, as usual, delicious. And they were served with a really crunchy peanut sauce.

Extremely good eatin'. We all left beyond full and eager to go again!
author: Matthew B.

description: Americanized pho... what happen to the big bowls?! i remember when i order a large, i was like what the hell is this?! seem like i need at least two bowls to get food. i rather go across the street to kevin noodle house instead.... taste ok, didn't really blew me away or anything... would i eat here again, not really.... next!
author: JessePanda C.

description:
Um yes. This place is good. Really good. Especially at 10:15pm after Cal Academy on a Thursday. There is a mixture of Asians and non-Asians, so I fit in perfectly. 

The food was good, hot, reasonable, and tasty. I recommend #5 pho, and 5-spiced chicken.
author: Misha F.

description:
Came here my freshman year, this place marked the first place I had pho in the city. Before, this was my go-to place and I LOVED IT.

But as the months went by, I felt that the soup got kind of bland, and the portions were less....not to mention that the prices were increased. Don't get me wrong, I did not say this place was bad. But after trying other pho places, I felt that this place is okay in relation to the very first time I had pho here. The soup base or the noodle portion, may depend on the chef that day, but I just know it could be better.

I use to rant all the time about the pho, because I loved it so much..AND i still do, but I'm just sad the taste changed. 

The imperial rolls are good though, and will always be my fave. The curry chicken pho is good as well, really spicy and flavorful. The rice plates here are always good too and I CANNOT forget about their five spice chicken, nomnomnom to the maxx. 

that's it, happy eating! :)
author: Liberty C.

description: Hmmm love their noodles here! Def the place I go when I'm in the mood for some pho! Curry chicken vermicelli noodle soup is my favorite(:
author: Gerline R.

description:
Sunday at 1 pm, and the place was lousy with bidness.  A lot of Asian people, but I don't know if they were Vietnamese, since this place is in the middle of a heavily Chinese area.  I'm one of those "all look same" kind of people.

I had the Pho, and it was very good.  I got the large bowl, which was like a bathtub filled with soupy noodles.  I was sharing it with someone who is not into spicy food, so I could not spice it up the way I like it.  It was a beautiful day and we found parking very easy, which is hard to do in this neighborhood on a weekend (see the aforementioned "Chinese neighborhood" comment).  The service was decent, though the wait staff seemed none too happy - I guess working on a Sunday does that to you.  Three people, three different plates, and a diet coke, it was $31, plus tip out the door.
author: M. J.

description:
Pho Tai! This is a great place to have lunch or dinner. I come here once a week with my family for lunch. Friends for dinner. It's great! The portions are good size. Services are great, always looking around, just to see if you needs are met for a meal.

This place needs to expand! It's always packed during lunch and dinner.
author: Danny W.

description: Stood there with fellow Yelper, Dave C. waiting to be seated. We saw three open tables. We continued to stand there being ignored again... with these three tables open. After about a 20 minute wait and not even being acknowledged, we went across the street to Kevin's Noodle House.
author: Angela K.

description: My go-to spot for pho.  Always clean, service is always prompt and friendly.  Consistent and delicious!  Imperial rolls are bomb, pho tai pieces of beef are always thinly cut and good quality.  I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.
author: Alicia T.

description: I've been eating at PPQ for years and their curry vermacelli noodle soup has always been my favorite. However, I took the advice of a fellow Yelper this past weekend to order the 5 Spiced Chicken (vs reg. chicken) w/ the curry vermacelli..: and it tasted even better! So if you are reading this, please take my advice and order exactly the same. :)
author: Lana L.

description:
OK, so over the past 15 years, I've probably been to PPQ about 100 times.  I've always touted it as my favorite pho in the city, and I've tried most of the usual suspects.  

So, now that we have kids who are willing and able to try more interesting foods, we took them to PPQ for a little early dinner.  

Got there around 6:30 and got a table right away.  Decor has been cleaned up a bit, but they can use some new tables and chairs.  We ordered both the fresh spring rolls and the Imperial Rolls.  Both were good.  Full porky flavor to the Imperial rolls, albeit a tad greasy.  Standard spring rolls were a little bland, not enough herbs and too much noodles.  

We got he grilled shrimp plate for the Z-man (child 1 aged 6) and the grilled pork for ms. Cheese (child 2 aged 7)  They were straight forward well seasoned and tasty.  The pork was a little under caramelized but the shrimp were yummy.  The particular Jasmine rice they use at PPQ is always a notch above other places and cooked perfectly, which is something most places don't get credit for.  Ms. Cheese commented that it was some of the best rice she's ever had.  (Agreed)

We got a #4 rare beef and meatball pho and a chicken pho.  They forgot to bring the beansprouts/veggies on the side so had to ask.  (Staff at this place has all turned over it seems in the past year).

The meat was scarce and cut in very small pieces - not so nice.  They changed their meatball spec which was down right not good.  The chicken pho was clean and the chicken had a good full chicken flavor.  Overall the pho did not live up to the many enjoyable years of eating here.  I'm giving 4 stars taking into consideration all the many great years of food I've had here, but I hope that they are not slipping.......
author: Aaron N.

description: Great Vietnamese food; mediocre service. I love coming here for a bowl of pho. It's always tasty and a great cure for a hangover. The service, like most Asian restaurants, leaves more to be desired. I'm not a picky eater by any means but I think customer service should always come first. At least greet people when they come in and ask how they are doing. Don't just ask how many and throw menus on the table and walk away. The personality of some of these servers are non-existent. I've been coming here for years and love the food, but hire some people that are actually happy to see you. Put a smile on your face. Don't act like I'm bothering you by coming into your restaurant.
author: Michael S.

description:
I have been here quite a few times. And everytime I go there, it is quite packed. I usually bus it there because driving and parking on Irving St. can get a little crazy. 

The pho tasted pretty decent. The sprouts and basil leaves look fresh and the soup is served nice and hot. After you're done, you'll feel full and warm! And the price is okay, so expect to spend at least $10. 

However, the service is not the best. They want to be quick with the orders and they want people in and out.
author: Ange G.

description: I tried this place for the first time on a late night after studying for finals, and thought I'd order what one of my friends recommended: the coconut curry pho. The first thing I noticed when it was brought to the table was its smell, which was a spicy coconut scent. Every time after I came after the first its spiciness and taste weren't very consistent, but when it was good, it was good. I highly recommend that you order this soup with pho noodles instead of the regular vermicelli!
author: Shannon M.

description: A bit too oily... That goes for the pho and imperial rolls.
author: Wendy R.

description:
Go to place for a hot bowl of pho on a normal San Francisco day! friggin delicious man! if you're not feeling like pho, then get the 5 Spice Chicken, it's not spicy, it's just DELICIOUS!

also if you're feeling adventurous, get the carpaccio! it's really good and if you can't handle it, just stick in in your bowl of pho and let that cook out, extra meat!

great place to eat at! check it out!
author: Jerald B.

description:
Hands down the best Pho I have ever had, and boy have I tried a few.  A friend of mine introduced me to this place on a visit home, and now I make it a point to go at least once every visit.  Even in a district with a number of other Pho places, this one can have a line out the door while other places are empty.  That should tell you everything you need to know.
Anything with the satay broth is my favorite, and even the "small" is huge!  It's not the place to go for anything fancy, but the food is wonderful and the service is really quick and accommodating!
author: Jo P.

description:
Phu Quoc is a triangular island about 50km by 25km off the southern west coast of Vietnam, very close to Cambodia. 

It was popular with the Chinese long ago for its rich seafood supply, especially sea cucumbers, thought by the Chinese to help the libido in old men. The French controled  it when they colonized the rest of Indochine until they were defeated in 1954 at Dien Bien Phu in Laos by Ho Chi MInh. 

The Americans controled it during their Vietnam War, and the Cambodians took it after that., but then the Vietnamese took it back when they defeated the Khmer Rouge and Pol Pot the murderer. 

Now it is a tourist destination with beautiful white sand beaches and hotels, with mostly fisherman and the production if fish sauce. They plan to have an international ariport soon, and build it up as a grand tourist destination to the likes of Phuket, Thailand. 

Perhaps the Chinese influence of the Island carries over to this restaurant, or maybe because it is in San Franciso, but I didn't think it was very Vietnamese. Everyone working there when I ate spoke Cantonese and acted Cantonese, from the waiters, the cooks, and the cashier. 

The Pho Tai Bo Vien (beef noodles soup with rare beef and beef balls) also tasted more Chinese than Vietnamese. The broth  flavor was bland, with out the hints of key Vietnamese ingredients you find in authentic Viet Pho places. 

On the plus side, the Large bowl is very Large, with a lot of noodles., but average or perhaps below average in  quantity of the Tai and Bo Vien beef. 

Another hint of its Chinese influence: all the decorations are Chinese with Chinese writing. Also some of the dish offerings don't seem authentic Viet, more of a mix with Chinese. 

So if you want Chinese-Vietnamese, go here. I think you will probbaly get better Viet food across the street, at Kevin's Noodle House. Nonething but Asians eating over there.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
Being that PPQ (pho not crab) is so popular, I was surprised the pho was so unspectacular. I could tell the broth was a beef broth, but the taste was so mild and I couldn't taste any distinctive pho spices like star anise or cloves. There wasn't much meat and what was there was chewy. 

The com dia (rice dish) was good and I was impressed to see so many other dishes like bun bo hue (Hue spicy beef noodle soup) and bun rieu (tomato crab noodle soup), but not sure they're going to be any good if the pho's no good.
author: Mimi L.

description: After looking on Yelp, I decided to try the Five Spice Chicken rice plate. I expected something amazingly out of the ordinary - but to me it was alright. GOOD, but not mind blowing. I've tried the Bun Bo Hue (Beef Spicy Noodle) soup here also. Out of all the Vietnamese restaurants I've tried in the city (to date), this one has the best bun bo hue. This is my favorite dish that I get in San Jose all the time and nothing in SF usually compares, but I'd say PPQ has potential.
author: Mighty N.

description: PPQ has the best Vietnamese Carpaccio. Their food is consistent. Best to get there by 6pm or you'll have to wait for a table. Their curry noodle soup, charbroil shrimp and beef and the egg loaf are the best items on their menu.
author: Samantha C.

description:
If you're torn between PPQ and Pho Hoa Hiep (Kevin's Noodle House) here are some differences that may help you decide.

Pho Hoa Hiep hands down, has the better tasting Pho broth and spring rolls.  But if all you have is a credit card, you better get some cash down the street at Chase, B of A or Wells Fargo before you come in because Kevin does not accept credit cards.
 
PPQ on the other hand, accepts credit cards. They also have the better Vermicelli dishes, rice plates and the BEST carpaccio in town. However if you're in the mood for Pho, you're better off heading across the street to Kevin's Noodle House.
author: Shirley W.

description: LOVE this place. My most recent trip to this place and I got the Coconut Curry Chicken Pho. Really hit the spot and I love coconut based soups. The chicken was tender and not chewy or dry! I also am a fan of the Five-Spice Chicken Vermicelli. The crispy skin is heavenly. Extra fish sauce please!
author: Angela D.

description: Im writing this as i eat and it is horrile. I came here with my family and will never come back again. The pho ga here is terrible, I asked for a thai tea and the sever asked me back what a thai tea was, even though it was on the menu. The chicken has no flavor. The beef noodle made me almost puke. There was rice in my tea when i poured it. Terrible experience, i do not reccomend it. PS: the paper towel in the bathroom smells like somebody took a dump on it.
author: Brian Z.

description:
Must try the FIVE SPICE CHICKEN with vermicelli (actually its good with anything) 

Imperial rolls are really good here too.

Everytime I go there, that's pretty much all I eat, with the occasional 'try something new' times but I don't remember what I ate.
author: Erica L.

description: Love this place! they bring you some tasty green tea to drink with your meal complementary. I always get the veggie pho which is great in either chicken or curry broth. Very reasonably priced and open late.
author: Ann B.

description:
Good Pho for the price.  The place is a major hole in the wall and not the cleanest place, but it's always busy.  

Offers the usual Vietnamese - pho, bun, rice plates.  Pho is reasonably priced at around 6 for small.  Everything is good but nothing spectacular or stands out here, just the usual pho, rice plates, spring rolls, like all the other places.    

Service is lousy here..... So, sometimes it's hard to leave a tip for being mistreated.
author: Paul K.

description:
This place is now run by Chinese... the broth is VERY BLAND..even more so towards the late night... its obvious they just add more hot water. This place use to good quality beef, now its tough and bland. They put sooooooooo much noodles. Typical Chinese. No Vietnamese in their right mind would come here a second time. WTF?! Never again! Luckily I work in the South Bay and can frequent 
authentic Vietnamese restaurants with my Vietnamese coworkers.  This place BLOWS!!!
author: Demanding T.

description:
I haven't given this place a chance since high school days.....hmmm....about a decade now!! Eeek!

The bf was craving five spice chicken over rice. He first went to google to find a restaurant...I'm like WTF, use YELP!! lol

Anyways, he found PPQ. At first I was a little skeptical of going there because I remember long time ago, I wasn't very impressed with their pho. I can't remember why, but I never went back and none of my friends ever suggested that place, therefore, I wasn't sure if it was a good pick.

After looking at some of the recent reviews from trusty Yelp, I said "sure, let's go!"

When we first walked in, given it was a Friday night, there was a short line for the next available table. That's usually a good sign, it means this place is pretty popping. Especially since there was another Viet restaurant right across the street without a line. MmmMM interesting.

Anywho, we were seated within 10 mins. The bf got his 5 spice chicken, I got the shredded chicken w/veggie pho. We also got fried egg rolls. The food came fairly quickly. I tasted the soup and Yummmy! it was very flavorful and the chicken didn't have the skin on it, which is a super plus!!! There was enough broccoli, buck choy and tofu as the veggie part as well. Bf's 5 spice chicken, and I quote, "This is definitely FIVE spices!!" hahaha He said that because we've tried other places that didn't taste any different from regular salt and peppered chicken. the egg rolls were huge and plentiful. The skin was made of that white rice paper, which is our favorite kind. Delish!!

I want to go back and try their other dishes now. I saw a few tables with the curry chicken pho....that will be my next order!
author: Christina T.

description:
I absolutely love PPQ. I eat there all the time, and never get tired of it.

In my opinion, the dish to get is the Beef Satay Pho. It is extraordinary. So carefully flavored, strongly spiced, and delicious. If you like spicy food, I would recommend the Beef Satay or the Curry Pho. The Bun bowls are also excellent. I would recommend getting one of the more interesting / flavorful dishes rather than just plain old pho, because those are PPQ's strong suit.

I am literally going to eat there right now.
author: Ben C.

description:
I love, love, love this place.  

PPQ provided me with my very first experience with Vietnamese food.  I fell in love at first sight.

The vermicelli noodles are wonderful and for only $7 for essentially two meals, you can't go wrong!  

They offer a great selection of veggie dishes, along with plenty of meat and fish options as well.  Definitely worth the trip to the Outer Sunset.  

Now if I could only find my PPQ equivalent in the Mission...any suggestions?
author: Maddie M.

description: Very busy place in the late evenings. The chicken pho was flavorful but I didn't care for the flat noodles. Overall I would definitely return. In my opinion Yummy Yummy still trumps them.
author: Stanley J.

description: This is a prime spot to get your Pho fix on.  I usually get the Satay bowl, #5 regular.  It has the right amount of spicyness and flavor, good portions.  Prices are excellent, service is fast and efficient.  There can be lines out of the door so take that into account.
author: Ben S.

description:
food: 4/5 (typical viet place)
decor/atmosphere: 3/5 (typical cramp asian place)
service: 5/5

This place has been in business for many years. They used to have a giant cow figurine outside. I've only come here a handful of times over the years. All the dishes are your typical Vietnamese fare with pho, vermacelli, rice plates. I got the pho bowl #1. The pho was served very quick and had great thick broth. I got the medium size and it was enough to make me full. I don't think I will come here often, but it is usually very good when I do come.
author: Cecile S.

description:
Although I love the taste of beef pho, it's just a bit too rich for me, so I've settled on chicken pho as a yummy, healthier (for me) alternative. After eating bowls and bowls and bowls of chicken pho at Vietnamese joints around town, I've settled on PPQ as my favorite. (Mind you, the actual chicken meat that comes in chicken pho isn't very good anywhere, so I usually get veggies or just plain noodles in chicken broth.) 

Unlike some other places, which are big on baby corn and other canned vegetables, the ones you get at PPQ are always fresh and tasty. And if I really want meat, I'll get the delicious five spices chicken pho with chicken broth instead of beef broth. 

I haven't strayed too far from pho on the menu, but the papaya salad with beef is astoundingly good -- a perfect marriage of flavors.

As others have noticed, the service isn't super-friendly, but I've never had anyone be rude to me either. More important to me is having hot, fresh food delivered to my table quickly -- and that always happens here.
author: Val P.

description: It's sad when quality goes down.   I used to come here all the time.  but their Pho has really gotten pretty gross.  overcooked and soggy.  the meat was skimpy and full of tendons, tasted like it was many days old.  I did not take another bite and vowed never to return.    avoid this crap hole.
author: Eli W.

description: Your standard Pho joint. Beware, it gets crowded and was popping at 1pm on a Saturday! The LARGE is LARGE! And also runs about $8. That's it. Pho real.
author: Rachel G.

description: So up until last year I've never tried Pho and in the past year I've problem tried pho at about 10 different restaurants.  I stopped by here for lunch and the waiter suggested the coconut curry pho.  I absolutely loved it.   Something good is going on here.  It was amazing and doesn't even compare to the other 9 places I've tried.  Hands down.  Winner
author: Tim R.

description:
After reading the reviews I came to this place wanting to try everything! So of course my eyes are wayyy bigger than my stomach. For two people we ordered the raw beef salad, imperial rolls, chicken curry (for me), and 5 spice chicken (my fiance), WAY TOO MUCH FOOD! But all so gooood.
Best chicken curry noodle soup, the broth was the right amount of thickness. Other places' soup is too watery. And it was pretty spicy.
The imperial rolls had the type of wrapping I like, they use the rice paper (it's clear). So it has this different chewy crunch. I'm always looking for a place that serve these kind of imperial roll!
Raw beef salad, yummm
I would definitely go back to get my chicken curry noodle soup and imperial roll fix
author: Flavia H.

description:
The raters are right with the service: it's not that great. But what is great are the non-pho noodles and their appetizers.

Stopped in at around 8 for quick dinner with my dad. I ordered my normal #8 chicken curry, large, with pho noodles instead of that vermicelli stuff. It definitely tastes better that way. Sometimes when it comes out I need to ask for more soup b/c they're a little cheap on that. Either that or the pho noodles suck up the soup more and they aren't used to it?

Anyways, the chicken curry pho is always the best. it's pretty spicy, and there's this film of oil on top that you can either eat or siphon off with a spoon (I do either, depending on my mood and current weight). Anyways, the curry and coconut milk broth is always hot, and mixed with their "chicken nuggets" and potatoes, it's a perfect meal for any day of the week. And like the other commenters say, their pho itself isn't the best, but they advertise using Harris Ranch meat, and you can taste the difference. kind of...

i also suggest their imperial rolls and their lemon soda. they literally squeeze the lemon in front of you while they're making the soda, so that's always nice.

The service leaves much to be desired. Sometimes they remember you, sometimes they forget. But if you're going to pay 8 dollars for a bowl of noodles sometimes you really don't care.
author: Derrick C.

description: Always good food, clean and fast service. One of the most authentic and best tasting vietnamese food I had in San Francisco. I love their special grill that comes with rice wrap you wrap yourself, the vermicilli is fresh and superb, their grill meats are delicious and juicy! The wait is minimal and the price is good. He are more casual dinning so no complicated dishes like cube steak or caramalized fis are served here, but their soup dishes are out of this world.
author: lisa s.

description: Decent Pho. One of the few Pho places that doesn't put nasty chicken skin in the soup. Some people might like that, but greasy chicken skin in my soup freaks me out. Good for take out too.
author: Cynthia J.

description:
You only really need to know two words:

Curry Pho.

That is all. Freakin' delicious. Spicy, tasty, perfect in every way.

I can't get around to trying anything else because I can't NOT order the curry pho.

I've been with some people who ordered different and they liked it enough to come back more than once, so it had to have been good.

They can accommodate larger parties (6ish or so?) relatively easy. It's a bustling lively place. Always a wait but never TOO long of one.
author: Sydney T.

description:
I've eaten here maybe 3-4 times.  In the past, I've gotten their pho, vermicelli, and oxtail.  I also ordered entrees and ate here family style with a group of friends before.  I'll admit that the food here is very good.  I liked everything that was ordered and I can't complain about their pho.  That said, I don't think I will step food into PPQ again.  

Their service has been consistently bad.  Not only have they been very slow each time we ate there, but on my last two occasions, they brought the wrong dish to our table. Because we were eating in a group, we ended up having to wait for them to make the dish again so that we could start eating at the same time.  Oh, and when we asked them for water, they completely forgot about it.  The only thing they have over Kevin's Noodle House across the street is that their menu has more of a selection.  But PPQ is also more expensive than most vietnamese restaurants in the Sunset.  Bad service + pricier = no thanks!
author: Tyler C.

description:
Sometimes I wonder about writing a review of a restaurant that has 486 (now 487) reviews, but then, it is in my hood, so I feel the need.  
PPQ is a totally utilitarian Vietnamese noodle joint.  There is little to none ambiance, but it really is unnecessary.  Why do you need ambiance, when you just want to go in there, get yourself a big bowl of meaty noodle soup, slurp them up and leave?  And the soup is tasty.  Just what you need on a cold night - or really any night.  Gotta love PPQ.
author: Cami B.

description:
So I came here after seeing Rachael Ray eat Vietnamese rice paper "burritos" in Maui on $40 a Day (when she was just slightly less annoying).  The dish I had was exactly as I had imagined and saw on TV. I forget the actual name, but you build your own roll with rice paper, bean sprouts, mint leaves, carrots, chicken, etc. and dip it in a delicious spicy sauce. It's one of the pricier dishes, but last time I checked it was still just $11.

I have since become a vegetarian, so I just eat the vegetable pho, which is still delish (love it with the hot sauce)--a great semi-late night snack.

The place is far from fancy, but it's a great place to pop into on an off-night for some filling noodles.
author: Kym M.

description:
Freezing cold outside, line out the door (or more so huddle of people inside the restaurant waiting for seats), but once I stepped inside and looked at the dishes others ordered...I knew it was going to be good! Small in terms of restaurant size, not recommended for large groups. 

- Spring rolls: A-okay. I've had better. This one mostly consisted of rice noodles, bean sprouts and vegetables, along with a few pieces of shrimp and pork. 

- 5 spice chicken pho w/an extra order of vegetables: The chicken was divine! It reminds me of eating fried quail x 10, because there is more meat and it is flavored really well. The skin is slightly crispy and it comes on the side, so it won't become soggy in your soup. Vegetables included bok choy and a few carrot slices. The soup was a little sweet, but a little squeeze of a lemon wedge did the trick. 

- Chicken curry pho: I tasted a bit of the bf's and this one was spicy! Bursting with flavor and large white meat chicken chunks along with potatoes. It was good, but a little too spicy for me. 

-Vietnamese coffee: The condensed milk is included in the strainer. It's super strong and bold. Lesson learned, do not drink late at night! 

The whole time I was eating, I was totally eyeing someone's order of Canh chua(sp?): a traditional Vietnamese sour soup with fish, pineapple slices, and other various vegetables. Bookmarked in my head to order next time!
author: Tracy T.

description: Pho here is good. Quick & easy. The service however is horrible. They don't pay much attention to you or check up on you. You have to flag then down with any needs or to get the bill.
author: Ezmarelda S.

description: This is a dirty little pho place, and not in a good way.
author: Erika C.

description:
Solid Vietnamese noodle shop.  BF tried the PPQ noodle soup-- the beef tendon was definitely the highlight.  Tender and flavorful.  Nicely flavored broth as well.  I had the grilled pork and imperial roll vermicelli-- the pork was delicious and the imperial rolls were also quite good.  Not as dense/flavorful as those at Tu Lan but also not as greasy, so the point might go to PPQ here. 

I'm RARELY in this area but if you are and you're craving some noodles at a reasonable price with a no-frills atmosphere, PPQ is your spot!
author: Kristin P.

description: Food is good. The employees need to be more attentive to their customers though. I was already half-way done with my food when they brought me my soda. Grrrrr
author: Carla F.

description:
Best fresh ingredients of any Vietnamese place I've been to in SF.  Clean and located on the sunny side of Irving.  The bun (cool rice noodle dish) and five spiced chicken pho blows away the competition.  My personal favorite is the grilled pork and imperial rolls bun.  BUT Kevin's Noodle House beef broth is a tad bit better in my opinion.  Sorry PPQ.  Again, the ingredients (plate of veggies for your soup) are still fresher than anyplace I've been to, which really makes a difference.  The ice coffee is the best too.  

The beef pho is pretty good.  Not as many variations as Kevin's, but there's still a decent spread.  Bottom line: I'm a fan of both noodle houses.  When I want bun, I go to PPQ; when I want pho, I go to Kevin's.  

The dining room can be a tight fit for more than two people at any table.  I've seen groups of eight squeeze in.  The staff always seems willing to accommodate whatever the request.
author: Stephen F.

description:
Two words: Satay Pho.

If you don't know what that is, Satay Pho is the greatest meal you can find in a bowl. Sometimes I think that I can eat it all day, everyday and just bathe in a spicy, soupy wonderland. My apologies for the visual.
author: Genevieve W.

description:
Passable Pho Quiz (=P.P.Q.)

1. Does the place have pho on the menu? 
2. Is interior decoration lacking?
3. Is there a stash of spoons, chopsticks, and napkins at the table for you to get on an as-needed basis?
4. Do you order by number because you can't pronounce the item (and the wait staff has to look at the menu to recall the number when you order by the item's name)?
5. Is the restaurant run by Chinese people?**Validity in trial stages of research.**

If you answered "yes" to all of the above questions, you may be in a passable pho place. What does that mean? It means that for those who don't know any better (such as myself), the food is decent but you have no idea whether it's authentic VIetnamese food. The fact that PPQ is run by Chinese people and has a largely non-Vietnamese customer base may indicate the food has a Chinese twist. But again I wouldn't know since I also like Slanted Door, which probably also isn't the most authentic Vietnamese you can get in the city. 

All the items I've tried - pho, vermicelli, rice plates - are decent or passable that I'd come back to eat because it's cheap and decent. I wouldn't tout to others that it's the best Vietnamese food I've had though. Oh and you come here to eat and just that. The service is tailored for that function only. You probably won't get refills on your water unless you ask. They service staff isn't rude or anything but you'll only see them initiate contact with you when you're seated to give menus, when you order, when your food comes, and to give you change. Total bill is usually about $10 tops for one entree including tip and tax. Parking is somewhat of a hassle since it's right by a busy intersection. Bring quarters for the meters (and if you're lacking cash since this is a cash only place).
author: Gwen L.

description:
All I have to say is 5 spice chicken. 

It is the best here. Every once in awhile, I'll have a hankering for their 5 spice chicken. It is so good. I get it with vermicelli noodles, but you can get it with rice or with noodles in broth. 

I only come here for the 5 spice chicken so I can't really attest to anything else on the menu, but apparently they have several other restaurants so they must be doing something right. 

Thinking about it now makes me want to get a bowl. mmmm yum.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Pros:
It's cheap.
Open relatively late.

Cons:
Miserable waiters. And that is considering the typically offhanded service you get in Pho places of the type. Maybe because it was late...?
Pho tasted like the cook washed his socks in. Table next to ours was thinking the same thing. Heh. Dump a lot of lemon in there. It covers the taste. 

If you are in that area and there is ABSOLUTELY nothing else open, walk in. Otherwise, rethink.
author: Ivo P.

description: Seriously, look for this on the menu: Pho noodles with five spice chicken. I come here only for this b/c the chicken is out of this world!! Slightly crispy with explosive flavor, served with a bowl of yummy pho noodles.
author: K. N.

description:
These are my go to pho soups when I go to PPQ:

Beef stew pho noodles   
Curry chicken pho noodles    
Pho Dac Biet Beef noodles
author: Peachie Y.

description:
So I came back a second time because my friend kept saying that this place is good. 

The Pho noodles were cooked all the way this time, but the soup was really bland. 

I don't think I would come back here again unless my friend really wanted to come here to eat.
author: Tina T.

description:
Went last Tuesday night, had the spring rolls, the spicy pho, and 5 spice chicken over rice.  The spicy pho was ok, didn't finish the bowl. The broth was a bit bland.  The 5 spice chix was good, and wished I had more chix.  

Will come back again and try a different pho, and give them another chance.

Really a 3 1/2 Star rating if I could.
author: David D.

description: Only come here for the vermecelli bowls. The pho here is sub par and the bun bo hue is also sub par. The five spice chicken is hit or miss on different days but the grilled pork or beef with spring rolls vermecelli bowls are pretty bomb.
author: Preston L.

description:
Been a fan of his place ever since i was introduced to it 6 years ago. The quality is always the best and i have never been disappointed by anything in this place. Standouts are the coconut curry (not too rich or spicy) the five spice chicken on vermicelli (healthy servings with great flavor) and the raw beef salad. This last dish takes a bit of courage to order and eat at first but is well wroth it. Peanuts and fried garlic top this "Vietnamese carpaccio" that is tasty, juicy, easy to eat, and never has made me sick.

CASH ONLY and good luck finding parking.
author: James T.

description: I clearly remember this place as the restaurant with the painted wooden cow in front! They offer the best five spice chicken pho here and it keeps me coming back for more whenever I'm in the city! Their bbq rice plates aren't bad either, I recommend the beef. I always order the thai tea it is fresh and not made from powder so that's a plus right there. The only thing I don't like is how small the place is, and the long wait lines, but other than that it's a great place. Definitely come try it out, you won't regret it!
author: Alysia W.

description:
This was my second and third experience of Vietnamese food. The first was at Kens in Westlake and I wasnt impressed with the stomach ache that the pho gave me. But I didnt give u!!!. The second time I tried PPQ. I decided to go safe and get the veggie sweet and sour soup. It was not to my liking (pineapple broth eww) but the owner was standing next to our table so I slurped it up with a smile. The third time I went here it was with a lot of coercing. I decided there had to be something  on the menu I would like. My date suggested the Bun bowl.
All I have to say is the bun bowl changed my life. It was indulgent. A happy bowl of explosive flavors- fresh noodles, crunchy veggies and mint leaves, topped with rich crispy egg rolls. I plan on going back here atleast once a week! I love Vietnamese!
author: M K.

description: Found a piece of plastic in my pho. Definitely not coming back for over-priced, average-tasting pho served with a hidden piece of plastic.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Post call, a buddy of mine in residency brought me here to get some grub.  We had the carpaccio and rice plates.  We soon forgot about our stress and lack of sleep.

Years later, I still eat that delicious red meat concoction of fish sauce, mint, and onions.    

The pho is good, though the quality of the broth has changed somewhat.  I recall it being less salty but more aromatic. 
Or, maybe I'm just turning into a grimy old bastard lacking sensitivity to everything around me.  

I am one jaded dude.
author: John L.

description:
I came here with my sweetheart to try the banh hai bo nuong sa (charboiled beef), which he loves, and had apparently eaten a million times.  Well, props to him, he is totally right.  It is super delicious.  It is one of those deals where you dip the ricepaper in water, then fill it up with all the yummy things sitting in front of you, dip it in the fish sauce and eat it up!  Perfectly chargrilled, and they brought us lots more lettuce & mint leaves at our request.   We also got the 5 spice chicken which was ok but didn't blow my mind.  It was actually kind of better later that night when we heated it up for dinner.  I think the spices ran deeper at that point.  

It is a little pricey!  $16.95 for the banh hai.   It was a lot of food though.
author: Sarah S.

description:
We stopped here when we had a change of mine as we were driving to Clement on 19th St. Instead of doing our D&A usual snack, we decided to give PPQ a try. We walked in the restaurant around 10:35PM. Surprisingly, they still serve us. 11 PM was their closing hours. We were sat down with menus. They have a nice varity of typical Vietnamese restaurant, Pho, Vermicelli, Rice Plate, 3 color bean drinks. 

So the waitress took our order, I ordered in Vietnamese. She goes "HUH? Sorry I don't speak vietnamese." So I ordered in English. I don't like restaurant that have no idea how to speak the language, and they serve that ethnic food group. It's unacceptable even if their food is extraordinary good. 

Anyways, we ordered, Bun Bo Hue (you notice that I don't order Pho when it comes to Vietnamese food, because if they know how to make bun bo hue right, they can ace anything on the menu), 5 spices chicken and fried calamari. Fried Calamari was a big disappointment. It was deep fried squid + panko bread and dipping sauce was KETCHUP. Yuck. At least give us something asian, sweet and sour sauce. Bun Bo Hue was okay, and I'll give them props for their 5 spices chicken, but it comes with no veggies at all. Then, we got thirsty, I ordered "Soda Chanh" aka Fresh Lemonade Soda (Squeezed Lemon Juice + Club Soda + Sugar). The waitress goes, I don't understand (UGH! ANNOYED). Then she said, you mean lemon soda. SURE! 

Bill comes to be about $25. Don't get their calamari! I'm generous to give them a 3 stars, their food made up for that 3 stars. I don't think I'm coming back, because their food doesn't stand out from any other Vietnamese restaurant that I've been too. It's not screaming my name, so I'm not coming back.
author: MT D.

description: This place has the BEST spicy pho around (satay beef pho). Bold, i know but this dish alone makes ppq my favorite pho joint.  There other dishes here that are also good like the five spices chicken..rice plate or pho bowl.  Overall a solid four . Note this is not the only place ive had spicy pho. Fact. I purposely order spicy pho where ever i eat Vietnamese food to see if it tops PPQ..its been over 5 years and i havent found one yet.
author: Chris O.

description:
After getting wasted on NYE, leaving my car in SF, and having to BART back to SF to get my car, not to mention the terrible hangover, I needed some comfort. So as I was driving back to 101 on 19th Ave, I took a right onto Irving and stopped here for some of their fabulous 5 spice chicken noodle soup. The chicken has never changed and it's always perfectly crispy, perfectly moist, and perfectly spiced. 

Let's just say this dish was a miracle cure for me, and I sure needed it!
author: Derrick V.

description:
I came here tonight after a long hiatus from PPQ.  The food was just as flavorful and fulfilling as I've remembered.  We started with the imperial rolls - fried sticks of awesomeness served with two slices of cucumber, mint leaves, and the smelly but tasty fish sauce.  I followed that with the bbq pork, pork shreds and egg over rice.  I also sampled some of the five spice chicken - which was as always the tastiest chicken in the city.  My sampling fork also stole an extra imperial roll from my brother's bbq pork and imperial roll vermicelli.  

Did you know??? Along with PPQ Dungenous Crab, they are owned/affiliated with Perilla (FiDi) and Toasties (Irving/9th and West Portal). NO WAYYY!!!
author: Dennis L.

description:
What the PHO?

On a foggy day, there is nothing better than curry noodle soup ($7).  Food stimulates and heals, so seeking for something spicy the curry noodle delivered.

With sweet on my forehead from spicy flavors, I chattered with my college friends.  After graduating from CAL almost 10 years ago, we have not aged.

"It's because we're Asians" my friend said.
 
I think its because the food I eat. Well, that's half the truth.
Ever date Asian girls? They spend half of their salary making themselves look good. 

Here's their menu

$75 monthly facials
$300 LV purses
$150 eating foods that have rumored to "heal the body"

including

$25 turtle soup
$75 tiger penis soup
$50 bird nest soup

$100 on plastic surgery

"with Pho noodles please"

Arriving in a golden colored, a sea of tender chicken meat and a few random chunks of potatoes bathes in a spicy yet tame soup.

A squeeze of lemon added a refreshing tart tingle.

Infused with a few drizzles of chili oil, the dish hits the spot.  Sliced green peppers added more heat.  Sprouts tend to lower the temperature of the otherwise piping hot soup, so asked for it to be blanched first.  

While American's have their classic diners with jukebox, PPQ brings a sense of nostalgia.  I dined here since high school days when menu items were $5 with my first girl friend.  This is my rendition. No disco music just  slurp! slurp! sounds.

Nothing much has changed.
Food remains consistent while service still nominal.

Expect good consistent food here, but no fanfare.

No exotic waitress greeting "honey, how are you lo today?"

For those who want a more sophisticated setting at the same prices, Bodega Bistro is a great bet in the tenderloin.
author: Rayfil W.

description: I've been here at least 5 times and it's always been an okay experience. The service is alright. The only downside is that they skimp on the toppings. My boyfriend & I both got a number 1 and they only gave us 1 beef ball. I don't know if it's the economy or what, but seriously...that's lame. PPQ is a lot cleaner compared to Kevin's Noodle House. (Or maybe there's just better lighting) But anyways, The only downside of this place is the little amount of toppings. Everything else is just about average.
author: Rebecca T.

description:
I haven't been here for years.  Yesterday, my friend and I could not decide on what to eat and finally decided on pho.  It was too hot for me to get pho so I got an imperial roll with charbroiled pork with vermicelli instead.  

It was ok.  I'd say it just average.  Not very memorable.  The price for the food is higher than it needs to be.  For almost $8 you get two imperial roll and about 3 oz of cooked pork.   I can go to tu-lan and get the same dish for like only $5 plus I get more food.  but I guess it is located in a district where I most likely will not be robbed or stabbed.  

Overall, it is probably not a place I will crave for, but if I am in the area and I want viet food again.... i guess I will go there.
author: Janet S.

description:
This is my number one go-to-pho-spot. My favorite dish right now is the Coconut Milk Curry Chicken w/ flat noodles and a side of fried tofu. Flat noodles give you more for the same price. My #2 is the satay beef.

I wanna give this place a five but i wish their beef stew was better - its not even up to par with the Westlake Pho's beef stew
author: Justin A.

description:
this place has an awesome raw beef dish that you gotta give it a try tho it looks kinda scary ro some ppl they cant stand eating raw meat but with their homemade sour soup with crispy peanut chops and dried onion... this dish is fantastic! but it gets you sated if you eat too much... haha
 
their rice dishes are very delish overall such as pork chop with egg and chicken thigh rice.. pho is good too but not like impressive. 

was their last night giving their bun bo hue a try cuz im looking for the best bun bo hue in san francisco who beats miss saigon! the result was miss saigon's bbh still won!
author: Candy C.

description: The only thing I order here is the curry chicken noodle soup.  I have ordered other items but they are small portion and not worth the money that you pay for.  The grill pork rice plate have very little meat in it.  Very not what I expected.  Stay away from the rolls. But my friend insists that we go here so I have been here for 5 yrs.  Much better food at the other 2 Vietnamese places across the st and down the block.
author: Mar H.

description:
I came here for the first time a few days ago. We arrived around 10:15PM. To my surprise, there were still a lot of people eating.

I ordered the large combination pho. Tasty, huge portions, but the broth could be tastier. The steak slices were VERY tender and delicious.

We also had the imperial rolls. GUSH** They were SO GOOD.You are definitely able to savor every ingredient inside. It consists of some crazy delicious textures and it's definitely out of this world. I've never had an imperial roll this good :)

I'd come back here again when I get the opportunity to. They close at 11 on weekdays! Pretty good since I'm a late muncher.
author: Bonita C.

description:
I managed to finish their large-size noodle soups without feeling overly stuffed; at other pho places, my stomach is usually uncomfortably distended. I ordered their PPQ Beef Noodle Soup (#1 on the menu), which had plenty of meat (rare flank steak, well done brisket, tendon, tripe, beef meatball), while my family tried their Satay Beef (#5) and Seafood Noodle Soups (#6) and Beef Stew Rice Plate. The soups each had a distinct and great flavor: #1 was earthy from the beef broth, #5 leaned toward the sour & spicy, and #6 was sweet. I wouldn't suggest getting the Seafood pho and Beef Stew, for their wasn't much seafood and the stew was average, respectively.

The place can feel cramped but service was cordial and efficient and the setting was adequately clean. I noticed prices on their take-out menu is higher than in their dine-in menu. They accept credit cards, including Discover.
author: Cliff W.

description:
Arguably the best pho/Vietnamese around, especially in the Sunset.

Pho: I usually get #1 which has a whole bunch of beef meats in it. It is absolutely delicious. I also split my devouring of pho with their 5 spice chicken pho. Their five spice chicken is literally the BEST 5 spice chicken pho i've ever had. I have an extremely hard time choosing between these two types of pho.

Plates: If I don't feel like pho (which is rare), I go for the charbroiled pork chop. Mmm... the pork is so tender and has an excellent charbroiled taste to boot. The fish sauce added to the rice and veggies really makes the entire plate YUMMYLICOUS.

Spring rolls: The veggie spring roll is excellent and is my favorite. The shrimp spring roll is also great but I definitely like the veggie roll more.

Drinks: Of course the Heineken is always delicious, but the Thai Iced Tea there is awesome too.

Conclusion: Great place to get Vietnamese food. The only downfall to this place is that it gets super crowded sometimes and it's kind of got that cleaning agent smell. Parking's horrible too.
author: Christina B.

description:
I know for a fact that this place serves their pho differently. So it doesn't surprise me that some people find this place... Not as desirable? lol.
I've been eating here with my family and friends for at least seven to ten years already. It's very decent food. Very quick. Very cheap.
 Their curry chicken pho is amazing. It's just spicy enough to make you warm enough on a cold night! :) And their salads are pretty good as well. My dad loves the green papaya salad! I'm definitely a big fan of their five spice chicken too. 
It's absolutely worth what you're paying for.
author: Susan Y.

description:
Really, really, REALLY good Vietnamese food. You can't go wrong with anything from here, pho, rice plate, or vermicelli. I ordered my usual, the Five Spices Chicken rice plate. My cousin got the same chicken except with vermicelli and Imperial rolls, and my aunts got pho. The food here is inexpensive yet fulfilling and delicious, but who knows how much MSG they use.

The restaurant is getting old and it could use a makeover, but it does its job. There's not much decor inside. The servers are kind of nonexistent, especially if you're sitting in the corner facing the front windows of the restaurant: they're the kind of servers who would give you your first kettle of tea, take your order, and drop off food. Then they just fall off the face of the Earth, and you'll need to get up and walk to the counter to get your check or a box.

In the end this is the best place I've ever encountered for Vietnamese food, and I've been returning here for years. I do wish they would improve their decor and customer service, but if you're ever in the Irving area searching for a bang-for-the-buck place to eat at, PPQ is always a safe bet.
author: Felix C.

description: I really enjoyed the 5-spice chicken and the taste of the curry pho. Yum! I myself ordered the #1 pho (w/ tripe, beef ball, tendon, flank steak, etc) and it was yummy. The beef ball was really dense and good, but there was only 1. Sad face!
author: Trisha T.

description:
Came here with my bf last week....Actually, my bf wanted pho and the place we wanted to go eat ate was actually closed. So we walked down Irving street in search for another Pho shop. We decided to try this place out purely because this place had a longer line. Longer line = better right? 

We ordered a bowl of regular pho which wasn't bad, But the soup wasn't flavorful enough. The chicken curry pho I ordered, basically tasted like a thai chicken curry with the coconut juice, thrown into soup. It was okay, a little oily for my taste tho. The spring rolls we're pretty delicious, although it was nothing spectacular. A small bowl of pho was about 7 bucks, and the spring rolls were about 5-6 bucks. Again, pretty average.

Overall, it was just an alright experience. Nothing special about this place at all. I think the place across the street was a tad bit better in terms of flavor. There's street parking which can be a little hard to find btwn 19th and 20th, so I suggest driving a little further down into irving to park.
author: Betty S.

description: Bear with me here! We got #2, 3, 4 and the five spiced chicken pho. They were all solid, man. They must put magic in that broth-- either that or I was really cold and hungry so anything tasted good. But this is good especially for those cold, rainy days.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
There are a lot of great Vietnamese restaurants in the city, but  PPQ is way better, because PPQ has bomb ass five spices chicken. I don't know what they put in their chicken, but it keeps me coming back for more. i don't think I've ever tried anything else on their menu. The chicken is juicy and tender and perfect with vermicelli noodles. 

Prices: cheap
Staff: fast
You: happy
author: Vanessa W.

description:
This is not a place you go for atmosphere. They have tables, chairs, and recepticles at each tables for grabbing your own set of chopsticks (red, black, or combo!). The location is out of the way (for me) and the parking is something to work for.

But onto the good stuff.

Curry pho. So good. Kind of addictive. Like powdery-substances-from-southeast-asia addictive. Can't find it anywhere else. Can't get it of my mind.

Okay, that's the only thing I've had there (except maybe a thai iced tea).
author: Greenballoon X.

description:
They had a "People love us on Yelp!" sticker on their ghetto window so I kind of expected at least a three star. Bad experience here, especially with the service. I'll start off with the food first. I ordered number 7, the five spiced chicken pho. The chicken was delicious! It was sweet, juicy, and partly crunchy. It was so good and was so complimentary with the pho because the pho was not that great. The pho just lacked flavor. The first taste you can really taste the Saigon cinnamon. But then I don't know...after a while of tasting the soup the flavor dies away. It needs salt.

The service was horrible. Old fobby vietnamese guy totally just walked past my group and I when we were ready to order. He went to go get the checkbook to take our order, but c'mon man at least say something so we don't think you're ignoring us. Not only that, he forgot to put down my aunt's dish so all of our food arrived except hers. Not once did he come by to fill up waters or ask if we needed anything. And you'd think the workers would pay a bit more attention and wonder why one person out of 6 weren't eating. You'd think they would come over and ask.

But eh. It's a ghetto pho place in a ghetto SF area. What can you expect.
author: Megan C.

description:
Mutha $%^&%!!! Son of a $%#$!!!

That's my story, I have tourette's.

[first visit]
As I came upon this entourage of people consuming their hot meals, I wonder why I never came here, limited seating area, especially on the weekends "%^& IT, let's go" 

Infamous amounts of happy people enjoying their mouth watering, slurping swallowing, anti-depressant pho bowl, I have to find out myself   "what's all this hype?" 

Yelling out loudly, "$%^% it, this weather is terrible" in ten decibels higher in normal conversation, patrons start to wonder who is this guy. Thinking to myself, maybe a understanding waitstaff will seat me immediately. I sat in the corner on a table that was hardly used, the one they probably use for prepping (next to the kitchen),unbalance, no fish sauce(gotta have the sauce), hardly any napkins( gotta have more than one napkins, and you know it's always paper thin and while eating your eating pho), and the worst part , no utensils.

"$%^%, I need utensil, I need utensils!" out loud. Thanks to the annoyed couple next aisle, I got me some. 

I don't know about you, but I suffer from OCD, (Obsessive-compulsive disorder) whenever I dine out. Some call it etiquette or sanitary, but I call it OCD. The napkin cleaning machine. The chopsticks. The saucer. The teacup. The plates. Sometimes, the table. 

To concluded my dining experience, I had a great meal. The original number one. Simply delicious, nutritious, and pho-riffic.....

Disclaimer: the story that you just heard is solely for entertainment / dining purposes. It doesn't not reflect any bias/ unbiased relationship to the restaurant. Therefore, a civil suit cannot be claimed.
author: Stanley K.

description:
Met the owner of PPQ on Irving at underdogs 2 weeks ago and he was wondering why I gave him only three stars.  I said I didn't even know you read yelp.  I said that's weird...........I really like your restaurant and I gave toasties and ppq on clement, their sister restaurants, 5 stars.  So I revisited my review and I noticed that I did give him 3 stars. hahaahha  So I guess I have to update my review.

I went there today with one of my workers.  They have a lot of new items on the menu.  I had the large satay beef and my friend had the tomato and crab meat noodle.  I remember back in the day when you order a large bowl of Pho you can actually drown someone in it.  I guess those days are long gone.  

The food is great and quality of meat is excellent.  Service is harsh but quick.  They can probably turn out a bowl of pho in 5 minutes and you can probably be in and out in 1/2 hour.  This is great because metered parking is .25 for every 10 mins.

Again..........we were left looking for more.  The portions have gotten dramatically smaller and the price like any place else have gone up.
author: jason g.

description:
after a long day in the sunshine at dolores park watching the amazing sf mime troupe performance, we took the train to ocean beach for a late pm walk. deep in the cold fog, ocean beach was quite a change of pace, yet so lovely. on our walk home thru ggp, got a little chilled and hungry, so headed out to irving st and found PPQ! 

waited a short while for a table, ordered some pho and pork vermicilli, which arrived super quickly. damn, that is good food!! tender meat balls and steak in a lovely broth warmed our bones and the pork and noodles were equally delicious. fantastic end to a lovely, perfect sf day! do yourself a favor, head into the fog and go to PPQ! you will love it!
author: Stu O.

description: What happened to this place?  It used to be my go-to for Pho but that was many mooncakes again.  Last few times there, I found my soup to be luke warm, spot a hair floating around and the mint leaves were so limp I thought I need to inject it with a shot of liquid viagra.  Wont be returning for a long while if ever.  For better Vietnamese far, head to Yummy Yummy or Y&Y
author: Tom L.

description:
THE Pho is pretty decent for dinner time but definitely not the best tasting one.  Its great just to hit the spot. Dont come here for Lunch though, 3 out of 3 times for lunch pho, the soup was terrible.   The imperial rolls are the best here  because the wrapper they use is different from the usual egg rolls.  THe Rice plates are all pretty good too !  
If in the mood for curry, the coconut curry rice vermicelli is pretty good, but careful, its spicy!

I dont recommend the one across the street because at least this side the pho  still tastes better AND its cleaner.
author: Helen Y.

description: Yum! This was my first Pho experience and I really liked it!  The 5 spice chicken was delicious.  I didn't like the beef pho as much - the meat in it was too fatty for my liking.  However, we will be back for the 5 spice chicken.
author: Christy L.

description:
I still scratch my eyes and thinking of barbecue when I see the sign.
How do you say it?
Pho Phu Quoc!?
So, I say,  
"Poo Poo Kyu" then !?
or,
"Fo Fu cKu".
I can't.
Is anyone knew that a grocery store called,
"Ka Ka Market "
used be on Clement St near by 22nd Avenue.
Well,
So what !
It's just a name.
I love Vietnamese food!
Their rice noodle soup is just awesome.
But,
I have to and I want to go there all by my self,
so I can eat like a fat pig making so much noise.

don't bother me, I'm eating.

Zuru-Zuru-Zuru, Jyuru, Zulu~Zlu~Zlu, ZZ~Z, Zuru-Zuru......ZZ
