One of a happiest moment of my life.
The End.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I love pho! 

My roommate introduced me to PPQ, and I've been coming here for the past 2 years. Its within walking distance from my house, which is good, since parking is really difficult on the weekends. 

For appetizers, we get the Vietnamese carpaccio, cabbage salad with chicken and imperial rolls. I usually alternate between #1(combo beef noodle soup) and #4(rare beef & meatball noodle soup). I always ask for extra limes because I like my soup tangy.....mmmm mmmm goooood. 

Here are some other dishes that I sometimes get: 
-Five spice chicken noodle soup 
-Seafood combo noodle soup 
-Imperial rolls and charbroiled pork vermicelli 
-Charbroiled pork rice plate 

We come here for good, quick eats and to nurse the post-party hangover. There's nothing better than a warm bowl of pho when your head is pounding and you feel like puking your brains out! =) 

A major plus is that they now take credit cards!!! YAY!!!!
author: Patra I.

description:
3.5 - rounded up for being the only good Pho I know of in San Francisco.... thus far.

I have had some amazing Pho down in Little Saigon.  

When craving pho (which is almost always), I want to go there, but living in San Francisco, that is not always feasible.
 
Second best is Santa Clara - -there's some good Pho there.
 
So last year, I said I was wanting Pho, and my friend with no tastebuds said that he knows the BEST Pho place.  (It was this visit that confirmed for me that he absolutely has no taste in food whatsoever.)  
 
Turtle Tower:  http://www.yelp.com/biz/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco#hrid:gDVl0jlJ3NfVapArz7klPg
 
Awful.
Horrible.
Disgusting.  Soggy flat (!!!) noodles in a bowl of bland water, that's what this is.
 
I asked everyone I know, "You know of a good Pho joint?"  Some people told me no such thing existed in SF - and others would again mention Turtle Tower, thereby inducing the gag reflex in me!  Nobody ever gave me an affirmative answer.  
Finally, I gave up.
 
Enter my wonderful friend Kathy who called to have lunch one day last week. 
Given my state that morning, all I wanted was Pho and told her as much.  "I know just where to take you then," she says.  My hero.
 
I threw on a cap, sweats, and in perhaps my most underdressed and plain state EVER, I left my house in my desperation for some soup in my tummy.  "Please God, let this be the real thing.... please, please!"
 
Over the next 100 miles we seemed to travel to get to this location on Irving (read: all the way out in the middle of nowhere of SF) - I thought to myself that this better be worth the $5.09/gallon gas I was blowing to get here.  While my taste in food generally agrees w/ Kathy - - I don't know her taste in pho, so I was getting a bit nervous as my anticipation was building.
 
We finally get there, and while we did score on good parking - - holy smokes, this area is BUSY.  It's like true Chinatown here - and an area of town that I had NEVER visited to date!  
We enter the busy establishment, and it's nearly a full house but we lucked out in getting seats immediately.  We placed our orders almost as soon as we sat down, and within a few minutes, our bowls of Pho were brought out to our table.
 
It looked like a real bowl of Pho.
It smelled like a real bowl of Pho.
It came with the real Pho accompaniments like basil, cilantro, jalapenos and a lemon.
 
Could it be?
 
After pouring in nearly half a bottle of Sriracha in my usual style, I stirred and took a sip of the soup.
 
AT LAST.......... REAL PHO!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
 
Compared to my ideal Pho, PPQ is a bit skimpy on the rare meat and tendon.  The soup is good, though, and the noodles are the real deal.  It was Pho as I knew it and boy, did it hit the spot - - I nearly started tearing up.
 
Thank you, my dearest Kathy, for bringing good Pho back into my life, locally - - - and for a wonderful lunch!
I will be making the 100 mile trip out to Irving Street to hit up PPQ time and again!
author: Grace K.

description:
One of the best Vietnamese places in the city! I love to order #4 large with flat rice noodles. It's my favorite dish. Another really great way to entertain friends from out of town who don't typically have Asian food. 

I also love getting their bbq skewers (1/2 chicken, 1/2 beef). There are six sticks that come with it. They are amaaazing!
author: Jj H.

description: SOOOOO good. Go here every time I come to SF. Best Vietnamese food I have ever had in my life. I wish they had this where I live. Love the shrimp rolls and beef wraps.
author: Emily H.

description:
Someof the worst bowls of pho I've ever had the displeasure of tasting: sickeningly sweet with MSG. The only reason why people go here is the trendy neighborhood: nearly every restaurant review in the Inner Sunset needs to be lowered by a star and a half to balance out the Hipster Factor.

No one here is Vietnamese, even though the menu is. The guy behind the register was Chinese, my waitress was Japanese. I tried ordering in Vietnamese and she was clueless -- if your menu is in French, even if you don't speak French, you should recognize the item on the menu when it's spoken, no?

Nothing but contempt and disgust for this overrated place. If you need pho, go to the huge place across the street -- 10 times better, and they have great Vietnamese curry.
author: Perci N.

description:
The other half and I come here so much that the guy who owns this place has to think we're stalking him.  We also go to his other restaurants Perilla in the city and PPQ on Clement so there's no hiding from us Mr.....buwahahahaha!

It gets busy and there's always a line when we come but we're usually seated within 5-10 minutes.  Parking sucks in this area especially on Sunday's so come with luck and patience.  Here's what we always order from our favorite pho spot:  fried imperial rolls with extra lettuce, a large number 1 (beef broth noodle soup with a variety of meat) and a small number 4 (seafood noodle soup with chicken broth).  After eating each roll with lettuce wrapped around it, slurping down the huge bowls of soup (and blowing our noses several times in between our meals), drinking about 2 pots of tea and a cup of water our bladders are super full BUT we are in pure satisfaction.  

To sum up, we're not stalkers, this place makes us have to urinate and we heart PPQ!
author: Michelle D.

description: yummy imperial rolls and good pho thai...wasn't the best i've had but certainly a contender. I mean it's hard to keep up with the pho of garden grove. But this place has fast turn around which is important when you need to get your pho on. Would certainly stop in again in if I were in the sunset.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Tonight I had my first experience with Pho. Came here with a friend from college I hadn't seen in almost 3 yrs.  Apparently, he lives only a couple of blocks away from me now.  Unfortunately, he works a lot...and is seeing someone.  A friend, he calls her.  Sure!  Ok!  WHATEVER!  In any case, I have no interest in him whatsoever. Seriously!  NONE!!!  AT ALL!!!  We almost killed each other one summer in college when we shared an apartment.  He argued with me about anything and I argued back.  I'm a Taurus and he's a Gemini.  It all makes sense astrologically!  He IS a good friend though...he's always been.  It's just too bad "life" (Jessica*) gets in the way of  you keeping in touch with the people you care about (i.e. sticks her nose where it doesn't belong and nearly destroys a friendship...bitch!).

In any case, we decided to meet up.  He wanted soup.  I wanted to try pho.  I've never had PHO and I wanted it badly!  So we went and it was exactly what I thought it would be.  I had Chicken Curry Vermicelli Noodle; he had some meat noodle pho.  FANTASTIC! 

The servers were fine...very efficient and quick.  The food was out a few minutes after we ordered, which pleased me greatly because I have very little patience and I don't like to wait.  The Pho was warm and filling...a little spicy, but not too much.  

I'll definitely be back.

*Name changed to protect a guilty wench
author: Daniela L.

description: The chicken satay pho and seafood coconut curry is so good. And tofu salad. I only give a three star because the waiters there want you to hurry up and order. And there was a language barrier when I asked for a different type of broth. The waitress made it seem so complex that I just ordered something regular all together. And then she went to her coworker and started talking crap. Then at the end of my meal I found a hair in the soup. The food is good tho and cheap. But the service is definitely not on point.
author: Christina S.

description:
Being Vietnamese, I'm always wary when a non-vietnamese person raves about a vietnamese restaurant.  I've been hearing about PPQ for a few years from all sorts of people, but never from a Vietnamese - enough of a red flag to keep me away.  

But when my sister moved just a few blocks away, we decided to give it a try.  It was a huge, whopper of a disappointment.

We ordered pho and pork and eggroll bun (pho dac biet and bun thit nuong cha gio).  What we got was a bowl of dishwater swill posing as a bowl of pho and the bun came as single rubbery, mass of over-cooked noodles, poor meat, and eggrolls with so much taro, it sucked all the moisture from my mouth.  

While it's hard to give a bad review to a small business that other people obviously love, I just can't recommend this place for quality Vietnamese food.
author: Chi L.

description: The noodle here is horrible. The broth is over salted! Ordered the beef pho and the noodles came out uncooked and the curry pho was good but still on the salty side. Meat portion is horrible.
author: Cain D.

description: The lemongrass pork here is amazing.  Their soups are really great as well.  Best Vietnamese I have ever had and they are really nice.
author: Amy H.

description:
Also known as PPQ, but not to be confused with PPQ Dungeness Island Vietnamese Cuisine on Clement Street!!

Absolutely delicious. Was craving a nice, hot bowl of Pho on Monday and PPQ did not disappoint. I had the small spicy beef bowl (with brisket) and added broccoli to it. It was about $7 and HUGE. The spice was just right, a nice warm heat but not overpowering. It definitely hit the spot. The ambiance is not much to speak of but you go for the FOOD.

Yummy yummy yummy I've got pho in my tummy!
author: Jill M.

description:
It tastes good, but I think they use loads of MSG.  
Heres why: the two passengers in my car fell alseep from PPQ to Russian Hill.  I couldn't fall asleep b/c I was driving but I was parched.  After I parked, I drank a gallon of water, then fell asleep for a few hours.
author: Wakako U.

description:
I love PPQ for one reason: the pho sate bo.  Spicy beef satay pho.  I could eat it every day.  Actually, I go through periods every few months in which I do eat it almost every day.  It's spicy, rich, complex and freaking delicious.  I know there are other places with better flavored regular pho (best I've had is at Pho Tan Hoa in the TL), but I don't care, because I only ever get the pho sate bo.  Imperial rolls are also great here.

Seriously, try the pho sate bo (#5) if you like some spice in your life.  You won't be sorry.
author: Katie M.

description:
If you're looking to dull the biting chill of winter, this is the place to go.  I go to PPQ for its pho (vietnamese noodle soup).  There are 10 different types to choose from.  Most of them have a rich clear broth and rice noodles as the base, to which any combination of the following meats can be added:  Flank stank, brisket, tendon, 5-spice chicken, meatballs, tripe, seafood.  The broth, meat and noodles are quite tasty on their own, but the fun (or phun!) part is doctoring up your bowl with all sorts of goodies.  Waiters bring a plate stacked with bean sprouts, sliced chilis, fragrant thai basil and lemon wedges.  Each table has bottles of Siracha and Hoisin sauce too.    

My only gripe is that the rice noodles sometimes come in one big clump at the bottom of the bowl.  I don't really mind since I'm more of a broth girl.

Another must-order item are the imperial rolls.  They are deep-fried cylinders of tastiness.  Wrap one up in a lettuce leaf with cucumber and  mint.  A perfect combination of hot, cold, savory, sweet, fresh and crunchy.  

The decor is sparse and the servers are efficient.  Prices are cheap and they only take cash.  

While PPQ may not serve authentic Vietnamese cuisine, it definitely satisfies me when I get a hankering for a steaming bowl of soup.  I leave warm, full and ready to brave the cold.
author: Emily L.

description:
The Vermicelli here is the best ive had up here in norcal so far, but the disclaimer coming from me in this statement is that I've only had a vermicelli dish from one other place: Pho Hyunh Hiep 3 over in the Westlake shopping area.

This place seems to be a real crowd pleaser since a lot of people come over here, but one really good dish is the five spice chicken dish.  

The vermicelli I had gotten was the one with an egg roll and five spiced chicken, which freakin delicious.  This place also has the best egg rolls that Ive had up here.  I have nothing, but good stuff to say about this place.  I think this place doesnt have sandwiches though, which would be probably the only weakness that I noticed so far.

Eat here, its yummy!
author: Mark L.

description:
Pho at PPQ??? FAIL!

If I was to duplicate their beef broth at home, it would consist of water, salt, Msg, and some Pho Hoa flavoring packages.  

=(
author: DAVID N.

description: I've been here a few times and it's been good. They are well known for their five spice chicken, a definite must-try. Also, I LOVE their coconut curry. It's found only here. Although outside it may seem like a hole-in-the-wall it's always cracking. There's just days and times that it really gets busy that service falls. But not too big that it ruins your experience. I'd recommend this for those looking for good filling food on a budget.
author: Andre J.

description:
On the third day of Christmas, 
My true love sent to me
Three PPQ dishes
Two Red Devil bands,  http://www.yelp.com/biz/BapzmqIvIth6bwCdFP047Q?hrid=KsZMEA6fPqfQNC3n4XmfQA
And a ticket for a Century movie!  http://www.yelp.com/biz/lRyFL9ujt0GMwTvwRY2JHw?hrid=rEKb2nwguqQLn_5Wa39-Dg



Friend:  The restaurant is on this block.
Me:  Which one?
F:  That one......or that one.....or maybe that one
M:  You just pointed out a Vietnamese restaurant, a Japanese restaurant and Chinese restaurant. Are you saying ALL ASIAN RESTAURANTS LOOK ALIKE???!!
F:  I don't know what it is. BBQ something something.   
M:  Pho Phu Quoc? (pointing to sign)
F:  Yes! That's it!
M:  You don't know Pho Phu Quoc is Vietnamese???

We didn't have to wait long for a table and the service was fast. The Imperial Rolls were good, and I liked the bbq pork better than the 5 Spice Chicken. Lots of bang for the buck.  Don't confuse this place with PPQ Chickenn Noodle House a block away.
author: Teddy B.

description:
I go here all the time becuase it is so delicious and super cheap. I always have to get the shredded pork roll and green papaya salad with beef. 

I brought, my now fiance, Paul W here when we were first dating, right when he was about to give up on me. Not only was he dazzled with my wit and charm, but also my impeccable taste in food. We had a great time together. So this place has a special place in my memories .... :)
author: Karen C.

description:
I love pho, but I don't like it went they don't have veggie or seafood broth options.  Here it is only beef or chicken for broth, even though they have a "veggie and tofu" pho, what is that about?  I had the seafood one, which had a mixture of odd fish balls, shrimp, and something that looked like spam, but was made out of fish (maybe?). 

Also, what is with SF pho places not given free cream puffs for dessert? This is one reason Seattle has better pho.
author: Cara J.

description:
I'd passed by this pho restaurant many times before, but it always seemed so busy, so I would go to the one across the street.  But finally, I got in on a Sunday night, snagging the last table in the restaurant.  Granted it was right by the door, which can get rather drafty, but I had my jacket so it was tolerable, and I knew I got lucky, as a lot of other parties stepped in after I got my table.

After a quick perusal of the menu, I picked the #1 Large.  (duh!)  It came out within about 5 minutes.  I looked at the huge bowl, spotting thin slices of still raw meat atop of the steaming soup.  Somehow I knew this was gonna be good.  I let the meat stay on top, knowing that it would be plenty hot and plenty tender when I got my eat in gear.  And it was nice and tender -- even the pieces of flank, which I'm usually wary of being rather chewy at other pho places.  And the tendon was soft, could slice it with a fork.  

The only possibly 'bad' thing was that I totally underestimated how much noodles they would give me.  I ran out of meat long before I ran out of noodle.  Oh well, lesson learned.  Maybe I should order more meat next time.  Top notch pho for your dollar!
author: Gerald C.

description:
Woah. I was just walking down the hall at work and realized: I was back in Norcal for 2 weeks and didn't make it here to eat the SATAY PHO even ONCE. SATAY PHO!!! HERE!!! (If you can find satay pho anywhere else, tell me and I will buy you lunch. For a week.) I crumpled onto the floor against the wall and emitted a piercing wolf's howl which sputtered into pained whimpering. Colleagues gathered, but alas, I could not be consoled. How could I have made such a gross oversight? How could I have forgotten?! HOW?!?!

The uninvited fog of senility gently rolls over hills on the horizon.
author: Eric P.

description:
PPQ has some nice Pho. Meats are tasty, broth is flavorful, and the noodles are stuff-your-mouth with them good. The service was spot on. No complaints except it's CASH ONLY.

The store itself, has like maybe 15-20 tables and seems to get very crowded at times. If you get a table by the door you can slurp your noodles down and smile at the hungry people waiting to get seated.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I love Pho, but I stay away from the tripe 'cause of the smell and the tendon 'cause I get tired of chewing. Other than that, any part of the cow will do. As an aside, when my friend saw "Tendon," she was bewildered as to why they would serve tempura rice bowls at a Vietnamese joint. :D Good times.

We order and the food arrives almost instantaneously.  To think, I changed my order from normal to large, worried that I wasn't going to get full since I was starving.  Yeah, I was one of those kids at the buffet who loaded their plate but couldn't finish half of it.  Hadn't I learned my lesson!?

Friend: That's a big damn bowl of pho sittin' in front of ya.  
Me: (wipes off sweat from forehead)  Tell me about it.
Friend: Are you sure you're going to finish it?  
Me: ...

I hardly put a dent in it.

Of course I took the leftovers home, but I learned something.  Pho doesn't taste as good the second day after it's congealed in the fridge.

Next time, I'm sticking with the normal size.
author: Manny P.

description:
I always get the same thing: bbq beef w/fried egg over rice and a lumpia-like thing and it's delicious. my friend who is more "daring" adores the pho with rare beef and the chicken w/vermicelli. I tried a piece of her bbq chicken and since I am a whore for crispy chicken skin, I devoured all of it. no bother, she is a gym rat anyway. I see a lot of patrons slurping down the coffee drinks . . . gotta try that the next time. the last time we were here we wound up at the Silver Spur a half block down -- delightful drunkenness after a good meal ! I still don't know how we managed to get home. Madd Mothers, save it, ok.

btw, the restroom at PPQ -- use at your own discretion
author: Prima D.

description:
This is my fav place to get some pho. It's like your typical pho place with good food and not so great service. My fav dish here is not even Vietnamese haha. I love their curry noodles, which is under the pho menu. It is actually served with vermicelli noodles, and is in a brothy curry soup, so its no where near pho. It has white meat chicken and potatoes in it. I actually really enjoy it with pho noodles instead of vermicelli noodles; waaaay better this way. Their Vietnamese chicken salad has a lot of cabbage, less chicken. Their vermicelli with grilled pork and eggrolls is really good. Their pho is good as well.

Cash only boooo :P but pretty normal for a Vietnamese place. and booo for this being a Vietnamese place run by Chinese who can't understand me when I order in Vietnamese. and theyre closed on Sundays.
author: Christine L.

description: I haven't been here in years! Like 13? Still a good pho place and they open till 10pm which is nice.  I forgot if they still had the spicy beef noodle soup that I used to get, but this time I ordered the Bun Rieu (crab and tomato noodle soup).  It was good, but a bit on the oily side.  The noodles were also too over cooked.  Yes, again....don't like over cooked noodles.  Kills the experience for me.  But I like it because its still good and cheap and they give you big portions!
author: Gina S.

description:
A decade ago...damn am i old?...anyway....I used to come here weekly for (1) beef stew over ho fun and (2) five spice chicken over ho fun.  And for some CRAZY reason they stopped making the beef stew!!!!!!!

But...I came here today and it's back!  It's probably been back, but I just haven't gone...and yes, it's still hella good.  And the five spice chicken...its the best in town.  It's a deboned thigh, yes, I hate bones.  I love boneless.  That's the only way meat should be served.

But shoot, when I found out my friends were eating at Roxie...my noodles started not tasting as good....damn it Roxie's....
author: Jenny K.

description:
Absolutely LOVE this place. Try the Vietnamese beef carpaccio) and the Bun Ga Cari (chicken, potatoes, and vermicelli noodles in a spicy coconut milk curry broth) --two excellent dishes you will be hard-pressed to find anywhere else. I never thought I would eat raw beef (marinated) until I came to this place. I find it addictive.

Service can be up and down. Atmosphere is "hole-in-the-wall." Food is divine.

Vietnamese beef carpaccio description from the menu: bo tai chanh. rare, thinly sliced certified angus beef flank marinated in lemon vinaigrette with basil, red onions, peanuts, and fried shallots with jalapeno nuoc mam.
author: Elaine H.

description:
Eat here once. Then come back and try the next thing on the menu. Keep coming back until you've tried everything. Why? Because it's that good. If you want a recommendation, try their five spice chicken. You can't go wrong with the 5 spice chicken...with your rice, your noodle soup or your vermicelli noodle. Their curry chicken noodle soup is also a favorite. On a cold day (abundant out in the sunset) nothing warms you up better than a PPQ noodle soup. Then again, I wouldn't mind sweating in the desert eating a bowl of PPQ's finest. On a warm day, go for the vermicelli noodle bowls. Rice plates are good for any weather. Don't forget to order the imperial rolls; they go well with everything.

Note to J k: The weird guy in the front that's always holding the phone ROCKS!!! Does he really do that? I've never noticed.
author: Tan N.

description:
The curry chicken noodle soup is the best ever. Perfect match for San Francisco weather. Everything is great, but we go to PPQ for the curry chicken noodle soup. The only down side is it's cash only, but the good news is PPQ is inexpensive.

Good news... They now accept credit cards (they have for awhile, but I haven't been on yelp for awhile).
author: Rathena K.

description:
Vermicelli noodles with bbq beef + spring rolls. Plus Lemon Soda. That's it- the only items I order here at PPQ- ever. Why mess with perfection? PPQ Restaurant on Irving has fast service, is relatively clean (for a place you'll spend all of 20 minutes in), and has the best Vietnamese food in NorCal. *shout out to Golden Deli for my LA yelpers (see my review)*

If you're ever in the vicinity of Irving Street, PPQ is the place to eat~ great food, cheap, and fast. What more can ya ask for??
author: Elaine T.

description:
Came here quite a few times. It's a clean place, but the bathroom is single, so that's also a downside. I would definitely rather go here than Kevin's right across the street. There's usually a wait if you go during a busy time. I think that says something. I never had to wait at Kevin's. Other than that, the bathroom's decent. I think Kevin's is cleaner though.

When I came here, I usually get pho. The rice plates aren't amazing. I would rate it below average. Over the summer, I came here with friends. We all ordered the largest size with extra noodles. When I came here again during a weekend off from school, it's been bland. It tasted like noodles with beef in a broth straight from a can or something.

The food here is getting worse and worse, but I would still choose this place over Kevin's. Why? No idea. However, if I was in the area, I would rather get something else. Vietnamese food can wait because it tastes better elsewhere.
author: Glen H.

description:
I live in the neighborhood, so I have been here countless times.
I think I might have eaten here for breakfast, lunch, and dinner... all on different days of course... 

I think Pho has become my new comfort food, and this place makes Pho that fills my tummy just right. I do have to say though, I have really only had Pho here, I haven't tried the other items because I love the Pho so much.  

Here are my favorites:
Spicy Beef Satay
Chicken Curry
Five Spice Chicken is always a safe bet.

A small is all you need and for such a good price.

I have tried other Pho places, but none hit the spot like this.  

Oh yeah.. I was thinking so much about the pho I almost forgot to mention the service.  The people are quick and cordial, food has never taken longer than 10 mins.

.... all this talk makes me want to go here for dinner....
author: Jaclyn O.

description:
Damn good pho!

Pho-shizzle, pho-realz, and pho-tastic!

Broth is excellent!  Clean, clear, and flavorful.  The noodles are cooked to perfection.  Lime, sprouts, and hot peppers only accent what is essentially good already on it's own.  

I always go beef with my pho, so can't really comment on the quality of broth for the chicken, seafood, and veggie options.

Summer rolls - fresh, minty, tasty.

The Bun is also the bomb!
author: Jenn A.

description:
Some of the best pho I have had around the city and at a good price/portion ratio. Robust flavor in the broth which you can tell is well prepared - no pho shortcuts (!) The broth is lighter than almost everywhere else in the city I have eaten pho (how many? Many.), but is very tastey nonetheless. I seem to always get a lot of beef in my pho here which is major plus points. Not a fan of going to places where they give you just a couple slices - I want rare steak all over the place damnit. Check this place out for some quick and easy tasty pho. 

The bun here is also excellent. Both the beef and the pork options for bun are awesome. Better than any place in the neighborhood.
author: Sven S.

description:
PPQ Imperial Rolls, I heart thee!  Dipping you into a sloppy bath of fish sauce, caressing you up in lettuce as I inhale your minty scent -- right before engulfing you whole, letting the hot, moist filling combine with the delicate, crunchy shell to create THE BEST DAMN TASTE ON THE PLANET.  Maybe even the universe.  At this point, picture angels singing and blinding white light filling the sky.  Hot damn!  You are good.

I've been eating here since the 90s.  I never tire of Pho #1 or Charbroiled Pork Vermicelli.  Their clear, light Pho broth is more to my liking.  Most other places make murkier stuff.  Seriously, their Imperial Rolls are in a different league.  It's the batter.  When fried they have a light, pockmarked, airy texture unlike any other.
author: Jason Y.

description: If you enjoy slurping down asian style rice vermicelli noodles in a casual informal setting for south of $10, then PPQ is for You.  A bowl of their signature noodles with beef in beef broth with will set your back $7.75 plus tax, and there is a cheaper bowl for .25 cents less.  This is for the regular sized bowl, which is roughly 8 inches in diameter.  I imagine the large bowl to be a full foot in diameter.  Now be aware that the beef in the soup is in several forms - thin slices of brisket, meatball, cartilage, and tripe.  I personally do not get out of bed for tripe, finding the texture rubbery and the flavor unappealing to my taste buds.  The noodles, on the other hand, are decent, and they give you a generous portion.  My favorite element would be the fresh spearmint leaves, the crisp white sprouts, and the lemon wedge, all of which you add into the bowl at your personal discretion.  Overall a warm and satisfying bowl of noodles.  If you are ailing with a bad cold, this is your ticket to ride, your bowl of health, your cup of tea, your bag!
author: Roland C.

description:
What do you call the first real meal after a serious battle with food poisoning?  CELEBRATION.  That's what I had today.  This morning.  I was their first customer in fact.  But soon after, there followed a terrific, diverse patronage.  

After I came in, this young, fresh-faced young man came in wearing a CCSF sweatshirt.  He sat down an ordered a large something-or-other.  An old, world weary though still spry with his tongue, man came in also and ordered a small bowl of something or other.  And two women with two violent little girls came in too.  Since the women were asian, I couldn't tell to whom the future husband beaters belonged.  

I ordered the pho tai and the imperial rolls.  They did not have a pho tai gan.  Did you hear me?  If I wanted to add tendon, it would have cost me an extra $2.  The Pho tai was already $6.50 for a small, $0.50 more than the Pho tai beef ball.  I asked for the tai on the side.

After an equally tragic accident with some imperial rolls, I applaud the timing that the imperial rolls came out.  Just a few minutes before the soup, but not so long that I lose my patience and burn the roof of my mouth again.  The soup was the right distraction to allow the imperial rolls to cool down from their volcanic heat.

Pho Tai: the beef they served was all in strips.  Long, inch wide strips.  They were marbled too, so it was not too lean.  And there was a decent pile, but it was strips.  Not sheets.  Not good.  As others have said, the broth is not notable.  

Imperial rolls: They skimped on the lettuce.  2 leaves for 3 rolls?  The rolls themselves were delicious!  The photo on this page does not do it justice.  They were big, turgid, juicy, delicious and flavored well.  I think this has the best imperial rolls I've tried.  The wrapper was also extra crunchy and not smooth.  

The waitress was very very nice.  But you can't get full on nice-ness, can you?
author: Christina C.

description:
Dependable. 

This is our neighborhood pho joint.

My bf and I like:
- Five spice chicken pho
- Beef satay noodle soup (spicy)
- Pork vermicelli bowl
- Pho with everything
- Roast duck noodle soup

We go here for late dinners and take-out sometimes.

Pho Hoa Hiep is across the street. I still haven't given that one a try..
author: Kay N.

description:
I'm torn... how to review Pho Phu Quoc.  By "regular" pho standards, PPQ is....eh.  By SF standards, PPQ is awesome.  

For those who know a thing or two about pho, you know that it's better in San Jose, LA, and (drumroll....) Denver!  No joke, the best damn pho is in Denver.  Must have something to do with the cows there.  The portions are huge, the broth is mighty savory, the noodles are perfectly chewy, and the beef is tender, flavorful, and plentiful.  Wait... what am I reviewing again?  PPQ..... ok, back on track. 

I have created my own standards based on awesome-ness:

PPQ

Cleanliness:  Fairly awesome
Service:  Shy of awesome 
Value:  Pretty damn awesome
Location:  Far from awesome... (because it's far, get it?)
Imperial Rolls:  Awesome
Shrimp rolls:  Less than awesome
Pho broth:  Awesomish
Noodles:  Awesomely al dente
Rare flank steak:  Not awesome (rubbery)
Beef balls:  Not awesome (rubbery as well)
Lemon Soda:  The awesomest

Thank you for reading this truly awesome review.
author: Sammi C.

description: Decent Vietnamese food. So many bad Pho joints. But the food here is good, tried Pho and Chicken with Five Spices. Both solid. Service kind of bad, but I suppose it's just one of those places where you get cheap, decent food and have to live with the trade off. Probably 3.5 out of 5 would have been more accurate.
author: W. C.

description: This is a good runner up but their service falls short, or at least it did the two times I've been here. On the plus side the beef was cut thinly just as I like it and it was fresh not brown or discolored. I enjoyed it, but would opt to go across the street to Kevin's because the service was much better. But Sandy's is my personal favorite.
author: M R.

description:
this place is my mom's favorite pho place in sf, she really hates the gaminess of most pho broths, but for some reason she says there is no gaminess, very clean.
and i agree with her, ive tried many pho places and this one is one of the better ones in SF for me too, plus I love their imperial rolls, crispy and potatoy, have a lot of flavor

i will say that their water masters can learn a thing or two about water bending here,
i lived in san diego for 7 years and they got the vietnamese food locked down there, the best pho ive had is in SD, and their water bending (water service) is unquestioned, masters of SF should take a field trip to SD and learn how it is done down there!

3.5 stars
author: Michael K.

description:
I'm not really a Pho expert, but I do love my noodle soups. That's gotta count for something right?

Like Ramen, I think that the key to getting Pho right is the broth. If that is any measure of how you like to rate your Pho... then I'd definitely say hit this place up. 

The broth is nicely seasoned. Not overpowering, but not watery. I rarely find myself squirting more "rooster" sauce and oyster sauce into the bowl. Additionally, the mung beans, jalapeno peppers and mint leaves always look fresh and crisp. 

A definite must try if you like Pho, and a regular spot for anyone brave enough to live in the Sunset district - especially during the Summer (brrrrrr!)
author: Stephanie I.

description:
I can never entirely remember this restaurants name. It's PPQ in my book. 

So I must say this place isn't bad. It's my second alternative to Tu Lan.
The BBQ plates aren't bad, and neither is the Pho. 

Can't really complain....it's like any other Vietnamese/Chinese restaurant. 
Wouldn't say the food or service is spectacular, but mediocre. :) 

I can never figure out if I'm suppose to leave the money on the table or pay up front....I usually bring it up to the register when I'm done eating. 

I'll continue to stop by here, if it's too late to cook dinner. You should too :)
author: Catherine O.

description:
I'm not from SF so when I have pho here, I'm comparing it to LA and San Diego pho standards.

It wasn't up to par.

We read the great reviews and decided to give this place a shot especially after noting it was open late (11pm), but then we realized that everybody that frequents this place is from SF and not from a pho mecca. As Sammi C. said, by SF standards this the pho here is awesome but by regular pho standards, this place is less than average. 

The broth didn't have a depth of flavor. It was almost bland. There was a lot of soup and but they skimp on the meat and veggies. The meat, onions, and cilantro had so much room in the bowl, they could've gone swimming in the pool of broth without hitting each other. 

When I asked for extra onions and cilantro, I got a tiny bowl that contained about a tablespoon of cilantro, green onion, and tiny (TINY) slices of purple onions. Talk about unsatisfying. Maybe they're trying to be authentic with the serving sizes? I heard from a Vietnam native the real bowls of pho in Vietnam are so small you need at least 10 of them to get a real meal. But this is the states. We do pho big here. Big bowls, heaping servings of noodles, bean sprouts and when you ask for more cilantro and onion, you actually get enough for you and even the person next to you, not just enough for a child. 

Needless to say, I was missing pho in San Diego after this meal.
author: Stacy C.

description:
Another great cheap eats on Irving and more pho for your money.  
Can't see why this place is always so busy with other restaurants in the area or the same block for that matter.  After eating here again, I can see why.  The pho, vermicelli bowls, rice plates are all good size portions.
The 5 spice chicken is better than I've eaten at other places, pho seemed decent, and we left fully satisfied. 3.5 stars*  Not the best I've ever had, but if you're looking for a casual quick bite or you're in a rush to get to a show afterwards this place does the trick.
author: Eric Y.

description:
Pho houses are so ubiquitous in the Tenderloin, it's easy to forget what good pho tastes like. You can randomly step into any number of places on Polk or Larkin and get rice sticks in some chicken broth, but if you're looking for some good quality pho, venture to Outer Sunset to experience this classic Vietnamese favorite.

PPQ Beef Noodle House was bustling when we arrived on New Years Day. I'm glad we got there in time to scoop a table. We ordered a large bowl of the pho with beef slices and beef balls. The broth was flavorful and rich. You could tell it wasn't being masked with salt and msg. The beef was very good quality and tender. We also got the vermicelli bowl with Chinese Five Spice Chicken and Imperial Rolls. This one is always one of my favorites and this one definitely lived up to my expectations. Tons to choose from on the menu. Portions are large.
author: Josephine H.

description: I don't know why this place gets a lot of the business when the place across the street tastes much better. I've had okay pho here before, but the last couple of times, the broth has been extremely bland. You would think that they just added water unfortunately.
author: Alton Y.

description:
Solid bowl of pho in the city.  Gotta try the 5-spice chicken.  

Standards are high for this pho connoisseur , and this is about a 4 out of 5 for the pho.  Good rice plates and other standard Vietnamese fair.  You should definitely try the 5-spice chicken.  We looked around the room and saw everybody w/ a plate, and then tasted what all the hype was about.
author: Kenny T.

description:
My fav is NUMBER 5! forgot what it is but it's good... some satay beef noodle soup. I would order my meat on the side sometimes because it's more tender and not as cooked. YUM! 
Side order of the 5 spice chicken, although I think the side order of that piece of chicken is a bit pricey. I think it was like $5.95 for it or $6.95. 
I guess it's okay if you're looking for something around the city. It's actually a very good place because they open later than other pho shops and taste pretty decent. YAy! I'm a fan.. only because my bf and cousin likes coming here so much~ -.-
author: Kady S.

description:
Decent joint for getting your pho or rice bun on...though like Wakako said--loads of MSG.  Do you remember your worst MSG high ever??? 
I do.. http://www.yelp.com/biz/GNjQKG-Satm0HjwpWXWoPQ#hrid:K5EypDV-r9q_OHckXPNJLQ

Service is alright, prices are reasonable though I feel they have become less caring of how clean their tables and presentation of dishes have become (ie- pho is much more greasy than it was 2 years ago).

This is the place to be after having some drinks over at Underdog's and the cha gio here is damn tasty.
author: omar b.

description:
Just deleted my first review of PPQ to write an update.  

Is it possible to just get better and better as time marches on?  Just had some of the 5 spice chicken pho and I don't think it was ever this good!   It was always good stuff here but now it's even better.  Just amazing!  Not too salty, not too bland, you can taste everything they put in there.   The chicken is always crispy.  Add a few green chili pepers for spice and squeeze some lime and DAMN!  Even if the 5 spice chicken is the only  good thing here, it's worth giving 5 stars.

Look across the street and there's an empty pho competitor waiting to go out of business - poor suckas.
author: greg e.

description:
Tried it one time, Pho was only so-so.  Not really enough choices for me, and to go took pho-ever.

Warning: Their meatballs are made out of flubber; man those mophos can bounce!
author: GIR ..

description: I just arrived in town and saw Claudia's review. She was so right! Portions huge, prices great and the curry chicken pho was wonderful. I will tell everyone I know to come.
author: Larry R.

description:
This is our house's favorite spot in the Sunset for pho, especially when one of us is ailing from a cold.  Their portions are huge - it's often difficult to finish a small bowl.  When I get my bowl of rare beef pho, I stir a swirl of Sriracha ("rooster sauce") and Hoisin sauce (the dark-brown slightly sweet sauce in the unmarked squeeze bottles).  A handful of bean sprouts, basil leaves, and a squeeze of lime make it complete.  The shrimp rolls are mouthwatering and very fresh-tasting; they come with a deliciously tangy peanut sauce.

The restaurant has never been less than bustling, and there is little on the walls to dampen the noise level.  Bathrooms are less-than-stellar, but serviceable.  They no longer serve beer, which is a disappointment.  If you like your food spicy, their Thai iced tea cuts the fire very well.  Service works more like hailing a taxi than having someone check on you.  All in all, a solid neighborhood joint, and I look forward to expanding to other dishes in the future!
author: Kate T.

description:
Of the contenders in the recent pho and wonton-a-thon, PPQ is emerging as an easy favorite. Of course, the beloved TK is in a different catagory; I go to PPQ for the classic #1. A large bowl of traditional beef pho with all the boeufy goodness, (rare flank steak, brisket, tripe, beef balls, etc) rice noodles, and the side plate of bean sprouts and jalapenos. They've taken fresh oj off the menu, which is a clear strike against them, especially when I'm hung over. 
The spicy coconut milk chicken curry noodle bowl is also very tasty when you need to deviate from consuming the various innards and random cow bits. 
PPQ gets points for using higher quality ingredients and making decent noodles that aren't super high in msg. They get strikes against them for not being open late night and for the oj business. If I could give them a 3.5, I would.
author: Candice L.

description:
After coming here for Nightlife at the Science Academy we were starving. The other place across the street was closed so we ended up coming here with a few other people.

I love pho long time, but it was uninspired at this joint. I had a large pho tai bo vien (rare steak and meatballs for the gringos) and the only good thing it had was it large bowl filled with nothing but noodles. Let me tell you...the soup was bland and not tasty. The noodles soft, not chewy. And whats up with lemons instead of lime? I had like 4 meatballs and hardly any rare steak. It seriously was way too much noodles and by the time I got like half of it finished my noodles were way beyond soggy. I was just eating to not waste food at this point. Will I repeat? Most likely not.
author: James T.

description:
If you're interested in exploring Vietnamese food beyond Pho, but you don't want to shell out for a French-Vietnamese bistro like Slanted Door, Dragonfly, or even Tao Cafe, PPQ is a good bet.  I came here following the buzz about the Imperial Rolls and Five Spice Chicken.

Both the ambience (there's actually a paint scheme and a skylight!) and the prices elevate this place from the status of "dive" to more of a cafe (though you can take comfort in the fact that it's still cash only).  Imperial Rolls are definitely way better your average egg rolls, though I didn't bother to look up what was actually in them.  I ordered the Five Spice Chicken "rice dish", which to my surprise wasn't a fried rice dish but several large strips of chicken with rice on the side.  It's not particularly spicy but it's very flavorful, cooked with the skin on like an asian duck dish.

Another must-try here is the Vietnamese Iced Coffee.  They bring you out a little contraption in which hot water is dripping through espresso grounds into a cup of sweetened condensed milk.  Then when it's done you pour it yourself into a glass of ice.  Super strong, creamy and sweet...incredibly addicting but far too skimpy on the portions.
author: Wes M.

description:
Solid Pho.

No insulation. So tonight it is 43 degrees, so I wore my coat until we got the pho. but the pho could not be eaten with the restrictiveness of the wool coat so I shed it and was pleased to have my bones warmed with the wonderous broth that is PPQ. Great aromatic experience. I wish mine was a little hotter though. I added the rooster (ha, insert other name for rooster) sauce to the pho and it was great. But i had to use about twice the amount i regularly use. 

Also, kind of a weird place cuz you run into people from high school.
author: Alexander L.

description:
I used to eat here about once a week until I moved South.  This was the local spot that I could depend on for an inexpensive dinner that was always good.  One good thing that makes PPQ a little different than other Vietnamese restaurants is that they use Angus beef in both their Pho and grilled dishes.  Also, another plus about this place is that their pho broth is not oily like other Pho places.  Even without all the oil, the broth is still pretty flavorful.

Some of my favortie dishes to order here are the Beef Pho, 5 spice chicken, sizzling platter beef with lemon grass, and the tender greens or asparagus.  The pork dishes here are also good: bbq pork, grilled pork chop, or that plate with three types of pork: bbq pork, shredded pork, and the steamed egg with pork.
author: Steve D.

description:
OMG. MOST. TERRIBLE. PHO. EVER. I am usually very laid back about whereever I eat, and think that most restaurants taste pretty good. I am also a big fan of pho and honestly can't really remember ever complaining about any pho house I've been to. However, this is the first time that I have been shocked at the quality of this place. How did it even get this many stars on Yelp??? I felt totally tricked because that's what lured me there in the first place.

About the pho: Very very very very bland. I am a huge fan of broth and their broth is probably the worst ever..so bland. Even when I add sriracha sauce, it barely did anything to the taste. Just became water + sriracha sauce. They also totally skimped on every topping. I also asked for them to add tendon, and then they forgot. It took me forever to flag them down to tell them they forgot, and finally they came back with this tiny tiny sauce bowl with like..3 tiny slivers of tendon...in WATER..and it was hard as a carrot. I was so annoyed by this point. My bf's pho tasted equally nasty. For the first time in my life, I left a restaurant barely touching my food. It was that bad. And I was soo disappointed.

Conclusion: Go to Turtle Tower. Their broth never disappoints!!! Or just go to King of Noodle down the street. They never disappoint in portion and quality. Plus, their noodles are hand made.

Ugh..why can't I give this place zero stars??? 1 is way more than they deserve.
author: Annie L.

description: Their dipping sauce that comes with the veggie garden rolls (or is it spring rolls?) is REALLY good.  It's got a little pizzazz to it, mm mmm.  The rolls are great too, light and just the right amount of filling to hold you over until your entree arrives.  My vegetables and tofu with rice was yummy.  Again I got the awesome dipping sauce with it and was very happy.  All in all, this place is ideal for a warm, quick and feel good meal.  And you won't burn a hole in your pocket either =)
author: Swetha G.

description:
Admittedly PPQ has already enough fans, but if you like Vietnamese and rice plates, you should check this place out.

The restaurant is a bit cleaner than most, and the service is pretty solid for a place that pools tips.   Pho broth is tasty and soup sizes are decent for both large and small.   A friend of mine told me once that Pho should be evaluated by how much you don't need to add to the soup, and maybe that is why PPQ has consistently given me a really small bean sprout/mint leaf/lemon/pepper plate for two people getting soup.  Unfortunately, my GF loves bean sprouts, which often leaves me with none.  If you have more than one person ordering Pho, then ask for more of what you want. 

For rice plates, the bbq pork here is one of my favorites.  The five spice chicken is just ok, and here, I like it better in the soup than with rice cause' the 5 spice flavor is not very pronounced.   The fresh spring rolls and imperial rolls are both pretty good.  Not really impressed with the desserts, especially the mango pudding.

Enjoy.  Like I said, this place has many fans, but the line moves fast.  This place is not the absolute best, but quite tasty and worth the wait.
author: Kapeli M.

description: I don't usually like 5 spice on anything, but their 5 spice chicken is an exception.  It  makes the perfect combo with their pho.
author: jane d.

description:
I have many cravings and pho is a frequent one for me.  But PPQ is never the first place that comes to mind when I want it satisfied.  Their rare beef pho comes out quickly and in a fairly big portion if I may add.  However, if the quality of pho is measured by the flavor of its soup, then PPQ's pho is just average at most.

After being persuaded by Gary L., I reluctantly gave it a +1 just because it is one of the better late night pho places opened in the city.
author: Nelson C.

description: Chicken Curry Noodle is to die for! No other places that could make it better than here =)
author: Rachel L.

description:
The 2** is for the Imperial Rolls. Pretty authentic as they actually have taro in the stuffing and actual spring roll skin wrap.
  
Now the BAD:
Curry noodle soup - OMG they used Thai curry paste from the can and threw in some white chicken.  So disappointed as I was craving for some authentic Vietnamese Curry noodle soup.  If I want Thai Curry, I would have gone to a Thai Rest. What a kill joy!! I guess for others who doesn't know the difference then it's mighty fine.
author: Mel T.

description: It's been a while since I wrote, and hadn't been back to PPQ in a long time. I don't know if it's a new item or I just ignored it before, but they have a green papaya salad with BBQ beef that is really fabulous. I stopped in for lunch a few weeks ago and really enjoyed it.
author: Spaulding A.

description:
5 stars for the curry chicken pho. I love it. So deliciously addictive. 

p.s. When I want regular pho I go across the street.
author: Pearl P.

description:
OMG.  I have been coming here for years, I mean years.  I always order the same thing.  Satay beef noodle soup.  It use to automatically come with yellow noodles, but in recent visit, they have been asking me what kind of noodles I would like and I would say yellow.

Now yesterday, the waitress did not ask what kind of noodles I would like so I assume I was getting the yellow.  When it came, it was the white pho kind which I detest.  I nicely ask to switch it out, which she was nice enough to do.  What followed was a screaming scolding session from the back, yelling at the poor girl in mandarin.  It sounded like both cooking ladies in the back just ripped her a new one and it amplified throughout the empty restaurant.  I felt so uncomfortable being there.  

The poor girl came out, in tears, apologized for the wrong noodles and told me to inform the staff in the beginning of wanting yellow noodles.  I asked if she was ok.  She flooded with tears.  The ladies in the back continue to bitch and scream.

I swallowed my food cringing the whole time.  I left the girl a giant tip, apologized and left.  I swear to never go back.  It felt like some third world, uncivilized, inhumane place to be.
author: germaine n.

description:
The best I've found!

get the thing that has the rice paper and you put it together yer self!
author: tyson r.

description:
5 star because the yumminess per dollar is waaaaay above normal here.

My favorite dishes are the green papaya salad with beef and the imperial roll over vermicelli.  Haven't tried the five spice chicken yet, but can't wait to.

Service here is whatevers, and atmosphere is crowded and busy.  Food standing alone is 4 star.  It's all about yums per buck.
author: Paul W.

description:
(3.5 rounded up to 4)

Last night, while waiting to be seated in this cramped restaurant without any standing room, I tried to look for the health inspection paper. It's interesting, this green piece of paper. It appears that many restaurants have it pretty well hidden. To find it is a scavenger hunt. Perhaps this is what they do to keep you entertained while you wait. In this case, the hunt had a clue but no answer. We looked everywhere! The inspection score was nowhere to be found.

We had a party of 8 that eventually grew to 11. Every table was packed and there were a few other people waiting, but they somehow managed to make enough room for all of us to sit down. Wanting to get away from my usual vermicelli dish, I ordered the BEEF STEW with RICE. It was delicious! The beef was tender and flavorful. Attached to each piece of meat are tendon pieces (as there should be, my mom later told me). I am not a fan of tendon, but even without eating about  1/2 of my dish, I was still extremely full. For those of you who are ordering pho, be warned that the SMALL bowl is quite large as is. Most of the guys at my table ordered the small bowl, and it was just right. 

Big portions at tiny prices ($6.95 for my dish). The food came fast. Service is non-existent, but expected. Due to our earlier failure at finding the inspection score card, I was a bit on-guard all through dinner. My eyes scanned the room more frequently than usual as I was nervous about finding a roach or another critter of sorts crawling on the walls. Thankfully, I did not (although that doesn't mean they are not there--i just can't say for sure). 

What I did find was that they were cash only. Good thing it costs less than $10. Otherwise, I may have been ordered to dish washing duties in the kitchen to pay off my meal...or worse, the person who cleans up the restaurant for the next health inspection.
author: Rona J.

description:
PPQ stands for palatable, priceworthy, and quality. 
Good stuff here. 
Service--quality...server readily re-filled our teas and brought us water without asking. A big plus in pho land. 
Food--palatable...have a high standards for their 5 spice chicken and #5 beef satay ..both 5 stars in my book. also their vietnamese capriccio salad is oh so tasty with fresh beef, delectable drizzle, and fried bits garlic and onion.
Fun--Priceworthy, not the nicest atmosphere, but hey you're paying for the homestyle cooking not the luxury seating.
author: Daniella B.

description:
Just like the pho place across the street, i have been coming here way back since the days of 1996 or so.  

The service here is definitely better and the place reminds me more of a real restaurant that other pho places.  I always get the "Charbroiled beef over rice"  I used to call it "CHARMANDER BEEF" back then, since i loved pokemon, but that will be on a different review.  

Its a pretty chill place to eat and the prices arent gonna put you in the poor house.  I mean hey, i go here pretty often still, so that should mean something after all those years.
author: Terence P.

description:
This place is quite tasty - tell tale sign by how it's always packed!

They have so many things on the menu and most of them are pretty good but in my opinion, not that authentic.  You know how if you're good at one thing, you stick to that?  This isn't the case.  It's a little diluted.  You must try since everyone & their mother's been there but then after you've tried it, go across the street to a more authentic pho house.

I know I'm a pho-snob, hence my profile....  With a name like this, I'd go by PPQ too!
author: hung n.

description:
I just went here because Pho Hoa Hiep(my usual stand-by) was closed at 10 on memorial day and this place was open until 11. 

Cons
First off, the service was slow to get our order in. We ordered the vegetable spring rolls which were just plain gross. Instead of the vegetables being fresh(like every other place I've been to) they were cooked into some soggy brown mass then put into a rice paper wrapping. I didn't enjoy the warm rice paper wrapper with the gross flavor of the cooked vegetables. blah.

Pros
The pho was decent...not as good of flavor as pho hoa hiep and the noodles seemed a little over-cooked. My bf ordered the beef rice plate which he enjoyed... the beef had a nice bbq char to it that I could smell across the table. 

I'd probably go back here if I ever run into the same situation again where pho hoa hiep is closed earlier. But I doubt that will happen.
author: Julie M.

description:
I treated my friend here one night, I like this place.
The seafood noodle was good, the seasoning and the way they cooked the seafood is just right.
My friend loved her beef noodle.
I enjoyed the noodle here.
author: Kim L.

description:
Just beginning to write about it makes my mouth water.  Give me a second.

Alright.  So PPQ.   I've been here a couple of times, but after the first two times i've only had #5, the Beef Satay Soup.  Not sure if it's the proper dish name, but that's what it has.  And boy is it delicious!  It's not for the "faint of tongue."  This is one spicy soup!  If you can't handle spicy foods, share a small with someone, taste it from a friend, or just pick up a spoon, run to someone else's table and take a sip, I don't care.  YOU HAVE TO TRY IT.

But that doesnt mean everything else on the menu isnt as delicious.   Their standard seafood pho soup is great, and their 5 spice chicken is one of the best I've ever had.  In terms of Pho, I'd say it's the best on Irving.
author: Andrew T.

description:
I am not well-versed in Pho, having only tried a few places, but I am the queen of the imperial roll vermicelli bowl... and Pho Phu did it up right. C went with the chicken Pho, and doctored it up with the rooster sauce (Sriracha) and I went with the IRVB - both were delicious. We started with veggie spring rolls, which weren't anything to write home about, but certainly fresh and well-rolled.
The nicest thing about the whole place was the family vibe. A Mom and her pig-tailed daughters came in right after us, and waited at a back table for Dad to join them in his UPS uniform, and had a whole system for feeding the little ones Pho.
Only problem with me and the vermicelli bowl is that I feel the need to keep eating and eating, so there was no room for the fried banana and ice cream, but it looked dreamy.

remember - Cash only!
author: Casey W.

description:
Frickin' Grilled Pork Skewers and Veggie Spring rolls to start...and the signature Beef Satay noodle soup (very nicely spicy) aka Soup #5, for my entree...WHAT???!!! My wife had the #1 (Beef steak, tendon & Tripe soup) my son had the chicken in Coconut milk Curry rice plate and my sister had the Coconut milk Curry vermicelli soup. (My younger son is a picky eater, so he smuggled in a slice of pepperoni pizza from across the street @ Irving St. Pizza.)
"PPQ" was definitely all that it was cracked up to be. I loved it! This place gets PACKED for dinner, so be prepared. My only problem was that there were so many damn items on the menu that I wanted to try. I guess that means I have to go back, right? Right.
author: Shannon F.

description:
of course i'm a fan... who is not a fan of certified angus beef?? i have two places for pho... TT and PPQ... TT for pho ga and PPQ for pho tai...

i can't speak for other types of beef noodles that they have on the menu because i tend to never sway away from my norm... when i find something good, i stick to it... because i hate the disappointment of ordering something that taste less than par from my norm... i know... u're wondering, well, how am i gonna discover other good dishes?? that's what friends are for... so they can order something different and i can tasted it!! 

i come here for one thing and one thing only... Pho Tai... basically, rare beef noodle soup... and i always get my beef on the side so i can cook it myself in my soup.  the beef is always sliced into thin strips... and the quality is always the same... tender never chewy... i love it!!  the soup is decent... but gets tastier as i add 3 slices of jalenpeno... the noodle, hmm... it's mostly good... but i came here on Monday and it was kinda clumpy...but still ok... i've had it better on other days.... 

their spring rolls are good too! the wrapping is always fresh... you can tell because it's chewy and not hard!

and... this place taste ultra good on a cold day... or during a hang over!
author: Kelly H.

description:
I was actually quite unimpressed when I got in the place. I heard so many great things yet when I came in all I saw was mediocre. The service was okay, but the food is what really disappointed me. My plate was eh, my friend's pho was boring... the food was just not that great for me.

Maybe I went on an off day, but I was hoping for more.
author: Sonlay V.

description:
I ate here last night.  I was dieing for pho, so that is all I had.  A small #1 no tripe for me, and my hubby had a Large with rare steak, tendon, & beef ball.  Both were really really good and piping hot.  All the ingredients were at peak freshness and rare steak was well marbled beautiful meat.  The broth wasn't as rich as we are used to, but that is just our preference.  

Super satisfying, the broth stayed HOT through the whole meal.  This place looks cleaner than any pho place I've ever been to.  The service was a little slow, but not bad.  This place felt like home.  I'm sure we'll be back here again.
author: Sonya C.

description:
This place was popular on a Saturday night.  It was filled up.  As I often do at pho shops, I had the chicken pho.  The chicken was listed as shredded (as opposed to sliced I guess), which is perhaps why it was tougher to chew than I've had at other pho shops.  Quantity of chicken was a little on the light side.  I prefer pho with the thin banh hoi rice noodle, but my chicken pho is served with the wide flat noodle.  I would rate the chicken pho about average among pho shops I've gone to.

Overall I didn't like the dining experience very much.  The tables are packed closely together.  It felt a bit like dining at a crowded food court.
author: Sun W.

description:
Honestly, forget about their Pho and everything else. Just order the Bun Rieu which at a large bowl around $7.25 is a bit pricey, it's well worth it. Piping hot bowl of vermicelli noodles, a loaf of fried tofu, some 'fancy pork' and crab meat, shrimp paste and egg. it's different, its foreign, it's insanely good. Just be careful and take your time unlike me who dove right in and burned my tongue and roof of mouth from the start. Nevertheless, it's awesome.

Oh and don''t forget their Cha Gio too. Pretty authentic!
author: Derrick L.

description:
5 stars. If I could, I'd give them more.

I come here almost weekly with my sister, getting the same pho dishes that  we are only familiar with. (call us habitual eaters but we like our food) She always gets the satay beef with pho noodles while I request the curry chicken with pho noodles. Absolutely amazing each time and it never fails us. The food is priced hella cheap and decent. And depending when you get to this place and what day, it will get either really crowded or the opposite. Regardless, the owner can get you seats pretty quickly.

Although we always get the same two dishes every time we go there, we have tried the other pho noodles dishes and even those don't fail us. The broth/soup is the best, cleanest, tastiest--really makes a difference when you're eating pho. Trust me: soup is a major thing for pho. If the soup sucks, then the pho is most likely gonna suck too.

Here are some dishes I'd recommend: Five Spice Chicken, Curry Chicken Pho, Satay Beef, the usual steak + flank + tripe combo... yeah.

Service is great, food is cheap (and fast!), and everything else... depends how you want your pho served to you!

Oh yeah, and don't be afraid to request something to go with your pho or however you want your beef steak. They'll be happy to do it for you.
author: Victoria N.

description:
This is a solid pho place. Too bad they have big competition right next  door, Ben and I thought to try this place since Kevin's was almost closing. Rather than be rushed out, we ventured across the street to get our pho grub on. 

The soup has a funny licorcy taste. I cant put my finger down on it but it taste kind of sweet. I didnt like it that much as a broth but the pho overall was very delish. 

We also ordered a curry-coconut chicen dish. HELLA GOOD. It was white meat and they gave us plenty of chicken. Yummm
author: Amy S.

description:
"I keep thinking of that rockin vietnamese place, God! it was just so good.. I just wanna sit there and eat!" my dining partner regularly nostalgizes.
Why you may ask.....

We crept around the corner of that splash of a neighborhood in outer sunset and with relief discovered a small conglomeration of folks waiting outside Pho Phu's door. Fifteen minutes later we were oohing and aahing the menu having a difficult time narrowing our options. With some assistance from our harried waitress we got the:
Pho soup was not exciting, but we were such amateurs we failed to put the pile of crisp veggies in front of us in it.
Summer rolls were fresh, the sauce zesty, delicious.
Green papaya salad was a perfect combination of flavors, yeah we licked the plate.
Curry chicken was delightfully flavorful, tender.
And we had these yummy plum sodas that the manager served with a smile and we couldn't help ordering a second one.

"I keep thinking of that rockin..."
author: Jeremi M.

description:
PPQ is back in my good graces after some recent consistency issues involving their broth flavor and portionings.  The service is always friendly and efficient and they have recently added some cool things to the menu that are really delicious, like the oxtail stew, which is a must have for anyone into oxtail!

Been coming here for a decade and it will remain forever one of my San Francisco standbys.  The #8 -- coconut curry chicken vermicelli soup -- is the most effective hangover, PMS and heartbreak cure I have ever found.  Not sure why but it makes me go weak with endorphins.  Which if you have ever been around me when I have PMS, you would probably want me mainlining on a drip-IV.  Hangovers, I am much more tolerable, just somewhat foggy and lethargic.  The chicken curry clears the fog in my head and over the avenues too.  I will share with you my little secret: you can order it with pho noodles instead of vermicelli for a nice variation on the usual texture & flavor.  The waiters are accustomed to this substitution, so don't worry, they won't look at you funny.  

Other mentionables are the imperial rolls, vegetarian spring rolls and the 5 Spice Chicken, which you can order as a side to your other dishes.  I am not crazy for their pho -- I find the broth lacking and often watered down.  Sometimes it can be good though.  You just have to catch them on the right night.  Speaking of night, my meal is for some reason 8 times better when I eat here at night, compared to lunch.  My curry chicken soup has been fraught with flavor and texture problems when ordered at lunch.  I also find it is more crowded at lunch, especially weekends.

Attention purists: the herb plate a lot of times comes with lemons, not limes.  I know, what a travesty.  Don't ask me why they do this.  That's just how they roll.  Doesn't bother me though... lemon actually goes better with the #8 than lime.  And with #8 on the menu, why order anything else?  So maybe if you are finnicky about having lime in your pho, this might not be the perfect spot for you.

P.S. if you get cold easily, try for a table in the back as it can get a little drafty by the front door.

Conclusion:  a happy return to 4 hot cocks
author: Molasses C.

description:
love it. 

Been going here for about 10 years now. My favorite are the vermicelli noodles. Any of them. i think #'s 12-16 on the menu. They are veerrry reasonably priced, cheap for SF. They are vermicelli noodles with vegetables, charbroiled meat, and some have egg rolls in them too! soo good. Pour some fish sauce on top and BAM! perfect meal right there. I usually have left overs too, which is always nice. For about $8 a bowl, it's one of the best cheap eats in SF. 

I haven't tried many other things. I know the pho is really good because members of my family always get that. I'm not a big fan of pho in general but their pho is quite good.
author: Nicole K.

description: What is better than five spiced chicken?? Five spiced chicken with the skin ON! This place is usually packed on weekends, so expect to wait. Don't be discouraged, just remember that you will be rewarded with a plate/bowl of yumminess for your patience. Anyway, back to the chicken skin. It absorbs the spices like a sponge, then grilled till it's crispy. The chicken always comes out perfectly cooked, juicy and tender. None of that rubber nonsense. Served over a bed of vermicelli, bean sprouts, peanuts, and topped with fish sauce. Mmmm...you salivating yet cuz I sure am. If chicken's not your thang, you won't go wrong with their noodle soups either.
author: Melissa Y.

description: There are alot of good vietnamese restaurants so that's why only 3 stars. I came here alot in high school, to get the rice plates to go for lunch and the vermicelli and spring rolls are pretty good, good fish sauce, not all watered down or sweet, drinks like fresh lemonade are good. interior is exactly what you'd expect in this area and prices to match (unless you order fish or beef which is annoyingly more $, I hate that wtf are prawns really like $2). Also I actually prefer the pho across the street.
author: Lily G.

description: The Chicken Curry Pho makes me happy! So good, I have cravings for it!
author: Pamela v.

description:
I went here years ago, completely forgotten about until my bf reminded me.  I looked over the reviews on yelp and saw that the chicken curry pho would be something good to try.  I ordered a small and was surprised it was about the same size as my friend's large 5-spice chicken pho.  My bf ordered the fried rolls with 5-spice chicken over the noodles.  The curry was good for the first half but a person could really have so much coconut milk.  AND, I only got one potato!  But really, who needs potatoes when you have a bowl full of noodles?  So if you're going to skimp on the potatoes just omit them all together because one is just pathetic.

I'd probably come here again but not before I go to Kevin's across the street.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Went to this pho joint while visiting SF and although it was good, i think i was expecting little more.  maybe that's the reason why i am only giving this place a 3 star rating  (i should seriously consider writing a whitepaper on how expectation can ruin customers/brand experience).

anyway, this place is cleaner than other viet places i have been to and service was about the same as others.  kinda sucked that they closed early and we were rushed to order something quick.
author: Ernie K.

description: Papaya salad is delicious. Pho + flavoring is yummy too.
author: Christina X.

description:
Soup is plain, bean sprouts plate is small, meat combo is not much either.  I could really get some better Pho anywhere else.  The spring roll skin is dry too.

However,  I looked around at the other tables and found some rice plates(Com Dia) look very delicious.  Also, this place is almost always packed everytime I walked by.  I think I will give this place a second try for Com Dia but Pho.
author: Smiley W.

description:
Gave em 3 shots, didn't like anything I ordered here.  

They don't understand it when I order in Vietnamese.  LOL.
author: Dong T.

description:
I'm glad this restaurant is in my neighborhood, especially because I get cravings for curry pho every now and then. The curry pho here is flavorful, spicy, and I like the basil served with it (more so than the basil served at the place across the street). 

The small bowl is actually pretty filling for me, and ridiculously affordable--under $7! By 'filling' I mean: I've worked up an appetite by the end of the day during which I ran 5 miles, and I only had a grapefruit and a small frozen yogurt from Tutti Melon (in retrospect, my frozen yogurt substitute for lunch was a bad idea). 

The five spice chicken is good, not as amazing as the curry pho but still pretty tasty. I also recommend the imperial rolls if you're looking for a greasy, deep-fried appetizer. If not, the spring rolls are a nice healthy (but still yummy) alternative. 

It's always a packed house..that must say something about their food (psst. "Affordable, large portions, and delicious"). Also, for those with a need for speed, the service is quick here. 

Note: It's cash only. BofA is across the street, Wells Fargo is a few blocks down. How convenient!
author: Liz L.

description:
PPQ is one of the best pho places I've come across in the city (probably tied with pho hoa on clement). All sorts of beefy goodness packed in one ginormous bowl.  They have some pretty good quality meat and a flavorful broth. They also provide you with a choice of noodles which is good because i tend to prefer the flat fun noodles.

The one thing that I was disappointed with however was the three color drink. First of all, it was way too beany and instead of those green jelly noodle things, they used clear ones. Also it was a bit too sweet for me. I was also a bit disappointed because I think they overcharged me for my pho. I asked for rare flank and meatball with some tendon. they tacked on a charge for the extra tendon, presumably. but had i just order something else but asked for no tripe, then they probably wouldn't have charged me extra. i was a bit peeved by that. nevertheless, the quality of food was pretty good, and I will definitely go again.
author: Bernie L.

description:
I love the rice plates here. I always prefer to come into PPQ instead of the one across the block because the pho and rice plates taste better here. The service is fast, and the eggrolls are excellent. 

I don't know, there's something about the Vietnamese restaurants deep fried eggrolls that leave an impression on me.
author: Andrew W.

description:
This is for the 5 spice chicken I had to-go. It hit just the right spot with the rice........hmmmm, craving for some just thinking about it.

Their satay beef noodle soup is not bad too.
author: Katie K.

description: My favorite Vietnamese restaurant in the city. Took my parents here and they loved it too (their first experience with Vietnamese food). My fav is the Satay Beef Noodle Soup. Imperial Rolls and Charbroiled Pork Vermicelli, and the 5-spice chicken is great too. Oh, and it's quick and cheap!!! Def a gem.
author: Jason P.

description:
I hesitate to review this place because it has been by favorite Pho shop for a decade but I think the word is out.  They take no reservations in this outstanding local Vietnamese Restaurant so expect a 10-15 minute wait on weekend evenings.  Every item on this menu 9I've tried almost all of them) is outstanding, the service is always fast and efficient, and the prices are the best bargain for the superiority of their authentic tasting Pho.  They are best known for their Five Spice Chicken Pho, although he curry soups are good and the bun dishes are a favorite.  Must try the shrimp rolls or cold vegi rolls.
I tried the Pho Restaurant across the street, the soup had a manky old meat taste.  So go for the Pho shop with the red awning.  The decor is simple but the place is always clean.
author: kim l.

description:
It's cheap, fast Vietnamese food.  Having said that, it is tastier than most and doesn't leave the icky MSG taste in your mouth.

Times visited: 4+
author: Amy L.

description:
I've been coming to PPQ for a long time- almost 7 years. The Pho is not bad. What I usually go there for is the Five Spice Chicken. I don't know any other Vietnamese Restaurant that makes their chicken this way. It looks like Chinese BBQ pork but it tastes like chicken. For $6 you can't go wrong with this meal.

On a cold day, some Pho and Five Spice Chicken,  will warm your stomach and will not clean out your wallet.
author: Bert T.

description:
I've always loved a good bowl of Pho, even though sometimes I could only imagine that the meat may not have come from the most savory of places. This is a great find, its under $7 for a large bowl of the standard beef combination pho (flank, brisket, tripe, tendon, meatballs) and the meat was great (it says they use Angus beef on the menu). I was so pleased with the soup that I think I'll branch out and try some of the other items on the menu.

Also, the servers were friendly and responsive, and substitutions were no hassle at all.
author: Eran C.

description:
PPQ is like the Durant Food Court for the post-college me.   It's cheap, good, reliable and fast.   I like their pho and spring rolls, and usually order their vermicelli with either shrimp, or chicken, or pork and they are all delicious.  Service is really fast, and people seem to eat fast too.  The turnover rate at PPQ is quite amazing, which means you never have to wait long and can be done with your dinner in half an hour.   

I have tried Pho Hoa Hiep II across the street once which made me appreciate PPQ so much more.  Although equally cheap, PHH II's food just wasn't as good as PPQ's.
author: Candice B.

description:
Not really great pho.   The soup was really really bland.

Nor would I say this is "Pho-nomenal."

I'd recommend going to Pho Clement still.
author: Alan T.

description:
Update 2017:
The pho broth here is way better than across the street. We go here now. 

2008:
this place is pretty good but it is a little more expensive for a vietnamese restaurant but it is not the typical whole in the wall. they do have more variety and you do get what you pay for, you can get dishes here like my mom would cook..but if all you want is a bowl of pho, i'd go across the street. rice plates are kind of dinky with the meat but it is good. so if you want a good big cheap meal go across the street but if you want a higher quality meal for about $1-2 more..i'd come here.
author: Linda L.

description:
