I came to the area with a group of friends on the hunt for some good Pho and we were going to go to the place across the street but the wait was far too long. We spotted Pho Phu Quoc and it was a smaller line so why not try it. 

I have only had Pho once before and it was a long time ago but I have to say that this place was pretty delicious. I can't recall what I had but it was tasty and the milk tea with boba was also delicious. 

I hear the place across the street is supposed to be better but I was not complaining about the delicious food already in my belly.
author: sergio a.

description:
NOMNOMNOM! 

I really like this place for their imperial rolls and rice plates. This place has THE BEST IMPERIAL ROLLS! Agh, just thinking about rolling them up in lettuce and dipping them in fish sauce makes me hungry :(

So, I like to call this place the Vietnamese restaurant, Chinese style. Every worker here speaks fluent Chinese and the food has a Chinese-y spark to it. Even then, most of the dishes here are really really good. The pho may not be amazing, and I prefer Kevin's Noodle House (except they have the nastiest hoisin sauce in the world, seriously) for pho over PPQ, but I think this place has got to be the best tasting Viet place on Irving.
author: M J.

description:
If I were a doctor I'd prescribe PPQ. The one on Clement Street is good but this one, near 19th & Irving, will heal what ails you.

Favorites: Sizzling Beef and Cabbage Salad w/ Tofu.
author: Richard S.

description: When I'm craving cheap, easy, soupy comfort food I come here or Pho Hyunh across the street. They have this good curry pho here that's pretty interesting. It's got like a thai coconut curry broth, and if you're in the mood for some thai/vietnamese combo, here you go.
author: Emy s.

description:
Way better than the place across the street! :)
I love Bo Thai Chanh, and they have it almost as good as at The Golden Deer. Their Pho is great, and the service is acceptable.
I did order a noodle dish and was suprised by their being some jellyfish in it, but I like that.
author: Tom S.

description:
Best Pho EVER!

They have this curry vermicelli pho thing that I love and I can't find it anywhere else. I crave this place! I drive over from Berkeley just to eat there.
author: Torrey F.

description:
Why is it so hard to find a good bowl of pho in this town?  Plenty of meat, but I had to add salt to the broth.  

The filling for the egg rolls was a mushy mess.
author: Max F.

description:
the pho broth tastes really bland!

My roommate ordered the com suong nuong through take out. but they gave him grilled pork instead. we didnt realize this until we got home. doh!

service totally sucks here too. the cashier kept on rolling her eyes and ignoring us.
author: Beach L.

description:
You gotta love the fact there are Chinese people running a Pho place.  Usually it's the other way around.  This place is really close to 5 stars, but I haven't been there enough to give it that high of a rating.  

Passing by, if you see empty seats then it is a sign that you are in luck.  This place is usually crazy packed with people grinding down their bowls of Pho.  It seemed that everybody had at least one plate of the house special chicken on their table.  5 spice rubbed, boneless, skin attached, and FRIED make for an awesome piece of protein.  And the great thing is, you can get just a plate of it on the side.  I sampled quite a bit on my maiden visit, including some of the best imperial rolls I've had in a while.  No excess of seafood flavor and the dipping sauce wasn't overwhelmed by bad tasting fish sauce.  

The only thing I didn't like about the place was the wait and the parking fun.  It's always a fun task trying to park in this hood during peak hours.
author: Simon Y.

description:
I once had a free gift certificate to an Applebee's Restaurant, a place I would never have thought to go.  I was surprised when I arrived to find a throng of people waiting to get in the door to sample, what turned out to be, a wide array of pre-fab food.  After my terrible meal, I was (and remain) puzzled by the popularity of the place.  

I am similarly puzzled by the popularity of PPQ.  I have been to this Vietnamese restaurant three times and have always ordered a bowl of pho.  Each time I have been, the experience has been the same-- throngs of people, dead average food.  I usually order beef pho, but decided to try the chicken the last time.  What came was a prodigious bowl of rice boodles bathed in tepid, flavorless broth with a fairly miserly amount of chicken.  In addition, they served the pho with lemon wedges instead of lime.  (On a previous visit, they didn't serve bean sprouts with the pho-- for the uninitiated, imagine getting a big order of those frozen Applebee's fries without ketchup).  

For a bit of perspective, let me just say that PPQ would probably be fine in a place like Kentucky or North Dakota.  But for SF, this place is unacceptably average.
author: Christopher M.

description:
Phantastic Pho, no doubt.  A more generous portion of noodles and meat than most other Vietnamese places in the Sunset for the same price.  The Seafood Combo Pho and the original meat combo pho are excellent.  The Bun is also very good and also comes in a generous portion.

For the price and the food this little gem is definitely worth the hike from time to time.
author: Jed W.

description:
I live in the Inner Sunset and come here quite often for pho.  The food is not too bad, but I don't think it deserves 5 stars rating as many has rated.  To me, it may be 3 to 3.5 stars.  

Not until recently, I have to down grade it to 1 star and add it to my "not to go" list.

I ordered Vermicelli with grilled pork.  This dish serves with fresh mint, carrots, rice papers and other condiments.  As I was preparing to take my first bite, I lifted up a sprig of mint , there it was A GIANT GRAYISH BLACK SLUG sitting on the mint leaf.  Disgusted, but remained calm.  I requested to speak to the manager.  The waiter talked to the bald head guy at the cashier desk, who refused to come to talk to me.  A young waitress from the back came to my table instead.  I showed her the GIANT SLUG.  She gave a gentle shriek and threw the mint away.  Talked to the Bald Guy, came back to ask me if I want another piece of mint.  OF COURSE NOT!!! I didn't want to pay the slug infested meal.  Unfortunately, my friends had to pay for theirs.  We were so disgusted the cleanliness and the way they handled the situation, we've stop going PPQ.
author: Gelato G.

description:
It's really hard to find a good pho place in the city.   Many times the stock is rather bland, poor beef taste or just plain salty.  I've been to this restaurant about 5 times now and for the most part the soup stock was very tasty but the most recent visit (about 1 week ago) the stock was watery and had no taste at all.  For this reason I'm taking away one of the stars.  The portions are rather generous and the small pho is more than enough noodles for me.  

The hot sauce in a ketchup plastic container is very tasty (you must request this from the waiter/waitress).   I'll still go back to this restaurant for  pho and will provide an updated review on the quality of the soup stock.  I hope my last visit was a rare off nite for them.
author: Oscar F.

description:
Let's be honest, the noodles have no taste and the broth that it sits in can't be any more bland.  The place is quite dirty and the ambiance is...well...practically non-existent.  Don't bother, you're better off going to the pho shop across the street.

That is all.
author: Terence K.

description:
This is my friends' go-to place for Vietnamese food. They were somewhat hesitant about taking me here. Perhaps in fear of me ripping apart their favorite Viet restaurant.

No need to fear guys. This place might not be legit Vietnamese, but they do serve decent food. Maybe not the greatest, but not the worst either. Their noodle soups come with way too much noodles. It would be better if they decreased the amount of noodles and increased the amount of meat and other goodies.
author: Victoria N.

description:
OK, I've had Pho pretty much everywhere in the Richmond and tried a few places in the Sunset.  Nothing ever compared to PPQ - my first Pho EVER.

I tried a few items besides Pho, that seabass is to die for, but lately all I've been having is the Coconut Chicken Pho and holy cow it's amazing.

I just can't get enough.  It's spicy, flavorful, chicken-y, noodley, mmmmmmmm

It's seriously the best Pho in the world.
author: Yelena E.

description:
I had a rice plate which was pretty good, but it came out 10-15 minutes after everyone at my table got their food.  Also, it was pretty annoying how one of the workers kept trying to take my plate when I wasn't finished eating yet.
I do recommend getting the imperial rolls.
author: Ace V.

description:
I wouldn't come here to eat regular pho as their non-pho noodle soups definitely take the cake here. 

Curry chicken pho = amazing! I'm from the city but am always away at college and I find myself craving PPQ's curry chicken pho all the freakin time. It has a coconut milk based soup with curry, obviously, and tons of spices. The soup might be a little bit on the spicier side for some people like me but that doesn't stop me. Just ask for more water refills, the service is good. Back to the pho..They throw in chunks of potatoes which are really flavorful and taste like they might've been fried/cooked before being dumped into the soup. REALLY TASTY! The chicken in it is just right, not too soft, not too dry. I recommend it with pho noodles as opposed to the usual vermicelli. My only complaint about this dish is the layer of oil that sits on top of the broth. I diligently scoop it off with a spoon everytime though so it's no biggie. 

I also recommend: 
- 5 spice chicken over rice
- beef stew soup with flat noodles
- vietnamese chicken salad 
You won't be disappointed!
I want to try a lot of their dishes sound really good but I usually walk in with a curry chicken pho craving so I'll wait til my cravings settle to try those.

Their dessert drinks are also the best I've had at any Vietnamese restaurant. Try the 3-color drink or red bean ice! =]

Quality here is good and really consistent. Prices are really good, too. Today, we ordered two larges and two smalls (a small can definitely fill you up and then some) and the total came out to just $30 including tax. The restaurant can get really cramped when it's busy though. 

4.5 stars
author: Helen L.

description:
3 words... CHEAP.... GOOD... SATISFYING... 

Seafood Pho please!  I love this place... large portions... pretty healthy... fast service.  Great if your on a budget....
author: Jenn Y.

description: I had better pho than this. I had pretty high expectations when trying this place for the first time but it failed to satisfy me. The pho came quickly but it lacked meat.  The beef soup base was nothing to rant about.  affordable but not something to full you up
author: Ann L.

description: I really enjoy this place! I usually switch off between Kevin's and PPQ, which are across the street from each other. The beef at PPQ is usually better seasoned and sliced thinner, and the broth is slightly different. I usually order the same thing at both restaurants - the Pho Tai. However, I recently had the friend calamari and was pleasantly surprised. It's not your typical calamari, more like cuttlefish coated with a thin layer of batter. Loved it!
author: D C.

description:
I'm currently addicted to Pho and anything Vietnamese. It's been my obsession for the past 6 months or so, and it doesn't seem to be ending anytime soon. Last weekend was Outside Lands, which basically gave me an excuse to eat here again since I don't regularly hang in this neighborhood. My friend and I didn't eat all day and got here hungry at about 7pm.
I've always liked the imperial rolls and spring rolls here (not as much as Tu Lan), and the Pho is excellent every time, with high-quality meat that isn't too greasy. The basil and bean sprouts are always fresh, and the atmosphere is relaxed and casual, even when it's crowded. I'm willing to try things like tendon and tripe and shrimp here because the quality is consistent - Pho Phu Quoc has earned my trust (it's not really that hard to, put i like to put up a little fight). 

My only complaint is that the prices are a little above what I like to spend. When I go to Tu Lan, it's about $10-12 max with a drink, here you're looking at $15 minimum without a drink if you order rolls and such. I don't like that - but it's better than spending that much and not having a great meal, I guess. 

I definitely recommend this place to anyone who would like to begin tackling Vietnamese food in the Sunset-Irving district. There are literally hundreds of Pho joints in this part of town, and you can never tell which ones are good. I'm not ready to go anywhere else right now because I still love this place enough and I'm not in the neighborhood often enough to experiment.
author: Chris j.

description:
I don't know how anyone can compare the pho here and place it on par with Pho Hoa. The pho here is bland and doesn't have the same flavor Pho Hoa across the street has. While the broth may not be as "salty," I enjoy ordering the five spice chicken pho and occasionally add chili sauce.

On the other hand, their imperial rolls are the best I've had. I've tried the Charbroiled Beef and Charbroiled Pork. Between the two the pork is more grilled and offers more flavor overall. The Charbroiled Pork Chop would also be a good choice.

Note: They are related to PPQ Dungeless Island on Clement St. They now accept credit cards.
author: Armstrong B.

description:
I was really upset when i got my #1 large Bowl of Pho today, really upset... THERE WAS ONLY ONE FREAKING BEEF BALL! ONE!... wait scratch that.. HALF A BEEF BALL! shouldn't there be a couple halves or a few. I'm really upset! But even though there was only HALF a beef ball, the portions were huge! and there was good portion of meat, so i can't complain all too much..(beef balls are so good though). The flavor of the broth wasn't all that great today, some days it's good, sometimes not.. i guess it's a hit or miss. 

The Egg Rolls tasted really divine today. One of the best Vietnamese egg rolls i had in awhile. 

I think if i come back again, I'll try the spicy satay beef noodle soup, that looked very appetizing on the menu.
author: Brian P.

description: One of the best vegetarian noodle soups (I like requesting fried tofu in place of the soft tofu).  Service is always courteous and fast.  For dinner, go before 7pm if you don't want to wait long.
author: George K.

description:
Vermicelli-yes. Servings are quite generous, and feels healthy (little oil, good amount of veges)

Pho- ehh it's A-OK. My friend always gets the curry chicken pho, so there might be something good about that. I, on the other hand, will warn you to stay away from the Bun Bo Hue here, as it's the worst I've ever tasted (and I am an adamant Bun Bo Hue eater, and will go out of my way to get it).

This place is always packed. Come early, drop someone off so they can get seats, while you try to find parking.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I have to say, the decor might not be much, but the service here is very efficient. Once the order is put in, the food comes out quickly. This place is good for those times when you're dying of hunger. (Just make sure you start dying of hunger after you find a parking space, because that might take you a while!)

I'm not a big Pho person. I tend to order rice plates at vietnamese restaurants. The bbq pork rice plate I got here was pretty good, but I guess I expected a little more pork. There was a HUGE mound of rice and a small pile of pork. I like my pork-rice ratio to be about 0.65. heh.

My friends love this place because of their Vietnamese Carpaccio. It's OK. I don't know what the big deal is. It's not my thing, I guess. Too much red meat gives you gout anyways.
author: Hue L.

description:
So glad we tried this. Actually we were looking for the other restaurant, the crab island one. But when we found parking, this was the one that was close :)
I tried the chicken curry pho. It was soooo good. Piping hot, the chicken was tender and the spices were just right. The accompanying basil leaves were nice to bite into. I am sure that must be their best dish to offer, but I haven't tried others.
My husband tried the shrimp vermicelli bun. He was confused that it did not involve any bun :) It was OK. He added lot of sauces to make it spicier.
Oh, and the prices were so reasonable for the serving size.
author: Swati R.

description:
Pho Delicious!

I am a huge fan of their Beef Satay Pho, the imperial rolls are pretty darned tasty too.  The prices are great, the service is fast and efficient.  This place is always packed, but the line moves quickly.
author: E R.

description: The Beef Carpaccio! Amazing. I've also had their beef vermicelli and pho, and everything seems to be consistently delicious. Prices are good and portions are great.
author: Beatriz A.

description:
Yes for me it is as good as it gets!! In Vietnamese food that is. 

My husband has been the one going here for years, he had to have his fix at least once a week until we moved out of the city. We now try at least once a month. 

I knew I liked the food here, but not until I ate at a different place in Daly City did I realize how much I loved PPQ!! 

They both had the same dish I like, one with charbroiled pork, egg rolls and vermicelli noodles ( I admit I did not know how to spell it, I copied from another reviewer ,thanks! ).. it is a very tasty dish, the other place it was disgusting, I would not even feed my dog the dish of the other Restaurant! SO eating elsewhere made me realize how much I love this place! 
( not that my dog eats human food, I swear his food costs more than what we spend in food) 

Another dish I eat here is a chicken broth soup with veggies and tofu in it, I am not much for noodles.. I know.. I know I am in a noodle house basically and not eating noodles, BUT that dish is so tasty and when you ask for no noodles they give you more veggies and tofu. It is a wonderful dish on a cold day. 

My husband would say I am a picky eater. I am not picky, I just do not like oil slobbered all over my food. 

Also when they are willing to substitute for you is great by me. 

As long as you do not mind waiting to sit down, sometimes it can be 10 minutes or more depending on the time of day you are there. 

This place to me is a little treasure in San Francisco!
author: Corina W.

description: My big problem when writing these reviews is that I dont always visit the place enough times to truly give a honest review. Since my first review of Pho Phu Quoc I have been back 4 times, and have to take away a star. Had the rare steak pho a few weeks ago, and it was anything but rare. It also had a spoiled smell and very gamey flavor- no bueno! And just a few days ago I tried the "meat ball pho." Well, it was definitely meat, and in ball form, I just cant tell you what kind of meat it was. It was grey, had the tecture of firm vaseline, and had absolutely no flavor at all.
author: David D.

description: There are so many great reviews alright. So i'll just say that I love the 5 spices chicken noodle soup.  I'm a picky eater and I cannot stop coming here!
author: David O.

description: My favorite dish at this place is the Spicy Curry Chicken Vermicelli. This is the only Vietnamese restaurant that serves this dish that I am aware of. The portion is filling and inexpensive. For a quick bite to eat, this dish is by far the best. I can't comment on their other dishes because the Spicy Curry Chicken Vermicelli is the only dish I get, other than the papaya salad with shrimp (also very good). This place is always packed even on a weeknight.
author: Anson C.

description:
Been going here for over 10 years now ! Absolutely love their pho! The flavor the taste of everything is just delicious. I almost will not go to any other place for pho. 

The other great part is their service. Super speedy & food comes out in around 5 minutes. Great if you're hungry, there's no need to wait forever for your food. Really nice staff. 

Can get really busy & crowded sometimes when you go during lunch hours. Place is quite small. Prices are reasonable & they have a wide variety of dishes to choose from. Sizes of pho bowls are reasonable but sometimes the rice plates come with too little meat. It really depends on what you order. But overall, definitely a favorite place of mine.
author: Vivian Z.

description:
This place is no-frills to be sure, but it has some of the most fantastic bun (vermicelli with cucumbers, sprouts, and some variety of meat or spring rolls) ever.

Service was quick and to the point, food was presented perfectly, and the Vietnamese coffee was excellent.

Order the bun with spring rolls and chicken for a really, really incredible meal-- the chicken is crispy and juicy and tastes wonderful!
author: Sassy B.

description: veggie combo pho every time!!! my favorite dish. sit in, get it to go, it tastes great. definitely my go to Pho place in the city.
author: Tati M.

description: You know it did take me three times before I thought I would be worthy of being able to write a review. Here is what I think, I am boring, and I seem to always get a the Pho Ga, no matter what Pho place I go, but let me tell you something I think if you can't get Pho Ga right, you should go out of business.... the first two times I had it, it tasted like they but  all spice in it... ew, however the third time there was no spice... I recommend that they leave it out, because after that the soup was GREAT! This is a great restaurant, I really enjoyed it. They are quick to seat you and take your order :D
author: Star Z.

description:
Tomato Crab Soup is a must order. It's so good. 

There's usually a line. The pho' is good. It's a perfect spot during the foggy days in the Sunset which is everyday.
author: Hebert J.

description: d e l i c i o u s . . . Came here last weekend in need of some hot soup. I had the vegetarian pho (which was actually really good). The husband had the large pho with five spice chicken on the side. We also had the fried imperial rolls. I'm going to have to say they have the best spring rolls here...it taste like there is taro in there! SO GOOD! Both meals were really good and we consumed everything! Left the joint satisfied!
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Definitely a place to hit for the pho, my experience on anything else on the menu has not been worth a penny in the pond.

If there is a line fear not!  It moves fairly quick and this area of Sunset Chinatown is colorful enough so just keep it chill.  Remember, you can't get your SF Merit Badge without a visit to PPQ.
author: Jim W.

description:
This place is definitely better than the Daly City pho I used to always get since it was the only pho place I knew of till now. I seriously don't know what Daly City had but it wasn't pho and all my friends tell me it's because there aren't a lot of Vietnamese over there. I don't know, I guess.

Anyway, this place is cracking, like really. My boyfriend and I got there just in time as a couple left giving us a place to sit unlike the crowds of people that poured in shortly after, having to wait a little.

We ordered the Fried Calamari and I really don't know which Pho bowl we ordered. Well his was the Number 1 and I know mine was like 3 or something, whatever, it was your basic beef pho with beef parts. The pho was good but the broth was a little off, I don't know how else to explain it. It wasn't a bad off but it was just off. As for the Calamari, it was done just right except it came out sorta in big chunks. Weird but still good so there's nothing to complain there. I really like this place and I plan on going back here whenever I crave pho, which is a lot.

P.S. Our waitress was super nice and sweet lady =)
author: Janell Y.

description:
Nothing fancy about this place, but I have been going there regularly for the past 6 years. 
I have a tendency to order the same things all the time so I can't talk about the whole menu but what I order is very good, affordable and portions are more than decent: pho (of course!), 5 spice chicken and the chicken salad.
Also the service is pretty fast, even when the place is jam packed.

Why I don't give 5 stars? Parking is a real issue... I once turned around for 20 minutes before finding a spot... for crying out loud, this is the Sunset, not Nob Hill!
Also at peak hours, it is so packed that you have to wait for your turn... problem is, there is no waiting area, so you have to stand next to the door, or outside, which sucks when it's cold.
author: Vithiet L.

description: I like this place. Always have people inside. Asian which means it is good, the pho sometimes can get oily but still state good. The slice meat is always so tender. The most important part is that the noodles are not over cooked.
author: Ge I.

description: Unlike the clement street location, this one does not service crab, however the imperial rolls are still pretty good. I don't really like the pho here since it taste rather bland to me and prefer pho hoa's across the street. Usually when I dine here I order the rice plate which is pretty good, but not as good as the ones I've had near Milpitas.
author: Petra S.

description: I got the rice plate with shredded pork, pork, and egg patty(?) I like it and I normally don't like the egg patty because other places are a bit dry. This place didn't whoa me though, perhaps I'll try the pho next time.
author: Mandy D.

description: Small pho bowl fills you up. If you're really hungry, try the large bowl. Not bad tasting either for the price.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
My boyfriend had been telling me about PPQ's pho for months, and I never bothered to check it out, since I was wary of soup being *that* amazing.  I had never tried pho and figured it couldn't be more amazing than posole or gumbo.  

Anyway, I found myself at PPQ one night recently when el bf decided that I should finally try it.  I wasn't quite sure what to order, so I just picked the five spices chicken soup.  Ha!  Some soup.  I wasn't convinced!  I just received a soup with chicken broth with a bunch of rice noodles thrown in, served with a SIDE OF CHICKEN.  Uh, no.  I am not going to add stuff in my soup.  They should have put it in in the first place!  I scoffed and declared pho overrated.  My bf cautioned me and said to give it another shot sometime.  

Well...I did... at Yummy Yummy.  That awful cold snap in early January drove me to eat anything that was piping hot.  That time, it wasn't that bad, so I decided that PPQ was worth another shot.  So, we were back at PPQ celebrating le bf's birthday, which happened to be about a month later from the first time I was there.  This time, I got the spicy chicken curry dish and MAN, was I won over.  This time, I was served an aromatic bowl of semi-sweet and spicy curry with tender pieces of all-white chicken meat and the most pillowy potatoes I have ever put in my mouth.  This one was most definitely a winner.  

Since then, I have found myself thinking about their glorious pho.  I tried other curry pho, hoping I could relive the magic, but they failed.  PPQ: expect me there this weekend slurping up every last drop of your delicious soup.
author: Christine S.

description:
PPQ!

On my first full day in San Francisco during my trip, a friend took me to PPQ for lunch.  An unassuming Vietnamese restaurant, I had expected the quality of food to be comparable to a lot of Vietnamese restaurants I've been to, but their five spice chicken definitely puts it above the average.  My friend kept telling me to order a five spice chicken dish before we got there, and so I ordered the imperial roll and five spice chicken vermicelli.  Their menu also offers the five spice chicken with either rice or pho.  But I was in the mood for vermicelli.  My dish consisted of a big bowl of vermicelli with, well, imperial rolls and five spice chicken cutlets.  The vermicelli was made just right.  I wasn't sure what was in the imperial roll, but it tasted like taro.  That was very good.  But it was the five spice chicken that made the dish great.  The chicken cutlets were meaty, the exterior was very tasty, and the interior was very tender.  This restaurant is a must-go for anybody who is visiting the Sunset neighbourhood.

On a side note, though this is a Vietnamese restaurant, the staff actually poke Cantonese to each other.  It could be that they are Vietnamese Chinese?  Not sure.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hoa
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five-spice_powder
author: Radford T.

description:
My favorite Vietnamese quick food in the city.  

Imperial Rolls are a must try (veggie rolls are just as good)

BBQ Pork Vermicelli bowl comes with the rolls, which is always a good option.

As far as soup goes, my two mainstays are the Curry Chicken Soup in coconut broth, or the Beef Satay.  Both can be fairly spicy!

Finish of your meal with a 5 color bean drink and you will be glad you did (although it is very sweet)

Their Vietnamese coffee is good as well.
author: Stephen H.

description: Fresh, crisp vegetables and balanced flavors make their pho especially delicious.  Service is prompt and efficient - most tables turn over in 45 minutes or less.  Lovely little spot to get a five spice fix.
author: Andy A.

description:
As a Vietnamese girl who grew up in Little Saigon in So. Cal. and just moved to SF, this place is as good as it gets for pho and bun.  After having their pho multiple times, I decided to try the bun thit nuong chai gio last night and was very impressed.  The charbroiled pork was flavorful and tender, and the eggrolls were traditionally made with spring roll wrapping, not the "egg roll" wrapping that is currently being used in other restaurants.  

Overall, great food.  Just be prepared to wait for a table as this place has been crowded every time I've come.
author: Rook B.

description:
love love love this place. 

I always get imperial rolls and pho, it's so good that I don't really want to order anything else. The imperial rolls are super crunchy and hot when you get them so wait a few minutes for it to cool off or else you'll burn your tongue. =/ trust me, I've done it. The broth is always flavorful and the meat is good quality. I like to order extra meat on the side. =) .. the only downside is that there's always a line but it's well worth it!
author: Raquel T.

description:
Best value for pho in the city! 5 spice chicken is a treat, as is their special Satay soup base. 

It can be a wait sometimes for a table, but it's well worth it any day of the week.
author: Jeff C.

description: Minus one star because of the extremely rude waitress.  There's this Chinese lady there with flushed cheeks that typically works on the weekends and she has the worst attitude ever and charges you for everything.  I go there all the time and she friggen charged me for an extra leaf of lettuce. lame.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Living in the neighborhood and having a lot of Vietnamese to choose from, PPQ delivers tastey goodies, cheap and fast.  I think my longest wait time for Pho or a noodle or rice plate was 3 minutes max and I've been there about 10 times.  Now don't get me wrong, I love Vietnamese food and this isn't what I would call California gourmet.  This is straight up Vietnamese basics, fried, breaded pork cutlets, vermicelli, and any rice plate that can be served with a fried egg on top (yes, a fried egg).  The Pho is pretty tastey and I would rank it pretty high on my broth meter.  

Don't go looking for stylie atmosphere, don't go looking for veggie dishes, go looking for a fast meal that is well worth the price.  PPQ beats any other Vietnamese in its neighborhood.
author: Jack S.

description:
as stated earlier, PPQ is PHO PHUKING REAL YO. 

The quality of meat here beats the quality at any other pho spot. The broth is always well seasoned and the imperial rolls are so crunchy that it makes me not wanna do crunches...

yeah that didnt work as planned, but i do plan on gettin pho a lot this winter. 

pho lyfe
author: Jason W.

description: They give a decent amount of noodles. Sometimes its too mushy ): their rice plates are good. Service is good. On Fridays and weekends, there usually is a wait. not too long though.
author: Kristina L.

description:
Sorry. Not my intent to cut this place down but I'm going to be candidly honest.

All the servers look and act as if they are indentured servants. They actually look irritated that you called them over for something. The people sitting at the counter also give you this "what d'ya want" look and attitude when you go to pay for the bill. I always treat waitresses and waiters with respect. But I do feel that if I'm paying for my meal and leaving a tip for services, that I shouldn't have to feel unwanted or bothered by the employees in the restaurant! I can understand if this happens occasionally there (maybe they're having a bad day, etc) but that's the ambiance there every single time I go!

Prices have gone up and portions have shrunk to half their size, haven't they?  Also, one of my pet peeves is restaurants that ONLY accept cash. In this fast-paced mileage-earning era, such places won't be earning my money anymore...
author: Mashimaro M.

description:
I've never had asparagus and crabmeat soup done so wrong... SO WRONG! Hardly any crabmeat, the complete opposite of rich and thick... don't get me started on the asparagus. 

I hardly ever eat pho from other restaurants because basically my mom's pho is the best, but we gave it a try anyway. The meat was all right, but the broth was seriously lacking in flavor.

I would have given PPQ another star if it weren't for the horrible stomach ache I got afterward. Boo :(
author: S. D.

description: Beef in their pho is very fresh & tender... loved their fresh summer rolls!!  Waiting to try the crab at their other location on Clement...
author: Cathy F.

description: The pho here is pretty good not the best since I've had better but tasty enough for me to return if I'm in the area.
author: Helen L.

description: The times I've been here before I thought it was okay... but now after trying other places and coming back, this place is pretty bad. The pho tastes like it has lots of msg... I didn't feel very good after eating it. The service was poor as well.. You're probably better off eating Vietnamese food in the Richmond than the Sunset...
author: Yuan T.

description:
Ordered the seafood pho, which was served in a chicken broth that was simple and clean, but lacked the depth of Turtle Tower's.  The assorted seafood - calamari, shrimp, fish balls and cakes, were a bit rubbery.  The noodles were thin and cooked till soft, which is how I prefer them.  Overall a satisfying bowl of soup, though not particularly noteworthy.

Sampled the six spice chicken, which was very flavorful, tender, and juicy.

Service was efficient and expedient like most Pho places, despite the full house.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
Imperial Rolls!

That is the main reason I go to PPQ.  Prices aren't comparable to pho places around the area but the rolls are great.  Try them with the Vermicelli and Charbroiled Pork.

It's not the best place to go to with more than six people as they only really have one table that can fit that many people.  The pho is there is pretty good.  The service is... typical asian.  You have to ask 3 or more times for ice water.
author: Chris C.

description:
I always liked the rice plates at Pho Phu Quoc, or PPQ, for short. I always thought the BBQ pork tasted better than at other Vietnamese Pho restaurants.

For whatever reason, though, if I go out for Pho with my buddies, we go across the street to Pho Hoa Hiep, where the rice plates are not as good.

If you are looking for sheer quantity, go to Loi's a few blocks west instead. Lots of meat.
author: Karl K.

description:
After going to AT&T/SBC/ The Phone Park and watching a Giants win, PPQ is a place that is on the short list of places to go.   But only after a win.   Sure, this is after chowing down a sheboygan sausage and a super large diet coke, but hey, a giant bowl of pho is a great way to celebrate.  Can't forget the spring rolls also.  

As others have mentioned, make sure you bring the cash, cuz they don't accept plastic.
author: Herb C.

description:
I like their curry coconut chicken soup.

Some people mention about possible MSG... I dunno, but it seems that these places that do a high turnover on soup are going to rely on broth mixes which usually have MSG in them. My experience is that you'll find better homemade tasting broth in a chinese restaurant where soup isn't all they do. Good broth has to sit on the stove. It takes time and these pho places don't have that kind of room in the kitchen to be making that much broth and doing it well.

I am still giving it 4 stars because of quality ingredients, cleanliness, and efficient service.
author: E. M.

description:
Great food at reasonable prices. Expect a bit of a wait during the dinner rush, but the service is fast and the food comes out quickly.

edit: 4/9/08

After participating in the protest today, I had a craving for some pho, so my sisters and I came here. I didn't feel like showering AGAIN after eating pho, so I ordered number #9 - the chicken broth with slices of chicken and flat noodles. Who knew that chicken broth DOES NOT make your clothes and hair smell??? AWESOME! And it was mighty delicious too!
author: Teresa Y.

description:
Prices have been going up lately, but it's so crowded all the time, so how can you blame them?  My parents and I used to go here every Friday night, circa 2000-2001.  I think everything on the menu was about $1.50-$2 cheaper back then, but PPQ is by no means "expensive."

I pretty much always order the large Curry Chicken Noodle Soup "with Pho noodles," and if I'm hungry, I get it with EXTRA noodles (very filling). They used to give me a weird look whenever I said this, but they don't anymore ;)  If you like your food a little spicy, this is delicious.   The vermicelli noodles that come standard with that dish just don't retain the taste of the curry broth, and it ends up tasting like... vermicelli noodles and nothing else.

Go here with your Bros/Gals when you just wanna have a cheap night out and chill, OR you're curious what kind of person your date is.  Any lady who is cool is PPQ is cool with me. (Disclaimer:  Don't take her here if you're trying to impress her, such as on Valentine's or on Anniversaries.)

They DO have BEER.  I don't know why there are 17 votes that say  "none."
author: Jin D.

description:
I wanted rice. My friends wanted pho. We came here.

Against my better judgment, I got curry. Hey, Thailand is right next to Vietnam and I love Thai curry. Can't be THAT different, can it?

Yes, yes it can. It was watery and not thick and saucy. No likey.  Other stuff looked pretty good.

Three stars cuz it's still worth eating at if I should be in the area and not craving curry.
author: Robert L.

description: The pho with the five-spice grilled chicken, the beef pho, the non meat pho, and the summer rolls are all excellent. The  home made lemon soda is wonderful, too.
author: Dee I.

description:
i love the five spice chicken here and the imperial roolls.
SOOOOOOO GOOOD.

But I minus one star since the broth of pho tastes like water, So go across the street to Kevins if you want good pho.
author: Anna K.

description:
OMG! best chicken ever! Great value and we had awesome service. The restaurant is small but filled to the gills. There were plenty of servers around to take care of the busy restaurant. We got our food and drinks quite fast.

Five spice chicken - yummy yummy in my tummy!
author: Purple Lotus x.

description:
NO NO NO, ok PPQ is only in business cuz snooty ppl tell other snooty ppl that its better than Kevins cuz its more expensive and is "cleaner". but im hating on u PPQ fans cuz u proly tried PPQ first and had ur loyalties set. 

I came here a few years ago and i remembered it to be a decent bowl of pho, pretty much on par with Kevin's so i was nice enuf to hand out an extra star. But theres usually a wait and its more expensive.

Anyway, I went here a months back because some friends insisted. I was hoping for a decent bowl of pho. what i got was an expensive bowl of  uncooked noodle blocks, a few pieces of beef and a soup that was absolutely horrible. ok this is gonna sound really weird but I tasted the soup and I noticed that there was WAYYYYYYYYY too much cinnamon and clove (sophicasted palette?) haha but no it was bad and the service was crap. GO TO KEVINS!
author: Ryan Y.

description: I came back today to try the rice platter with grilled pork and wouldn't recommend it as a first thing to try at PPQ.  The rice was a little dry and I did not really like the shredded lettuce served with the dish.  They really should use broken rice instead.  The fish sauce was great, nonetheless, and that definitely redeemed this.
author: Ben T.

description: Generally I am not a big fan of Vietnamese stuff. But this one is good! Again, because my bad memories, can't remember the names of what I ordered. (And I feel silly if I wrote them down every times if I go somewhere.) But! I know I order #0 Pho (Spicy Beef something... lol) almost every single time I visit. Much better than the others I've ever tried. The other day, tried some vegetable dish as well... Fresh and tasty! And the BBQ Shrimp wrap was tasted really good! Such a great place to eat if you are in hurry and also wanna something good. Check that out!
author: Flora F.

description:
I love this place!! Always has people at it; which is always a good sign...

The chicken salad is amazing...the dressing and the mint in the salad is awesome. I never knew mint in a salad would be so good... refreshing dish for sure. 

The BBQ beef and rice is good and the Red Bean drink is definitely worth checking out.
author: Deborah H.

description:
So what's the big deal? I notice a lot of people seem to like this place, but out of all the Vietnamese restaurants on Irving St, this is the worst one. I haven't been in here in a while, so maybe things have changed,  but I haven't wanted to go back ever. 

The food's decent, it's average if anything. But with Vietnamese food, portions play a big part, and their portions aren't big at all

I would write a full review but I haven't been there in a long time. The food really isn't that bad, nor is the customer service, which really means 3 stars, but this place gets two because it's sooooo overrated.

Would I ever come back here again? If all the other Vietnamese restaurants on Irving St closed, yes.
author: Calvin L.

description:
4 STARS- 5 SPICE CHICKEN!  
4 STARS- close to the sunset where i stay every week
3 STARS- other food
2 STARS- for not accepting Credit Cards...
2 STARS- parking sucks

Average Total = 3 STARS
author: Elaine L.

description:
Very solid, competent Vietnamese fare... outside of the pho!  Every item here is pretty tasty, except for the pho!  Grilled meats are nicely marinated and seared, rice is pretty fragrant jasmine long grain, curry is light but has a pleasant flavor (great on a warm evening), imperial rolls are tasty (just watch out for hard bits in the filling, which not uncommon here it seems), goi cuon (cold shrimp rolls) are fine, just... the pho is not very good here.  Why?  The broth is just not robust enough.  It's pretty anemic, actually.  That's the Achilles Heel of PPQ.

I mean, so what if the prices have gone up over the years or the service has always been so-so at best, at least everything (except for the pho) is still pretty big and tasty.

4 stars for the stalwart PPQ.  Plus, this is where I met Miss Tasaki for the first time.  That's sentimental value right there haha!
author: Ryan D.

description:
A pho staple for those in the sunset area of SF.  We seem to always head here the morning after... 
Inexpensive and large portions.  I had the shredded chicken with flat noodle soup which was great.
author: linda d.

description:
If you happen to be in the "Middle Sunset" (between 18th-25th on Irving as I like to call the area) and you're craving Pho (why else would you be in the neighborhood), then there is no better place than PPQ.  My wife an I come here almost once a week, especially when it's foggy and windy out, which for the middle sunset is normal.

With a street that boasts many Pho  joints, PPQ reigns above them all.  What sets PPQ apart? It's the intangibles.  They have a great selection of Pho as well as a vast menu of other Vietnamese delights.  It's clean and they even let us bring in our own beer once.  Who can argue with tallboys and Pho?  

When my wife and I gauge an ethnic restaurant we always see if 1) are the cooks native? and 2) are most of the patrons native (we're Filipino btw).  PPQ fits the bill on both.
author: Mike T.

description:
3.50 stars

the pho is really hearty here!  i get the small bowl, which is pretty big for me.  

the five spice chicken bun and rice plates are the bomb!  all the rice plates are really good too!
author: Wendy S.

description: Probably one of the better vietnamese places in the area. I come here a lot, especially with some of my friends over the summer. This places has really good pho and the prices are pretty reasonable. The five spice chicken here is also really good. Even better than the one they have down at Lam Hoa Thuan.
author: William C.

description:
Came here at a friend's suggestions cause plans changed. I'm not really a pho guy, but I'll have it once in a while. I usually go for the vermicelli or just a rice plate. I decided to have the 5 spice chicken rice plate and I thought it was pretty good. Maybe not the best thing I've ever had but it satisfied my hunger. Also ordered the imperial rolls, and I think these are the best imperial rolls I've had. I know I may not visit many Vietnamese restaurants but personally they are the best I've had. 
The place is neater/cleaner than other spots I've been to, so thats a plus. And we didn't have to wait long for our food so thats another plus right there. I'll probably give their pho a shot next time I eat here.
author: Cee D.

description: ALWAYS Enjoy our/my Pho/Vietnamese Food here @ PPQ, I'm/we're long time customers & have NEVER EVER had a bad experience... The 5 Spice Chicken is really good, Curry Crab Tofu is also really good. We always get Spring Rolls, too, both Fried & Chilled... I've had their All Beef Pho, Chilled Vermicelli Noodles are awesomely good. But it's their Broth that makes all the Pho Noodle Dishes so Tasty, very clean/crisp/flavorful... The Service is very good too, very attentive & friendly... & the Host is a really great guy, always greets everyone w/a warm smile when you arrive & on your way out... You honestly cant go wrong ordering any item off the menu & the prices are very very reasonable... If you're ever wanting or have that Pho urge, I highly recommend heading out to the Sunset Dist & dinning @ PPQ!!!
author: Chef S.

description:
I really love this place, usually pho has really crappy broth but you can tell that they cook it well and right, as hard as it is to perfect pho this place has perfected the broth, the only soup I can take is the PHO DAC BIET.  Usually I like getting the Beef stew but this place doesn't do it quite right, I heard their rice plates were really good but I only had their five spices chicken, one of the best chicken i've had in a while...

The veggies that come with the pho were surprisingly fresh, usually other pho places don't really have all the fresh bean sprouts and what not but here it was fresh every single time i've went...and i go here alot!
author: Genesis K.

description: Bun Bo Hue (round vermicelli noodles with meat in spicy soup)! YUMMMMMMMYYYYYY!!! Bun Rieu here is really good too. Haven't found any other restaurants with these two varieties or none that makes it as good as PPQ. mmm!
author: Nancy N.

description: I love their rare beef carparcio and their beef is angus beef!!  I have their Pho Tai with beef on the side every time and love it.  I truly think it's their beef...fresh!!
author: Patrick C.

description: PPQ is still good, but in terms of quantity, it has fell behind a tad compared with my original review. The prices did go up, but I point my finger at the economy. I got my usual, the number 1 with all the meat fixings, which is the same for the most part, but it was $8+. That's more expensive than it used to be. Still, this is one of the best so far for pho in the Sunset district.
author: Jeremy L.

description: PPQ is one of my family's favorite Vietnamese restaurants in San Francisco.  The food there is amazing.  I highly recommend getting the #4 which is the Pho with flank steak and meatballs or the Beef Vermicelli with Imperial Rolls.  The prices here are very reasonable and the service is very fast.  I love their Pho so much that I wouldnt mind coming back once a week.
author: Ryan C.

description: The 5 spice chicken pho is great.   I've tried most of the SF & NYC pho places and PPQ is still up there as one of my favorites for the combination of a good friendly, fairly clean and reasonably priced dining experience.   I get less of a chance to dine in these days but do get take out from here regularly.
author: alvin l.

description: This place is okay. Just okay. I came here one night for dinner with two friends after ten minutes of trying to decipher what we wanted to eat.  We finally had our hearts set on having pho. When we got there, the restaurant was pretty full but most people were pretty much heading out. We wrote a name on the waiting list& pretty much were called for a table in less than 10mins. After they seated us, one of the employees came by and told us that we shouldn't order any soup because they were running out of broth.... SERIOUSLY? (Where dey do dat at?!) Half of the damn menu is pretty much soup. That was disappointing & on top of that the guy wasn't very friendly about it either. How unpleasant. When the server came to take our order, she never mentioned anything about them being out of broth so we ordered it anyway... & Guess What? They had freeeekin' broth. Enough to serve other customers who came in after we did! How ridonkulous. I don't think the hostess/cashier dude liked us very much (for no apparent reason, it was our first times there, ever!!).  The pho is pretty much on point. Everything on the menu is decently priced. Don't know if I'll really come back though. Customer service is 80% of what makes a restaurant worthy for me& they pretty much lacked that.
author: Cat M.

description:
All I have to say is:  Coconut Curry Pho...TO.  DIE.  FOR.

(Actually I have more to say).

1 star off for forgetting my order. :(  I went with a friend and we both ordered the coconut curry pho, but lo and behold only one came out!  I was thoroughly sad until I reminded them that I wanted in on the goodness, and all my worries were washed away in 70% saturated fat.  YUM.

Will be back again, for SURE.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
This place has the best pho for its location! Hands down.

Where else can you go and get a big fat freakin bowl of Pho for $6-7. Maybe in the tenderloin but thats about it and I don't wanna go all the way there. The broth is usually nice n hot, its clear not muddy, on the salty side but it tastes super good! Noodles good texture, meat handout is somewhat generous but not all would agree. 

For people who want superior customer service, dont expect too much. OK service, neither good nor bad, these are just ordinary workers. They just bring you the food and accomodate simple requests. I don't care though. I'm there for the food, not for someone to go and say "hi, how are you doing today, yes sir no sir, most definitely sir" As long as they bring my food and treat me okay im all good.

The service is extremely fast, your food comes in like 5 minutes, literally. I would almost consider this fast food. Sometimes they bring out Pho faster than a crowded In n Out. Its crazy!

Also don't be mad if they give you the bill 3/4 through ur meal while still eating. It's how they do things to speed up the process. They're not trying to be rude or anything.

That's it. Go enjoy!!
author: David N.

description:
A great find, this non-descript vietnamese restaurant serves great food for a reasonable price.  The food is fast, tasty, and consistent.  The wait-staff doesn't smile much.  They're all business, but they'll take care of you well and the cashiers are very nice and personable if you try to get to know them.

Newly update decor is a nice touch, but don't expect fine dining.  This place is for loud talking, friendly, chowing at a great price.
author: Kash-money K.

description:
One of my favorite vietnamese restaurant in town. It's cheap and it's good. Consider pretty clean for an asian restaurant. Favor curry chicken noodle soup, five spices chicken noodle soup, spring roll. Not much fond of there ice vietnamese coffee.

They only accept cash. And if you go by car don't go to Irving Street on Saturday or Sunday around noon till 2pm. Very very difficult to find parking space unless you happened to be very lucky.
author: Nancy T.

description:
San Francisco winters is reason enough for pho (noodle soup)! 

The curry chicken pho is so damn good, I don't even try anything else cause there isn't anything better. It's nosey runny good, that damn good. Hehe, sometimes I go out of my way to drive my lazy butt down to Irving Street for curry chicken pho. And that's hella far. 

Only downfall, cash only. I know I'm not the only girl out there who only carrys credit cards so this is kinda annoying cause I gotta remember to make a trip to the bank. That's the only reason why it isn't five stars.
author: Sara D.

description:
I can't believe this place is still open and is sooo busy. I remember coming here years ago, and they couldn't even speak vietnamese. I understand that most viet places are owned and run by chinese. But, they usually understand how to speak and read viet cause most grew up there. I gave this place another chance this weekend. Once again, the waitress couldn't speak any viet. I don't even know many words, but i know how to order food besides pho in viet. 

However, that wasn't the real problem. My friend and I ordered our food. But we didn't get our food till all the tables around us got their food, even though they ordered after us. It doesn't make sense, our table was for two while all the other tables had a big group. And it's not like they wait for everyone to get their food first.

 I had the banh hoi, which is grilled meats that you order to make summer rolls, rice paper wraps. They burnt all the meat. Every bite was bitter from the charcoal on the meat. So many other places to eat viet food in san francisco, people should go elsewhere.
author: dI c.

description:
PPQ is great for when you're sick. 

Their PHO is the best I've had anywhere. 

You can get anything on the menu to go....though I recommend that you eat there. The food just comes out better.

Service can be a bit lacking at times. They can even be a bit rude. But the food is really good. 

Great for a quick lunch with friends.


Parking is virtually non-existent around there. So plan on parking at least a block away
author: Leo V.

description:
Was craving for some soup after the Alice concert this past Sunday. Great thing this restaurant was close by.

Cheap food pho soup for $5-6
I ordered the seafood soup, it was pretty good.
Service was descent.

Hard to find parking but we were lucky enough to get a good parking.

By the way, it's CASH only and they only have 1 unisex bathroom.
author: jubi l.

description:
My boyfriend and I first came here because the service from Kevin's Noodle House (our ex-go-to pho place that is just across the street from Phu Quoc)  became incredibly horrible. Pho Phu Quoc has been our go-to-pho place for the past year.

The service is okay here - they won't go out of their way to be courteous - so keep your expectation low. Just remember that for $6-8, you came here for the pho and not the service.

I really like their curry pho (it was my first dish ever from here... guess it carries some sentimental value). In general, everything here is okay good, not exceptional. I like the phos, but the beef balls in the pho are not the best. Their vermicelli always taste really fresh. The boyfriend is a huge fan for the BBQ chicken vermicelli. 

However, they do need to calm down about the MSG... the problem with MSG is that it makes food taste so good in your mouth, but it'll make you suffer after. I'm always soooo thirsty (i'm thirsty now...) it's can be quite awful, since drinking a bunch of water after I'm already full from all the pho is not one of my favorites.

Anywho, we keep coming back... afterall, it is our *re-bound pho place*, and the food isn't bad~
author: Daven D.

description: I wish this place was a bit closer to me because the food here is definitely better than the fast food Pho Saigon places in my hood!  I've gone here only 2 times but I really like it.  The first time, my friend kept nagging me to go to this place because of the carpaccio.  I was scared to eat raw meat but wow....it was really good!  I remember I had pho that first time but don't remember which one but I remember actually finishing the bowl!  Well that was about 9 months or so ago and finally I got to eat here again....last night!  My boyfriend and I shared carpaccio, pork chop rice plate and imperial rolls!  Wow I was pretty impressed!  The carpaccio was just how I remembered it....possibly better, the pork chop had a lot of flavor and was juicy (not dry like other vietnamese places I've gone too) and the imperials rolls.....well, I don't think you can ever go wrong with them.  Love this place....looking forward to more visits in the near future!
author: Mary-Anne C.

description:
Great food - some of the best meat I've had to accompany a hot bowl of pho.  Good soup.

Other noodle options good too.  Open till 11pm which is fab.
author: C L.

description:
The Pho is uninteresting (the meat is fresh) and the spring rolls are chewy and tasteless.

P.S. In the battle between Pho Phu Quoc and Pho Hoa Hiep right accross the street, Pho Hoa Hiep prevails (hands down).
author: Bobby T.

description:
Pho - I'm pretty sure that's Vietnamese for Comfort. 

My favorite here is the chicken curry Pho. It's super savory, the small bowl is HUGE, and it's reasonably priced. Yes, there are better Vietnamese restaurants in the City, but I like this one for its casual, family style atmosphere and their prices. 

I usually take my visiting relatives here because they can't get this where they come from and the money we save means extra cable car rides. Yay.
author: Prattle P.

description: I haven't had the opportunity to eat very much Vietnamese food, but I like that they have a vegetarian selection that I haven't been able to find at very many other places. Plus I can eat their egg rolls! Awesome.
author: Maira M.

description: I've been coming to PPQ since I was probably 10 years old? I used to always get pho but then my best friend introduced me to the five spice chicken and I haven't looked back. The one annoying thing about PPQ is the customer service. As I mentioned in another post I'm deathly allergic to peanuts so every time I order I inform the waiter NO PEANUTS but probably three out of five times the dish arrives with a crushed peanut topping. The last time I was there I had to send the dish back and the waitress rolled her eyes at me. WHAT A B! But after I received my five spice chicken bun with no peanuts I was a happy camper. I may complain about the customer service but the five spice chicken is the best I've ever had and that's what keeps me coming back for more eye rolling and peanut filled fun. Btw, they finally accept credit cards. Welcome to 2009!
author: Melinda Y.

description: This place is my go to place if i want some good charbroiled beef rice plate. The meat is nicely flavored and moist. The beef carpaccio is yummy too but what i won't order from here are the pho. The flavor of the soup is the blandest i had ever had..ever! Even though they have good meat, it doesn't erase the fact that the broth is tastesless. However, i tried their curry chicken noodle soup and that was quite tasty.
author: Cindy C.

description: Best pho in the area.  It's not blow you away good, but best in San Francisco.  The broth is good, the PPQ pho is always a safe call.  Their beef balls are not so good, but all their other meats are good.  Their Five Spices Chicken is a must get on the side (at least).  It's a hole in the wall place, typical Asian restaurant.  Imperial rolls are AWESOME.
author: Kimberly L.

description: After a failed attempt to go to the CA Academy of Sciences, we decided to make a day out of it in the city.  PPQ hit the spot.  I ordered the chicken curry noodles, which was so delicious that I asked the broth to be boxed up (I used the broth for my lunch the next day with a batch of noodles that I boiled up from scratch).  My husband ordered the ox tail noodles -- excellent as well.  The kids shared a pork chop over rice, with shrimp extra.  We didn't ask, but when the bill came, I found that they had charged us an extra $4 for those three little shrimp.  Ah well, this was still spring break, so a little bit extra splurge doesn't hurt.
author: Patty W.

description:
Three years ago I lived in Seattle where they don't have the fortune of Mission burritos at 2 am, let alone the array of veggies and fruits year round. 

But one thing they DO have that we don't have in SF is really yummy asian food - particularly Vietnamese pho and bahn mi joints. So, when I returned to SF, I had sort of acquired a taste for big bowl-fuls of pho. 

So, I've been on a bit of a quest, searching for the best pho in the city. And so far, this is my favorite. Turtle Tower's broth is a bit bland for my taste, and I prefer condiments. Other spots in the Tenderloin have sort of fallen short overall, and Tu Lan isn't really a pho spot. But PPQ make a lovely heaping bowl of pho, and you can order extra raw beef on the side, or - even better - simply order the five spice chicken pho. This is my absolute favorite. 

The five spice chicken pho comes with beef broth and the crispy  boneless five-spice chicken leg is served on the side. This means you can dip the chicken in the broth while still keeping the fried yummy bits crisp. They also serve all the pre-requisite condiments (basil, sprouts, chiles and lime). 

True - I love Vietnamese food so much that I visited Vietnam last spring just to try the pho from the motherland. This is good basic Vietnamese street food - nothing fancy - but the best pho had the warm tasty broth, just like PPQ. The atmosphere here is vaguely sterile - typical for your cheap Vietnamese restaurant - and the menu is extensive (I typically get the green papaya salad and the spring rolls, too, though these are pretty basic and not worth the Inner Sunset trek). 

Overall, I'm still looking to try Yummy Yummy across the street (while in Vietnam, I learned you never say "Yum Yum" since it has sexual connotations; "yummy yummy" is preferred) and the newly opened Pot de Pho, but in the meantime, this place is great on a rainy afternoon.
author: Chrissy L.

description:
Cheap and delicious!  Just make sure you make a reservation.

This place overall is great. Come here for the dungeness crab.  They come in many different varieties.  Lots of other dishes that are great.  

Have a birthday party here in the back room where you can play the guitar or sing karaoke while drinking and eating the night away!
author: Patrick T.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Saturday afternoon a little past 12:30 pm. There was a good size crowd in the waiting area. If you're stuck waiting, you'll want to make sure you give your name at the counter so they can put you on the waiting list. After about 25-30 mins of waiting, we were finally seated. 

Looking at the menu, there's something for everyone. This time around we had fried egg rolls (i think you get 6 pieces?), rare steak pho, and 5 spice chicken pho. I LOVED the 5 spice chicken. We loved it so much we ordered a side of it. We found out later that they charged over $10 for 6 pieces of the chicken. You get 5 pieces if you order it w/your pho. If you want more of this, it's more worth it to order it over rice or vermicelli. The rare steak was good too. You get a good amount of it in your soup. The broth was excellent and full of flavor. Not salty at all. Eggrolls were good. Prices are fair.

I will definately come back several times in the future.
author: Veronica H.

description:
PPQ YUM!!!

I'm spoiled to live close to it!!

Here's the our usual order and why the 4 stars:
5 spice chicken with rice, large seafood soup
and one thai ice tea!!!!

YUM!!!!!
always quick if i eat there or pick up & not too expensive

one star subtracted because they don't take credit cards!!
c'mon i'm trying to earn all the mileage I can using my debit card so maybe my many orders from PPQ can pay for a vacay!! LMAO!!
author: M R.

description:
I've eaten here a number of times, and I've enjoyed their rare beef pho. The soup base is good. The imperial rolls, fresh shrimp rolls, curry chicken vermicello pho, 5 spice chicken and bbq beef dish with rice area all yummy too.

Service was fast and the service was ok, too. I'll be back....
author: M M.

description:
This place is fabulous! The pho is some of the best in town. Others that would beat it would be in the mission. The prices are cheap and it's absolutely great. the eggrolls are awesome too. The broth is wonderful along with the choices of noodles. 

one of my favorite is the spicy curry noodles, especially with the pho noodles.
author: Josephine N.

description:
Huge portions, tiny prices and the best bun with imperial rolls i've ever had.
The rolls are far tastier than Tu Lan, freshly prepared when you order, with a hint of taro that adds a slightly potatoey flavor that complements the meat....perfection!
The bun has plenty of fresh herbs, cucumber, bean sprouts etc., which is far better than any other places I have tried.

Free tea & friendly service.
I always order the same thing and I'm never dissapointed.
Consistent!
author: Little B.

description:
Have been eating here for more then ten years and my favorite dish is the 5 spices chicken with rice or pho.

The pho here is also very good.
author: Fannie C.

description: I love this place.  The telephone number made it to my speed dial which is something to say.  The chicken vermicilli is something I get such a craving for that I haul all the way across town for it regularly.  I think about it.  My mouth waters.  I go there and grub!!
author: Chris B.

description: Went to this restaurant with a group of friend for the first time.  Good selection of food that all looked very appealing and descriptions also seemed worth our time.  We ordered rice plates and Pho.  They were all OK but not as good for the price. Three of our meals together coated about forty dollars.  Just a typical Pho place that satisfied our hunger but not a place that wowed us. Would go back to probably try another dish because many say that the five spice chicken is delish, but wouldn't be first Pho choice in the city.
author: Jared B.

description: I can only write a review for one thing- the Curry Chicken Pho!!  For me, this is somewhat to die for.  It's got everything I like rolled into one.  I like creamy things (which this definitely is with the coconut milk), lots of chicken, and a kick of spiciness.  I'm actually craving this right now... But anyways, definitely give this a try and I'm sure you won't be disappointed.  My two best friends & I all enjoy this dish and we rarely agree on the same foods.  Score!
author: Nicole G.

description: One of my favorite Pho restaurants in the city. Their 5 spice chicken over rice or pho is very tasty. They also have good cold or fried imperial rolls.  Come here early if you want to get a table. It gets packed w/ locals after 6:30 and there isn't much standing room for those waiting.
author: J. K.

description: It's a little more expensive than normal, but I have to say the soup for the pho is really good.  The noodles was not as soft as it should have been but nothing too major.
author: Terrence L.

description: The 3.5 star for the PHO is appropriate. BUT, do not get the Bun Rieu (crab noodle soup).  It was bland, bland, bland. By far, the worst bun rieu I've ever had.
author: Michelle T.

description: The 5-space chicken with rice is a great deal and very tasty. Sometimes the pho broth lacks oomph - just throw in a little fish sauce and it's just fine. Order the smallest size, it's still monstrous.
author: c t.

description: I've been here a couple of times with friends but I haven't been back in a long time since Kevin's is right across the street. The times that I came here, I always ordered Pho. Some times I ordered the Large size which I can finish, but that's only when I feel hungry. I've had Pho at different restaurants in the city, but there's nothing that really stands out here. The service isn't that great but service at Kevin's isn't any better.  However, the quality of food is greater at Kevin's than PPQ. It's not that difficult to take a couple of steps across the street.
author: Lauren L.

description: The Pho here is great ! i really like it . The imperial rolls are awesome ! you gota try some ! some of the rice plates here are good but i think they are a little too pricy on those. Doesn't really fill me up that much. The price is pretty reasonable. The only bad thought was, its just a bit filthy.... it kind of looks dirty but you know how chinese people do it.. we order tea for dish washing basically... ahah
author: Andrew H.

description: I love their five spice chicken, vermicelli salad, ox tail rice, egg rolls, curry seafood noodle soup, and raw beef lemon grass salad, satay beef noodle soup. All of which has been by far the best I've tried from anywhere else in SF.
author: John W.

description: pho huynh hiep 2 across the street is much better if you are looking for pho. I only went here because pho huynh hiep was closed. The broth was very watered down and very little meat, plus it cost more. So if you are looking for pho go across the street!
author: Ryan D.

description:
When I was still dating SFSU students, I'd come to PPQ and get their five spice chicken pho.  It's noodles and broth with a grilled slab of chicken on the side.  Crispy skin, tasty marinade.  Broth is decent, noodles are bunched on the bottom.

Their rice and bun dishes are not good but not bad.

I give PPQ three stars (from a base of  three) just because I ate there so mmany times, and often in preference to Pho Hoa Hiep across the street.  Easily the place to go if you're in that neighborhood.
author: Amanibhavam K.

description:
After an afternoon of semi-beauty maintenance, I had to feed myself and several other people.  I decided to opt for a Pho and decided to go here because I remembered that I loved the egg rolls.  I ordered my usual, bun with imperial roll and charbroiled beef and the rest of my party ordered their BIG ASS SOUPS.  They were quite surprised at the size of a 'large". (Maybe we've been going to crappy restaurants who don't like giving out big portions.)
Here's a rundown of our dinner:

Appetizer: deep fried calamari- Yum  
Pho with only beef balls-"wow so many beef balls"
Pho with lots of tendons-" wow! So many tendons. This is heaven! OMG, too many tendons. I can't eat it anymore"
Mystery Pho (forgot what the husband ordered)-I'm full
Bun- Egg Rolls!!!! Yum!

I am not the biggest pho fan around, but if I had a craving for some soup or noodles, I'd definitely come back here.
author: A L.

description: I think what's unique about PPQ is their 2 noodle soups: Satay noodle soup and their coconut milk one. Both are quite spicy, especially the coconut milk one, but very tasty!  For taste coconut milk one then Satay noodle soup.
author: Stevie C.

description: i always come here for my pho. there are like 10 ther spots around that have it too. but i always just come here. it is never too busy, is very good with big portions, cheap, and fast. why go anywhere else?
author: Jake C.

description: I've been here several times. The beef noodle soup is okay, but the bun rieu (crab + tomato noodle soup) is kind of gross. The bun rieu noodle soup was very salty. I had to add 3 lemon wedges to it to make it taste better. To me, you shouldn't have to add anything if the food is delicious. So there you have it, I am not a fan of their bun rieu and I will not order that again here. I will probably come back for their rice dish or beef noodle soup when I am having a vietnamese food craving again.
author: Forest T.

description: Something strange is happening at PPQ... they are making the dishes that I always order hotter and hotter... And even when I ask for no fish sauce I get fish sauce... I used to love this place but its starting to get tougher to get the meals I used to get there the way they used to serve them... Last night my curry soup came to my table spicy as hell and cold as ice... Whats up???
author: chris c.

description: I've been here many times in the past . I personally think this place is overrated .. it's not as great as you think . The food is actually mediocre if you ask me . The pho here is decent . The spring rolls here are loosely wrapped and aren't that tasty . I like the ones across the street more . I had the satay beef noodle soup yesterday which is pretty good .. I really liked the soup . I also had the taro coconut sago which was alright .  Service is pretty good and fast . Food is decent , but I prefer the Vietnamese place across the street . It's less crowded and the food is yummier .
author: Eileen L.

description: I admit I haven't been here in a few months.  Before, when I had more craving for beef pho, this would definitely be my top choice.  I usually order something beef with tripe.  The soup, for me, comes out quite tasty especially letting the peppers that they provide soak in there long enough to provide some spiciness.
author: H K.

description: Good prices, good food. Didn't knock my socks off. Can't put my finger on what bothers me about this place. I has the hue spicy noodle soup with beef and pork. It was not that spicy even after I added rooster sauce. Anyway, I'll probably try it again.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Came to get some late night pho since Loi's wasn't open at 10 but PPQ was. I got the generic special pho that is at every pho place with tendon, brisket, rare steak, tripe and meatballs (medium bowl $7). It was rather underwhelming. 

The bad: The noodles broke into short pieces as I fished them out with my chopsticks. Broth was, as others have said, a little bland. Can't really taste the spices they used. Skimpy on the garnish--no slices of onion, just a tiny smatter of green onion and cilantro. Only 1 meatball. That's fine, but at least cut it in half so it looks like I have 2! I have to bite it in half to eat it anyway! And there was only 1 lone piece of tendon!

The good: They topped the bowl with one slice of rare steak, and it stayed rare till I swished it around in the broth to cook it.

Wish Loi's were open later. $4 vs $7 for a superior bowl of pho is a no brainer.
author: Crystal L.

description: My best friend works here! But I will have to give it a-OK because I felt like I was jippppped! Anyways I ordered the five spiced chicken vermicelli bowl with the imperial rolls. When the food came my bowl only had like 3 pieces of chicken? I expected to get more then 3 pieces of chicken! I had more imperial rolls then chicken! The good thing is that we got thai iced tea on the house and that our food came quick because I WAS HUNGRY!
author: Janet Z.

description:
all i have to say is chicken curry pho.  never had this combo before PPQ and never will i get it out of my mind.  so damn good.  so for that, 5 stars... oh, and they have viet beer and viet coffee. 

and get the small bowl.  it's huge.  i haven't been able to finish it yet...and i can EAT.
author: Jen S.

description: In a neighborhood with MANY MANY choices for Pho and other wonderful Asian soups, PPQ is a close winner with it's chicken soup.  I recommend getting the vermicelli noodles over the flat noodles.  Besides that, the soup itself is mightily tasty and gets better the more times you eat there.
author: David K.

description: My first time here and also my last. The food was so so. But that's not the reason why I won't come back. There was a dead fly on the lettuce and the lemon was rotten. Yuck! What a bad 1st impression. The waiter did apologize and gave me a new plate of lettuce with no bugs, but this time the lettuce was just wilted. Didn't even bother asking for another lemon at that point. Ordered the 5 spice chicken with pho. The 5 spice chicken was good as the other reviews have mentioned but the pho had no taste. It was so bland. Wth? I thought it would've been loaded with MSG. Lol. Oh! But the imperial rolls were good.  The freshness, quality, and taste of the food was just not there.
author: Beth L.

description: Don't get me wrong. I love the food here but sometimes I feel like I'm getting ripped off for the portion size. I am not a huge eater and not a crazy fan of meat but charging 8.95 for barley 2 oz of beef + 2 egg rolls and rice noodles is a bit over priced. I don't care if you use Angus beef which by the way" no longer stated in their menu" but that is hella little beef for 9 dollars! I am never going to order that again!
author: Aylee G.

description: This place is normally good and usually has a lot of people in it, which means it gets good business.  However, after my last visit here 2 days ago (after not coming here for a while), I was disappointed.  I ordered the #1, as I always do, but this time the broth was watered down and it wasn't even that hot.  The broth looked clearer than it usually does for some weird reason.  Next time, I think I'm going to try the pho place across the street from this one.
author: abby q.

description: Okay, not even gonna lie, I had my first bite of pho just last weekend thanks to Cindy & Theresa. Whenever I go to Vietnamese restaurants, I NEVER order the pho. I don't know why, I mean the slurping of noodles and the splashing of MSG-laden soup just never appealed to me. But when I told Cindy & Theresa that I've never had pho before, they were flabbergasted and demanded that I order some. So, I ordered a small #1, which Cindy pointed out is like the #2 except it comes with a beef ball--ONE beef ball; btw, that beef ball cost an extra 50 cents. I must say that the noodles were soft and the soup was not overly salty, so I was not at all disappointed. We also ordered some imperial rolls, which were pretty good as well. Okay, thanks, Theresa & Cindy, I will order pho more often now! :)
author: Audrey T.

description: I love noodles.  Chinese, Japanese, Vietnamese, Thai, Italian ... I guess it's the Asian in me.  The one problem I have is finding really good soup noodle that doesn't include pork or beef.  Overall, the dishes at Pho Phu Quoc are all fine but the chicken curry noodle soup is great.
