Often, if we go here late, they run out and I am heart-broken that I must settle for one of the other soup noodles.  I guess the lesson here is early diner catches the curry worm ...
author: Jessica G.

description:
Interesting that at a Vietnamese restaurant none of the staff or even the person who cashiers - the owner or related somehow - can speak Vietnamese.  I think the best thing on their menu is their five-spice chicken, which I think tastes more Chinese-like then Vietnamese.  

I even entertain giving it one star because of the horrible service (similar to White T's 7/10/06 post) and high MSG factor (see other posts), but I know some care more that it's cheap and tasty enough.  
During slow times, the service is passable, but the service is NEVER great.
author: Faye W.

description:
I live in this neighborhood and it has been an absolute joy to stand witness to the  'great pho wars' that have torn this neighborhood apart for years.  Friendships have been lost, family members banished to even deeper, darker corners of the sunset...all over who's pho reins supreme.

But a las, the people of the outer sunset have spoken!  There is peace on the PPQ front as a clear leader has risen from Irving like a vietnamese phoenix - yes, this native son, is none other than Pho Phu Quoc!!!  

...and don't forget to try the bun here...it's pretty delicious as well.

p.s. they don't take plastic, so bring cash.
author: John H.

description: This is the best pho and 5 spice chicken in the city and perhaps the world.  The 5 spice chicken pho comes with the chicken on the side, a tantalizing slab of super-crispy on the outside, juicy on the inside chicken, conveniently sliced into striplets.  It pleases me when crispy chicken comes on the side because I like the option to plunk some chicken in my pho and eat some from the plate.  I am a little in love with their spicy Cambodian coconut vermicelli noodle soup - #8 on the menu.  I've never had this soup anywhere else; it's creamy and spicy and full of lemongrassy, chickeny goodness and surprise chunks of fried potatoes, which sounds gross, but is strangely delicious.  PPQ's cold noodle rolls are also amazing, as is the bun (cold noodle salad).   Complimentary tea and cheap prices.  $6.75 for the small bowl of soup, which is huge.
author: T L.

description: This is my GO-TO restaurant whenever I'm craving pho.  The food is fast, cheap, and consistently good.  Lines can get long during the weekend lunches, but definitely worth the wait.
author: Caroline C.

description: A no-nonsense restaurant with great food, clean utensils, and reasonable prices. My "go to" place for a good bowl of Pho and they got some kick ass spring rolls! Wait can be a pain at times tough during peak dining hours.
author: Wil L.

description:
I ordered the oxtail soup which is one of my favorite kinds of soups.  The oxtail was tender, but the broth had  a sweet artificial taste.  Then I discovered that they use MSG.  That explained everything.

Very disapointing that they need to enhance their cooking by trying to flavor it via artifical means.  They can't stand by their own cooking.

Thus, the broth for me totally sucked.  I will never go back since I HATE MSG.
author: Dina L.

description: Get the coconut curry pho, but with beef brisket and pho noodle substitutions to the usual chicken and vermicelli noodle. You wont regret it. My favorite pho hands down.
author: Brian T.

description:
We had the same experience with a recent reviewer where they came and asked us to move to a smaller table.  I felt bad since we were having a good conversation and enjoying our food, and the table we had was already small to start with.

We live only a couple of blocks away and have since eaten at Pho Hoa Hiep across the street.  The food is comparable and we have never been asked to move mid-dinner.  

Rated on food alone, they should be somewhere around 2.5/4 stars.  But of course service is a big part of dinning out so I give them a 2.
author: V P.

description: I love pho, hands down and I decided to try this out since my cousin's friend told him about this place and since we were in the area, I decided to try it with him. He always gets their 5 spice chicken bun while I got my usual Tai Pho (the one where it comes with only flank steak) and man, it was good. The broth was tasty and the meat was very tender. I always ask for my meat to be on a separate place since I like to cook it myself in the broth. I also tried the Five-Spice chicken as well which is really good as well. A definite place to check out if you are a pho lover like me!
author: Sean E.

description: If you are looking for some pho that will satisfy your craving on a chilly San Francisco night, this is the place! The staff is fast and the food is always fresh. I had the chicken pho and it is full of flavor! Also, the fact that a large serves two people at a such a reasonable price is a plus!
author: Manda P.

description:
it was my mom's birthday today, so my brother decided to treat my family to viet for dinner. we arrived in the outer sunset and decided on ppq, not kevin's. this was a mistake. we ordered the oxtail stew rice plate,charbroiled pork chop plate, ppq beef noodle soup, and rare flank and meatball noodle soup.

my mom's oxtail stew plate was pretty decently sized, but the bulk of it was just rice. my pork chop was really greasy and half fat/half meat (which meant that there was barely anything there to eat for $8.00, unless you count the two pickled carrot slices and nutrition-less iceberg lettuce that accompanied the monster scoop of rice that came on the plate). my brother had ordered his his flank steak and meatball pho with flat noodles, but they told him that they had run out already (dinner just started). both his and my dad's pho bowls were quite large, but the substance inside was not. noodles were distributed in a stingy manner, and the actual meat content was scant at best. the restaurant also skimped on their bean sprouts, and they only gave us one sprig of basil to divide between the two pho bowls.

i don't know about the other dishes, but mine was really greasy and salty. the dish was supposed to come with the nuoc mam sauce on the side, which it did, but my chop was already doused in it beforehand. MAKES NO SENSE. i came home really unsatisfied and not full, so i had to make a separate dinner. my mouth was also super parched even though i had guzzled down a cup of water at the restaurant, a cup which smelled like my waitress's perfume...also, when i had asked her about what kind of veggies come in the 1.95 side order, she said, "just order the veggie plates on the back and share with everyone." i said maybe, but let me see what is in the veg side first. she said, "nah, just go with the bigger plate." i told her forget it then, and she said, "no, no, we can do the side plate." i had become disenchanted by then and had already given up. our total came out to 32.58, without tip, which is a very reasonable price for 4 people eating dinner, but it definitely was not worth the amount of food (and its quality) we received and bad service.
author: Danny C.

description: my go to pho place, I'm never dissapointed and for me this is pho, I mean don't get it twisted I have no clue what "authentic" pho is, I'm Russian, I'll show your real vodka, real piroshki, and some salads, but not pho. I've had alot of different pho from living in San francisco and being hung over alot, and I keep comparing all the other places to this, minus one star because the service is iffy, asked for the check and sat there for 15 mins, ended up going to the cashier to pay. I get the 5 spice chicken or the seafood pho, also their carpachio is bomb
author: Sergey A.

description: Oh good god!  This is the best food ever!  I've been coming here for years sand It never disappoints!  It was the only thing I could ever eat when I was pregnant!  Best Pho in town!  Try it
author: Raquel B.

description: Ive been here a handful of times because my boyfriend likes it and its rather inexpensive. The first time i ordered the 5 spice chicken and liked it, however it gave me the worst diarrhea of my life the next day.  I went back because my boyfriend and his friends had has a hankering for Pho and its literally right across the street from where we live. The 3 people i went with all ended up getting sick off the food.  My boyfriend ordered the 5 spice chicken, my friend ordered Curry chicken and my other friend ordered the regular Pho with tendon and tripe. I ordered a papaya salad, which is probably why i was the only one that night that did get sick.  I fell asleep to the sound of 2 different people throwing up. This place is DANGEROUS TO EAT AT.
author: Yolanda V.

description: I eat here at least once a week. I rotate between the #4 small, Five spice chicken or the chicken spicy curry noodle soup. Imperial rolls and beef carpaciou (sp?) is good too. I love that you can pay by credit card now instead of being a cash only joint.
author: Julie F.

description: I don't really like eating pho here.. i think the place across the street is better.. but i like the rice plates from here, its pretty good! I don't come here often because parking on irving sucks..boo...!!
author: Heather C.

description:
I am a creature of habit and always order one type of pho: meatballs and rare steak.  I have eaten this particular type of pho combination in over 2 dozen restaurants.  Maybe more, I swear.  

Can you imagine how far my stomach sank when I hungrily accepted the pho bowl at PPQ, only to see 3 meatball pieces and 2 small slices of rare steak?!  WHAT!?  

This has never happened.  Panicked, I looked around the room.  It was a full restaurant with happy customers.   Across the table, my boyfriend was happy with his meal.  Am I missing something?  

I calmed down and asked the waiter for more meatballs.  He came back with 2 more pieces of rare steak, no meatballs.  

Do I really need to further explain the 2 stars?
author: Mai N.

description: You must order the Vietnamese Carpaccio.....best $13.00 I've ever spent. Tender (ginormous) mound of raw beef sprinkled with basil, peanuts and crispy shallots.  Phenomenal.
author: Christina S.

description: The wait can be long sometimes, but this is one of my favorite places to get pho. And when I'm not in the mood for pho, I like the barbeque pork rice plate. Everything I've tried here tastes good.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Consistently good pho, except for the wayward bits of tripe that sneak into my soup & pretend to be noodles.  Little phockers.
author: Jess T.

description: i love coming here for pho and their appetizers.  I usually get the shredded pork spring roll and their 5 spice chicken pho. It is soo yummy the five spice chicken!! That chicken will leave you craving for more!! The portions are decent sized for medium but if you get large, you better be really hungry because the large bowls really fill you up!
author: Juliana L.

description:
Five spice chicken to die for. Best served with bun (cold rice noodles). Stir up the noodles, find all kinds of goodies underneath, like sprouts, mint, peanuts, pour on the vinegar sauce, then slip the chicken on top. Takes a while to eat, which is good for a hangover. Their broth is nowhere near as good as Yummy Yummy, so I stay away from the clear pho and go with the bun.

As others have suggested, curry pho is also life-affirming. Haven't seen it much elsewhere, coconut milk base, reminds you of Thai food, very addictive.

Place is incredibly popular, try to come off hours, like mid-afternoon on the weekend. If truly incredible pho is your thing, and you believe it starts with the broth, like me, then this maybe isn't your place. But the five spice chicken really is superior, and you can even order just a plate of the chicken.

Service is brisk and impersonal, not a place to linger unless you're with a big group. Good place to "feed" if you're in solo mode.
author: Jay K.

description:
Pho Phu Quoc. Best pho in the city besides my mom's house. Don't know about anything else there. Too bad they don't speak Vietnamese (!) and they don't use the wide noodles. But I can't find those noodles anywhere else either. Bad experiences mean you probably went late at night or at a slow time. Despite the quote I had to share (below), I believe the most auspicious times for restaurant pho are morning and noon. What you doing ordering a rice dish at a pho restaurant, foo? Vietnamese cuisine is highly specialized, like the ancient craft neighborhoods of Hanoi. Vietnam II for bun cha gio thit nuoung. Anh Hong for 7 kinds of beef and table-top grilling. Thap Rua in the Tenderloin for pho ga (chicken pho). Thanh Long for crab. That place on Larkin where all the construction workers go for Vietnamese sandwiches. Le Soleil used to have an exquisite banh xeo (crepe) but I haven't been there in years.

"Morning, noon, afternoon, evening, late night, anytime is a good time for a bowl of pho. During the day, having an additional bowl of pho is like brewing a second pot of tea when the company is enjoyable; almost nobody would turn down an invitation to a pho shop. And the beauty of it is that pho makes it possible for a poor man to treat his friends without breaking the bank." 
-Nguyen Tuan, Canh Sac va Huong Vi Dat Nuoc (Scenery and Flavor of My Country)
author: Katrina D.

description: If you're looking for pho, look across the street to Kevin's Noodle House. The only reason to get pho here is if Kevin's is closed (PPQ is open until 11 on weekdays, while Kevin's closes at 10). They do have a more extensive menu though, and I've always found their food to be pretty good. Not worth a special trip, but a worthy option if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Brian H.

description:
love it. 
spring rolls & BBQ shrimp bun. or vege pho.
no ambiance & bathrooms aren't the cleanest, but it's good food.
author: Alana R.

description: Please if you plan on going here for pho... please don't.  It's a sad sad sad thing to have people experience pho like this because it can leave bad impressions.  First of all, I tried ordering in Vietnamese and the waitress didn't even understand me.  In fact, no one in there talks vietnamese.  How sad is that?!  I should've known better just by that interaction, but I stayed and ordered the pho.  The pho broth is oily, the meat is oily, and the broth isn't even good.  The only reason why i would ever come back there is for their beef carpaccio because Kevin's Noodle House (or Pho Hoa Hiep across the street) doesn't have it.  Other than that, I refuse to come back here, and will even ditch my friends to go across the street.
author: Diane L.

description: seriously, the imperial rolls are effin' ridiculous. we had gotten some pho's this time around. i got the raw beef on the side which was totally fun to cook it at my own pace. he got the chicken pho and it was the kinda of chicken soups grandmas would make aka delicious. i did see something that could possibly top that, its next on my list to try- the noodle dish with five spice chicken AND imperial rolls cut into bite size pieces. i mean combining these two items and throwing it into pasta just seems orgasmic :)
author: Abigail W.

description:
Another over rated pho place.

I ordered the 5 spice chicken with imperials rolls. My noodles were colder than I liked and the chicken portions were small. The imperial rolls however were fantastic. Service sucked here even though I sat right in front of the register.
author: Brian W.

description: priced higher....pho bigger....justification to higher pricing in bigger pho....priced just under $eight large...enormous pool of pho....mound of thin rice noodles.....tasting standard....appetizers being dark fried rolls tasting decent...small sizing...standard portioning....but..wishing for frying in fresher cleaner oil.....chugging '33' beer....at first refreshing....second decent...third luke warm....pushing back 'n' passing....no warm beers please....
author: Hen A.

description: I usually stick with Pho Hoa Hiep II when I'm craving pho, but my grandmother insisted that we try PPQ Restaurant last week. I was very impressed by their imperial rolls -- to say they were addictive is an understatement! Every bite was filled with super delicious, crispy goodness, which perfectly complemented my pho with the extra hot and delicious broth. Yummy.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
i believe the difference between the #1 and #2 bowls are tripe and beef meatball.

for an additional $1.25, i got one stamp shaped tripe, and one grape sized beef meatball.  scammed.

*breaks beer bottle...*
author: Ethan L.

description: This is my favorite pho restaurant in the whole city, their service and food is excellent. The only bad part about this place is the seating, there isnt a lot of seats available like their competition across the street. Their pho noodles, spring rolls, and their egg rolls are DELICIOUS. I always come here whenever I'm around the neighborhood. I'd rather come here than the other place across the street. Never going to that other place again. This pho place is the yummiest one. (:
author: Claudia M.

description:
Driving back from the peninsula stopped by a chain restaurant to visit my roommate who bartends there.  Ewwwwww...I felt dirty going in, and dirtier running out after seeing that he wasn't working.  MUST...GET...BACK...TO.....THE...HOOD, I drive as fast as possible out of the crowded strip mall parking lot.  WTF...full parking lot when the only things that were open were places like Appleby's.

HUGE sigh of relief when the bf and I walked into PPQ.  It's not the most appetizing atmosphere, however it's all about the food.  It's a quick meal choice and really delicious.  We started off with the fried calamari, even though they were the big strips, not the rubber bands and spiders I normally like to eat, they came out nicely coated and not over cooked.  We also had the pork spring rolls, they weren't my absolute favorite, no specific reasoning behind that, I think we would have been happier with the shrimp ones.  I had the pork vermicelli dish, lots of mint and greens under rice noodles, topped with delicious grilled pork.  It was really tasty with the siracha hot sauce and some fish sauce poured on top.  The BF had the chicken curry in clay pot.  YUM, it was a generous portion of wonderfully seasoned curry with loads of white meat (ie. identify able cuts of chicken).  I am in fact trying to curb myself from having the leftovers with my coffee this morning.  

 We didn't arrive there until nearly 9:30, ate a huge meal, went home and dumped ourselves into bed and because the meal was so fresh didn't feel like crap on a full greasy belly.

Update:  Just finished the leftovers, lasted me two meals today.  Still good the second day!!
author: Brye L.

description:
two words: beef carpaccio!

it really deserves the exclamation point. i couldn't get enough of it. 

thinly sliced beef resting atop a bed of sliced thai basil leaves, with chopped fried garlic, peanuts, fried scallions and nuoc cham dipping sauce. the beef had been marinating in lime juice, i believe, and was extra tender, like the round rice noodles in my hue noodle soup. oh WOW, was it good. 

i tried to be polite and offered the last bite to my man-friend, but was secretly giving it the lustful eye, and crossing my toes hoping he'd decline. he did. 

me thinks this last gesture was the reason he got a little lovin' last night. here's to the power of tasty raw beef!

(cash only, neighborhood joint)
author: May T.

description: Great Vietnamese restaurant. The shrimp roll and pork roll are excellent, The Pho noodles are fresh and in large portions. Parking is the only problem if you can find it.
author: deals y.

description: I think their pho needs to go back to wherever it came from.  I went there once and I ain't coming back for more.  They should be embarassed to serve this stuff to Vietnamese people but LOL I was the only Vietnamese in there.  The waiter could barely speak Vietnamese. Even my Vietnamese manicurist agrees that this place sucks.
author: Amber L.

description:
i heart this place.  the homies have been talking it up so when i finally i had Very high expectations, and they were all met, and then some! 

very small place and if you have to wait you end up, even if you're not intending too, kinda just stand there muggin' on people eating to get them to get up and not dilly-dally around.  haha.

the coconut curry pho is where it's at. though each option comes with a certain broth/sauce, you can substitute for whatever you like. the deep fried veggies rolls were Amazing. maybe the best i've had. seriously. 

the servings are also HUGE. i got the small and ended up taking half of it home. and it was like 8pm at night and i hadn't eaten all day so i was starving. still couldn't finish. 

the bestest most wonderful part? totally affordable! the small bowl of pho was only like $6.95. yes!
author: nzingha s.

description: The Vietnamese are serious about naming their restaurants; none of this "Golden Flower Delight" or "Five Spice Lotus Plum" sh*t for them, no, they go hardcore with their names.  Pho Phu Quoc is an odd little noodle house with a sky light.  The place resembles my high school cafeteria much more than it does a restaurant dining room. I knew a vietnamese girl named Phuc Yu in high school, I sh*t you not. But I digress. I got the rice vermicelli noodles with five spice barbequed beef and a side of imperial rolls, it was pretty darn swell.
author: Rick H.

description: This is a common go to restaurant for my gf and I.  Its close, cheap (cash only), fast and always good.  I love the Curry noodle soup.  I'm pretty sure its just a bowl of pho with a whole can of coconut milk and some curry, but it's dam good.  My gf always gets the Imperial rolls with beef and vermicelli, again, always good.  It's not a fancy place, just a place to get consistently good Vietnamese food.  The wait staff are fast to severe you, but as with many places it can be hard to get an extra glass of water.  I hate that.
author: Robert S.

description: A great place to come for pho on a chilly San Francisco evening, a common occurrence in this neighborhood.  I was here for a late-night meal on a recent Wednesday, and was amazed at how many people were here.  I think they were open til 11 or 12, which is good to know!  My friend got the pho with tripe, which I had never tried before.  I took a little nibble at his suggestion that it was really good here, but I have to say, I am not a fan.  The beef in my soup was good, but I was also not too fond of the meatballs.  Good noodles, and fantastic peanut sauce!  (It was served with our spring roll appetizer.)
author: Lindsay B.

description: Although the setting looks a little like a cafeteria, Ppq delivers cheap, hearty, and yummy noodle bowls.  If you aren't in the mood for the pho and you want a lighter meal you can always try their summer spring rolls (with mint leaves).  One con is that they only accept cash...but there are ample amounts of banks in the area.
author: Jaki B.

description: I've been going here since I was for 12 years and the haole invasion recently came through...  I was waiting to get seated and you let some gai jin butt-plugs cut me for the second time!!!  you guys screwed me, mufaka LOYAL CUSTOMER!!!
author: erik e.

description:
Ahhhh the BEST cheap noodle soup bowl around. I could eat here every day. 
I'd give it 5 stars but there was a hair in the soup the last time..
author: Jen H.

description: Not opened yet but coming soon. Since their PPQ Chicken Noodle House wasn't very popular and closed down, PPQ is set to open another 3rd restaurant, PPQ Beef Noodle House! It will be located at the old New Cheung Hing Space.. I really love PPQ so hopefully this will be a big hit!!
author: Juliane N.

description: "PPQ!!! Phu for days!! Yummy hot, steamy bowls of brothy, noodlely and meaty soup. Mmmm.....you can't go wrong with any of the soups that this place doles out. With it comes sprouts, basil, lemon and jalapenos in a side dish for additional condiments-all fresh. For some crunchy substance pre soup-dive they have great Imperial Rolls that come with lettuce, cucumber and mint and some vinegar dipping sauce. Tastyness...and pretty low cost, too. Perfect Outer Sunset food fare...warms up the body in minutes."
author: Jay H.

description: Gotta love this place.  the grilled pork on vermicelli noodles is the best I've had anywhere - and I've been to a lot of cheap Vietnamese places.
author: Harry W.

description: Simple Vietnamese resturant.  My friends and I usually come here after taking our midterms or finals.  I love their five-spiced chicken pho....always felt better after a bowl.
author: Mick S.

description: Not the cheapest pho, but big portions. Lost of noodles but just fair amount of meat. Soup tastes a bit bland. I guess good if you need to watch your salt intake. 5 spice chicken seems fine. Tofu salad is alright also. Prices are not that cheap. To me not worth waiting in line for this quality of food.
author: Dijon Y.

description: I've been going here for a few years now and it's the best place for noodle soup on a cold winter day. My favorite is #8, the curry chicken noodle soup!!!! SOOO GOOD!!!! I'm salivating just thinking about the yummy coconut curry soup! MMmmmmmm......
author: Sharon H.

description: This place has decent food, definitely worth the price. However, the Pho broth was a little bland. Definitely worth a try.
author: David A.

description:
How does PPQ not have five stars? If you know the city, this place is legendary in SF. It's by far the best pho in the city. Every other place you go to will probably be okay, but not PPQ. the pho is amazing and is perfect for every cold night in the city and in the sunset. I usually get the rare beef pho which is five stars as well. raw beef cooked at the bottom of the broth and a little sauce with thai basil? i'm not sure there's anything else more perfect. another regular dish for me is the imperial rolls with bbq pork or beef vermicelli. you really can't beat it. 

one thing against PPQ is that, you could say the service isn't five stars. probably three and a half stars. but working in a restaurant that's always busy and dealing with a line out the door isn't always all that easy. plus, if service is just okay and the food is great, does anybody really remember the service? as long as it's not atrocious, and ppq's waiters aren't that bad. i once saw a guy take this racist drunk white lady's crap for an hour and didn't even kick her out. so i guess that's an extra star to them. 

i would recommend PPQ to everyone. keep in mind, however, that the restaurant will pretty much always be crowded and you should try and avoid tables closest to the door. not that people are rude, but it often gets so crowded in there that people will be standing right behind you if you're close to the door. ENJOY!
author: Austen K.

description:
2 years ago i would have given this place 5 stars. i used to eat here all the time, since my st annes days. i always got #5- which is fabulous and will make you sweat. when i do come here, i get #5 still.

the prices have increased - i think they are too high for pho.
the quality has gone down since back in the day.
my fave waitress doesnt work here anymore. 
they take credit card here now, but jesus the prices are too high.
author: just k.

description: My little brother was the first one to tell me about this place years ago, and he used to hang out with the "bad" city kids. Back in the day, their high-haired, Z.Cavaricci-wearing selves never studied and just hung out at Asian eateries. Obviously, the "bad boys" of SF middle schools knew where to find the best pho.
author: jenn h.

description:
i think i've been going here for lunch once per week for the last 4 months.

my hands down favorite dish is the spicy crab tofu soup with extra lime.  

the imperial rolls are piping hot and crispy w/ refreshing greens on the side.  

inexpensive, consistent, and fast service.  

i haven't brought anyone here who hasn't liked it.
author: kim n.

description: I love this place! I come here almost once a week! The chicken nice noodle soup, Crab meat noodle soup and Fried Tofu Cabbage Salad are my top three favorite here!
author: Jenny C.

description: PPQ's food never wows you, but is consistently above average to good. It's also cheap and hits the spot for late night meals. The food usually comes out pretty quickly.
author: Bill K.

description:
this place is A-OK to me. kudos for staying open till 11pm with good service and fast yummy food. 

yummy summer rolls in my tummy. I have a very picky friend who insists the pho here is better than the pho across the street in pho hoa hiep with the red awning. I have to say I agree. 

I repeat. yummy summer rolls in my tummy. Must try.
author: Scarlet S.

description: Something about the service here bugs the heck out of me. It just seems like they really don't care if you actually like the food or if you actually want to come back. What I really like here is the Chicken Pho. That actually is the only thing that I really  like here. The broth is tasty and comes in a pretty decent size bowl. My bf usually orders the Five Spice Chicken noodle soup. The chicken is yummy. I have tried it and the chicken is tender. The food is decent, but the service here definitely makes me not want to come back here. I think there are better  choices for Vietnamese food on Irving than PPQ.
author: carebear l.

description:
We decided to try this place after a Yelper canonized the garlic noodles & crab.  But...OOPS...we went to the WRONG PPQ on Irving. The garlic noodles & roasted crab are only served at the PPQ Dungeness Island on Clement  W-M.  "Du-fus", me hubs says to me. We stayed anyhoos to try:  Ox-tail stew rice plate $6.95, Imperial rolls $5.95, and Seafood Noodle Soup, small $6.50 and 5 spice chicken rice plate $6.75.

The 3 fried egg rolls had an outer skin which was a paler, anemic shade from what I'm used to seeing. I wasn't sure it was fully cooked when it arrived.  Parts of the outer wrap/skin was chewy.  It was OK, wouldn't order again.  It did come with lettuce, cucumber & mint to wrap around the roll.  The ox-tail was definitely better than the dish served at Little Henry's in the Richmond district.
I actually prefer the broth and pho at Kevin's Noodle House, across the street.  I could barely finish it all.  It came with 2 slices fried tofu, 2 shrimp, 3 pieces of squid and about 4-5 seafood balls.  It didn't look like it would be enough food for a high school linebacker vs mini-me.  The noodles were long, thin rice noodles, a clump in the middle and bottom of the bowl.  I had to give it a good stir and yank with the chopstixs to mix it up.  The noodles had a nice chewy texture.  The fried tofu slices had an after taste, didn't like that.  
My kid liked the 5 spice chicken at Kevin's Noodle house better but they do give more chicken here, a whole piece sliced up with rice.  Kevin's will give you a sm bowl of plain MSG ladened broth to go with that same order.  The place is frequented by families but a group of 10 high schoolers came in as we were leaving.  Even a young police officer stopped by to look at the menu, nodded in acknowledgment at the owner, looked at the menu, changed his mind & left.
Hubs says the true test of a good restaurant would be where the cops go, citing they know where the good, inexpensive places are to eat.  If that's the case, that young slender cop is headed in the right direction.  In time, he'll earn the esteemed jutting happy belly so commonly adorned by our SFPD blues.  CASH only.
author: Ry T.

description: This was actually one of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in the city... UNTIL I found a big cockroach in my Pho.  And then they didnt even apologize and comp our entire meal!  The negatives are that there are house flies and fruit flies around and the kitchen is dirty. Another negative is that if you go there for dinner, you may get a whiff of tobacco smoke from the people hanging outside of the bar next door.... yuck!  The food is good and reasonably priced.  I always get the Five Spice Chicken Noodle Soup (#7) and their Beef Noodle Soup is also good too (#4).  I guess the extra spice comes from the roaches and flies.
author: Mary W.

description:
The highlight of the meal was twofold. First off was the imperial rolls. While the cost of a roll plate was significant, 6 bucks for 3 rolls. It came with a good amount of lettuce and other fixings. Second was the ice coffee. While it is hard to really screw up viet ice coffee the method of serving was what caught my eye. It was dripped into a pretty, but simple, silver cup.

The negatives were twofold. One was the fish sauce. I'm pretty sure it is the prepackaged stuff u can get from ur local asian market. It was incredibly sugary. And lacked any spice punch. Second was the pork. I got the chargrilled vermicelli noodle bowl. The pork was really fatty. The person I ate with removed half her pork because of this. It also wasn't really that special. They had no real kick or spice in it. 

That was the highlights. The rest was ok. The bowl was lacking in cucumber. And the bowl with the rolls didn't have enough pork for eating the noodles. Of course that's to be expected as u are supposed to eat the noodles with the rolls.

Pork bowl was 8 bucks and the coffee standard 2.75.

Meal total 13
author: H B.

description: Mmmmmm... it's the only place where I can count on my rare beef to be raaaww!
author: Faffy L.

description: This place is better than Pho hip hop (pho hoa hiep)....cuz that place is nassssssssssssssty. This place isn't that bad though, BUT Vietnamese & Chinese restaurants should learn that it is 2007 and credit cards should be accepted everywhere. goshhhh its not that much to rent  a credit card machine....us asians are so cheap...i swear...ha
author: Rosalynn D.

description: five spice chicken, but a bit pricey if you want the best of both worlds. try getting bun bo hue and the chicken on the side.
author: Moko R.

description:
My fave Vietnamese joint in town. Sure, there are numbers of others, but for a comfortable, fresh, reasonable meal, this is my pick. I have their number programmed into my phone, and have to quietly order on the bus home for takeout. It's always the #15 (imperial rolls with grilled pork). Crispy rolls with a thin skin. Carmelized, charred pork with sweet marinade. Peanuts and green onions on cold vermicelli. Yum. Satay noodles and Pho are also great standbys. If it is lunch, I get the Iced Coffee with glorious beans from a local roastery. I'm gonna keep the name of that a secret. I'm already talking about this place aren't I?
BTW, if you are into a$$ kissing service, you won't get it here. But the wait during peak hours mean others will gladly take your place if you get turned off. The prices have also been upped a bit to pay for their long overdue, but barely noticeable remodel. If the creme brule tempts you, resist. It is some lame out of the box thing with NO carmelized,  sugar shield top thing. Just a crumbled sugary sprinkling.
Instead, if you want heavenly creme brule in the Sunset district, go to David's on Taraval.
author: E. W.

description: This place is a shocker!  The first few times I have eaten here, it was so-so, but I went there last weekend and something changed!  I love pho noodles and when I ordered it this time, they had the most delicious strips of steak in the soup and I was in hoison-sauce-dipping HEAVEN!  Also try their imperial rolls!  (If you like rolls, that is.  If not, then you won't like them.)  DUH!
author: Keika L.

description:
curry chicken noodles was pretty good. . . .just enough coconut milk to cut into the spice in just the right way.  my bf had the pho - the broth is stronger than most pho places in the south bay. . heavier in cinnamon and anise, if you like it that way.  my sister got the 5spice chicken and it looked really good.  i'll have to try that the next time i come.

i also like that you have your choice of chicken, beef, fish or hue (spicy lemongrass beef) broth with any noodle dish.
author: erika n.

description: Eh- I guess PPQ will do the job if you're craving some comforting noodle soup or rice plate on a cold day.  All the apps we had were decent- imperial rolls, spring rolls, and vietnamese carpaccio.  However, the pho was meh- noodles were good and chewy but the broth was bland and the meat was cut oddly so it cooked way too fast.  My friends thought the 5 spice chicken was akin to jerky.
author: Amina B.

description:
PPQ--you suck! what's up with bowls of Pho taking longer than 30 min to be served?? hello?! the meter expires in an hour!! it's not hard to re-boil pho noodles, dump in bowl w/piping hot broth which should be simmering over stove at all hours!

btw, Mr. manager at PPQ--your business ethics suck ass--nickel & diming your waitresses so you can report less on ur taxes reserves you a spot in hell.
author: Yolanda L.

description: Great Vietnamese food, average atmosphere.  It is your typical Pho place with simple tables and chairs, but the food is well priced and tastes so yummy!
author: Pele N.

description: I had to convince my friends to quit writing average reviews for this place.  It's so good, they didn't want a line so they lied!  So good.  Okay there is florescent lighting involved but try the shredded cabbage salad (I hate cabbage mind you but yum with the oil) and the grilled angus beef.  They rock the house, I crave them now!
author: Joan S.

description: Ah, this restaurant is one of my favorites! I love the chicken curry pho and five spice chicken. The servings are large. I usually order the chicken curry pho with a side of rice and pour some of the curry and chicken over the rice for two dishes in one with plenty to take home. The place is usually packed and eating on a cold day can be hard as the door is constantly opening with the wind blowing in. Cash only. I used to live around the corner and my roommate and I would go all the time.
author: Jen R.

description: IF you find yourself freezing in the SF near Lincoln, this is the spot to go. I'm not really a big fan of PHO but my boyfriend & our friends took me here a few times & I'm already starting to crave it! If you look through the menu, there's a lot of appetizing entrees. THE main reason why a lot of my friends go here is for the five spice chicken! It's just cut up pieces of chicken but the seasoning makes it worth while. It comes with rice, tomatoes, or cabbage. If you're feeling cold, I suggest you get the five spice chicken pho -- PHO & five spice. My main dish is Curry soup Pho with five spice on the side :) TRY IT, at least once you won't regret it. Also, try coming in before 10pm so you won't have to wait 'cause seats go fast. I did give this place four stars only because the service is really dull, they just ask you or order ... give it to you & never return to tend to you about any needs (water, napkins, forks, & etc). You have to get up to the register to ask for your check, minus one star.
author: Jazzie D.

description: I am in utter L-O-V-E with their charbroiled beef rice plate!  The marinade and seasoning are scrumptious, the beef is thinly sliced, and it's charbroiled to crispy-edged perfection.  Pour on the nuac mam (some heavenly combination of fish sauce, simple syrup, and lime juice), and I'm pushed over the edge.  Where else can you get such an experience for under $6?  Their pho and imperial rolls are excellent, too.  It's all good enough to make me care less than a hoot about the bland interior.
author: M A N I K.

description: Good pho, fast services. Cleaner than many other pho restaurants.
author: Jeff L.

description: Mmmmmm.  Pho is one of the best culinary inventions known to man. Being a soup junkie, I used to visit PPQ around once a week when I lived in the Sunset. I get to visit less frequently now days, but I do visit every chance I get.  Go for the pork or chicken satay skewers to go with your Pho dish, a perfect compliment, and will surely fill you up.
author: Lucas M.

description: AMAZING FOOD! I have gone here since I was 0 and I LOVE it.  The waiters are really nice, great service, and of course, good food.
author: Barbie W.

description: Greasy and sad vegetable pho.  Flavorless broth.  Large white chunks of raw tofu.  Giant raw brocollis and bok choy.  And that's it.  In the pursuit of delicious veggie pho, this place falls very short.
author: caitlin p.

description: This was one delicious bowl of pho. When I came on a Friday night the place was packed. It was a one party out, one party in situation with a bunch of people crammed waiting in the doorway. The pho broth was really hot, which I like because it maintains its temperature better throughout the meal. And the soup itself was served in what I can only describe as a giant mixing bowl. It was so big that the nice guys next to us were ordering their soup and inquired about the different sizes. They looked at my soup bowl and said loudly that they wanted a bowl smaller than mine...eee. Way to make me seem like a pho piggy guys.
author: Dana H.

description: This is THE BOMB for Pho (pronounced "Phu" not "Pho" as I've been told). They have great cold shrimp rolls to go w/ a steaming hot bowl of any kind of Pho.  Friends have told me that they trek out to the Sunset just to go to PPQ for their inexpensive V-food fix. I'm now a convert, having schlepped to many Pho joints that claim to be the title holder. PPQ takes the prize hands down; a TKO. If I were an ice skating judge, 9.9. Instead: 4 duckets for kick ass Pho!!
author: Johnny C.

description: Yuck.  Horrible Pho.  I felt like I was in a Vietnamese restaurant in New York.  The waitress looked at me like a retard when I asked for vinegar onion for my Pho.  Well, she didn't speak Vietnamese.  I couldn't really blame her when she didn't know anything about Pho.  The soup was bad.  The rice dishes look really good.  I'll try that next time.  If you're used to food in San Jose, don't come to this place.
author: Lan P.

description: Had pho here a few weeks ago on a windy cold Monday night,  The XL bowl was so big I almost passed out after I ate. It kept me full for a long time and warmed up my body. Guess where Im going the next time this damn cold weather comes? But I have to make sure to order the small bowl or else no one will be able to carry my fat ass out the restaurant.
author: Daniel W.

description: Absolutely the best pho within striking distance. Perfect noodles paired with quality indgredients. That means Angus beef, as advertised on their window, fresh vegetables and tofu. Portion size fits the price. Pho broth is genuinely broth and not just water with MSG. The bun (cold noodle) dish contains a good balance of both noodles and the lettuce-bean sprout-veggie salad. You can't go wrong with any of the rice dishes either. This place does not earn five stars because you have to deal with a stinky bathroom if you sit too far in the back of the place. Also, be prepared to wait 10 to 15 minutes during peak times.
author: Laura L.

description:
pho phu quoc you!

i don't like sharing tables at noodle shops. the slurping, people eating with their mouths open so as to share their gastronomic explosions with you sitting next to them (not to mention noises), and last but not least, the drops of soup being dispensed all over your shirt as they slurp in the noodles (i can do this by myself, thank you very much).

all that aside, it's pho. as long as there's msg in the base, it's hard to mess up. for a quickie, come to pho phu quoc. just don't say that in front of your mother - you may get slapped for cussing her out!

at least you don't have to drive down irving very far from 19th to get here. good luck finding a parking space, though.

rating: two rubber hoses
author: dave tastic fantasmo x.

description:
dear PPQ, (clever little acronym, you)

i waited in line for almost 40 minutes on a thursday. at 2:30pm. 

BUT ask me if it was worth the wait... because it truly was. your eggrolls were divine. the curry chicken pho converted me into a fan because i was skeptical at first. the mint was super fresh, your peppers crispy and delicious. even the tea was scalding hot, just the way i like it. god, you're just amazing. the next time im back in san francisco, its just you and me big boy. maybe alice can come.

love, fester
author: Festher C.

description:
this place is actually pretty good.  i ate at their restaurant first and i didn't realize that they had a pho shop.  so what the hey!

depending on certain days they have their good and bad days for the broth.  first time was really good but it's always a hit and miss here.  one thing for sure is that the noodles are never ending!  i don't know why but no matter how much i try to finish there seems to be MORE noodles left in the bowl!  lol  normally i'm able to finish a large but everytime i go here i can never finish all the noodles.  haha
author: mea f.

description: The five-spice chicken pho is totaly awesome!  And so is the price!
author: Amy S.

description:
this place has such a rep for having good pho, b/c everyone is always waiting for a seat. i'd have to suggest just go there wanting pho, and no other expectations, not to be wowed or anything... and you should be ok. the pho here just gets the job done.

yeah, don't sit close to the door, its really cold, and theres people who are waiting to get a seat that stand right behind you breathing on your back basically.

i like the five spice chicken noodle soup. the reason why i like this dish is that its just hot chicken broth, pho noodles, and then u add your regular fix-ins like your lemon, and sprouts and basil and whatever.... i add hot sauce!!! :D

then on the side you have your five spiced fried chicken. if you feel compelled to throw it in the broth, please do. i like its crispy goodness all on its own, with a mouth full of noodles, and to wash it down with some hot, spicy chicken broth. 

basically any of the hot noodle soups will be the thing you need for any cold day in the city... which is like 80% of the year.... 

sucks that you always have to wait for a seat at this place, parking sometimes is an issue, but location is good. 

please don't be tempted to walk across the street to the other pho place with all the empty seating. def a step down. you don't want to do that to yourself right??? 

service is pretty fast. nothing out of the ordinary. 

cash only.

and of course they have your usual hot tea.

this place is pretty crowded, dirty and ghetto, but i guess thats a lot of places, it might be the reason why its so good?? o_O??


and i find the wooden cow in the front a bit odd... but i guess its b/c its beef noodle soup that they serve? hence the cow? haha


***** UPDATE ******

didn't really change my 3 star rating but i just wanted to add that their dessert fried banana and mitchell's ice cream (F.B.I.) is SOOO GOOD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! $4.50

they give you one banana cut into two pieces (i wish they sliced it into slivers) tempura batter deep fried, with two scoops of ice cream in a bowl. they give you orange ice cream, and coconut. SO GOOD!

highly recommended
author: Irene C.

description: Besides the almost certain wait, this place is tops.  Appetizers are fantastic, especially the imperial rolls.  Pho is on par w everywhere else I've tried but the five spice chicken is some of the best I've ever had.  Def worth the wait when you and your homies need a fantastic meal for under $10.
author: Scott R.

description: I just to go here all the time for pho, until one bad incident. I had a bad bowl of pho.. I know, it's only one time, so I give it 4 stars. Probably that batch of broth was done wrong that day, but to a pho lover, that's a big no no. I had the rare beef pho and the soup was not hot and it was filled with oil. The soup was only luke warm, it barely even cooked the raw meat. The oil in the soup is a big turn off, who wants to drink the oil in the soup? I have to admit, this only happened once. The other thing I was a bit disappointed with is the peanut sauce for my shrimp rolls, it was a bit too watery and runny. I'd never had bad cold noodles here before... overall, this is my second choice pho place in sf next to pho hoa heip...
author: Denise L.

description: Fresh seafood, decent priced, not as good as the chinatown eats but this is a vietnamese seafood restaurant i would recommend. Hard to find parking at dinner time, but i believe they are parking space assigned for customer for couple hours, drive by the restaurant to read the signs
author: Angela H.

description:
during my first visit, i tried to order in vietnamese only to be interrupted by the server who said she didn't speak vietnamese. i asked her what language she did speak and she said, "cantonese." when i asked her if there was anybody with whom i could order in my native vietnamese, the server replied, "no, but the owner, who is not here, is vietnamese." 

i was stunned. 

for one, this is a vietnamese restaurant...indeed there are plenty of vietnamese/chinese folks out there but a restaurant run by chinese people who have no affiliation to vietnam (other than that they work in a vietnamese restaurant)??? 

for two, "phu quoc" is an island located in vietnam. my family happens to originate from there. 

these two MAJOR points greatly diminished the restaurant's credibility. 

but then...i had the pho. and it's damn delicious. steeped in the flavors i know and appreciate so well. it's one of the best bowls of pho available in the city. there is NO denying it. i mean, i wish i could say i hate it because of the lack of vietnamese staff. but really, a restaurant should mainly be judged for its cuisine - less for ambiance, service, etc. and pho phu quoc pho really kicks ass. it really does. oh man.
author: Baochi N.

description:
First off, THE EGGROLLS aka the EMPERIAL ROLLS were so YUMMY! 

I ordered the Bun Rieu. It was good but the broth was thick and oiling... I dont know if that's right? 

But all in all it was a good dinning experience and I will definately come back to try out their other specialities =).
author: Nina M.

description:
oh how i miss my ppq! the 5spice chicken -- so good, so good, so good. on bun -- mmmmm. the pho is very tasty here, good broth, especially the chicken. i'm a big fan of the veg spring rolls, so give these a whirl if you can.

a perfect spot for lunch on a sunny day. bright interior and nice vibe. 5spice, i'll be back for you!
author: Antoi C.

description: Best 5 Spice Chicken EVERRRRRRRRRR!!!! Totally makes me forget about the unhappy workers.
author: Stefanie Y.

description: PPQ is my favorite restaurant for a quick and inexpensive Vietnamese fix. The pho here is quite good--try the combination with brisket, tendon, flank, beef balls, and tripe--but the menu of Vietnamese standards merits careful consideration. The imperial rolls and spring rolls are a solid and generously-sized way to start your meal, and the salads, green papaya or cabbage, are clean and flavorful. PPQ boasts two of my favorite dishes anywhere, a magnificent sizzling pork and five spice chicken, magnificently textured and spiced crispy dark meat. Cool off  with a refreshing fresh lemon soda, and for a change of scene, try the PPQ Dungeness Island location located in the Outer Richmond.
author: Jon L.

description: For cheap no frills Vietnamese food Ppq is a good choice.  My favorite dish on the menu is the coconut soup w/ chicken and vermicelli.  They use all white meat and you get a nice portion for the $$.  If you are looking for ambiance and service this is not your spot.  If you like quick food w/ flavor Ppq will not disappoint.  PS.  They only take cash...
author: Kiera E.

description: I took Hizzle Dee for some pho on Saturday. There's nothing better than a bowl of beef pho when you're hung over and sick. We ordered the same type of pho, beef with meatball. The meatball had the texture of a fishball. Weird! I was expecting like italian style meatballs and Heidi started passing the meatballs into my bowl. I thought they kinda skimped on the thin sliced beef. Seriously, I only got like 3 small slices of thin beef over the top. It seemed like they were running low on beef.  The lady who served us just pushed the bowls on the table and walked away without saying anything. I said thank you twice and she just walked away without any eye contact. Good broth, skimpy meat portions and a mean lady in the kitchen.
author: Glenn C.

description: Would've given it five stars but there was a piece of chicken in my vegetarian bowl one out of the five times I've been here thus far.  "Small" servings are filling, "large" are huge.  Pho, rice plates, rolls, skewers....  You can substitute the beef broth for curry or satay for an extra 75 cents.  Try to come here before six-- by dinner time, it can be hard to get a table without a 15 minute wait (especially for groups).
author: Lynn O.

description: It was cold out, I wanted some Pho, went to Irving, saw this place was packed, gave it a try.  Got the PPQ Beef Combo soup, it was excellent.  Everything was fresh, service was quick and attentive, and for $6 I left stuffed on soup.  Complimentary tea is great, and everything coming out of the kitchen looked delicious. I saw and smelled the Curry Pho, I'm going to get that the next time, because I will be back.  Oh yes, don't forget your cash, that is all they take.
author: Scott R.

description: Good Vietnamese food (that is not pho).  Definitely a 4-star in my value for money book.
author: Puchu ..

description: I'm no pho connoisseur, but I wanted pho so I came here and I left satisfied.
author: Marcus C.

description: i still like this place better more than Kevin's Noodle house across the street. PPQ feels more like a family restaurant while Kevin's Noodle House is the place to go to when you're with all your friends on a late night out because they have bigger tables and what not. besides the bigger tables, i think PPQ's pho is better. dont know why, just does, its something in my tastebuds.
author: Kenny L.

description: I've been going to PPQ for years.  Whenever I catch a cold, I run over and order the large #3 and it knocks it right out!  The quality has kind of gone up and down a little bit over the years, but it's still one of the best pho places in town.  The imperial rolls and five spice chicken are also must trys.  Parking, as usual, is terrible and they only take cash.
author: Eric G.

description: All three stars are for the Chicken Curry noodle soup. #8 if memory serves correct. I pretty much only eat this soup. I've tried some of the Pho and the fresh rolls. They are fairly standard. Nothing too exciting. But the #8 chicken curry soup is freakin' amazing. I could eat an entire vat of this stuff. yumm!!!
author: Amanda B.

description: The pho here is really good, and it's my become my stopoff when the desire to pho hits!  There's almost always a wait though, and they don't really have much space for it...which can be a downer when it's raining outside and all you want is a nice steaming bowl of soup.  The staff is usually friendly and attentive and the food is pretty quick.  If you're in the neighborhood, I would recommend trying it out!
author: Kristine C.

description: The 5 spices chicken is da bomb!  You can't really beat the prices here.  The pork chops are also great!
author: Mike K.

description: I've been going to PPQ since I was 7 years old. It has the best flavored broth in the city: perfectly seasoned and not too sweet or anise-y. Their rare beef is top quality Angus steak and is very tender and fresh. Their food quality has remained delicious for many years, which is always comforting. The charbroiled shirmp over rice and the Imperial Rolls are some of my favorites. If you think you are a pho connoisseur, you have to check out PPQ -- the best pho broth in the city. Please note: cash only.
author: Marisa S.

description: I haven't gone to PPQ in years, but had a craving for pho yesterday and stopped by for some take-out.  I don't remember ever seeing it so crowded!  There was even a wait out the door.  Word of mouth must have increased their business over the years.  You can never go wrong with the pho from PPQ!
author: Kris L.

description: Some of the best Pho I have had. They use a good quality beef in a delicious clear broth. Blocks from my house and cheap...a great weeknight meal on a cold winter day.
author: Scott M.

description: I'm a huge fan of PPQ.  The rare beef pho can range from simply delicious to magnificent depending on the day.   I can't really speak to the other dishes except for the fried veggie rolls which are also scrumptious.  If you're going to PPQ, try pho first and then wander into other dishes.  If you go during off hours - before 6pm - it is less crowded except on the weekends when it can be crowded around lunch time.
author: Mary H.

description: I'd say authentic vietnamese food!! yummy!  Besides pho, they have the cold vermicelli, rice plates and they have the rice paper, vermicelli, veggies and meat where you can wrap them yourself.  I have no idea what they call it, but they are yummy.  When you come here, you can't but help compare them to Pho Hoa HIep across the street, b/c both places are about the same and people would ask, why should I come here versus Pho HOa Hiep??  I think Pho HOa Hiep is more like a fast food vietnamese pho restaurant.  When you want cheap pho, that is the place to go.  When you're in the mood for some good vietnamese food, you come here.  Plus, they are way more authentic that Pho Hoa Hiep.  A bit more pricey, but not by that much, couple bucks per dish more, but I think they take much more care about your food at PPQ instead of PHH.
author: AhLin C.

description:
is it REALLY vietnamese?  they sure have a lot of chinese writing up all over the place. 

but it matters not.  i had my first taste of the satay beef pho here and it made my knees buckle.
author: Andrew P.

description: Solid food.  Great price and it's quick for hot food.  Curry noodle soup good.  #1 combo good.  Spicy Pho good.  5 spice chicken good.  Bun with chicken and rolls good.  You leave satisfied with a couple bucks extra to spend on a shot of tequila at Underdogs.
author: goldberg d.

description: This is my favorite Vietnamese restaurant.  My husband and I have been going here for years.  It's nothing fancy, but it's definitely comfort food one can enjoy.
author: Jinny K.

description: OK, so the food is good but the service is awful. "Can I get a water, please?"... And the survey sais? NO! BUZZZ! EEEEGH!!! Whatever the kill noise is. Will I go back. HELL YEAH. Soon? Maybe? How soon. In the immortal words of Black Sheep; "I just don't know. Hun, I just don't know. Somthin' aint right..."
author: Lou Z.

description: Basic inside, with the usual yellowy plasticy feel of Vietnamese and other inexpensive ethnic joints, but oh soooo good food at such great prices.  Love the veggie spring rolls, the papaya shrimp salad is nice, everything i've tried is just great.  Nothing i haven't wanted again. Man, I'm hungry just thinking about it now.
author: Today Y.

description:
the prices are fair, food good and service mediocre. 

1) The pho soup has lots of MSG, dont be fooled - the noodles are over cooked - but still delicious

2) pork chop rice was good, well marninated but obviously fried on a greasy pan and then seared to get grill marks.. oldest trick in the book
author: B H.

description:
in the mood for fried egg rolls that will probably clog your arteries? then come to PPQ and order their imperial rolls! 
these are probably theeeee best imperial rolls ever! wrapped in lettuce and dipped in their yummy sauce...i'm drooling just thinking about it.

oh yea, their pho is uber delicious too! i especially love their tripe. most pho places serve very tough tripe and i can never eat it cause it's just not that tasty. but PPQ's tripe is tender and an A+ in my book!
author: Suzan L.

description: noodles and pho are good! good portions and good prices. fast and easy to deal with. parking is a hassle sometimes, but its not that bad.
author: Q W.

description: Didn't have any pho that last time I was here but I had a plate of really really really good spare ribs & rice. Great customer service too.
author: Maricel B.

description: I've been here over twenty times and always order the same thing, Pho. It's the perfect cure for a cold day and/or a hangover. I've tried a few other things too, all of which has consistently been great.
author: Sara W.

description:
Forget the fact that you may like good, attentive service and expect it everywhere you go for just a moment.  Here, like the movies made by M. Night, suspense of disbelief is in order.  Yeah, I mean that routinely when I now start writing reviews of good Asian restaurants.  Service is not the main thing to write about here, right?? 
Everything that I've had here has been terrific.  All my friends who have been here have enjoyed their plates of 5 spice chicken or good bowl of pho.  Some have even slurped up the entirety of the soup and broth in the curry chicken noodle (I won't point out who right now).  Obviously, I like the place a lot.  Reminds me of my grandma's cooking and places that I go to when I return to L.A. for Vietnamese food.  
But if you're looking to enjoy some exotic food at a good price range, please bring at least four stomachs (by that I mean friends) to the table when you order the carpaccio (perfectly seasoned with Vietnamese spices and garnish).  It's enough for 4 peeps, but too much for two as Paola and I have found out twice :)  If not that, imperial rolls or even the calamari is pretty tasty.
Go there and eat now!
ps they now accept credit cards.
author: felix c.

description: I cannot fully express my love for PPQ. The parking is hell but once you do find a spot, walk inside for some tasty soothing pho. I don't pretend to know a whole helluvalot about pho, but I've had enough to know that this place is my favorite in the city.
author: April B.

description: I think I used to like this place better than the one across it. But I don't recall the beef being as great recently. But the rare steak w/ lemon juice & peanuts (although I'd rather skip the peanuts) is delicious! So if I feel like just pho, I might go across the street. But if I want rare steak w/ lemon juice.. MmMm Mmmm here!!
author: Elaine H.

description: Above average vietnamese food and consistant quality.  I go there often if i want something quick  and simple.  Among the dishes i usually order, 3 color rice plate and 5 spice chicken are good.  The beef pho is good too, but portion is a bit light even with the big size.  Beef stew Pho is a bit too greasy for me.
author: Jasmin Y.

description: My friends and i were touring SF and we came across this Pho restaurant so decided to give it a try since we saw the Yelp sticker on the window and there were a lot of people in there, that's usually a good sign. We all ordered number 2 on the menu. When the bowl came out it was pretty big for a size small. All 3 of us girls are from Orange County and one of our other friend is from SF area and we all agreed the pho here is NOT good. It didnt really taste like pho but since we were so tired and hungry we ate it anyways. This is the second Pho restaurant i've been to in SF and i would have to say the pho here does not even compare to the Pho in Orange County....OC makes the BEST pho all around. Sorry SF...you might be a beautiful city but your pho is anything but. I am Vietnamese and i know what good Pho tastes like and the pho here sure doesnt cut it for me. =( thanks for trying anyways!
author: Leyna V.

description: Used to be my favorite pho place in the entire city. Does not even deserve one star.. Saw a giant rat run across the floor and no one did thing. Gross huge rat the size of a small dog.
author: Kathleen P.

description: Best 5 spice chicken here. That's the only thing I eat (because I don't eat beef or pork). Great summer rolls too but a little overpriced. Their broth is delicious! Not too much MSG.
author: Al T.

description: The set dinner menus are great and includes a variety of the restaurant's specialty including crab and garlic noodles! Definitely a plus for group dinners....
author: Yan M.

description: I'm not a huge fan of Vietnamese food.  But I have to say that PPQ is great when I'm in the mood for it - especially when you branch out from the Pho/5 spice chicken typical dishes.  I really like their prawns wrapped around sugar cane, and their crab is consistently good.
author: Serena Y.

description: My office always orders out from here so I eat here montly. The 5spice chicken pho is delicious! Its a great meal for a cold day...the Vermicelli noodles with beef is also another of my favorites. It comes with an imperial roll (which is the main thing I love about this place). If I eat in here I usually go during the mid afternoon. However lunch on the weekands are usually packed. This place is very tasty with reasonable prices.
author: Miss H K.

description: Boooooooo.  Used to be good 10 years ago.  If you know what good Vietnamese food is, you won't be frequentinghere.  You'd at least walk across street to Pho Hoa Hiep if you're too lazy to get yourself to the TL.  The broth is so thin here, you know it's just MSG and water.
author: Audacity L.

description: I don't order anything but the five-spice chicken over vermicelli here. Pour the sauce over all of it, mix it and eat it up. It is so damn good. Nuff said.
author: Kimberly H.

description: When I'm HUNGRY and I want something fast and large, I go to PPQ. It always seems crowded, but the wait for either seating or food to go is extremely quick. The noodle salads are good, but I usually stick with the special grill (grilled meat on skewers, noodles, rice paper and all the vegetables needed to build your spring rolls). Who knows how I have the patience to actually make the rolls when I'm drunk... but it's real messy, damn fun, and oh so yummy.
author: Cathy C.

description: this place is awsome to go to for pho on those cold nights that us san franciscans have been getting and are used to. my usual is always a #1 large with my meat on the side. OH..and an order of imperial roll to start off with. this place has always been a place for me to go to but sometimes it does get busy and they do forget about your request. boo to that!
author: Tuan D.

description:
This is one of the first places I visited when I came to SF.  It is a family fave.  Went Saturday after a long hiatus (sold my car and live in Russian Hill so I can't get there too often) and it was just as good.  They'd even remodeled!  Had the spicy coconut chicken pho - yum!  I think I'll come here more often, the 28 goes right there!  Too bad for my bf, he'll really love being dragged out there!

Oh yeah, if I ever have another BF, this is going to be a test place for him.  I took another BF there, who hated it cause it was divey... he turned out to be a total wus... I should have known!  Next time, I'll take someone here on the 3rd date, and if they are don't like it they are out!
author: jessica d.

description: i don't like that fact that their pho isn't boiling hot so that you have to wait a min for it to cool. When it come to you it is medium temp, the rare steak isn't cooking and the noodles are still stuck together.
author: Robin L.

description: Three words: Five Spice Chicken. The chicken is one of the best in the city. The only major problem I have with it is that the pho noodles are not that fresh. It seems like they just mass produce it and dump it into your bowl. Also, it can get ridiculously crowded on a weekend and Fridays.
author: Jonathan L.

description: Only a couple of dishes I thought are good at this restaurant, the five spice chicken and the satay noodles.  Once in awhile we like to order the fried egg rolls and they are just average.  I always keep my expectation low with the service here so I never had any disappointments.
author: Nume C.

description: Definitely a hole-in-the-wall experience. Food is very tasty. We had the crispy imperial rolls, rare flank steak and meatball pho, curry chicken noodle pho. All very good. Surprisingly, a little pricier than other hole in the wall pho places. Quick service !
author: Andy W.

description: I discovered the love of pho from this place.  Nothing beats a nice bowl of soup noodles in beef broth when you're down or sick.  Ohhhh yeahhhh....comfort food!
author: Kit E.

description: This is a good place to goto if you are looking for a noodle house that serves a variety of different types of noodle soup. The prices are reasonable and the servings are decent. If you goto this place during peak hours, expect to wait in line for a seat.
author: Dao C.

description: Solid 3 stars beacuse I have yet to try the crab. Vietnamese food doesn't really do it for me like chinese or japanese does, but PPQ isn't bad at all. The noodles are good and I will definitely be back.
author: Jen Y.

description: Used to be our favorite place for pho. So much, that we measured other pho restaurants against it. Well, the last few times we've gone, it's been only average...
author: Paul T.

description: My friend owns this place and I've known the two of them for over 7 years now, yet I still eat a lot across the street. Haha. I must admit that when I eat here every now and then, it is far better than eating at the other pho place across the street. Though the pho may cost more, at least it tastes better. I was upset that I only got 1 big fatty meatball, but I guess thats how they roll now. The place is also clean, so thats a plus. The place is rather narrow and cluttered, but overall, not a bad place.
author: Edgar G.

description: This place has the best imperial rolls.  The grilled meats are very good too.  It's a little higher priced than other Vietnamese restaurants.  Sometimes there's a wait for dinner, especially on weekends and holidays.  Parking is difficult so plan to park and walk a few blocks.
author: Stacey L.

description:
there may be a wait, but it's short and worth it.

i spent more money on booze than food going here... but i didn't order any alcohol! wth you ask?

byob

i went across the street to the liquor store and bought $35 worth of beer! i only bought 3 beers, and they were big ones -mostly Belgian. 

the bun was good, not too big, not too small. fast, tasty, yum.
author: Ameer N.

description: Not much ambience here, but the food has always been consistently good with huge portions.  I've never actually gotten Pho, but I've had some of my husband's and it was quite tasty.  It's significantly better than the place across the street.  I ordered the Cha Gio for the first time last night, and they were super tasty; however, there still wasn't enough lettuce for the two orders we got.  I'm not sure if there's some lettuce shortage or something.  I had the bun w/ 5 spice chicken and the chicken is very tasty (though they leave the skin on so it's probably not super healthy).  Service is fast, but don't forget they're cash only.
author: Joann C.

description:
good food, friendly and fast service. i even like the rice dishes, not just the pho. 
but, it would be better if it was called pho Q. 
haha!
author: Roy N.

description:
More like 2.5 stars. Yes, it is a solid Pho place, but it's really nothing to write home about. You should judge a good Pho by its broth. With the colonial French influence, Properly made broth should be cooked like consommé, with beef bones and other vege/herbs, chilled and de-greased, and then reheated to serve with the Pho. The broth here is decent, but nothing close to a real good pho. 

That said, their pho is one of the better ones in the area, and the place is always packed. The cold weather of the sunset and lack of better pho around probably contribute heavily to that. The rice dishes are okay here, but not as good as across the street (Pho Hua). 

The service here is mediocre, but at least it's reasonably clean. 

Bottom line, it's better than most pho places around that use MSG or instant bouillon, but if you want a truly good pho, go somewhere else.
author: Paul C.

description: Cheap cheap cheap. Their pho broth gets a 8.5/10. I think they compete with Kevin's Noodle House right across the street. Not a bad place.
author: Prescott T.

description: Cheap and tasty food for the price. Honestly, I don't have that much experience with Vietnamese food to judge quality, so I can only speak of flavor, and I enjoyed a good plate of food and something to share for around $10. Deal.
author: Javi V.

description: Good, clean-tasting Vietnamese food. However, I still think the bun and imperial rolls at Bodega Bistro are better. Also, the place was SO damn cold when we went for dinner, we had to keep our jackets on the whole time, as did everyone else in the restaurant. I don't go to places like PPQ looking for ambiance, but I don't go looking for frostbite either. Solid choice if you're in the neighborhood, but I wouldn't cross town for it.
author: Michelle A.

description:
My boyfriend is obsessed with pho, so we go here pretty often. He gets the #1 (regular beef pho) and I usually get the charbroiled beef plate. He loves the pho here more than any other place in the city. I've tried it as well, and it's good--good flavor, tasty meat, lots of noodles (but not too many), very generous portions. The charbroiled beef is surprisingly tasty and flavorful and I always really enjoy it. Sometimes we split the imperial rolls, which are completely delicious, but also so filling that it can be hard to eat them and the rest of the meal.

The restaurant itself is not at all fancy, but it is clean and pleasant. The service is prompt and friendly, though at peak lunch times the place is often crowded enough that we have to wait for a table.
author: Joanna L.

description: The imperial rolls are decent, so is the broth for the pho.  Summer rolls are worth an honorable mention.   It's not as good as Tu Lan, though its worlds cleaner.
author: K W.

description: Ahh it's ok. Mmm, why is my beef chewy and smell kinda strong? Actually I don't like this place, lol.
author: John L.

description: Nothing like some Angus beef pho w/ a shrimp and papaya salad to start...EVERYTHING is clean and fresh. Can't wait to hit this up again when I'm back in the Bay.
author: Yvette C.

description:
i would say a 3.5, but because of the many positive experiences i've had here, i'll err on the higher side.  the pho i have heard is not on par at all, so i would watch out.  the vermicelli noodle bowls on the other hand are very good.  the pork with fried imperial rolls was good, but man, the 5 spice chicken is just sooooo juicy and tender with crispy skin, just the way you want it.  

because the vermicelli bowls are so good, i haven't really tried anything else.  so keep that in mind, when reading this review.
author: Jason J.

description: This is our "go-to" Vietnamese place. When we are craving for Vietnamese food, we come here. I love their imperial rolls and satay beef noodle soup.
author: Wakaknee J.

description: So I was also confused and thought we were going to the crab palace, rather than the noodle house, but that is really just my bad. The noodles were really good, I had the spicy satay beef bowl, which I recommend, very spicy and hearty. The atmosphere is nothing special, but our service was just fine, and they didn't mind us bringing in our own beer. Great value!
author: Kai H.

description: This place is pretty darn good.  I don't go that often but I went tonight and felt compelled to Yelp.  Mostly I like it because they have a spicy beef satay pho that is almost as good as the most delicious beef satay pho ever (which is served at Ba Dat in Boston, MA, don't know if there are any other fans out there?).  My first experience eating real Vietnamese food was at Ba Dat and it was very formative.  As was that spicy beef satay which I have since spent many years scouring west coast Vietnamese restaurants for.  Finally I found it at PPQ.  Quite tasty.  Usually I go here after peak dinner hours so never have to wait, but it is busy enough to feel festive and not desolate.  No complaints about the service in my experience.  Loving that spicy beef satay - missing Ba Dat.
author: Judith S.

description: Whenever I need a fix of bun or Pho, I come here.  They are excellent.
author: p w.

description: I've been coming here for years and years.  The lemongrass pork is super good.  The 5-spice chicken pho is my favorite.  I do dress up the broth a lot because I like my pho spicy!.  The spring rolls and imperial rolls are excellent.  Service is efficient and fair.  The place is average on the clean scale.  I'll keep coming here as long as their open.  Love it.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: I'm not the biggest fan of Vietnamese food, but I am an advid fan of garlic and seafood.  The flavors are extremely strong and it's definately a place where you gather with those who just love food and like to be low key for a night.  Not the best in terms of ambiance, however your stomach and taste buds won't know the difference.
author: Grace K.

description: PPQ, great soup dishes.  booo for the rice plates, I get what I don't expect.
author: Michelle N.

description:
aka PPQ.

Decent place.  Been coming here on and off for a few years now.

Had the five spices rice plate for ~$6. Not bad. You get about 8 strips of chicken with skin that are spiced up and sorta glazed. You get a good portion of rice. 

Their shrimp spring roll is good too.

I've had their five spices chicken soup noodle. They give you the bowl of soup noodles, and on a second plate the chicken. Not a great idea to dump the chicken into the soup, you'll wash away the spices.

Parking can be hard at times, but nothing too crazy.
author: qirk z.

description: I give PPQ a 3.5 actually. I guess I just read into the hype a little too much from all my friends or maybe just because I'm biased to the Viet food I usually get from the one at Westlake. The food at PPQ is pretty norm, I would definitely go back. There isn't anything really special about it, but then again there isn't anything abnormally wrong either. I heard their Five Spice Chicken or something is REALLY good, so I'm going to try that the next time I go.
author: Katrina C.

description:
I love coming to place when I need a quick meal no hassle meal. I always get the big bowl numero uno, because I love eating all the shredded animal parts. Nothing like thin sliced beef, meat balls, tripe, tendons, and a good amount of noodles. I don't think they have as much meat as Yummy Yummy number 1, but they are still really good. Thank you Pho Phu Quoc. 

P.s. I always come her because they look busy unlink the other one across the street.
author: Mike h.

description: When I first moved here I was a chef . I lived @Lincoln and 16th Ave. So after work I would go out drinking till about 4 AM , as a good chef should . When my hangover was killing me I would go here for breakfast (at 11:00 ) Pho noodles are great for hangover cure . I don't cook or drink till 4AM anymore but this place is still one of my favorites . I have lost girlfriends due to the fact that they didn't like this place ! I just couldn't be with someone who didn't like P.P.Q. I recommend 5 spice chiken noodle soup or the chicken curry noodle soup , you'll love it !
